name: BRIEF HISTORYThe graduate program of the Universit...
intro:
BRIEF HISTORY

The graduate program of the University was given temporary permit no. 382,s. 1971 on 28th December 1971 with expiration date on July 5, 1972. These temporary permits were renewed yearly until Government Recognition No. C-0033,s. 1977 was awarded on 25th May 1977 with effectivity starting 14 June 1977 for the Master of Arts in Education (MAEd).

 In 1993, DECS granted permits for two additional programs: the Master in Management (MM) and the Master of Arts in Nursing (MAN). Because of the additional programs, the name was changed to the School for Advanced Studies (SAS) in school year 1993-1994.

 On October 16, 1998, and December 10, 1999, CHED granted recognition of Master in Public Administration and Doctor of Public Administration (DPA), respectively. The Doctor of Education was also granted permit in 1999.

 On August 23, 2002, the change of name from Trinity College Graduate School (TCGS)  to Trinity University of Asia Graduate School (TUAGS-2006) was done to accommodate more programs.   

In the year 2010,  The Commission on Higher Education granted recognition to the Doctor in Nursing Management.

 In 2017, the Graduate School, to heed the clamor from the health sector, offered Master of Science in Medical Technology and the Master in Hospital Management.

name:
Message from the DirectorI hope this
message find...
intro:
Message from the Director


I hope this message finds you and your family in good health. Recent developments have been very challenging for our Trinitian community as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic. We are living in a time of unprecedented uncertainty. I just want to say “Thank you” to our students, faculty, and staff for your patience, understanding, and perseverance during their trying times.

 I am sure that most of you had problems with online registration and enrollment. But because you would want to pursue education despite Covid-19, you are here and now to experience learning in the new normal school setting. There is much going on with caring for our families, social distancing, and living very differently than what we were used to.

 Thanks to investments in technology and distance learning, the academic year is resuming with all classes online starting August 24, 2020. The Trinitan journey of discovery and self-improvement that occurs in our classrooms will now continue in distance learning. We will all persevere and our goal is to successfully complete the school year with no student being left behind.

Again, we welcome you, and please continue to be safe and well.


Sincerely,

JEANETTE VICTORIA A. NAVAL, RGC

What are self-affirmations?These are positive phra...
intro:
What are self-affirmations?


These are positive phrases or statements used to challenge negative or unhelpful thoughts (self-affirmation theory, 1988).

You may choose positive affirmations to:
 motivate yourself
 encourage positive changes in your life
 boost your self-esteem

Practice positive affirmations regularly for lasting, long-term changes to the ways that you feel and think.

Source:
Moore, Catherine. (2021, March 16). Positive Daily Affirmations: Is there a Science Behind it? PositivePsychology. https://positivepsychology.com/daily-

name: &nb...
Self-affirmations help you to motivate yourself, e...
intro:
Self-affirmations help you to motivate yourself, encourage positive changes in your life, or boost your self-esteem.

Choose which resonates with you and repeat it to yourself.

name: Here's a powerful positive affirmation for women t...
intro:
Here's a powerful positive affirmation for women to help you realize the wonderful person that you are. Keep on reminding yourself that you can create your happiness by accepting yourself and giving yourself unconditional love.

Happy National Women's Month, Trinitians!

name: Career Quotes to Inspire You   &nbs...
intro: Career Quotes to Inspire You

name: Career Preparation TipsPlanning your career as ear...
intro:
Career Preparation Tips

Planning your career as early as now will provide you with a roadmap for your future. As a student, there are a number of ways you can do to prepare yourself for your career.

name: A Guide to Identifying your Career Interests ...
intro: A Guide to Identifying your Career Interests

name: 6 Key Traits for Working in a TeamAre you a team p...
intro:
6 Key Traits for Working in a Team

Are you a team player?

Teamwork is important to have a meaningful and lifelong career. You need to work well with others because the diverse skills of teams are needed for reaching success. So, what makes a good team player? Here are some excellent traits to bear in mind whenever you’re working in a team.

name: Character Strengths for SuccessPlanning for your c...
intro:
Character Strengths for Success

Planning for your career? The Guidance Center wants to help with your career success by discussing Character Strengths.

24 Character strengths were introduced by Seligman and Peterson (2004), which contribute to "good life" and well-being. Moreover, there has been an increasing study of Character strength to job satisfaction and career success (Ruch, 2019).

name: Holland's Theory on Career ChoiceAre you having a ...
intro:
Holland's Theory on Career Choice

Are you having a hard time choosing a college course? or are you questioning your career path?

Holland's theory on career choice can help you in your career choice by determining the interaction between your personality and the environment. 

If you want to find out more, you can reach out to your counselors for assistance.

name: Spread love and kindness. Share with all the teach...
intro: Spread love and kindness. Share with all the teachers & school staff you know to remind them that their mental health and well-being are important too.

name: ​What we think in ​our ​minds will eventuall...
intro: ​What we think in ​our ​minds will eventually become what we believe. This is why it is so important that we start saying positive things about ourselves many times each and every day.

name: Relationships are vital to our emotional well-bein...
intro: Relationships are vital to our emotional well-being so take time to nourish your support systems and say hello to your friends.

name: ​What we think in ​our ​minds will eventually beco...
intro: ​What we think in ​our ​minds will eventually become what we believe. This is why it is so important that we start saying positive things about ourselves many times each and every day.

name: Getting enough good-quality sleep keeps your immun...
intro:
Getting enough good-quality sleep keeps your immune system running at its best to fight off infections.

There are parts of the body’s immune response that happen only during sleep.

Scientists know sleep is also one of the top ways we can help keep stress in check, as sleep deprivation can make us more sensitive to the effects of stress, ramping up our reactions (or overreactions).

Finally, the brain needs sleep to function; without it, you'll be less patient and focused, make poor decisions, and be more moody, irritable, and emotional.

Source: everydayhealth.com

name: What kind words can you share with others today?Sm...
intro:
What kind words can you share with others today?

Small acts of kindness can have profound effects on others and on us. Even better, those acts ripple out to the wider community, so in offering them we’re doing more than helping one other person and supporting ourselves. We’re doing something real to build a better world.

name: This weekend, spend some time hanging out with you...
intro:
This weekend, spend some time hanging out with your friends & family.

Research shows that spending time with loved ones is the number one determinant of happiness.

name: Practice deep breathing exercises.Deep breathing i...
intro:
Practice deep breathing exercises.


Deep breathing is one of the best ways to lower stress in the body. This is because when you breathe deeply, it sends a message to your brain to calm down and relax.

name: Listening to your body and reaching for a glass of...
intro: Listening to your body and reaching for a glass of water when you are thirsty can help you feel healthier and more energized. Your best bet is to stave off thirst in the first place by being proactive about drinking water. Make drinking a glass of water a part of your morning routine.

name: Working from home can blur the lines of when the w...
intro:
Working from home can blur the lines of when the workday starts and ends. Determine a schedule that takes into account a start time and an end time, your self-care practices, and breaks.

Realize the importance of setting boundaries for yourself and others.

name: Social media is an invaluable tool for keeping in ...
intro:
Social media is an invaluable tool for keeping in touch with friends, loved ones, and the wider world. But be mindful of how it makes you feel. If spending time on social media exacerbates your stress, anxiety, and uncertainty, take steps to limit your engagement.


Sharing positive things and expressing gratitude will not only uplift your mood but also those who will see your posts. Let's practice and encourage positivity.

name: Rest is essential.You can't pour from an empty cup...
intro:
Rest is essential.

You can't pour from an empty cup. You can't be your best if you're always stressed.

This weekend, find time to calm your mind, rest your body and listen to your soul. These moments of serenity will give you the replenishment and re-energizing you need for better days ahead.

name: As the weekend approaches, make time for yourself ...
intro:
As the weekend approaches, make time for yourself to protect your peace. This means maintaining a healthy environment for growth and also guarding your state of mind. It also means cultivating a safe space internally and externally where you can be productive rather than just doing things just to do them.

Make time for self-care.

name: Self-care is important for everyone. Stay in the p...
intro: Self-care is important for everyone. Stay in the present instead of what may happen in the future.

name: The Trinitian Community Development Section (TCDS)...
intro:
The Trinitian Community Development Section (TCDS) is the official arm for extension programs and services of Trinity University of Asia, supporting its Vision and Mission to lead its constituents to live a life that is God-centered and service-oriented. 

TCDS primarily ensures that the University Constituency, meaning its students, faculty, staff, and administration, works collaboratively to develop and implement programs and services based on the needs of its partner communities and civil society as a whole, and according to its existing capacities and expertise.

name: LEGAL BASIS AND GENERAL GUIDELINES OF THE TCDSIn C... (copy)
intro:
LEGAL BASIS AND GENERAL GUIDELINES OF THE TCDS


In CHED Memorandum Order NO. 8, s. 2010, Extension refers to the act of communicating and transferring knowledge and technology to specific sectors and target clienteles (as distinguished from those enrolled in formal degree programs and course offerings) to enable them to effectively improve production, community and or institutions, and quality of life, at the same time enhance the academic and research programs of higher education institutions (HEIs).

TCDS adheres to the CHED mandate that the Extension program is integrated and shall include the following components: 

  1. Training programs – non-degree and non-credit course offered by a college or unit; 
  2. Technical assistance and advisory services- to agencies, organization, associations and other groups;
  3. Communication/information services – communication and or dissemination of knowledge and skills in particular client groups through the various means of dissemination such as person-to-person contact, radio, television, newspaper and other printed materials;
  4. Community outreach activities- extension activities conducted increase outside the university /college, e.g. community-based social services, pilot projects, mobile clinic, etc.; and
  5. Technology transfer and utilization – the process of circulating, promoting and marketing research outputs or technologies to potential users

TRINISYANO- Framework of Community Engagement 
(Kristyanong Trinitian sa Paglilingkod- The Trinitian Brand of Service)


The concept of TRINISYANO came from the two words, “Trinitian” and “Christian” or “Kristyano” in Filipino which were combined to represent a brand of service of Trinity University of Asia, thus contributing to its vision, “Premier Christian University in Asia and the Pacific Transforming Learners into Leaders towards a Humane Society."

The “Kristyanong Trinitian sa Paglilingkod” also known as the TRINISYANO exemplifies Christ distinct way of serving and leading people as He build His church through discipleship, developing leaders as servants that will continue and sustain His service to the least - the marginalized sectors (depressed, oppressed, poverty-stricken and struggling) honoring God through the service to our Country – Pro Deo et Patria!

The programs and services of the University to its partner communities and organizations shall be geared towards building the Trinitian brand of service which also adheres to the Anglican Communion’s Five (5) Marks of Mission: 

  1. To proclaim the Good News of the Kingdom 
  2. To teach, baptise and nurture new believers
  3. To respond to human need by loving service
  4. To transform unjust structures of society, to challenge violence of every kind and pursue peace and reconciliation 
  5. To strive to safeguard the integrity of creation, and sustain and renew the life of the earth


“To make the greatest impact on society requires first and foremost a great organization, not just a great program.”- Jim Collins


The Trinitian Community Development Section plays a pivotal role in building and organizing the community using the perspectives of community development as its main practice framework through identifying potential leaders, capacitating them with necessary perspectives and tools of development and to prepare them for community organizing. Thus, transforming their lives in the achievement of holistic development towards building resilient and empowered communities. The following goals shall serve as the University’s commitment and stronghold towards the realization of the Trinitian Brand of Service across all academic and non-academic engagements:

  1. Enhancement of knowledge, skills and attitude of identified leaders in the community to serve as committed agents of change of their community and the society at large 
  2. Facilitate empowerment of communities through discipleship and servant leadership 
  3. Sustainable and holistic programs and services that respond to the needs of the communities 
  4. Engaged administrators, faculty, staff and students in issues of social justice and human rights through education, information and advocacy
  5.  Ensure progressive measures and intervention towards the protection and conservation of environment


The major academic programs such as the National Services Training Program (NSTP), Christian Education and the Service-Learning shall closely coordinate with the Trinitian Community Development Section (TCDS) to ensure that all efforts and initiatives are concerted towards contributing to TRINISYANO- The Trinitian Brand of Service.

name: @@PLUGINFILE@@/TCDS%20VIDEO%20EDITED%20%281%...
intro:
1.      Education and Training – The coverage of this program component are: formal, non-formal and informal training including leadership formation and other capacity-building efforts for community sustainability. The activities and services that are conducted under this program component are as follows:

      • Free Pre-school Education in Barangay Tatalon
      • Mentoring Sessions with Grade School and High School Students on English and Mathematics
      • Computer Literacy Training for Barangay Workers and Officials
      • Computer Literacy Training for Public School Teachers

2.      Alternative Livelihood Opportunities –The community residents are provided technical assistance to develop community enterprises that will be able to augment the income of their family without compromising quality time with their loved ones.  The activities and services that are conducted under this program component are as follows:

      • Food Preservation Training
      • Therapeutic Massage Training
      • Cosmetology Training
      • Dressmaking and Tailoring Training
      • Soap Making
      • Welding Training
      • Barista Training
      • Housekeeping Training

3.      Community Organizing- The center assists in organizing people’s organizations and other sectoral groups as requested and needed.

4.      Advocacy- through the different colleges, we help build mechanisms to address violence in the communities as well as advocating for the rights of women and children.

TCDS ACT Sessions

The Trinitian Community Development Section (TCDS) launched its information and advocacy drive, “Advocate, Conscienticize, and Transform,” or ACT Sessions as a response to one of the Anglican Communion's Five (5) Marks of Mission in "transforming unjust structures of society, challenging violence of every kind, and pursuing peace and reconciliation." Specifically, it aims to provide an avenue for the Trinitian Constituency and its partner communities to enhance their awareness in pressing socio-political and economic issues and challenges that affect different members of the society, especially the marginalized, which eventually aspires them to become advocates or agents of social change and transformation.

5.      Networking –collaboration with other like-minded institutions is a potent force for cost sharing and best practice in community development work. The following organizations and agencies are partners of the University Extension office:

      • Alban Memorial Foundation, Inc. – Scholarship Grant for High School and College level to selected children and youth
      • St. Joseph Foundation for Children and Aging, Inc. – Scholarship Grant for College level to selected children and youth
      • Assisi Development Foundation, Inc.- Scholarship Grant for College level to selected children and youth
      • Philippine Center for Population and Development, Inc.- Funding agency for the advocacy and cause on population, health and environment
      • National Council of Social Development- Network of NGOs working for the welfare and development
      • United Board for Christian Higher Education in Asia (UBCHEA)- Partner of the University in service learning programs and to community service programs focusing on health and environment
      • Tzu Chi Buddhist Foundation- Partner of the University in the advocacy for environment wherein PET bottles are recycled into shirts and blankets

 6.      Health and Wellness– health is an integral part of the development programs of the Center.  This program ensures that our partners are healthy through curative and preventive activities for the total well-being of people. The activities and services that are conducted under this program component are as follows: 

      • Feeding Program with malnourished and undernourished children
      • Health Education sessions with the mothers and elderly
      • Free Laboratory Tests (Glucose Testing, Urinalysis, Fecalysis)
      • Blood Donation
      • Health and Nutrition Session for parents

7.      Ecological – The Center is in the forefront of ensuring that environmental activities are carried out for awareness, protection and conservation of the environment where our beneficiaries live.

name: INTERDISCIPLINARY COMMUNITY EXTENSION PROJECTS&nbs...
intro:
INTERDISCIPLINARY COMMUNITY EXTENSION PROJECTS 


HEALTH AND WELLNESS 


Project CHANGE (St. Luke's College of Nursing)

The Community Health and Nursing GearedTowards Empowerment  (CHANGE)started in 1977, the program provides free diagnosis and consultations, visitations, and taught mothers basic health practices, child care, nutrition, and first aid remedies. CHANGE and HEALS work hand in hand in assisting medical doctor-volunteers during medical mission activities.

 

Project HEALS (College of Medical Technology)

Health Education and Life Services (HEALS) started in 1990. It complements the Nursing community outreach program through blood typing, sputum testing, urine and stool examination, de-worming of children, dialogue on health services and procedures, demonstration on desirable health habits, home visitation, or follow-ups and other allied activities.


Project SNACK (College of Hospitality and Tourism Management)

Supervised Nutrition Advocacy for Community Kids or the SNACK program started in 2007  as one of the health services for the community is focused on nutrition advocacy for the kids. Likewise,  mothers are involved in the program to participate in the preparation of nutritious, low cost, and easy to prepare meals. 

Now, Project SNACK also ventures in conducting learning sessions on local tourism and basic tour-guiding as a livelihood opportunity for the partner communities to consider in the future.

 

EDUCATION AND TRAINING


Project COPE and ASPIRE (College of Arts, Sciences, and Education)

Started in 1982, Community Outreach Pre-School Education (COPE) provides a head start in formal education for children aged 4 to years old; initiates among children and their mothers good health practices; promotes good eating habits and practices through feeding program, which is worked out by the mothers under the supervision and guidance of the volunteer student-teachers. needed in applying for a job. The program started in 1984 to assist out-of-school youths and adults who wish to finish their studies.

On the other hand, the Arts and Sciences Programs for Inspired and Responsive Education (ASPIRE)helps children in the community develop and/or enhance their reading and mathematical skills thus helping them achieve better academic performance. The program started in 1990.

 

Project CODE-IT (College of Engineering and Information Sciences)

 The Community Development and Empowerment Through information technology (CODE-IT) envisions to make information technology accessible to our partner communities through education and training in current information technology (IT) skills practices as well as technical assistance on information technology issues and solutions


Project CAN (Graduate School)

The Graduate School's Change. Achieve. Nurture (CAN) started in 2002,  assists community-based researches mainly to determine the relevance of outreach programs, actual needs of recipients, quantify and quality impact of programs, investigate areas of concern that would contribute to the improvement of the outreach programs.

 


Project DREAM (Basic Education Unit)

The Developing Responsible, Excellent, Action– Driven and Magnimous Youth (DREAM) of the Basic Education provides an avenue for the youth of the University’s partner communities to understand themselves and acquire real-life skills that will foster their growth and development. Their previous program was with the pre-school children but they eventually transcend with the youth, the majority population in the community.



ALTERNATIVE LIVELIHOOD

 

Project BEST (College of Business Management and Accountancy)

The Business Education for Self-Reliance and  Trade (BEST) started in 1987. It trains participants in basic bookkeeping, record keeping and inventory and other financial and management skills necessary in the operation of a small-scale business. It also introduces to participants various means of procuring either for start-up or expansion of small business holding. It likewise gives training on cooperatives for associations in the community that intend to set-up a cooperative. The project BEST is also in-charge with practical skills training that aims to improve the economic and quality of life of people.

name: The extension office consists of ten (10) members,...
intro:
The extension office consists of ten (10) members, administered by the Program In-charge, and assisted by the Community Development Assistant. The remaining eight (8) are selected faculty members from each of the University's academic units that function as the lead Coordinator of their respective community extension projects. Together, they conceptualize and facilitate programs and services using interdisciplinary approaches to benefit the University's constituency and partner communities. 

TCDS is also enjoined by the official student volunteer organization of the University, the Trinitian SHARES (Sustain, Help, Act, Respect, Empower, and Support).  The organization's primary goal is to strengthen volunteerism among Trinitian Students through actively participating in health, education, and livelihood programs and services of the University towards its partner communities.

name: The Student Affairs Center (SAC) is resp...
intro: The Student Affairs Center (SAC) is responsible for planning, coordinating, and implementing a variety of student programs and services aimed at engaging students and providing opportunities for them in achieving academic and personal success.  Headed by the Dean of Students, the SAC coordinates with the academic affairs units, academic support units, administration and finance units, and outsourced process units of the university in providing an integrated approach in the delivery of programs and services for student welfare and development.

name: Hello and Welcome!!We in  Student Affair...
intro:
Hello and Welcome!!

We in  Student Affairs aims to provide the best educational experience for our students. We complement Trinity University of Asia's academic excellence with a variety of co-curricular and extracurricular activities that make up for engaging college life. We nurture our students in a school environment that is safe, secure, and diverse.   

 We help our students connect with peers, scholars,  and our communities for them to broaden their perspectives in life and learn more from the experiences they gain in their conversations outside of the classroom.  

Through these experiences we expect our students and graduates to make a difference in their communities, their workplace, and the broader society that we live in. We take pride in HELPING YOU SHAPE A BETTER TOMORROW.   TEAM SAC!!!

name: Our student development program contributes to the...
intro: Our student development program contributes to the development of the "whole person" of our students. We always strive to let our students rediscover themselves, either thru self-expression in the performing arts, literature, and writing, participation in sports, faith, and action, and community service.

name: We provide student services that are crucial to ou...
intro: We provide student services that are crucial to our student's wellbeing and success from the day they set foot on campus and until they graduate. The services provided by the SAC relate to three major areas, (1) Student Activities, (2) Linkages and Networking, and (3) Discipline.

name: Message from the Dean of Students, Student Affairs...
intro:
Message from the Dean of Students, Student Affairs Center SY 2022-2023


Dear Students, 

It is with great pleasure to welcome you to your second home, Trinity University of Asia. We are very happy and excited to serve you at Student Affairs Center. As we gradually transition to our 'Now Normal', we are continuously praying for you and your family's wellbeing. 

At Student Affairs Center we endeavor to provide all necessary opportunities and support you need, for you to enjoy learning, and experience our university online and/or face to face.  We created avenues and opportunities for us to interact and engage as one Trinitian community. This maybe a difficult time but be assured that we are with you in this journey. We prepared a year round of activities and Student Affairs and Services continuity plan for you to participate and will that will address your needs and carry you through during this extraordinary times.  

If there are concerns that you wish to relay to us, or simply to send your regards,  do not hesitate to email us at sac@tua.edu.ph, hcbalmes@tua.edu.ph or at facebook@tuasac.com

Yours in Service,

Your Dean of Students, 

HOMER C. BALMES

The digital age, and now social media have unwritten online “rules” that most people find mysterious or obscure. This leads to poor behavior online.

name: Reposting from June 29, 2016. This letter to ...
intro: Reposting from June 29, 2016. This letter to students, even more, rings true during this pandemic. Econometrics treat education as part of social capital, the collective worth of education, and training of the citizens of a country or a state that help in fueling prosperity and progress. The coronavirus single-handedly, swiftly, and broadly shifted the paradigms of most components and drivers of society. More so for education.

On google maps, the right side is the direction from Cubao (East), and coming from the left is from Rotunda, Manila (West). From the East after reaching St Luke's Hospital you will find Trinity Main campus (Collegiate and Senior High courses) to the right side along  E Rodriguez Ave. Further down the road is Campus 1 (original campus) just in front of Capital Towers Condominium.

name: Label

Student OrganizationsThe University
recognizes th...
intro:
Student Organizations

The University recognizes the importance of developing creative, critical, and responsible student leaders who shall eventually assume the mantle of leadership in their chosen fields of endeavor. For this purpose, she encourages the formation of student groups that pursue clearly-established common objectives and the initiation of student-directed endeavors along social, cultural, religious, literary, educational, or recreational lines. Students may join religious organizations, professional organizations, socio-civic organizations, or special interest organizations. 

 A student organization is a group of at least 15 bonafide students that pursue common objectives and interests, initiate student-directed endeavors along with these objectives and interests, and meets regularly to form close bonds. A recognized student organization is one that has been given permission to conduct its activities within the University premises, to make use of its facilities, to attach Trinity University of Asia (TUA) to their names, and to avail of funding from the student development fund.

name:
Classification of Student Organizations

Accordi...
intro:
Classification of Student Organizations

According to membership 
o    University-Wide
− membership is open to all colleges
o    College-Wide
− membership is exclusive to a single college or department
For purposes of supervision, university−wide
organizations are under the Student Affairs Center while college−wide
organizations are under their respective deans. 

According to categories 
    • Academic – organized within the degree-granting academic departments or fields of discipline. Religious - engaged in campus ministry. 
    • Women’s Group – advocacy groups for women issues and women empowerment. 
    • Sports and Recreation – engaged in sports, physical fitness programs, and other activities. 
    • Theater and Performing Arts – primarily concerned in the artistic expression of students through the theater and performing arts 
    • Cause-Oriented – advocacy groups espousing human rights, socio-political issues, and related concerns. 
    • Alliance – a confederation of at least two recognized organizations sharing the same interests and ideals. 
    • Special Interest- organizations whose classification and activities, ideals, and objectives are different from those mentioned above.

𝑻𝒉𝒆 𝒐𝒇𝒇𝒊𝒄𝒊𝒂𝒍 𝒔𝒕𝒖𝒅𝒆𝒏𝒕 𝒑𝒖𝒃𝒍𝒊𝒄𝒂𝒕𝒊𝒐𝒏 𝒐𝒇 𝑻𝑼𝑨 - 𝑷𝒉𝒊𝒍𝒊𝒑𝒑𝒊𝒏𝒆 𝑺𝒐𝒄𝒊𝒆𝒕𝒚 𝒐𝒇 𝑴𝒆𝒅𝒊𝒄𝒂𝒍 𝑻𝒆𝒄𝒉𝒏𝒐𝒍𝒐𝒈𝒚 𝑺𝒕𝒖𝒅𝒆𝒏𝒕𝒔. 𝑭𝒐𝒍𝒍𝒐𝒘 𝒕𝒉𝒆𝒊𝒓 𝑭𝒂𝒄𝒆𝒃𝒐𝒐𝒌 𝒑𝒂𝒈𝒆 𝒇𝒐𝒓 𝒎𝒐𝒓𝒆 𝒖𝒑𝒅𝒂𝒕𝒆𝒔 : https://www.facebook.com/CMT.INFOCUS



𝑻𝒉𝒆 𝒐𝒇𝒇𝒊𝒄𝒊𝒂𝒍 𝒔𝒕𝒖𝒅𝒆𝒏𝒕 𝒑𝒖𝒃𝒍𝒊𝒄𝒂𝒕𝒊𝒐𝒏 𝒐𝒇 𝑺𝒕𝒖𝒅𝒆𝒏𝒕 𝑵𝒖𝒓𝒔𝒆𝒔 𝑨𝒔𝒔𝒐𝒄𝒊𝒂𝒕𝒊𝒐𝒏. 𝑭𝒐𝒍𝒍𝒐𝒘 𝒕𝒉𝒆𝒊𝒓 𝑭𝒂𝒄𝒆𝒃𝒐𝒐𝒌 𝒑𝒂𝒈𝒆 𝒇𝒐𝒓 𝒎𝒐𝒓𝒆 𝒖𝒑𝒅𝒂𝒕𝒆𝒔 : https://www.facebook.com/SLCNGazette



𝑻𝒉𝒆 𝒐𝒇𝒇𝒊𝒄𝒊𝒂𝒍 𝒔𝒕𝒖𝒅𝒆𝒏𝒕 𝒑𝒖𝒃𝒍𝒊𝒄𝒂𝒕𝒊𝒐𝒏 𝒐𝒇 𝒕𝒉𝒆 𝑪𝒐𝒍𝒍𝒆𝒈𝒆 𝒐𝒇 𝑨𝒓𝒕𝒔, 𝑺𝒄𝒊𝒆𝒏𝒄𝒆𝒔 𝒂𝒏𝒅 𝑬𝒅𝒖𝒄𝒂𝒕𝒊𝒐𝒏. 𝑹𝒆𝒂𝒅 𝒎𝒐𝒓𝒆 𝒂𝒕 http://www.tua.edu.ph/students/student-publications/

name: LIBRARY MISSION﻿Trinity University of Asia Library...
intro:
LIBRARY MISSION

﻿Trinity University of Asia Library supports the academic programs through instruction, collections, technology and services which enable students and faculty to access recorded knowledge and information resources. This support empowers our constituencies to develop the information and technological competencies necessary to achieve their educational, research and professional goals; succeed in the workforce; apply lifelong learning skills; and participate in a diverse society.

name: The Digital Filipiniana at SOS Digital Filipi...
intro:
The Digital Filipiniana at SOS 


Digital Filipiniana is a collection of digital, open-access material from the SOAS Library and Archives. With a 2017 grant from the Philippine Embassy in London and the Office of Senator Loren Legarda, Digital Filipiniana is an on-going project to digitize copyright-free material from the SOAS Archival Collections, and make them accessible to the public.

name: Filipinas Heritage LibraryCollection covers books ...
intro:
Filipinas Heritage Library


Collection covers books and other materials authored by Filipinos or about the Philippines, with a focus on Philippine history and culture.

name: IMF eLibrary: Philippine StudiesThe International ...
intro:
IMF eLibrary: Philippine Studies


The International Monetary Fund (IMF) eLibrary delivers comprehensive online access to IMF information. The eLibrary contains over 12,000 publications that provide authoritative perspectives on topics ranging from macroeconomics and globalization to technical assistance and poverty reduction. The data eLibrary contains over 9,500 financial and economic data concepts containing more than one million statistical data.

name: Philippine E-Book HubThe largest online library of...
intro:
Philippine E-Book Hub

The largest online library of Filipiniana e-books. This website is designed for your easy access to Filipiniana works—those that are: 1. printed in the Philippines. 2. about the Philippines. 3. written by Filipinos.

name: The Philippine Islands (Full-text)The Philippine I...
intro:
The Philippine Islands (Full-text)


The Philippine Islands is a monumental 55-volume book by Emma Blair and James Alexander Robertson. It consists of primary source documents for Philippine history translated into English.

name: South-East Asia Digital Library (SEADL): Philippin...
intro:
South-East Asia Digital Library (SEADL): Philippines



Contains digital facsimiles of books and manuscripts, as well as multimedia materials and searchable indexes of additional Southeast Asian resources. Nations represented in the collection include Brunei, Cambodia, East Timor, Indonesia, Laos, Malaysia, Myanmar, the Philippines, Singapore, Thailand, and Vietnam.

name: Unit 1: Getting Ready for WorkAt the end of this u...
intro:
Unit 1: Getting Ready for Work

At the end of this unit, you would be able to:
1. Differentiate the different types of accommodation;
2. Identify the parts of a basic accommodation organizational chart;
3. Describe the different duties and responsibilities of different Housekeeping staff.

name: Unit 2: Handling Housekeeping RequestsAt the end o...
intro:
Unit 2: Handling Housekeeping Requests

At the end of this unit, you should be able to:
  • Apply appropriate procedures in:
1. Accepting housekeeping requests.
2. Recording housekeeping requests
3. Advising on time for delivery of service or items
4. Providing housekeeping requests;
5. Providing advice to guests; and
6. Liaising with other departments.

name: Label

Unit 1: Getting Ready for Work
At the end of this...
intro:
Unit 1: Getting Ready for Work

At the end of this unit, you should be able to:
 1. Recognize the responsibilities and characteristics required of a position, and the role of communication in the Guest Room Attendant Job.
2. Discuss Good Grooming practices required from a Guest Room Attendant and their daily activities.

name: Unit 2: Preparing for Cleaning DutiesThis uni...
intro:
Unit 2: Preparing for Cleaning Duties


This unit covers the preparation procedures which includes: 

1. Familiarity with the Room Assignment Sheet of the Room Status Report 

2. Need to be ready with supply and equipment preparation 

3. Do proper loading of the housekeeping trolley 

4. Familiarity with the items, and the other operation of the housekeeping Trolley 

5. The Knowledge which rooms to be cleaned based on room status report and room assignment 


By the end of this unit, you should be able to know and do the necessary procedures in preparation for the cleaning duties.

name: Unit 1: Introduction to Valet ServiceAt the end of...
intro:
Unit 1: Introduction to Valet Service

At the end of this unit, you should be able to:
  1. Identify what a Valet Staff is;
  2. Identify the responsibilities of a Valet Staff;
  3. Demonstrate good grooming in the workplace
  4. Demonstrate proper use of Personal Protective Equipment; and
  5. Learn the main responsibilities of a Valet Staff.

name: Unit 2: Providing Valet ServiceAt the end of the u...
intro:
Unit 2: Providing Valet Service

At the end of the unit, you should be able to:

  1. Demonstrate how to welcome guests;
  2. Demonstrate how to pack and unpack guests’ luggage;
  3. Demonstrate how to handle guests’ laundry;
  4. Demonstrate how to clean guest shoes; and
  5. Demonstrate how to handle guest requests.

Unit 1: Getting Ready for Work

At the end of this unit, you should be able to:
 1. Recognize the responsibilities and characteristics required of a position, and the role of communication in the Guest Room Attendant Job.
2. Discuss Good Grooming practices required from a Guest Room Attendant and their daily activities.

name: Unit 2: Preparing for Cleaning DutiesThis uni...
intro:
Unit 2: Preparing for Cleaning Duties


This unit covers the preparation procedures which includes: 

1. Familiarity with the Room Assignment Sheet of the Room Status Report 

2. Need to be ready with supply and equipment preparation 

3. Do proper loading of the housekeeping trolley 

4. Familiarity with the items, and the other operation of the housekeeping Trolley 

5. The Knowledge which rooms to be cleaned based on room status report and room assignment 


By the end of this unit, you should be able to know and do the necessary procedures in preparation for the cleaning duties.

name: Unit 1: Introduction to Valet ServiceAt the end of...
intro:
Unit 1: Introduction to Valet Service

At the end of this unit, you should be able to:
  1. Identify what a Valet Staff is;
  2. Identify the responsibilities of a Valet Staff;
  3. Demonstrate good grooming in the workplace
  4. Demonstrate proper use of Personal Protective Equipment; and
  5. Learn the main responsibilities of a Valet Staff.

name: Unit 2: Providing Valet ServiceAt the end of the u...
intro:
Unit 2: Providing Valet Service

At the end of the unit, you should be able to:

  1. Demonstrate how to welcome guests;
  2. Demonstrate how to pack and unpack guests’ luggage;
  3. Demonstrate how to handle guests’ laundry;
  4. Demonstrate how to clean guest shoes; and
  5. Demonstrate how to handle guest requests.

intro: TOPIC 1.1 Concepts and Principles of Sustainable Food Systems, Environmental Sustainability, and Sustainable Dining

name: A. Duration: 1 hour and 30 minutes - Lecture / 30m...
intro:
A. Duration: 1 hour and 30 minutes - Lecture / 30minutes - 1 hours for SGD


B. Learning Objective: 

           At the end of the topic, the students should be able to appreciate and understand the concepts and principles related to sustainable food systems, environmental sustainability, and sustainable dining.


C. Competencies to be Developed

            The student should be able to understand and explain related concepts and be familiar with environmental sustainability and sustainable dining practices being implemented in the foodservice (hospitality) industry.


D. Topic Inputs and Reflections
  • What is a sustainable system?
  • What is sustainable dining environment sustainability?

E. Materials
1. Lecture PPT

2. Link for the Food Quiz: https://foodprint.org/quiz/?utm_source=kitchn&utm_medium


F. Student's Responsibilities for the Day: Listen, Reflect & Respond

TOPIC 1. 2 Policies and Practices that Promot...
intro: TOPIC 1. 2 Policies and Practices that Promote Sustainable Food Systems, Environmental Sustainability and Sustainable Dining

name: A. Duration: 1 hour and 30 minutes - Lecture / 30m...
intro:
A. Duration: 1 hour and 30 minutes - Lecture / 30minutes - 1 hours for SGD


B. Learning Objective: 

           At the end of the topic, the students should be able to identify policies and practices which promote sustainable food systems, environmental sustainability, and sustainable dining in different foodservice systems.


C. Competencies to be Developed

            The student should be able to acquire knowledge on the policies and practices related to the concept of sustainable food systems, environmental sustainability, and sustainable dining in different foodservice (hospitality) systems.


D. Topic Inputs and Reflections

  • What are the policies and practices related to the promotion of sustainable food systems, environmental sustainability, and sustainable dining being implemented?

E. Materials
1. Lecture PPT

2. Food Sharing Network Program: https://www.foodsharenetwork.com/

3. Hotel Kitchen Toolkit: https://hotelkitchen.org/about-toolkit


F. Student's Responsibilities for the Day: Listen, Reflect & Respond


G. Activity: "Restaurant Maker"


H. Group Activity: 

After the discussion, the class will be divided into groups into their respective group. Each group will have to develop their own concept for a restaurant that upholds environmental sustainability and sustainable dining policies and practices. The students will also evaluate the pros and cons of their developed restaurant concept.

name: MODULE 2: EMBRACING SUSTAINABLE DINING  &nbsp...
intro:
MODULE 2: EMBRACING SUSTAINABLE DINING

          The sustainable diner food path begins with production, distribution, transportation, preparation, and then consumption. This module covers the means and strategies in applying sustainable dining principles from food establishment operations to everyday living including menu planning, ingredient, and supplies purchasing, and meal preparation and consumption. This module also tackles the importance of resource management including water and energy, as well as the importance of waste management in its achievement. After the completion of this module, the students are expected to apply and promote sustainable dining and its strategies.


This module has the following topics:

Topic 2.1. Planning the Menu
Topic 2.2. Choosing Resources and Ingredients
Topic 2.3. Managing Resources
Topic 2.4. Managing Waste
Topic 2.5. Implementing Sustainable Dining as a Way of Life (Operations and Management)


A. LEARNING OBJECTIVE
At the end of this module the students should be able to:
1. plan a regional menu according to sustainable dining principles;
2. discuss cost-effective means for sustainable purchasing;
3. describe ways on how to manage resources in the context of sustainable
dining;
4. develop sustainable water and waste management system for the
establishment;
5. commit to practicing sustainable dining regularly.

B. COMPETENCIES TO BE DEVELOPED
           The students should be able to acquire knowledge and skills on sustainable dining practices, particularly on: regional cuisine and menu development, choosing resources and ingredients, resource management, development of sustainable water management system, development of proper waste management system and composting, and development of a statement of commitment on sustainable dining practices.


C. TOPIC INPUTS AND REFLECTIONS FOR STUDENTS
1. How can I apply sustainable dining principles in developing menus at home? In a food establishment?
2. How do I choose the resources and ingredients according to sustainable dining principles? How can I support local producers?
3. How can I help save water, energy, and other resources?
4. What can I do to minimize food waste at home?
5. Am I ready to practice sustainable dining? How can I be more sustainable?

D. MATERIALS
● Soft copy of PowerPoint presentations
● Copy of video presentations
● Computer

E. METHODOLOGY
● Lecture-discussions
● Individual reflections
● Group activities

G. EXPECTED OUTPUTS
● Individual reflections
● Group written reports
● Oral presentations
● Statement of commitment and/or establishment policy

name: TOPIC 2.1 MENU PLANNINGA. Duration - 30...
intro:
TOPIC 2.1 MENU PLANNING


A. Duration - 30-45 minutes

B. Learning Objective
        At the end of this topic, the students should be able to develop a regional menu following the principles of sustainable dining.


C. Competencies to be Developed
         The students should be able to acquire knowledge and skills on menu development considering the principles of sustainable dining.


D. Topic Inputs and Reflections
             How can sustainable dining principles be applied in menu planning?
● Lecture-discussion on the principles of sustainable dining as applied in menu planning.
● Writing a regional menu following the principles of sustainable dining.

E. Materials
1. PPT.
2. Soft copy of video presentation. 
Global:
● WWF International. (2020, October 9). Planet-based diets - good for us, good for nature! [Video]. Youtube. https://youtu.be/fiMOh0DEUSg
● Lifehacker. (2019, May 10). Food tips from the most sustainable restaurant in the world [Video]. 

Youtube. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=baO37bGFDRU
● Mashable Brand X. (2016, March 24). The San Francisco restaurant redefining what sustainable eating can mean - the new way [Video].

Youtube. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TuV8mJtZw7s

● The Atlantic. (2020, January 11). The struggle of zero-waste restaurants [Video]. 

Youtube. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Gj38m08QLoE

Local:
● WWF-Philippines. (2018, February 28). The sustainable diner - how chefs can promote eco-friendly dining [Video]. Youtube. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sjgULQ752Qs

3. Laptop, 


F. Preparation Activities (FOR FACULTY)
● Prepare the slide deck and video presentations.
● Prepare examples of menus following the principles of sustainable dining. This can be incorporated into the slide deck.
● Instruct the students to:
a. Listen: Concepts in sustainable dining will be discussed. Choose any of the videos suggested.
b. Reflect: How can I apply the principles of sustainable dining in developing menus at home? In a food and/or food-related establishment?
c. Respond: Create a regional menu for the household or for a food
and/or a food-related establishment.

G. Methodology
1. Lecture-Discussion
2. Video Presentation
3. Menu planning activity

H. Process
1. Lecture-Discussion: The faculty-in-charge will discuss what is sustainable dining, its principles, and current trends in adopting such practices. Menu planning, the process and its principles should also be discussed to guide the students in doing their own menu.

2. Video Presentation: The faculty-in-charge will show the video presentations where sustainable dining principles are being adopted in real life settings.


3. Activity 1. “Menu for Thought”
The faculty-in-charge will show examples of menu items. The students will be asked to identify the principles applied and will be asked to share in class their recommendations and ideas to improve the said menu.

Example 1:
Herbed Grilled Grouper in Lemon Butter Sauce
Steamed Broccoli Florets
Crispy-Skinned Oven-Baked Potatoes
Carrot Cake Slice
Brewed Iced Tea

Example 2:
Spiced Lentil Soup
Vegetable Paella served with Hummus Quesadilla
Vegan Shortbread
Fruit-Infused Green Tea

Example 3:
Oyster Mushroom Soup
Baked Chicken Breast with Buttered Corn
Brown Rice
Kesong Puti and Fresh Fruit Plate
Freshly Squeezed Calamansi Juice
Note: The faculty-in-charge can include more relatable examples; can be
from instructional materials used in the course.

4. Ask the students to form groups with three (3) to four (4) members. Let the
students choose a region to represent.

5. Activity 2: “What’s on the Menu?”
The students will write a menu for a household or a restaurant, with at least one menu item, for each of the following categories:
1. Main entrée with a vegetable side dish
2. Rice or any other carbohydrate-rich food
3. Dessert
4. Beverage

Include specific instructions such as ingredient substitutions, ways to minimize waste during preparation, efficient use of resources, portioning, and serving materials to be used for dine-in and/or take-away. Take note that the menu to be developed should follow menu planning and sustainable dining principles. The students can visit the WWF Planet-Based Diet website, Build Your Diet (https://planetbaseddiets.panda.org/impacts-action-calculator), for menu ideas. The students can decide on what will be the theme and other aspects of the food establishment. Make sure that each group will have a unique theme/cuisine/aspect to avoid duplication of output. Each group should report their output in class the next meeting.

I. Expected Output
1. Group menu
2. Oral presentation by group (submit slide deck used)

Topic 2.2. Choosing Resources and IngredientsA. ...
intro:
Topic 2.2. Choosing Resources and Ingredients
A. Duration - 30-45 minutes

B. Learning Objective
At the end of this topic, the students should be able to:
1. explain the environmental, economic, and health impacts of different consumer food purchases and practices; and
2. apply cost-effective means for sustainable purchasing.

C. Competencies
The students should be able to acquire knowledge and skills in choosing resources and ingredients for their food establishment following the principles of sustainable dining.

D. Topic Inputs and Reflections
REFLECTION: How do I choose the resources and ingredients according to sustainable dining principles? How can I support local producers?
● Lecture-discussion on how to choose resources and ingredients according to sustainable dining principles.
● Critique the menu (output) from Topic 2.1 based on the sustainable dining principles
● Written and oral reports containing prospective local suppliers for the menu planned in Topic 2.1


E. Materials
● PPT
● Menu from Topic 2.1

F. Preparation Activities
● Prepare the slide deck.
● Each student must prepare a copy of their menu from Topic 2.1.
● Prepare the interview guide.
● Instruct the students to:
a. Listen: The importance and factors that need to be considered when choosing resources and ingredients will be discussed.
b. Reflect: How do I choose the resources and ingredients according to sustainable dining principles? How can I support local producers?
c. Respond: Get to know local suppliers through market visits and/or online or phone interviews with key persons, e.g., suppliers, managers, restaurant owners 


G. Methodology
1. Lecture-discussion
2. Online or phone interviews

H. Process
1. Lecture-Discussion: The faculty-in-charge will discuss the importance of and factors that need to be considered when choosing resources and ingredients following sustainable dining principles.

2. Activity 1: “Think-Group-Share”
a. Make sure that all students have a copy of the menu that they developed in Topic 2.1.
b. Ask them to present their prepared menus then discuss answers to these guide questions:
1. What can you say about the ingredients and methods used?
2. What do you find interesting about their menu?
3. How can it be improved?
4. What makes a sustainable menu?
c. The faculty in charge will process the activity.


3. Activity 2: “Off to Market”
a. The faculty-in-charge is to choose from these two (2) activities:
Option 1: Each group will be asked to go to a local market and look for prospective suppliers for their developed menus. The students may also use other methods such as online platforms in searching for local suppliers.

Option 2: Each group will interview one (1) food establishment to learn about their sustainable practices in sourcing ingredients using the attached checklist on sustainable purchasing policy (on p. 19 of
the Sustainable Kitchen Egyptian version). Ask the students to highlight the practices that demonstrate sustainable dining principles.
b. Each group will report their output in the next session.
c. The faculty-in-charge will process the activity.


I. Expected Output
1. Insights on the menu developed from Topic 2.1.
2. Oral presentation by the group for the take-home activity (submit slide deck used).

name: Topic 2.3. Managing ResourcesA. Duration - ...
intro:
Topic 2.3. Managing Resources

A. Duration - 30-45 minutes


B. Learning Objectives

               At the end of this topic, the students should be able to develop ways on how to manage resources in the context of sustainable dining.


C. Competencies

             The students should be able to acquire knowledge and skills on resource management considering sustainable dining principles and the development of a sustainable water management system.


D. Topic Inputs and Reflections

How can I help conserve resources such as energy and water?

● Lecture-discussion on managing resources such as energy and water. Introduce the cost-benefit monitoring tool.

● List of equipment by workstation and/or what is available in their food laboratories to include description, specifications, consumption rate, source, price, etc. of the most cost-efficient brand or model for each equipment on the list they submitted.


E. Materials

Soft copy of the slide deck

Cost-benefit monitoring tool (MS Excel spreadsheet)


F. Preparation Activities

● Prepare the slide deck and the cost-benefit monitoring tool.

● Instruct the students to:

a. Listen: The guidelines in managing resources such as energy and water will be discussed.

b. Reflect: How can I help conserve resources such as energy and water?

c. Respond: List all equipment by workstation, or based on what is available in food laboratories, with energy and water requirements


G. Methodology

1. Lecture-discussion

2. Listing of equipment with specifications


H. Process

1. Lecture-Discussion: The faculty-in-charge will discuss the guidelines in managing resources in accordance with sustainable dining principles.

Introduce the cost-benefit monitoring tool.

2. Activity: “Making Sense of My Equipment Specs”

a. Each group will be preparing a list of all equipment, specifically those

with energy and water requirements, by workstation or based on what is available in their food laboratories. Work stations include receiving, preparation, production, service/dining, dishwashing, and waste disposal areas.

b. The report should contain pertinent information such as description, specifications, consumption rate, source, price, etc. of the most cost-efficient brand or model for each piece of equipment.

c. Each group will report characteristics of each of the listed equipment that makes or do not make them cost-efficient.


I. Expected OutputTopic 

1. List of equipment per workstation by group

2. Written output and oral presentation by group (submit slide deck used)

name:
Topic 2.4. Managing Waste A. Duration
30...
intro:
Topic 2.4. Managing Waste 

A. Duration 30-45 minutes 


B. Learning Objective At the end of this topic, the students should be able to develop a sustainable waste management system for the establishment. 


C. Competencies to be Developed The students should be able to acquire knowledge and skills on the development of proper waste management systems and composting in a food service establishment following principles of sustainable dining. 


D. Topic Inputs and Reflections for Students How can I minimize food and food-related waste at home and in a food establishment? 

● Lecture-discussion on waste management. 

● Demonstrating proper use and maintenance of compost bins. 

● Developing a waste management system following sustainable dining principles for a home or a food establishment. 


E. Materials 

1. Soft copy of the slide deck 

2. Laptop and projector 

3. Materials for composting (soil, soil box/container, hand trowel, gardening gloves, scissors, water in a spray bottle, dried leaves/sawdust/wood chips, and food wastes like trimmings, peels, eggshells, etc.) F. Preparation Activities 

● Prepare the slide deck 

● Prepare the bokashi composting video: Green Space. (2020, April 12). 

HOW TO #BokashiComposting 

[Video]. Facebook. https://www.facebook.com/watch/?v=242254873847139 

● Prepare the needed materials for composting (you can ask the students to bring their own before this session) 

● Instruct the students to: 

a. Listen: The strategies on managing waste will be discussed. 

b. Reflect: How can I minimize food and food-related waste at home? 

c. Respond: Create a waste management system based on sustainable dining principles. 


G. Methodology 

1. Lecture and discussion 

2. Demonstration of composting using bins (by faculty-in-charge) 

3. Activities 


H. Process 

1. Lecture-Discussion: The faculty-in-charge will discuss proper waste management in the context of food businesses, including the food waste hierarchy for cost-saving opportunities. Ways on preventing food waste, measuring food waste, reducing food spoilage, plate waste, and packaging wastes will be emphasized. 

2. Composting demonstration: The faculty-in-charge will demonstrate the proper way of using a compost bin while using common food waste in a food business or play the video demonstrating bokashi composting. 

3. Option 1: “Compost it!” a. Ask the students to form groups with 3 to 4 members. The students will make their own compost following the proper way described or demonstrated by the faculty. Another option is to do individual composting using miniature compost bins fit for the amount of space they have at home. For example, students can use empty ice cream tubs or plastic containers. 

Here is an example of how to make an indoor compost bin: Better Homes and Gardens. (2019, February 22). DIY indoor compost bin [Video]. Youtube.https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jBTNCJa4rw8 b. The faculty-in-charge will guide, check, and grade the students accordingly. These will be stored in a designated area in the school premises. c. The compost bins should be maintained by each group (i.e., regular watering and mixing) throughout a specified period (e.g., end of semester). 

d. The final product of the compost bins will be part of grading for this sessiontion : 

“Let’s track it” 

a. Ask the students to form groups with 3 to 4 members. The students will be assuming hypothetical amounts of food, packaging, and operating supply wastes (and other sources, if any) that their home or a food establishment can produce in a specified period (e.g., 1 month). The students can use the table template attached to summarize the hypothetical number of generated wastes. 

b. Using these hypothetical values, the student should prepare a waste management system for their home or a food establishment based on the guidelines discussed during the lecture. The waste management 95 system should be holistic and can include improvements in other aspects of the food business. 

c. Each group should report their output in class the next meeting. 

e. Expected Output 1. Compost bin individual or by group to be maintained throughout a specified period or a group written output on recommended waste management system 


2. Oral presentation by group (submit slide deck used)

name: Label
Topic 2.5. Adopting Sustainable Dining as a Way of...
intro:
Topic 2.5. Adopting Sustainable Dining as a Way of Life (Operations and Management)
A. Duration - 30-45 minutes

B. Learning Objective
At the end of the activity, the students should be able to:
1. develop a personal statement of commitment and establishment policy on sustainable dining; and,
2. apply sustainable dining practices regularly.


C. Competencies to be developed
The students should be able to acquire knowledge and skills on the development of a statement of commitment and establishment policy on sustainable dining and to apply sustainable dining practices in their daily living.


D. Topic Inputs/Reflections
Am I ready to practice sustainable dining? How can I be more sustainable?
● Lecture-discussion on recommended approaches, solutions, and promotions to sustainable dining.
● Creating a personal statement of commitment and an establishment policy on sustainable dining.
● Documenting day-to-day activities to showcase applied sustainable dining principles and to suggest improvements.

E. Materials
1. Soft copy of the slide deck
2. Laptop, projector, and sound system

F. Preparation Activities
● Prepare the slide deck
● Prepare the needed materials for oral reporting (Laptop, projector)
● Instruct the students to:
a. Listen: The recommended approaches, solutions, and promotions to sustainable dining will be discussed.
b. Reflect: Am I ready to practice sustainable dining? How can I be more sustainable?
c. Respond: Create a personal statement of commitment and an establishment policy on sustainable dining and document day-to-day activities to showcase applied sustainable dining principles and to
suggest for improvement.

G. Methodology
1. Lecture and discussion
2. Activities

H. Process
1. Lecture-Discussion: The faculty-in-charge will discuss ways on how to embrace sustainable dining as a way of life in operational and management aspects. This also includes the importance of policy statements in encouraging the staff and customers of the food establishment to adopt such measures, thereby promoting collective efforts towards the achievement of sustainable dining.

2. Activity 1: “Commitments”
The students will be asked to make the following:
a. individual statement of commitment on sustainable dining following the guidelines discussed in the lecture.
b. an establishment policy on sustainable dining per group. The establishment policy should also include specific guidelines on how they are going to implement it among their staff, suppliers, and customers.

3. Activity 2: “Sustainable Diary”
The faculty-in-charge will provide instructions:
a. After the lecture discussion on sustainable dining principles in session the students will already be asked to document their day-to-day activities wherein they were able to showcase and apply the said principles. 

a. They can take pictures and videos about it and write short content for each.
b. As the class advances on this module, it is expected that more and more principles will be applied and documented by each student.
c. The students can be creative using videos by adding a storyline or theme for it to be more engaging. The pictures and video clips will be consolidated in a 3–5-minute video presentation (with captions or
narrations) and will be viewed in class on a specified date towards the end of the module.

I. Expected Output
1. Statement of commitment (individual) on sustainable dining
2. Oral presentation per group on establishment policy (submit in MSWord format)
3. 3–5-minute video presentation of applications of sustainable dining principles in day-to-day activities (individual)

name: MODULE 3: Conducting Research on Sustainable Dinin...
intro:
MODULE 3: Conducting Research on Sustainable Dining
This module is designed to develop among the students and faculty the knowledge and skills
on designing and undertaking research on sustainable dining.

A. DURATION - 60 minutes

B. LEARNING OBJECTIVE
At the end of the module, the students should be able to develop a research proposal on sustainable dining.

C. COMPETENCIES TO BE DEVELOPED
● Knowledge on the importance of conducting research on sustainable dining
● Knowledge and skills on how to prepare a research proposal on sustainable dining

D. TOPIC INPUTS AND REFLECTIONS FOR STUDENTS
Information from the provided reading materials (online and offline)
Guide Questions: 

Why is it important to conduct research on sustainable dining?
What are the essential elements in preparing a research proposal?

E. MATERIALS
● Manual
● Handouts, resource materials
● Soft copy of PowerPoint presentation

F. PREPARATORY ACTIVITIES FOR THE FACULTY
1. Prepare session guide for a detailed instruction of activity (should contain link of activity sheet)
2. Prepare and upload PowerPoint presentation
3. Read the handouts/resource materials provided 


G. METHODOLOGY
A combination of lecture, writeshop and presentation-critiquing will be used. Students and faculty members have the option to work on an individual research or a small group that consists of up to three (3) members per group.


H. PROCESS
1. Discuss the PowerPoint presentation for this module.
2. Instruct the participants to:
a. Read Resource materials provided including the uploaded PowerPoint presentation
b. Reflect: What are the essential elements and requirements in developing a research proposal?
c. Respond: Develop a research proposal on sustainable dining 


I. EXPECTED OUTPUTS
● Research proposal on sustainable dining

name: MODULE 4. DEVELOPING A COMMUNICATION PLANA. DURATI...
intro:
MODULE 4. DEVELOPING A COMMUNICATION PLAN


A. DURATION: 45 minutes


B. LEARNING OBJECTIVES

At the end of the session, the students should be able to:

1. Define a communication plan; and

2. Develop a communication plan for the promotion of sustainable dining.


C. COMPETENCIES TO BE DEVELOPED

The students should be able to acquire knowledge and skills in developing a communication plan for the promotion of sustainable dining to different types of audiences.


D. TOPIC INPUTS AND REFLECTIONS FOR STUDENTS

How can sustainable dining be promoted to different types of audiences?


E. MATERIALS

● Soft copy of PowerPoint Presentation


F. PREPARATORY ACTIVITIES FOR THE FACULTY

● Review this guide for a detailed instruction of activities

● Prepare and upload the PowerPoint/Slide presentation

● Review the sample communication plan

● Instruct the students to:

a. Listen: The importance and steps in creating a communication plan will be

discussed.

b. Reflect: How can sustainable dining be promoted to different types of audience?

c. Respond: Make a communication plan following the steps discussed or create

an infographic with environmental sustainability and sustainable dining

messages.


G. METHODOLOGY

● Lecture discussion

● Develop communication plan


H. PROCESS

a. Lecture-Discussion: The faculty in charge will discuss the importance of promoting sustainable dining, define communication, and explain how a communication plan is developed.

b. The faculty in-charge can choose between these two activities based on available resources:

Activity 1: “One Step at a Time”

The faculty-in-charge will provide the instructions:

a. After the lecture-discussion on developing a communication plan, instruct the students to find a partner.

b. The students will be asked to apply what they have learned by filing up the action plan matrix. Provide the guide questions:

- How can you promote environmental sustainability and sustainable dining?

- What is its purpose?

- How will you deliver your message to your target audience?

- How often will this be implemented?

- Who are you communicating with?

- Who will lead the implementation of your communication plan?

- How much will it cost?

Activity Objective Medium/Channel, Frequency Target, Audience, Person-in-charge, Budgetary Requirement

c. The pairs will present their work in class. 


Activity 2: “Making an Impact”

The faculty-in-charge will provide the instructions:

a. This activity can be done individually.

b. Create an infographic promoting environmental sustainability and sustainable dining. Examples can be found in:

c. The student may present his/her infographic in class or post on any online learning or social media platform.


WWF-Australia. (2018). Shop sustainably. 

https://www.wwf.org.au/get-involved/change-the-way-you-live/shopping#gs.upn6ft


Yogurt in Nutrition. (2020, June 15). Sustainable healthy diets: from science to your plate! https://www.yogurtinnutrition.com/infographic-sustainable-healthy-diets-from-science-to-your-plate/


Mah, V. (2019, April 17). Food waste – A major worldwide problem. Andatech distribution. https://www.andatechdistribution.com.au/blogs/news/food-waste-infographic


I. EXPECTED OUTPUTS

• Communication plan or infographic on environmental sustainability and sustainable dining.


J. SLIDE DECK

intro:
A. Duration: 1 hour and 30 minutes - Lecture / 30minutes - 1 hours for SGD


B. Learning Objective: 

           At the end of the topic, the students should be able to identify policies and practices which promote sustainable food systems, environmental sustainability, and sustainable dining in different foodservice systems.


C. Competencies to be Developed

G. Activity: "Restaurant Maker"


H. Group Activity: 

After the discussion, the class will be divided into groups into their respective group. Each group will have to develop their own concept for a restaurant that upholds environmental sustainability and sustainable dining policies and practices. The students will also evaluate the pros and cons of their developed restaurant concept.

name: MODULE 2: EMBRACING SUSTAINABLE DINING  &nbsp...
intro:
MODULE 2: EMBRACING SUSTAINABLE DINING

          The sustainable diner food path begins with production, distribution, transportation, preparation, and then consumption. This module covers the means and strategies in applying sustainable dining principles from food establishment operations to everyday living including menu planning, ingredient, and supplies purchasing, and meal preparation and consumption. This module also tackles the importance of resource management including water and energy, as well as the importance of waste management in its achievement. After the completion of this module, the students are expected to apply and promote sustainable dining and its strategies.


This module has the following topics:

Topic 2.1. Planning the Menu
Topic 2.2. Choosing Resources and Ingredients
Topic 2.3. Managing Resources
Topic 2.4. Managing Waste
Topic 2.5. Implementing Sustainable Dining as a Way of Life (Operations and Management)


A. LEARNING OBJECTIVE
At the end of this module the students should be able to:
1. plan a regional menu according to sustainable dining principles;
2. discuss cost-effective means for sustainable purchasing;
3. describe ways on how to manage resources in the context of sustainable
dining;
4. develop sustainable water and waste management system for the
establishment;
5. commit to practicing sustainable dining regularly.

B. COMPETENCIES TO BE DEVELOPED
           The students should be able to acquire knowledge and skills on sustainable dining practices, particularly on: regional cuisine and menu development, choosing resources and ingredients, resource management, development of sustainable water management system, development of proper waste management system and composting, and development of a statement of commitment on sustainable dining practices.


C. TOPIC INPUTS AND REFLECTIONS FOR STUDENTS
1. How can I apply sustainable dining principles in developing menus at home? In a food establishment?
2. How do I choose the resources and ingredients according to sustainable dining principles? How can I support local producers?
3. How can I help save water, energy, and other resources?
4. What can I do to minimize food waste at home?
5. Am I ready to practice sustainable dining? How can I be more sustainable?

D. MATERIALS
● Soft copy of PowerPoint presentations
● Copy of video presentations
● Computer

E. METHODOLOGY
● Lecture-discussions
● Individual reflections
● Group activities

G. EXPECTED OUTPUTS
● Individual reflections
● Group written reports
● Oral presentations
● Statement of commitment and/or establishment policy

name: TOPIC 2.1 MENU PLANNINGA. Duration - 30...
intro:
TOPIC 2.1 MENU PLANNING


A. Duration - 30-45 minutes

B. Learning Objective
        At the end of this topic, the students should be able to develop a regional menu following the principles of sustainable dining.


C. Competencies to be Developed
         The students should be able to acquire knowledge and skills on menu development considering the principles of sustainable dining.


D. Topic Inputs and Reflections
             How can sustainable dining principles be applied in menu planning?
● Lecture-discussion on the principles of sustainable dining as applied in menu planning.
● Writing a regional menu following the principles of sustainable dining.

E. Materials
1. PPT.
2. Soft copy of video presentation. 
Global:
● WWF International. (2020, October 9). Planet-based diets - good for us, good for nature! [Video]. Youtube. https://youtu.be/fiMOh0DEUSg
● Lifehacker. (2019, May 10). Food tips from the most sustainable restaurant in the world [Video]. 

Youtube. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=baO37bGFDRU
● Mashable Brand X. (2016, March 24). The San Francisco restaurant redefining what sustainable eating can mean - the new way [Video].

Youtube. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TuV8mJtZw7s

● The Atlantic. (2020, January 11). The struggle of zero-waste restaurants [Video]. 

Youtube. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Gj38m08QLoE

Local:
● WWF-Philippines. (2018, February 28). The sustainable diner - how chefs can promote eco-friendly dining [Video]. Youtube. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sjgULQ752Qs

3. Laptop, 


F. Preparation Activities (FOR FACULTY)
● Prepare the slide deck and video presentations.
● Prepare examples of menus following the principles of sustainable dining. This can be incorporated into the slide deck.
● Instruct the students to:
a. Listen: Concepts in sustainable dining will be discussed. Choose any of the videos suggested.
b. Reflect: How can I apply the principles of sustainable dining in developing menus at home? In a food and/or food-related establishment?
c. Respond: Create a regional menu for the household or for a food
and/or a food-related establishment.

G. Methodology
1. Lecture-Discussion
2. Video Presentation
3. Menu planning activity

H. Process
1. Lecture-Discussion: The faculty-in-charge will discuss what is sustainable dining, its principles, and current trends in adopting such practices. Menu planning, the process and its principles should also be discussed to guide the students in doing their own menu.

2. Video Presentation: The faculty-in-charge will show the video presentations where sustainable dining principles are being adopted in real life settings.


3. Activity 1. “Menu for Thought”
The faculty-in-charge will show examples of menu items. The students will be asked to identify the principles applied and will be asked to share in class their recommendations and ideas to improve the said menu.

Example 1:
Herbed Grilled Grouper in Lemon Butter Sauce
Steamed Broccoli Florets
Crispy-Skinned Oven-Baked Potatoes
Carrot Cake Slice
Brewed Iced Tea

Example 2:
Spiced Lentil Soup
Vegetable Paella served with Hummus Quesadilla
Vegan Shortbread
Fruit-Infused Green Tea

Example 3:
Oyster Mushroom Soup
Baked Chicken Breast with Buttered Corn
Brown Rice
Kesong Puti and Fresh Fruit Plate
Freshly Squeezed Calamansi Juice
Note: The faculty-in-charge can include more relatable examples; can be
from instructional materials used in the course.

4. Ask the students to form groups with three (3) to four (4) members. Let the
students choose a region to represent.

5. Activity 2: “What’s on the Menu?”
The students will write a menu for a household or a restaurant, with at least one menu item, for each of the following categories:
1. Main entrée with a vegetable side dish
2. Rice or any other carbohydrate-rich food
3. Dessert
4. Beverage

Include specific instructions such as ingredient substitutions, ways to minimize waste during preparation, efficient use of resources, portioning, and serving materials to be used for dine-in and/or take-away. Take note that the menu to be developed should follow menu planning and sustainable dining principles. The students can visit the WWF Planet-Based Diet website, Build Your Diet (https://planetbaseddiets.panda.org/impacts-action-calculator), for menu ideas. The students can decide on what will be the theme and other aspects of the food establishment. Make sure that each group will have a unique theme/cuisine/aspect to avoid duplication of output. Each group should report their output in class the next meeting.

I. Expected Output
1. Group menu
2. Oral presentation by group (submit slide deck used)
