Topic 2.2. Choosing Resources and IngredientsA. ...
intro:
Topic 2.2. Choosing Resources and Ingredients
A. Duration - 30-45 minutes

B. Learning Objective
At the end of this topic, the students should be able to:
1. explain the environmental, economic, and health impacts of different consumer food purchases and practices; and
2. apply cost-effective means for sustainable purchasing.

C. Competencies
The students should be able to acquire knowledge and skills in choosing resources and ingredients for their food establishment following the principles of sustainable dining.

D. Topic Inputs and Reflections
REFLECTION: How do I choose the resources and ingredients according to sustainable dining principles? How can I support local producers?
● Lecture-discussion on how to choose resources and ingredients according to sustainable dining principles.
● Critique the menu (output) from Topic 2.1 based on the sustainable dining principles
● Written and oral reports containing prospective local suppliers for the menu planned in Topic 2.1


E. Materials
● PPT
● Menu from Topic 2.1

F. Preparation Activities
● Prepare the slide deck.
● Each student must prepare a copy of their menu from Topic 2.1.
● Prepare the interview guide.
● Instruct the students to:
a. Listen: The importance and factors that need to be considered when choosing resources and ingredients will be discussed.
b. Reflect: How do I choose the resources and ingredients according to sustainable dining principles? How can I support local producers?
c. Respond: Get to know local suppliers through market visits and/or online or phone interviews with key persons, e.g., suppliers, managers, restaurant owners 


G. Methodology
1. Lecture-discussion
2. Online or phone interviews

H. Process
1. Lecture-Discussion: The faculty-in-charge will discuss the importance of and factors that need to be considered when choosing resources and ingredients following sustainable dining principles.

2. Activity 1: “Think-Group-Share”
a. Make sure that all students have a copy of the menu that they developed in Topic 2.1.
b. Ask them to present their prepared menus then discuss answers to these guide questions:
1. What can you say about the ingredients and methods used?
2. What do you find interesting about their menu?
3. How can it be improved?
4. What makes a sustainable menu?
c. The faculty in charge will process the activity.


3. Activity 2: “Off to Market”
a. The faculty-in-charge is to choose from these two (2) activities:
Option 1: Each group will be asked to go to a local market and look for prospective suppliers for their developed menus. The students may also use other methods such as online platforms in searching for local suppliers.

Option 2: Each group will interview one (1) food establishment to learn about their sustainable practices in sourcing ingredients using the attached checklist on sustainable purchasing policy (on p. 19 of
the Sustainable Kitchen Egyptian version). Ask the students to highlight the practices that demonstrate sustainable dining principles.
b. Each group will report their output in the next session.
c. The faculty-in-charge will process the activity.


I. Expected Output
1. Insights on the menu developed from Topic 2.1.
2. Oral presentation by the group for the take-home activity (submit slide deck used).

name: Topic 2.3. Managing ResourcesA. Duration - ...
intro:
Topic 2.3. Managing Resources

A. Duration - 30-45 minutes


B. Learning Objectives

               At the end of this topic, the students should be able to develop ways on how to manage resources in the context of sustainable dining.


C. Competencies

             The students should be able to acquire knowledge and skills on resource management considering sustainable dining principles and the development of a sustainable water management system.


D. Topic Inputs and Reflections

How can I help conserve resources such as energy and water?

● Lecture-discussion on managing resources such as energy and water. Introduce the cost-benefit monitoring tool.

● List of equipment by workstation and/or what is available in their food laboratories to include description, specifications, consumption rate, source, price, etc. of the most cost-efficient brand or model for each equipment on the list they submitted.


E. Materials

Soft copy of the slide deck

Cost-benefit monitoring tool (MS Excel spreadsheet)


F. Preparation Activities

● Prepare the slide deck and the cost-benefit monitoring tool.

● Instruct the students to:

a. Listen: The guidelines in managing resources such as energy and water will be discussed.

b. Reflect: How can I help conserve resources such as energy and water?

c. Respond: List all equipment by workstation, or based on what is available in food laboratories, with energy and water requirements


G. Methodology

1. Lecture-discussion

2. Listing of equipment with specifications


H. Process

1. Lecture-Discussion: The faculty-in-charge will discuss the guidelines in managing resources in accordance with sustainable dining principles.

Introduce the cost-benefit monitoring tool.

2. Activity: “Making Sense of My Equipment Specs”

a. Each group will be preparing a list of all equipment, specifically those

with energy and water requirements, by workstation or based on what is available in their food laboratories. Work stations include receiving, preparation, production, service/dining, dishwashing, and waste disposal areas.

b. The report should contain pertinent information such as description, specifications, consumption rate, source, price, etc. of the most cost-efficient brand or model for each piece of equipment.

c. Each group will report characteristics of each of the listed equipment that makes or do not make them cost-efficient.


I. Expected OutputTopic 

1. List of equipment per workstation by group

2. Written output and oral presentation by group (submit slide deck used)

name:
Topic 2.4. Managing Waste A. Duration
30...
intro:
Topic 2.4. Managing Waste 

A. Duration 30-45 minutes 


B. Learning Objective At the end of this topic, the students should be able to develop a sustainable waste management system for the establishment. 


C. Competencies to be Developed The students should be able to acquire knowledge and skills on the development of proper waste management systems and composting in a food service establishment following principles of sustainable dining. 


D. Topic Inputs and Reflections for Students How can I minimize food and food-related waste at home and in a food establishment? 

● Lecture-discussion on waste management. 

● Demonstrating proper use and maintenance of compost bins. 

● Developing a waste management system following sustainable dining principles for a home or a food establishment. 


E. Materials 

1. Soft copy of the slide deck 

2. Laptop and projector 

3. Materials for composting (soil, soil box/container, hand trowel, gardening gloves, scissors, water in a spray bottle, dried leaves/sawdust/wood chips, and food wastes like trimmings, peels, eggshells, etc.) F. Preparation Activities 

● Prepare the slide deck 

● Prepare the bokashi composting video: Green Space. (2020, April 12). 

HOW TO #BokashiComposting 

[Video]. Facebook. https://www.facebook.com/watch/?v=242254873847139 

● Prepare the needed materials for composting (you can ask the students to bring their own before this session) 

● Instruct the students to: 

a. Listen: The strategies on managing waste will be discussed. 

b. Reflect: How can I minimize food and food-related waste at home? 

c. Respond: Create a waste management system based on sustainable dining principles. 


G. Methodology 

1. Lecture and discussion 

2. Demonstration of composting using bins (by faculty-in-charge) 

3. Activities 


H. Process 

1. Lecture-Discussion: The faculty-in-charge will discuss proper waste management in the context of food businesses, including the food waste hierarchy for cost-saving opportunities. Ways on preventing food waste, measuring food waste, reducing food spoilage, plate waste, and packaging wastes will be emphasized. 

2. Composting demonstration: The faculty-in-charge will demonstrate the proper way of using a compost bin while using common food waste in a food business or play the video demonstrating bokashi composting. 

3. Option 1: “Compost it!” a. Ask the students to form groups with 3 to 4 members. The students will make their own compost following the proper way described or demonstrated by the faculty. Another option is to do individual composting using miniature compost bins fit for the amount of space they have at home. For example, students can use empty ice cream tubs or plastic containers. 

Here is an example of how to make an indoor compost bin: Better Homes and Gardens. (2019, February 22). DIY indoor compost bin [Video]. Youtube.https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jBTNCJa4rw8 b. The faculty-in-charge will guide, check, and grade the students accordingly. These will be stored in a designated area in the school premises. c. The compost bins should be maintained by each group (i.e., regular watering and mixing) throughout a specified period (e.g., end of semester). 

d. The final product of the compost bins will be part of grading for this sessiontion : 

“Let’s track it” 

a. Ask the students to form groups with 3 to 4 members. The students will be assuming hypothetical amounts of food, packaging, and operating supply wastes (and other sources, if any) that their home or a food establishment can produce in a specified period (e.g., 1 month). The students can use the table template attached to summarize the hypothetical number of generated wastes. 

b. Using these hypothetical values, the student should prepare a waste management system for their home or a food establishment based on the guidelines discussed during the lecture. The waste management 95 system should be holistic and can include improvements in other aspects of the food business. 

c. Each group should report their output in class the next meeting. 

e. Expected Output 1. Compost bin individual or by group to be maintained throughout a specified period or a group written output on recommended waste management system 


2. Oral presentation by group (submit slide deck used)

name: Label
Topic 2.5. Adopting Sustainable Dining as a Way of...
intro:
Topic 2.5. Adopting Sustainable Dining as a Way of Life (Operations and Management)
A. Duration - 30-45 minutes

B. Learning Objective
At the end of the activity, the students should be able to:
1. develop a personal statement of commitment and establishment policy on sustainable dining; and,
2. apply sustainable dining practices regularly.


C. Competencies to be developed
The students should be able to acquire knowledge and skills on the development of a statement of commitment and establishment policy on sustainable dining and to apply sustainable dining practices in their daily living.


D. Topic Inputs/Reflections
Am I ready to practice sustainable dining? How can I be more sustainable?
● Lecture-discussion on recommended approaches, solutions, and promotions to sustainable dining.
● Creating a personal statement of commitment and an establishment policy on sustainable dining.
● Documenting day-to-day activities to showcase applied sustainable dining principles and to suggest improvements.

E. Materials
1. Soft copy of the slide deck
2. Laptop, projector, and sound system

F. Preparation Activities
● Prepare the slide deck
● Prepare the needed materials for oral reporting (Laptop, projector)
● Instruct the students to:
a. Listen: The recommended approaches, solutions, and promotions to sustainable dining will be discussed.
b. Reflect: Am I ready to practice sustainable dining? How can I be more sustainable?
c. Respond: Create a personal statement of commitment and an establishment policy on sustainable dining and document day-to-day activities to showcase applied sustainable dining principles and to
suggest for improvement.

G. Methodology
1. Lecture and discussion
2. Activities

H. Process
1. Lecture-Discussion: The faculty-in-charge will discuss ways on how to embrace sustainable dining as a way of life in operational and management aspects. This also includes the importance of policy statements in encouraging the staff and customers of the food establishment to adopt such measures, thereby promoting collective efforts towards the achievement of sustainable dining.

2. Activity 1: “Commitments”
The students will be asked to make the following:
a. individual statement of commitment on sustainable dining following the guidelines discussed in the lecture.
b. an establishment policy on sustainable dining per group. The establishment policy should also include specific guidelines on how they are going to implement it among their staff, suppliers, and customers.

3. Activity 2: “Sustainable Diary”
The faculty-in-charge will provide instructions:
a. After the lecture discussion on sustainable dining principles in session the students will already be asked to document their day-to-day activities wherein they were able to showcase and apply the said principles. 

a. They can take pictures and videos about it and write short content for each.
b. As the class advances on this module, it is expected that more and more principles will be applied and documented by each student.
c. The students can be creative using videos by adding a storyline or theme for it to be more engaging. The pictures and video clips will be consolidated in a 3–5-minute video presentation (with captions or
narrations) and will be viewed in class on a specified date towards the end of the module.

I. Expected Output
1. Statement of commitment (individual) on sustainable dining
2. Oral presentation per group on establishment policy (submit in MSWord format)
3. 3–5-minute video presentation of applications of sustainable dining principles in day-to-day activities (individual)

name: MODULE 4. DEVELOPING A COMMUNICATION PLANA. DURATI...
intro:
MODULE 4. DEVELOPING A COMMUNICATION PLAN


A. DURATION: 45 minutes


B. LEARNING OBJECTIVES

At the end of the session, the students should be able to:

1. Define a communication plan; and

2. Develop a communication plan for the promotion of sustainable dining.


C. COMPETENCIES TO BE DEVELOPED

The students should be able to acquire knowledge and skills in developing a communication plan for the promotion of sustainable dining to different types of audiences.


D. TOPIC INPUTS AND REFLECTIONS FOR STUDENTS

How can sustainable dining be promoted to different types of audiences?


E. MATERIALS

● Soft copy of PowerPoint Presentation


F. PREPARATORY ACTIVITIES FOR THE FACULTY

● Review this guide for a detailed instruction of activities

● Prepare and upload the PowerPoint/Slide presentation

● Review the sample communication plan

● Instruct the students to:

a. Listen: The importance and steps in creating a communication plan will be

discussed.

b. Reflect: How can sustainable dining be promoted to different types of audience?

c. Respond: Make a communication plan following the steps discussed or create

an infographic with environmental sustainability and sustainable dining

messages.


G. METHODOLOGY

● Lecture discussion

● Develop communication plan


H. PROCESS

a. Lecture-Discussion: The faculty in charge will discuss the importance of promoting sustainable dining, define communication, and explain how a communication plan is developed.

b. The faculty in-charge can choose between these two activities based on available resources:

Activity 1: “One Step at a Time”

The faculty-in-charge will provide the instructions:

a. After the lecture-discussion on developing a communication plan, instruct the students to find a partner.

b. The students will be asked to apply what they have learned by filing up the action plan matrix. Provide the guide questions:

- How can you promote environmental sustainability and sustainable dining?

- What is its purpose?

- How will you deliver your message to your target audience?

- How often will this be implemented?

- Who are you communicating with?

- Who will lead the implementation of your communication plan?

- How much will it cost?

Activity Objective Medium/Channel, Frequency Target, Audience, Person-in-charge, Budgetary Requirement

c. The pairs will present their work in class. 


Activity 2: “Making an Impact”

The faculty-in-charge will provide the instructions:

a. This activity can be done individually.

b. Create an infographic promoting environmental sustainability and sustainable dining. Examples can be found in:

c. The student may present his/her infographic in class or post on any online learning or social media platform.


WWF-Australia. (2018). Shop sustainably. 

https://www.wwf.org.au/get-involved/change-the-way-you-live/shopping#gs.upn6ft


Yogurt in Nutrition. (2020, June 15). Sustainable healthy diets: from science to your plate! https://www.yogurtinnutrition.com/infographic-sustainable-healthy-diets-from-science-to-your-plate/


Mah, V. (2019, April 17). Food waste – A major worldwide problem. Andatech distribution. https://www.andatechdistribution.com.au/blogs/news/food-waste-infographic


I. EXPECTED OUTPUTS

• Communication plan or infographic on environmental sustainability and sustainable dining.


J. SLIDE DECK

name:
COURSE DESCRIPTIONS
 
 
 
  
  COURSE
  CODE...
intro:
COURSE DESCRIPTIONS

COURSE CODE

BIOE_100

COURSE TITLE

BIOSTATISTICS AND EPIDEMIOLOGY

COURSE CREDIT

Lecture: 36 hours (2 hours/ week)

Laboratory: 54 hours (3 hours/week)

INDEPENDENT STUDY

8-11 hours (20%-30%)

This course introduces the basic epidemiological and biostatistical principles, concepts, and procedures for the surveillance and investigation of health-related states or events.
Collecting data and analyzing disease incidence and prevalence to provide analyses leading to effective interventions and preventions. It reviews sources of information, associations between diseases and precipitating factors, and statistical representations.


COURSE OUTLINE - PART 1 - BIOSTATISTICS

name:
Welcome to our Statistics Class!!!This course
inc...
intro:
Welcome to our Statistics Class!!!

This course includes the history of statistics, uses in the different fields;  collection;  organization & presentation, analysis, evaluation and interpretation of data;  measures of central tendency;  measures of variability;  normal curve and its applications;  formulation and testing of hypothesis;  linear correlation and regression.
Analysis and reasoning in mathematics are stressed and hence, emphasis is placed on critical thinking and problem solving.

name: CHEMBIO_2: ANALYTICAL METHODS FOR BIOLOGY (Lecture...
intro:
CHEMBIO_2: ANALYTICAL METHODS FOR BIOLOGY (Lecture)

COURSE DESCRIPTION

This course deals with the study of the theory and practice of qualitative and quantitative measurements with special attention given to chemical reactions, solution equilibria, and stoichiometry. It will cover important titrimetric methods: acid-base titrations and redox titrations where titrimetric techniques still play an important role in the modern analytical laboratory.  Basic instrumental methods of chemical analysis like spectrophotometry, atomic absorption spectroscopy and some electroanalytical methods which are commonly used in analytical laboratories will also be introduced. Theory is brought to practice in the laboratory by introducing the students into basic analytical techniques of sample preparation and separation.

name: Good Day Trinitians!!!I am very glad to have you i...
intro:
Good Day Trinitians!!!

I am very glad to have you in my course. 😃

I will be your mentor for the semester.

As a student, you surely have felt pressured in one way or another. But always remember, with focus, positive mind and attitude plus time management, everything will be fine. 



"God does not give us everything we want, but He does fulfill His promises, leading us along the best and straightest paths to Himself."  - Dietrich Bonhoeffer
God Bless and hope you succeed in your journey in life.


DR. SERENA CORBETA - GOMEZ
Prof. Lecturer, Graduate School

Faculty, Mathematics and Physical Sciences Department, College of Arts, Sciences and Education

Doctor of Education (TUA,2007)
MAT-Mathematics (TUP, 2000)
BS Mathematics (TCQC, 1995)

Email Add: scgomez@tua.edu.ph

name: Hi! I am your teacher in the Laboratory. The ...
intro:
Hi! I am your teacher in the Laboratory.
 

The Statistical Techniques you will learn from this course will provide you adequate background and foundation in handling data in both qualitative and quantitative research that soon you will take up.

For easy computation and analysis of data, please make sure to install Data Analysis Apps in Microsoft Excel and Download JAMOVI version 2.2.5 solid version in your laptop. Thank you.

 Let's together navigate towards a successful journey in life. 
God Bless and Keep safe always.

name: Welcome to Research and Applied Data Analytics Cla...
intro:
Welcome to Research and Applied Data Analytics Class!

This course will enable you to examine the role of data analytics  research, by helping make better decisions based on data. You  will explore various models that can be utilized to help summarize, visualize, and interpret data in a variety of discipline.



I am Dr. Serena Corbeta-Gomez.
Your professor in this course.
You may communicate with me through our Workspace and thru email: scgomez@tua.edu.ph

name: COURSE DESCRIPTIONSCOURSE CODEMPA/MBA 112COURSE TI...
intro:
COURSE DESCRIPTIONS

COURSE CODE

MPA/MBA 112

COURSE TITLE

RESEARCH AND APPLIED DATA ANAYTICS

COURSE CREDIT

Lecture: 54 hours (3 hours/ week)

The main purpose of the course is to introduce students to quantitative and qualitative methods for conducting meaningful inquiries and research. They will gain an overview of research intent and design, methodology and technique, format and presentation and data management and analysis informed by commonly used statistical methods. 
The course will develop each student's ability to use this knowledge to become more effective in the field of business and public administration.
These tasks include:
1. developing a hypothesis, a research problem and related questions
2. framing the problem with the correct research methodology
3. collecting data that accurately addresses the research problem
4. measuring the effectiveness of a project/program
5. using data to make better decisions
6. evaluating feasibility of research proposals
7. presenting data to support project/programs to decision makers and consumers


This course will provide an overview of the important concepts of research design, data collection, statistical and interpretative analysis and final report presentation. The focus of this course is not on mastery of data analytics but on the ability to use research in business and public administration.

name: Motivation is what gets you started. Habit is what...
intro:
Motivation is what gets you started. Habit is what keeps you going.
-Jim Ryun

name: Happiness can be achieved through training the min...
intro:
Happiness can be achieved through training the mind.
- Dalai Lama

name: Human beings can alter their lives by altering the...
intro:
Human beings can alter their lives by altering their attitudes of mind.
-William James

name: By disciplining and training the mind to focus on ...
intro:
By disciplining and training the mind to focus on one thing, we gain control of perception; we learn to grab it and put it some place we want it to be.
- Frederick Lenz

name: “Strong minds discuss ideas, average minds discuss...
intro: “Strong minds discuss ideas, average minds discuss events, weak minds discuss people.” – Socrates

name: “The mind is a powerful force. It can enslave us o...
intro: “The mind is a powerful force. It can enslave us or empower us. It can plunge us into the depths of misery or take us to the heights of ecstasy. Learn to use the power wisely.” – David Cuschieri

For any inquiries that you would have regarding today's sessions, a forum page is available below where I will be entertaining your questions

Thank you and God bless.

name: Introduction and Focus Questions:Swimming is a gre...
intro:
Introduction and Focus Questions:



Swimming is a great recreational activity. Since Philippines is surrounded by water, swimming becomes one of the great hobbies for some Filipinos. Swimming is also good workout for people who want to stay fit. Swimming can be fun and can be take it to a competitive level. The main strokes used in competitive swimming are breaststroke, freestyle, backstroke, and butterfly. The picture on the left is an example of freestyle. In doing freestyle, a swimmer requires a lot of energy because it needs to move against the current. However, for some people who just want to swim for fun, they may do floating like the picture on the right. Floating does not require much energy because it is only moving with the current. Likewise, in transport mechanisms of the cell, active transport requires energy while passive transport does not. Passive transport does not require the cell to expend more metabolic energy. The small molecules just move through the process of diffusion.

            In this module, you will learn the different types of transport mechanisms and differentiate the active transport from passive transport. At the end of the lesson, you will be able to answer the following questions:

1.    What are the different types of transport mechanisms in cells?

2.    How does exocytosis differ from endocytosis?

3.    How can I relate the concepts of transport mechanism to real life applications?

name: Intro and Focus Questions:      &nb...
intro:
Intro and Focus Questions:


                                                                            


Why Do Cells Divide? Cells divide for many reasons. For example, when you skin your knee, cells divide to replace old, dead, or damaged cells. Cells also divide so living things can grow. When organisms grow, it is not because cells are getting larger. Organisms grow because cells are dividing to produce more and more cells. In human bodies, nearly two trillion cells divide every day.

You and I began as a single cell, or what you would call an egg. By the time you are an adult, you will have trillions of cells. That number depends on the size of the person, but biologists put that number around 37 trillion cells.

In cell division, the cell that is dividing is called the "parent" cell. The parent cell divides into two "daughter" cells. The process then repeats in what is called the cell cycle. 

Cells regulate their division by communicating with each other using chemical signals from special proteins called cyclins. These signals act like switches to tell cells when to start dividing and later when to stop dividing. It is important for cells to divide so you can grow and so your cuts heal. It is also important for cells to stop dividing at the right time.  If a cell cannot stop dividing when it is supposed to stop, this can lead to a disease called cancer.  

Some cells, like skin cells, are constantly dividing. We need to continuously make new skin cells to replace the skin cells we lose. Did you know we lose 30,000 to 40,000 dead skin cells every minute? That means we lose around 50 million cells every day.  This is a lot of skin cells to replace, making cell division in skin cells is so important. Other cells, like nerve and brain cells, divide much less often.

Depending on the type of cell, there are two ways cells divide—mitosis and meiosis. Each of these methods of cell division has special characteristics. One of the key differences in mitosis is a single cell divides into two cells that are replicas of each other and have the same number of chromosomes. This type of cell division is good for basic growth, repair, and maintenance. In meiosis a cell divides into four cells that have half the number of chromosomes. Reducing the number of chromosomes by half is important for sexual reproduction and provides for genetic diversity.

name: INTRODUCTION TO EARTH
intro: INTRODUCTION TO EARTH

name: Our universe is ...
intro:
Our universe is approximately 13.8 billion years old and the expansion still continues. Have you ever thought how big the actual universe? Is there even a word to describe how vast our universe is?

Universe consists everything from space, time, energy and all matter in it. It has billions of galaxies which also consist billions of stars and planets. Like every other galaxies, Milkyway galaxy is just a small part of the universe, it is one of the million galaxies that exists where our solar system is located. 

Excluding Earth, our solar system consists of seven other planets where the sun is in its center. The third planet from the sun is Earth that harbours astronomical amounts of organisms. Why do you think that Earth is the only known habitable planet up to this day? What’s so special about this planet and how did the intricate land, aquatic and marine forms are built in the first place?

In this lesson, we will explore processes in Earth’s nature and dynamism. At the end, you are expected to answer the focus questions: What is the relationship of all the earth’s subsystems? Can one subsystem survive without the other?

name:
Your goal in
this section is to know the differen...
intro:
Your goal in this section is to know the different subsystems of the Earth.

For now, you already have an idea about the appearance of the Earth. From the picture below, what are the most prominent features that can be seen from space?

As seen in the picture, the most prominent feature is the swirling clouds that are suspended above the ocean. It emphasizes the importance of water but it doesn’t mean that the Earth is dominated by water alone. You’d also see land as patches of brown or green. These are all actually parts of the physical environment of the Earth.


Four Subsystems of the Earth

1. Geosphere –largest solid portion of the earth that includes the Earth’s interior, rocks, minerals, landforms and the processes that shape the Earth’s surface.

2. Atmosphere – blanket of the planet.

3. Hydrosphere – the existence of this provided the medium for different life processes to occur.

4. Biosphere – includes all forms of life.


CHARACTERISTICS OF EARTH NECESSARY TO SUPPORT LIFE

Earth has some characteristics that are unique compared to all planets in the solar system, it has water, an atmosphere, and a source of energy that are essential for life.

WATER

Water is one of the most essential ingredients for chemical reactions that is vital among living organisms. Chemical reactions needed for life would not happen if there is no water. It is considered the universal solvent that is capable of dissolving many substances which in turn can be easily absorbed by living organisms.

ATMOSPHERE

Earth’s atmosphere contains oxygen that is coming from photosynthetic organisms like plants and trees. Another is carbon dioxide which helps in regulating the Earth’s temperature. These examples of gas are essential for life to be sustained.

ENERGY SUPPLY

Sun is the main source of Earth’s energy. Its ideal distance from the Sun gives Earth the right amount of heat and light needed to support life. Nutrients produced by plants with the help of sunlight are used as fuel that living things use. There are also different sources of energy like deep water vents which is internal heating of Earth.

name: In the past, wealth, influence, and progress is de...
intro:
In the past, wealth, influence, and progress is determined by the amount of land, livestock, and workers. Now it is measured by the amount of data and information that a nation or organization controls. 
The advent of the internet and smart devices reshaped the landscape of how society sees itself, how it relates to others, how it learns and relearns, how it improves itself, and, most importantly,  how it governs its citizens. Technology has become ubiquitous in the daily lives of people and has produced a natural byproduct - DATA. 


Data, however, is growing exponentially.  In 2009, 2 zettabytes of global data were generated. This year, experts measured it at 33 zettabytes and predicted to grow to a staggering 175ZB by 2025, a compounded annual growth rate of 61 percent.  


How is data generated?  Data is mostly generated instantaneously. Take for example a mobile app user. Every time that you pause to look at a product, every time you hit that like button, every time that you type in a query....data is generated, stored, and put into some other use. Just like that, the next time you browse your computer, an advertisement pops up. A new video similar to the last one you liked is put in the queue. Your social media friend whose posts you reacted to become more frequent in your feeds. Data that is processed and analyzed becomes information. It further becomes meaningful information if it is used for its intended purpose or why it was collected in the first place. 

In this context, data and information are important resources in any organization. For educational institutions, it may determine school persistence and student retention, for the financial institutions it may spell the difference between a performing and a nonperforming loan.  The COVID 19 pandemic is a glaring example, data, and information on health care capacity, patient behavior, patient characteristics drive policy response and implementation. 

As an introductory course, it will orient you on how data is created, processed and how the organization will work with data and translate it to data driven decision making and action. You will explore the main types of analytics, the basic statistical, and management tools needed in the analytical process. The set of rules or algorithms used for each will be explained by employing illustrative examples. Some discussions would not include the mathematics behind the scenes but will focus on the conceptual and contextual aspects. Learning will be supported by carefully designed laboratory work and exercises and will conclude with a capstone data project. 
The data analytics course endeavors to introduce and prepare students to undertake analysis of data involving multivariate analysis, modelling, data mining, factor analysis, text analysis, and cluster analysis. Students will be exposed to data management of program related information.

It further becomes meaningful information if it is used for its intended purpose or why it was collected in the first place. 

In this context, data and information are important resources in any organization. For educational institutions, it may determine school persistence and student retention, for the financial institutions it may spell the difference between a performing and a nonperforming loan.  The COVID 19 pandemic is a glaring example, data, and information on health care capacity, patient behavior, patient characteristics drive policy response and implementation. 

As an introductory course, it will orient you on how data is created, processed and how the organization will work with data and translate it to data driven decision making and action. You will explore the main types of analytics, the basic statistical, and management tools needed in the analytical process. The set of rules or algorithms used for each will be explained by employing illustrative examples. Some discussions would not include the mathematics behind the scenes but will focus on the conceptual and contextual aspects. Learning will be supported by carefully designed laboratory work and exercises and will conclude with a capstone data project. 

The data analytics course endeavors to introduce and prepare students to undertake analysis of data involving multivariate analysis, modelling, data mining, factor analysis, text analysis, and cluster analysis. Students will be exposed to data management of program related information.

name: Why is DATA ANALYTICS important?Data analytics inv...
intro:
Why is DATA ANALYTICS important?

Data analytics involves qualitative and quantitative procedures and methods to increase efficiency and profit. It is a general term that refers to various data analysis techniques.

In the health care industry,  BIG DATA is converted into insights that improve patient outcomes and operational efficiencies. 

  • Making healthcare data easier to share among colleagues and external partners, and easier to visualize for public consumption
  • Delivering accurate data-driven forecasts in real time to allow healthcare providers to respond more quickly to changing healthcare markets and environments
  • Boosting data collaboration and innovation among healthcare organizations to convert analytics-ready data into business-ready information by automating low-impact data management tasks

 MANAGEMENT

name: In the past, wealth, influence, and progress is de...
intro:
In the past, wealth, influence, and progress is determined by the amount of land, livestock, and workers. Now it is measured by the amount of data and information that a nation or organization controls. 
The advent of the internet and smart devices reshaped the landscape of how society sees itself, how it relates to others, how it learns and relearns, how it improves itself, and, most importantly,  how it governs its citizens. Technology has become ubiquitous in the daily lives of people and has produced a natural byproduct - DATA. 


Data, however, is growing exponentially.  In 2009, 2 zettabytes of global data were generated. This year, experts measured it at 33 zettabytes and predicted to grow to a staggering 175ZB by 2025, a compounded annual growth rate of 61 percent.  


How is data generated?  Data is mostly generated instantaneously. Take for example a mobile app user. Every time that you pause to look at a product, every time you hit that like button, every time that you type in a query....data is generated, stored, and put into some other use. Just like that, the next time you browse your computer, an advertisement pops up. A new video similar to the last one you liked is put in the queue. Your social media friend whose posts you reacted to become more frequent in your feeds. Data that is processed and analyzed becomes information. It further becomes meaningful information if it is used for its intended purpose or why it was collected in the first place. 

In this context, data and information are important resources in any organization. For educational institutions, it may determine school persistence and student retention, for the financial institutions it may spell the difference between a performing and a nonperforming loan.  The COVID 19 pandemic is a glaring example, data, and information on health care capacity, patient behavior, patient characteristics drive policy response and implementation. 

As an introductory course, it will orient you on how data is created, processed and how the organization will work with data and translate it to data driven decision making and action. You will explore the main types of analytics, the basic statistical, and management tools needed in the analytical process. The set of rules or algorithms used for each will be explained by employing illustrative examples. Some discussions would not include the mathematics behind the scenes but will focus on the conceptual and contextual aspects. Learning will be supported by carefully designed laboratory work and exercises and will conclude with a capstone data project. 
The data analytics course endeavors to introduce and prepare students to undertake analysis of data involving multivariate analysis, modelling, data mining, factor analysis, text analysis, and cluster analysis. Students will be exposed to data management of program related information.

Data analytics involves qualitative and quantitative procedures and methods to increase efficiency and profit. It is a general term that refers to various data analysis techniques.

In Educational management system, there are different components like technology, content, services, e-learner etc.

Data analytics in the educational management system has a potential to discover, analyze and predict meaningful knowledge from vast data which will help in managing system for flexible planning, execution and prediction for future.

name: COURSE CODE: BR/CA 158 - DATA ANALYTICSCourse Cred...
intro:
COURSE CODE: BR/CA 158 - DATA ANALYTICS

Course Credits: Lecture -  2 units (2 hours per week)

                                 Laboratory - 1 unit (3 hours per week)

This course will enable students to examine the role of data analytics in helping how to make better decisions based on data. The students will explore various models that can be utilized to help summarize, visualize, and interpret data in the field of Media Communication. 


COURSE OUTLINE

name: GENERAL COURSE REQUIREMENTSClass participation is ...
intro:
GENERAL COURSE REQUIREMENTS

Class participation is both important and required. In cases the students failed to comply with the assigned tasks for the week due to an emergency, they must contact the teacher thru email at scgomez@tua.edu.ph or thru the CHAT spaces group posted above.

It is expected that assignments or tasks will be submitted on time (by Midnight the day they are due). However, it is recognized that students occasionally have serious problems that prevent work completion. If such dilemma arises, students should contact the teacher in a timely fashion.

The completion of all readings of learning materials assigned for the course is assumed. Since the class will be structured around discussion, completion of learning modules and all class assignments/tasks is crucial. 


GRADING SYSTEM

The following provides the criterion for the overall performance in class.

           CLASS STANDING - 60%

             - Case Analyses, Case Presentation, Oral and Written Presentation - 30%

             - Class Participation, interactive discussion/recitation - 10%

             - Group work/Assignment/Research Capsule - 20%

              

             MAJOR EXAM - 40%

              - Midterm and Final Exam

name: GENERAL COURSE REQUIREMENTSClass participation is ...
intro:
GENERAL COURSE REQUIREMENTS

Class participation is both important and required. In cases the students failed to comply with the assigned tasks for the week due to an emergency, they must contact the teacher thru email at scgomez@tua.edu.ph or thru the CHAT spaces group posted above.

It is expected that assignments or tasks will be submitted on time (by Midnight the day they are due). However, it is recognized that students occasionally have serious problems that prevent work completion. If such dilemma arises, students should contact the teacher in a timely fashion.

The completion of all readings of learning materials assigned for the course is assumed. Since the class will be structured around discussion, completion of learning modules and all class assignments/tasks is crucial. 


GRADING SYSTEM

The following provides the criterion for the overall performance in class.

           CLASS STANDING - 60%

             - Case Analyses, Case Presentation, Oral and Written Presentation - 30%

             - Class Participation, interactive discussion/recitation - 10%

             - Group work/Assignment/Research Capsule - 20%

              

             MAJOR EXAM - 40%

              - Midterm and Final Exam

name: Course Code/Title: TIC114 - Data AnalyticsCourse C...
intro:
Course Code/Title: TIC114 - Data Analytics

Course Credits: 3 units (2 units Lec, 1 unit Lab)

Course Description: 


This course will enable the student to examine the role data analytics plays in helping to make better decisions based on data. The student will explore various models that can be utilized to help summarize, visualize, and interpret data in a variety of disciplines.
 

Topic Outline


Week

Topics

1

Introduction to Data Analytics

-What is Data Analytics

-Data vs Information

-Types of Data Analytics

-Big Data vs Small Data

2

Data Management and Wrangling

-Data Management

-Data Processing Errors

-Data Wrangling

-Examples of Data Wrangling

-Data Wrangling Steps

 

3-4

Descriptive Analytics

-Types of data

-Data Visualization

- Descriptive Univariate Analysis

-Univariate Indicators

-Understanding Data Summary and Trends  Using Box Plot, QQ Plot, and Scatter Plot

5-6

Diagnostic Analytics

-. Bivariate Analysis

- Understanding Data Distribution Using  Histogram, Density Plot, and Correlograms

- Multidimensional Scaling

- Statistical Inference, Estimation & Hypothesis  Testing

-Model Selection and Test of Significance

- Quantitative Attributes and Test of Relationship

- Qualitative Attributes and Test of Association

- Qualitative & Quantitative Attributes and Test of Difference

7-8

Predictive Analytics

-Regression Analysis Model

- Visualization Using Data Pivoting

-Forecasting Model

-Logistic Regression Model

9

MIDTERM EXAMINATION

10-11

Machine Learning

-Cluster Analysis

-Classification

12

Text Analytics

-Understanding Unstructured Data

- Word Frequencies and Word Clouds

- Text Sentiment Analysis

-Thematic Analysis and Pattern Analysis

- Infographics

13

Map Analysis

-Understanding Spatial Data and Patterns

- Heat maps

- Geographic Trends

14

Audio Analysis

-Speech Analytics and Deep Learning

- Audio Data Processing

- Audio Sentiment Analysis

15-17

DATA ANALYTICS PROJECT

18

Final Examination

name: Course Code/Title: DA_100 - Data AnalyticsCourse C...
intro:
Course Code/Title: DA_100 - Data Analytics

Course Credits: 3 units (2 units Lec, 1 unit Lab)

Course Description: 


This course will enable the student to examine the role data analytics plays in helping to make better decisions based on data. The student will explore various models that can be utilized to help summarize, visualize, and interpret data in a variety of disciplines.
 

Topic Outline


Week

Topics

1

Introduction to Data Analytics

-What is Data Analytics

-Data vs Information

-Types of Data Analytics

-Big Data vs Small Data

2

Data Management and Wrangling

-Data Management

-Data Processing Errors

-Data Wrangling

-Examples of Data Wrangling

-Data Wrangling Steps

 

3-4

Descriptive Analytics

-Types of data

-Data Visualization

- Descriptive Univariate Analysis

-Univariate Indicators

-Understanding Data Summary and Trends  Using Box Plot, QQ Plot, and Scatter Plot

5-6

Diagnostic Analytics

-. Bivariate Analysis

- Understanding Data Distribution Using  Histogram, Density Plot, and Correlograms

- Multidimensional Scaling

- Statistical Inference, Estimation & Hypothesis  Testing

-Model Selection and Test of Significance

- Quantitative Attributes and Test of Relationship

- Qualitative Attributes and Test of Association

- Qualitative & Quantitative Attributes and Test of Difference

7-8

Predictive Analytics

-Regression Analysis Model

- Visualization Using Data Pivoting

-Forecasting Model

-Logistic Regression Model

9

MIDTERM EXAMINATION

10-11

Machine Learning

-Cluster Analysis

-Classification

12

Text Analytics

-Understanding Unstructured Data

- Word Frequencies and Word Clouds

- Text Sentiment Analysis

-Thematic Analysis and Pattern Analysis

- Infographics

13

Map Analysis

-Understanding Spatial Data and Patterns

- Heat maps

- Geographic Trends

14

Audio Analysis

-Speech Analytics and Deep Learning

- Audio Data Processing

- Audio Sentiment Analysis

15-17

DATA ANALYTICS PROJECT

18

Final Examination

name: The midterm examination is scheduled on: LECT...
intro:
The midterm examination is scheduled on: 

LECTURE : 21 October (Friday) - 5:00 to 6:00 PM
LABORATORY : 22 October (Saturday) - 4:30 to 5:30 PM

We will be using Google Meet for proctoring purposes. Video must be open during examination.

     *Coverage for lecture: Lecture presentations and activities

      Examination type: matching type, multiple choice, and short essays


    *Coverage for laboratory: Determination of index/indicator microorganisms

      Examination type: multiple choice, true or false statements

name: The final examination is scheduled on: LABORA...
intro:
The final examination is scheduled on: 

LABORATORY: Food Product Evaluation and Presentation - 16 DECEMBER 2022 (FRIDAY) - 3:00 - 5:00 PM
LECTURE: Written Examination - 17 DECEMBER 2022 (SATURDAY) - 4:30 - 5:30 PM


     We will be using the Google Meet link for proctoring purposes.

     *Coverage for lecture: ALL TOPICS

      Examination type: multiple choice 50 items

name: The midterm examination is scheduled on: LABO...

LABORATORY : 22 October (Friday) - 9:00 to 10:00 AM 
LECTURE : 23 October (Saturday) - 9:00 to 10:30 AM

    We will be using the ClassIn room for proctoring purposes.

    *Coverage for laboratory: Laboratory presentations, worksheets, food pathogen reports

     Examination type: Fill-in-the-blanks (20 points), Procedure Enumeration (30 points)

     Total: 50 points

name: INTRODUCTION TO FRONT OFFICER SERVICESIntroduction...
intro:
INTRODUCTION TO FRONT OFFICER SERVICES

Introduction to Front Office (FO) Services covers lessons that will help you know and understand the duties and responsibilities of the front office department. In addition to that, this module will be tackling the specifications and job descriptions of front office staff, as well as the design and equipment used in the front office.

name:
UNIT 1: THE FRONT OFFICE DEPARTMENT
At the end of...
intro:
UNIT 1: THE FRONT OFFICE DEPARTMENT

At the end of this unit, you should be able to:

  1. Identify the tasks and roles performed by the staff of the FO department;
  2. Describe FO work shifts and scheduling practices;
  3. Enumerate traits and qualities that an FO staff should possess;
  4. Identify supporting equipment of the FO department; and
  5. Perform clerical procedures.

name: &...

COURSE OUTLINE
 
 
 
  
  PART 1 - RESEARCH
...
intro:
COURSE OUTLINE

PART 1 - RESEARCH

PART 2 - APPLIED DATA ANALYTICS

MODULE 1 - INTRODUCTION TO RESEARCH

1.1 Nature of Research

1.2 Why Research is Important?

MODULE 4 – DESCRIPTIVE ANALYTICS

4.1 Univariate Analysis - Measure of Central Tendency, Variability, Location and Shapes

4.2 Data Visualization Techniques

MODULE 2 – THE BASICS OF RESEARCH

2.1 The Research Problem

2.2 Variables and Hypotheses

2.3 Ethics in Research

2.4 Reviewing Literature

2.5 Sampling

2.6 Instrumentation

2.7 Validity and Reliability

MODULE 5 – DIAGNOSTIC ANALYTICS

5.1 Hypothesis Testing

5.2 Test of Difference

5.3 Test of Association

5.4 Test of Relationship

5.3 Text Analysis

MODULE 3 – TYPES OF RESEARCH AND METHODS

3.1 Quantitative Research

3.2 Qualitative Research

3.3 Mixed Methods Research

3.4 Elements of a Research Paper

3.5 Common Errors in the Research Process

MIDTERM EXAMINATION – Research Capsule

MODULE 6 – PREDICTIVE ANALYTICS

6.1 Correlation Analysis

6.2 Trend Line Analysis

6.3 Multiple Regression Analysis

6.4 Logistic Regression

FINAL EXAMINATION – Written Examination

name: GENERAL COURSE REQUIREMENTSClass participation is ...
intro:
GENERAL COURSE REQUIREMENTS

Class participation is both important and required. In cases the students failed to comply with the assigned tasks for the week due to an emergency, they must contact the teacher thru email at scgomez@tua.edu.ph or thru the CHAT spaces group posted above.

It is expected that assignments or tasks will be submitted on time (by Midnight the day they are due). However, it is recognized that students occasionally have serious problems that prevent work completion. If such dilemma arises, students should contact the teacher in a timely fashion.

The completion of all readings of learning materials assigned for the course is assumed. Since the class will be structured around discussion, completion of learning modules and all class assignments/tasks is crucial. 


GRADING SYSTEM

The following provides the criterion for the overall performance in class.

           CLASS STANDING - 60%

             - Case Analyses, Case Presentation, Oral and Written Presentation - 30%

             - Class Participation, interactive discussion/recitation - 10%

             - Group work/Assignment/Research Capsule - 20%

              

             MAJOR EXAM - 40%

              - Midterm and Final Exam

intro:
COURSE DESCRIPTIONS

COURSE CODE

MEM210/EDUC_202

COURSE TITLE

DATA ANALYTICS APPLIED TO EDUCATION

COURSE CREDIT

Lecture: 54 hours (3 hours/ week)


This course will enable the student to examine the role data analytics plays in helping to make better decisions based on data. The student will explore various models that can be utilized to help summarize, visualize, and interpret data in a variety of disciplines.


COURSE OUTLINE

name: Prayer Before ExamGod of Wisdom, I thank you for t...
intro:
Prayer Before Exam
God of Wisdom, I thank you for the privilege to study here in Trinity University of Asia where I learn the lessons of life and prepare for the challenges of the future. Be gracious to me this day, O Lord, as I ask you to grant me a mind that does not waver, a heart that is strong, and a will that endures.  Let your Holy Spirit be with me this hour, reminding me of the lessons I  have taken, and giving me the understanding to know what is true and good.  May I honor your name as I keep my integrity, to be honest in all my ways , and do what pleases you, O Lord, who sees all things in secret.  Now, dear Lord, may your peace be with me knowing it is your will that I come to follow, to submit to your perfect will and plan, and to humble myself as I take this test now.  I ask this through Christ our Lord and Savior, Amen.

February 07, 2022Maligayang pagdating sa bahaging ...
intro:
February 07, 2022

Maligayang pagdating sa bahaging ito ng ating modyul. Ating tuklasin kung gaano kalalim ang iyong nalalaman tungkol sa aralin na ito. I-click ang letra ng iyong kasagutan na siyang inaakala mong pinakatamang sagot sa tanong. Sagutan lahat ng aytem. Pagkatapos gawin ang maikling pagsusulit na ito, ay makikita kung ilan ang iyong nakuha. Tignang mabuti ang mga aytem na hindi mo nasagot ng tama at matatagpuan mo ang kasagutan habang pinag- aaralan ang modyul na ito.

name: Label
Mga Isyung Moral Tungkol sa Sekswalidad1. Pagtatal...
intro:
Mga Isyung Moral Tungkol sa Sekswalidad


1. Pagtatalik bago ang kasal ( Pre-marital sex)

Ito ay gawaing pagtatalik ng isang babae at lalaki na wala pa sa wastong edad o nasa edad na subalit hindi pa kasal.

May iba’t ibang pananaw na siyang dahilan kung bakit ang isang tao lalo na ang kabataan ay pumapasok sa maagang pakikipagtalik. Ito ay ang sumusunod:

A. Ito raw ay normal at likas na gampanin ng katawan ng tao upang maging malusog Siya at matugunan ang pangangailangan ng katawan. Kapag hindi raw ito isinagawa hindi mararating ng tao ang kaganapan ng kaniyang buhay. 

B. Maraming kabataan ang nag-iisip na maituturing na tama ang pakikipagtalik lal na kapag ang mga gumagawa nito ay may pagsang-ayon. Karapatan ng tao na makipagtalik at malaya silang gawin ito.

C. Naniniwala ang mga gumagawa ng pre-marital sex na may karapatan silang makaranas ng kasiyahan. 

D. Ang pakikipagtalik ay isang ekspresyon o pagpapahayag ng pagmamahal. 

2. Pornograpiya 

Ang pornograpiya ay nanggaling sa dalawang salitang Griyego, "pome," na may kahulugang prostitute o taong nagbebenta ng panandaliang aliw, at "graphos" na nangangahulugang pagsulat o paglalarawan Samakatuwid, ang pornograpiya ay mga mahahalay na paglalarawan (babasahin, larawan, o palabas) na may layuning pukawin ang seksuwal na pagnanasa ng nanonood o nagbabasa. 

Balikan natin ang mga epekto ng pornograpiya sa isang tao. Ito ay ang sumusunod:

1. Ang maagang pagkahumaling sa pornograpiya ay nagkakaroon ng kaugnayan sa pakikibahagi ng tao o paggawa ng mga abnormal na gawaing seksuwal, lalong- lalo na ang panghahalay. 

2. May mga kalalakihan at kababaihan ding dahil sa pagkasugapa sa pornograpiya ay nahihirapang magkaroon ng malusog na pakikipag-ugnayan sa kanilang ay asawa. Nakararanas sila ng seksuwal na kasiyahan sa panonood at pagbabasa ng pornograpiya, at pang-aabuso sa sarili at hindi sa normal na pakikipagtalik. 

3. Ito rin ay ginagamit ng mga pedophiles sa intemet upang makuha ang kanilang mga bibiktimahin. Ang mga mahahalay na eksenang ipinakikita ng pornograpiya ay pumupukaw ng mga damdaming seksuwal ng kabataang wala pang kahandaan para rito. Nagdudulot ito nang labis na pagkalito sa kanilang murang edad.

3. Mga Pang – aabusong Sekswal 

Walang pangkalahatang pagpapakahulugan ang maaaring ibigay sa pang- aabusong seksuwal. Sa gitna ng mga pang-aabusong ito, ang nangingibabaw na posisyon ay ang pang-aabuso ay isinasagawa ng isang nakatatanda na siyang pumupuwersa sa iIsang nakababata upang gawin ang isang gawaing seksuwal. Ang pang-aabusong seksuwal ay maaaring paglalaro sa maseselang bahagi ng sariling katawano katawan ng iba, paggamit ng ibang bahagi ng katawan para sa seksuwal na gawain at sexual harassment. Maaari rin itong hindi pisikal tulad ng paglalantad ng sarili na gumagawa ng sekswal na gawain at pagkakaroon ng kaligayahang sekswal sa pamamagitan ng pagtingin sa mga hubad na katawan, sekswal na pag – aari o kaya’y panonood ng pagtatalik na isinasagawa ng iba.

4. Prostitusyon 

Ang prostitusyon na sinasabing siyang pinakamatandang propesyon o gawain ay ang pagbibigay ng panandaliang – aliw kapalit ng pera. Dito, binabayaran ang pakikipagtalik upang ang taong umupa ay makadama ng kasiyahang sekswal.

name:
Magandang araw! Gusto mo ba na patuloy
na pag-usa...
intro:
Magandang araw! Gusto mo ba na patuloy na pag-usapan ang tungkol sa paggalang ng seksuwalidad? Batid kong alam mo na ang iba’t-ibang isyu tungkol sa kawalan ng paggalang sa seksuwalidad dahil natalakay na natin ito sa ating mga nakaraang aralin. Ngayong araw, kailangan mong makagawa ng malinaw na posisyon sa isang isyu sa kawalan ng paggalang sa seksuwalidad.

Handa ka na ba?


Ngayon, tatalakayin natin ang ilan sa mga pahayag tungkol sa paggalang sa seksuwalidad. Bawat isa sa atin ay hinahamon na buuin at linangin ang seksuwalidad sapagkat ito ang batayan ng pagiging moral. Malaking hamon sa mga guro, lalong-lalo na sa mga magulang ang pag gabay sa mga anak nila dahil sa mga makabagong teknolohiya na nagdudulot ng malaking epekto sa pag-uugali at kilos ng mga kabataan ngayon. Balikan natin ang mga isyung seksuwal na palagi nating naririnig at nababalitaang madalas na kinakasangkutan ng mga kabataan.

__________________________________________________________________________________________________________________

Pag-usapan natin ito isa-sa. 


Una, Pagtatalik bago ang kasal (Pre-marital sex) 

Ang Pagtatalik bago ang kasal o Pre-marital sex ay gawaing pagtatalik ng isang babae at lalaki na wala pa sa wastong edad o nasa edad na subalit hindi pa kasal. Lumilitaw sa isang pag-aaral na dumadami ang mga kabataan na nakikipagtalik sa ka-partner na hindi pa nila asawa. Ayon sa pag-aaral na 2013 Young Adult Fertility and Sexuality Study o YAFS 4 na ginawa ng UP Population Institute at Demographic Research and Development, lumitaw na isa sa bawat tatlong kabataang Pinoy edad 15 hanggang 24 ang sumasabak na sa pre-marital sex. Katumbas umano ito ng 6.2 milyon kabataang Pinoy na kumakatawan sa 32 porsiyento na mas mataas sa naitalang 23.2 porsiyento noong 2012.(1) Marami sa mga kabataang ito ay walang proteksyon na nagdudulot ng maagang pagbubuntis o ‘di kaya’y pagkakaroon ng Sexually Transmitted Disease o STD. May mga kabataang gumagawa rin ng casal sex o pagtatalik ng walang emotional attachment. Pangkasaysayang itunuturing ito na bawal sa maraming mga kultura at itinuturing na isang kasalanan sa maraming mga relihiyon. Hanggang wala siya sa wastong gulang at hindi pa tumatanggap ng sakramento ng kasal, hindi siya kailanman magkakaroon ng karapatang makipagtalik. Mahalaga ang papel ng mga magulang, guro, at maging sa buong komunidad sa pagpapaalala at pagtuturo ng tamang landas sa mga kabataan ngayon. 

Pangalawa, Pornograpiya. 

Ang pornograpiya ay mga malalaswang litrato, panoorin o babasahin. Samakatuwid, ang pornograpiya ay mga mahahalay na paglalarawan na may layuning pukawin ang seksuwal na pagnanasa ng nanonood o nagbabasa. Sa panahon ngayon, hindi lamang ang paninigarilyo, pag-iinom ng alak, at paggamit ng bawal na gamot ang kinahuhumalingan ng mga kabataan kung hindi pati na rin ang panonood ng ipinagbabawal na palabas o porno. Isa sa mga dahilan nito ay ang tinatawag nating “curiosity”. Dahil din sa modernong teknolohiya mas lalong madali na lamang sa mga kabataan ang makakuha o makapanood nito. Ito ang isa sa mga dahilan kung bakit marami ang pumapasok sa pre-marital sex na nagreresulta ng early pregnancy sa mga kababaihan. Sinisira ng pornograpiya ang kakayahan ng isang tao na masiyahan sa normal na paraan o damdaming dulot ng paglalambingan at espiritwal na pakikipag-ugnayan sa katapat na kasarian. Nawawala rin ang kakayahang mag desisyon, nababago maging ang kagandahang-asal at nagiging hindi normal ang kilos at pag-uugali ng tao dahil dito. Kapag ang tao ay nagiging kasangkapan sa seksuwal na pangangailangan at pagkahumaling, lahat ng mabuting layunin sa pakikipagkapuwa ay maaaring hindi na matupad. Gabay ng mga magulang ang kailangan upang ito ay maiwasan. Kailangan din ng tamang pagtuturo at impormasyon tungkol sa masamang epekto nito mula sa mga paaralan at maging sa komunidad.

Pangatlo, Pang-aabusong Seksuwal. 

Ang pang-aabusong seksuwal o kilala rin sa tawag na pangmomolestiya, ay ang pagpilit ng mga hindi kanais-nais na seksuwal na pag-uugali ng isang tao sa iba. Ang pang-aabusong seksuwal ay maaaring paglalaro sa maseselang bahagi ng sariling katawan o katawan ng iba, paggamit ng ibang bahagi ng katawan para sa seksuwal na gawain at panonood ng pagtatalik na isinasagawa ng iba. Ang kadahilanan ng mga taong nagsasagawa ng mga pang-aabusong seksuwal ay taliwas sa tunay na esensya ng seksuwalidad. Palaging tatandaan na ang paggamit ng kasarian ay para lamang sa pagtatalik ng mag-asawa na naglalayong ipadama ang pagmamahal at bukas sa tunguhing magkaroon ng anak upang bumuo ng pamilya. Ito ang esensiya ng seksuwalidad. 

Pang-apat, Prostitusyon. 

Ang prostitusyon ay ang pakikipagtalik na may bayad at layunin na ang taong umupa ay makadama ng kasiyahang seksuwal. Ito ang tinaguriang pinakamatandang propesyon sa buong mundo sapagkat hindi pa lang ipinapanganak ang mga magulang natin, ay marami na ang gumagawa nito. 6 Karamihan sa nasasangkot sa prostitusyon ay ang mga taong madaling makontrol dulot ng kahirapan at kawalan ng kaalaman o muwang. Nawala na ang kanilang paggalang sa sarili at tamang pagkilala kung kaya’t minabuti na nilang ipagpatuloy ang kanilang masamang karanasan. Dahil nasanay na, hindi na nila magawang tumanggi kung kaya’t naging tuloytuloy na ang kanilang pagpagamit sa masamang gawaing ito. Sa prostitusyon, naaabuso ng tao ang kaloob ng Diyos na seksuwalidad. Isa sa mga halaga ng seksuwalidad ay ang pagkakaranas ng kasiyahang seksuwal mula sa pakikipagtalik sa taong pinakasalan. Nakakaranas ng kasiyahan ang taong nasasangkot sa prostitusyon ngunit hindi ito angkop sa tunay na layunin ng pakikipagtalik. Mahalagang maunawaan na ang pakikipagtalik ay hindi lamang para makadama ng kaligayahang sensuwal. Hindi ito isang paraan para makadama ng kaligayan, kundi ito ay isang paraan na naglalayong pagisahin ang isang babae at lalaki sa diwa ng pagmamahal. Ito ay regalo ng Diyos upang magbuklod ang mag-asawa at magpakarami ayon sa kaniyang kagustuhan.
