name: LESSON 1 TOPICS:1. The Health Care Environment2. H...
intro:
LESSON 1 TOPICS:

1. The Health Care Environment

2. Health care settings

TOPIC LEARNING OUTCOMES: 

After the end of the lesson, the student should be able to: 

1. Identify various settings involved in the delivery of health care.

2. Describe the functions of the health care environment that participate in patient’s total health care.

INTRODUCTION

The healthcare environment is important in the field of medical services. It is required to be taken into major consideration when it comes to society’s health. To maintain a healthy environment, health care systems are providing extra services in order to make patients feel healthier and fresh.

A Healthy Work Environment is one that is safe, empowering, and satisfying. It is not merely the absence of real and perceived threats to health, but a place of “physical, mental, and social well-being,” supporting optimal health and safety. A culture of safety is paramount, in which all leaders, managers, health care workers, and ancillary staff have a responsibility as part of the patient-centered team to perform with a sense of professionalism, accountability, transparency, involvement, efficiency, and effectiveness.

A Radiologic Technologist (Radiographer) uses critical thinking and independent judgment to obtain a diagnostic imaging study while maintaining quality patient care and minimizing radiation exposure. Technologists are employed in various healthcare and hospital settings such as acute care settings, ambulatory care settings, physicians’ offices, education, and management or sales positions. With additional education and training, radiographers may be employed in Radiation Therapy, Computed Tomography, Mammography, Magnetic Resonance Imaging, Diagnostic Medical Sonography, Nuclear Medicine, Special Vascular Imaging, and Cardiac Catheterization. 

        

CONCEPTS

HEALTH CARE SETTINGS

HOSPITAL

        A building in which the sick, injured, or infirm are received and treated. It is a public or private institution founded for reception and cure, or for the refuge of persons diseased in body or mind, or disabled, infirm or dependent, and which they are treated either at their expense or more often by the charity in whole or in part, being an institution which is not carried for private gain.


TWO GROUPS OF HOSPITALS:

1. GENERAL HOSPITALS

      They care for patients with various disease conditions for both sexes to all ages, medical, surgical, pediatrics, obstetrics, etc.

2. SPECIAL HOSPITALS

       These hospitals limit their service to a particular condition, orthopedics, maternity, pediatrics, geriatrics, etc.

CLINIC

        It is an establishment or hospital department where outpatients are given medical treatment or advice, especially of a specialist in nature. It is smaller than a hospital where patients are less sick and do not stay overnight.

MENTAL HEALTH FACILITIES

        Any licensed private hospital or hospital affiliate, institution, or facility operated by the state which provides treatment of persons with mental illness.

LONG-TERM FACILITIES

        A facility that provides rehabilitative, restorative, and/or ongoing skilled medical care to patients or residents in need of assistance with activities of daily living.

RESIDENTIAL FACILITIES(RESIDENTIAL TREATMENT CENTER/REHAB)

        It is a live-in health care facility providing therapy for substance abuse, mental illness, or other therapy problems. It is considered the last-ditch approach to treating abnormal psychology or psychopathology.

HOSPICE

        It is a home providing care for the sick or terminally ill. It focuses on the comfort of the patient and provides a better quality of life with the goal to enable you to have an alert, pain-free life and live each day as fully as possible.

OUT-PATIENT/AMBULATORY CARE

        A patient who receives medical treatment without being admitted to a hospital. Medical care is provided with diagnosis, observation, consultation, treatment, intervention, and rehabilitation services.

PREVENTIVE CARE

        It is the care to prevent illnesses or diseases. Examples are screenings and immunization to help patients to stay healthy.

HOME HEALTH CARE

        These are distinct types of care that are provided in a home setting. It is provided by a registered nurse, occupational therapists, physical therapists, or other skilled medical professionals and is described as part of a care plan following hospitalization.

TELEMEDICINE

        It is a remote diagnosis and treatment of patients by means of telecommunications technology. It is used to overcome distance barriers and to improve access to medical services that would often not be consistently available in distant rural communities.

SYNTHESIS

Imaging professionals must understand the health care environment and settings so that they may address the challenges that reforms in health care distribution presented to imaging services. Health care is an all-encompassing term that includes any type of system to coordinate the care and treatment of patients. Health care is designed to provide better access, improved outcomes, more efficient use of resources, and control costs for the patient. More simply, health care is any type of delivery and reimbursement system that monitors or controls the type, quality, use, and costs of health care. The aim of health care is to reduce unnecessary or inappropriate care and reduce costs. Therefore, health care is a practice, a commodity, an approach, or a collective responsibility to ensure the wellness of a population.

References:

  • Patient Care in Radiography with Introduction to Medical Imaging, R. Ehrlich, 7th Edition, 2016
  • Radiologic Science for Technologists, S. Bushong, 11th Edition, 2017
  • Introduction to Radiologic Technology, L. Gurle, 7th Edition, 2016
  • Introduction to Radiologic Science and Patient Care, A. Adler, 5th Edition, 2017

name: LESSON 2 TOPICS:1. Hospital Organization2. Philoso...
intro:
LESSON 2 TOPICS:

1. Hospital Organization

2. Philosophy, Vision, and Mission

3. Administrative Services

4. Medical Services

TOPIC LEARNING OUTCOMES: 

After the end of the lesson, the student should be able to: 

1. Discuss the role and value of a vision and mission statement to the operation of an institution.

2. Identify the role and functions of various administrative and medical services in the conduct of the healthcare delivery system.

INTRODUCTION

Understanding hospital organizational structure ensures that hospital employees know their own responsibilities, the responsibilities of those around them, to whom they report, and who to talk to about particular responsibilities or fields of knowledge.

Hospitals require precision in the execution of job responsibilities and multiple layers of accountability in order to function. To accomplish this, hospitals use a vertical organizational structure with many layers of management. With lives in their hands, hospitals have to function very precisely, executing high-quality services every hour of every day. Organizations that have this sort of requirement usually take on a vertical organizational structure – having many layers of management, with most of the organization's staff working in very specific, narrow, low-authority roles. The numerous layers of management are designed to make sure that no one person can throw the system off too much. This structure also ensures that tasks are being done exactly and correctly.

Patients are the most important people in the health care community. They come to us for help in preserving health and solving health-related problems, and all the efforts of the health care team should be directed toward meeting these needs. You will be an important member of this team, so it will be helpful to become acquainted with other team members and their functions in the hospital. Although you may see patients in physicians' offices, outpatient clinics, and other health care settings, most of your clinical experience will occur in a hospital setting. The hospital administration must see to it that suitable facilities and equipment are provided, adequate hospital personnel and staff must be well trained professional, technical, and support personnel are present.

CONCEPTS

HOSPITAL ORGANIZATION

It refers to levels of management within a hospital. It allows efficient management of hospital departments and helps one understand the hospital’s chain of command. Hospital administrators are responsible for organizing and overseeing the health services and daily activities of a hospital or healthcare facility. They manage staff and budgets, communicate between departments and ensure adequate patient care amongst other duties.

PHILOSOPHY

It is the study of the ethics, processes, and people which constitute the maintenance of health for human beings. It is an approach to dealing with health issues and a level of service provision. It is the study of ideas about knowledge, truth, and the meaning of healthcare.

VISION

It is something that you imagine or a picture that you see in your mind.  It is a thought, concept or object formed by the imagination. It is the ability to think about and plan for the future, using intelligence and imagination or someone’s idea or hope of how something should be done, or how it will be in the future. A vision statement describes what a company desires to achieve in the long run with a time frame. It depicts a vision of what the company will look like in the future and sets a defined direction for the planning and execution. Example of hospital’s vision: a future in which everyone has the best care and health possible. 

MISSION

 It is a specific task or job that should be done. It provides the basis for judging the success of an organization and its programs. It helps to verify if the organization is on the right track and making the right decisions.  It provides direction and a strategic planning framework when the organization must adapt to new demands. It is the core purpose of an organization or company. A summary of the aims and core values. A mission clearly tells what you as an organization does for customers. A mission is comprehensive but also very specific to set you apart from other organizations. A mission can be seen as a great tool to develop your goals and objectives. A mission should fit your identity. Example of hospital’s mission:  to provide patient-centered healthcare with excellence in quality, service, and access.

GOAL

A goal is an idea of the future or desired result that a person or a group of people envision, plan and commit to achieving. People endeavor to reach goals within a finite time by setting deadlines. It is the result or achievement toward which effort is directed.

CORE VALUES

Core values are the fundamental beliefs of a person or organization. These guiding principles dictate behavior and can help people understand the difference between right and wrong. Core values determine if the organization is on the right path and fulfilling its goals by creating an unwavering guide. Core values are values that guide you when making important decisions and doing work. Core values are a set of fundamental beliefs, ideals, or practices that inform how you are personally and professionally. Core values help an organization determine how to allocate resources, make important decisions and grow. Identifying core values for yourself or within a company can provide structure and instruction, especially when dealing with a certain decision or dispute. 

Trinity University of Asia Vision, Mission and Core Values

VISION

“A premier Christian University in Asia and the Pacific transforming a community of learners as leaders towards a humane society”

MISSION

To promote the formation of integrally developed, competent, productive, and socially responsible citizens by:

1. Instilling Christian values in all its academic programs, co-curricular and extra-curricular activities;

2. Providing excellent services for a quality learning environment;

3. Extending our ideals of service-learning for our partners by empowering communities to be self-reliant and by collaborating with other institutions;

4. Encouraging self-improvement among employees to gain higher competence and better skills towards service excellence; and

5. Exercising sound management of our resources.

MISSION

To promote the formation of integrally developed, competent, productive and socially responsible citizens by:

1. Instilling Christian values in all its academic programs, co-curricular and extra-curricular activities;

2. Providing excellent services for a quality learning environment;

3. Extending our ideals of service-learning for our partners by empowering communities to be self-reliant and by collaborating with other institutions;

4. Encouraging self-improvement among employees to gain higher competence and better skills towards service excellence; and

5. Exercising sound management of our resources.

TUA CORE VALUES

1. INTEGRITY - We uphold honesty, accountability, and fairness in the performance of our tasks.

2. EXCELLENCE - We are guided by the highest standard in the performance of our duties in instruction, research, and community service.

3. INNOVATION - We courageously explore avenues to develop new programs and processes to assure the faithful achievement of our institutional goals and

objectives.

4. TEAMWORK - We move as one in the spirit of mutual trust, loyalty, and solidarity to achieve our common goals.

5. SOCIAL RESPONSIBILITY - We commit to deliver services through an integrated community development program.

College of Radiologic Technology Vision, Mission, and Goals

VISION

To become the prime center for Radiologic Technology education in the country propagating a culture of excellence, enabling students to become leaders who are competent, efficient, and caring Radiologic Technologists.

MISSION

To develop Radiologic Technologist of broad intelligent perspective, able to contribute to the total development of the country and to provide quality educational opportunities through the application “state of the art” facilities for total clinical experience in Radiologic Technology.

PHILOSOPHY

To serve as a mark of excellence with the highest standard of professionalism in the field of Imaging Science.

PROGRAM GOALS

1. To develop competent radiologic technologists capable of functioning in the highly technical and dynamic field of radiologic technology.

2. To develop competent radiologic technologists who demonstrate proficiency in communication skills.

3. To develop competent radiologic technologists who demonstrate proficiency in critical thinking skills and problem-solving skills.

4. To develop radiologic technologists who model a high degree of professionalism.

ORGANIZATIONAL CHART 

The organizational chart is the graphical representation of an organization’s structure. Its purpose is to illustrate the reporting relationships and chains of command within the organization. Employee names and titles and/or job positions are generally depicted in boxes or circles with lines linking them to other employees and departments. The purpose of an organizational chart is to gain a quick understanding of how the organization is designed, its number of levels, and where each employee fits into the organization, and for updating new hires and when employees change positions or leave the company.

It is also used for presentations, to justify adding or reducing headcount and to determine where an employee might have the opportunity to shift job roles. For the new hire, the organization chart can be a lifeline, helping them to learn names and titles and to better understand where they fit into the overall organization structure. New hires get names thrown at them constantly and the organizational chart can be a great resource to find out who all those people actually are. 

 


HOSPITAL’S OBJECTIVES

An acceptable health care delivery system should have two primary objectives:

1. It must enable all citizens to access health care services

2. The services must be cost-effective and meet certain established standards of quality. 

HOSPITAL ADMINISTRATIVE SERVICES

These are services that maintain the facilities and supervises activities that include recordkeeping, mail distribution and office upkeep. The hospital administrative manager plan, direct and coordinate supportive services of the hospital.

HOSPITAL STAFFING

Adequate hospital staffing and organizational or managerial support for all sections in healthcare facility are key to improving the quality of patient care, to diminishing job dissatisfaction and burnout and improving the personnel retention problem in hospital settings. To assure the quality of care in hospitals, staffing of medical personnel must be matched with patient needs.  Hospital administration must involve all hospital workers in designing and staffing configuration in the process of planning and implementation. Training of competent and deserving medical personnel for specialized sections of the hospital must be provided for future appropriate hospital staffing.

MEDICAL SERVICES

It refers to assessment, screening, diagnosis or treatment for the purpose of promotion of health or the detection and management of diseases or injury within the competency and training of the direct primary care provider.

CLINICAL SERVICES

It brings together the work of physicians, nurses, and other healthcare providers across multi-specialties to ensure that patients receive comprehensive, personalized care.

CLASSIFICATION OF HOSPITAL SERVICES:

1. MEDICAL SERVICE

     1.1. Chief  of Clinics

     1.2. OPD

     1.3. Ward Sections

     1.4. Ancillary Department

2. ADMINISTRATIVE SERVICE

     2.1. Chief Administrative Officer

     2.2. Personnel Department (HRD)

     2.3. Security Section

     2.4. Sanitary(Utility) Section

3. NURSING SERVICE

     3.1. Chief Nurse

     3.2. OPD

     3.3. Ward Sections

TYPES OF MEDICAL SERVICES

1. CLINICAL SERVICES

1.1 Medicine                                          1.11 Stroke Center                                                 

1.2 Surgery                                            1.12 Urology

1.3 Pediatrics

1.4 Obstetrics and Gynecology

1.5 Neurology

1.6 Ophthalmology

1.7 Otolaryngology (ENT)

1.8 Dermatology

1.9 Gastroenterology

1.10 Cardiology

2. CLINICAL SUPPORT SERVICES(Ancillary)

2.1 Pharmacy

2.2 Laboratory(Pathology)

2.3 Diagnostic Imaging

HOSPITAL ADMINISTRATION

It is responsible for organizing and overseeing the health services and daily activities of a hospital or healthcare facility. They manage staff and budgets, communicate between departments and ensure adequate patient care amongst other duties. The hospital administrator makes sure the hospital operates efficiently and provides adequate medical care to patients the require assistance from the medical and support staff.

RESPONSIBILITIES OF HOSPITAL ADMINISTRATOR

1. Serve as liaison among governing boards, medical staff, and department managers.

2. Organize, control, and coordinate services as per the hospital board regulations.

3. Oversee the development and implementation of programs and policies for patient services, quality assurance, public relations, and department activities.

4. Evaluate personnel and prepare daily reports.

5. Assist with recruitment, consenting, screening and enrollment of personnel.

6. Authorize admissions/treatment as per agreed protocol.

7. Ensure that stock levels are adequate and orders are made on time.

8. Communicate medical results to patients under clinical supervision.

9. Complete timely and accurate documentation of patient visits.

HOSPITAL ADMISSION

The act or process of accepting someone into a hospital, clinic or other treatment facility as an in-patient.

TWO TYPES OF HOSPITAL ADMISSIONS:

1. EMERGENT – when a patient seen in the emergency department is subsequently admitted to the hospital.

2. ELECTIVE – hospital admissions occur when a doctor requests a bed/room be reserved for a patient on a specific/scheduled day.

HOSPITAL INFORMATION SYSTEM(HIS)

It is a computer system that can manage all the information to allow healthcare providers to do their jobs effectively. It refers to a system designed to manage healthcare data. This includes systems that collect, store, manage and transmit a patient’s electronic medical record (EMR).  It provides better care for patients and helps achieve health equity. It increases patient safety, decreases medical errors, and strengthens the interaction between patients and healthcare providers. 

HOSPITAL INFORMATION SYSTEM(HIS) includes the following:

1. Health Management Organization(HMO)

2. Billing System

3. Electronic Medical Record(EMR)

4. Master Patient Index(MPI)

5. Patient Portals

6. Remote Patient Monitory(RPM)

7. Clinical Decision Report(CDS)

8. Picture Archiving and Communication System(PACS)/DICOM

HOSPITAL PROCUREMENT

It controls the purchase of bulk services, equipment, and supplies. It quantifies medicines requirements, selecting appropriate methods, prequalifying suppliers and products. It also involves managing tenders, establishing contract terms, assuring medicines quality, obtaining the best prices, and ensuring adherence to contract terms.

HOSPITAL ACCOUNTING

It accumulates, communicates and interprets historical and projected data that are useful for the purpose of ascertaining the financial position and operating results of a hospital.  It is also part of HIS used for storing financial data, calculating healthcare costs, and providing patient billing information.

HUMAN RESOURCES

These are the people who make up the workforce of the hospital. It plans, directs, and coordinates the administration functioning of an organization. It oversees the recruiting, interviewing, and hiring of new staff consults with top executives on strategic planning, and serves as a link between an organization’s management and its employees.

SYNTHESIS

There are many different positions within a hospital’s organization to make the facility operate properly. Typically, hospitals are set up with a hierarchical and divisional structure. This structure means various levels of staff —ranging from high- to lower-level positions—are responsible for others within their respective divisions.

While the hierarchical structure works well for accountability purposes, it can often create disconnect with many broken lines of communication throughout the organization.

REFERENCES:

  • Patient Care in Radiography with Introduction to Medical Imaging, R. Ehrlich, 7th Edition, 2016
  • Radiologic Science for Technologists, S. Bushong, 11th Edition, 2017
  • Introduction to Radiologic Technology, L. Gurle, 7th Edition, 2016
  • Introduction to Radiologic Science and Patient Care, A. Adler, 5th Edition, 2017
  • A Practical Guide to Leadership and Management in Academic Radiology R. Arenson, 2nd Edition, 2016 
  • https://smallbusiness.chron.com/organizational-structure-hospitals-3811.html
  • https://comps.canstockphoto.com/entrepreneurship-concept-drawing_csp46435500.jpg 
  • https://i0.wp.com/real-leaders.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/07/leadership.jpg?fit=900%2C600&ssl=1

name: LESSON 3 TOPICS:1. Introduction2. The medical scie...
intro:
LESSON 3 TOPICS:

1. Introduction

2. The medical science and its relation with radiology and radiologic technology

3. Radiology: Historical Perspective

4. Overview of the application of radiation in medical diagnosis and therapy

TOPIC LEARNING OUTCOMES: 

After the end of the lesson, the student should be able to: 

1. State and explain the correlation of medical science with radiology and radiologic technology.

2. Outline the history of x-ray discovery and its subsequent application in medicine as well as distinguish radiology and radiologic technology.

3. Describe the overview application of radiation in diagnostic and therapeutic medicine.

INTRODUCTION

Over the years, medical imaging studies have provided practical solutions to a number of medical conditions. The majority of imaging professionals find jobs in clinics, physicians offices, private hospitals, and medical centers.

Medical imaging is an indispensable component of modern medical science and practice. It is uncommon to diagnose or treat a medical condition without taking advantage of medical imaging because of the incredible level of anatomical and functional details that the medical images reveal about the human body. 

The intrinsic properties of biological tissues vary spatially and temporally in response to structural and functional changes, including those caused by disease or disability, and medical imaging can reveal such changes. This permits the accurate and prompt delineation and characterization of the disease or disability. Alternatively, definitive information about the disease can be made available through surgical procedures, but surgery is obviously much more invasive and thus practically prohibitive. Instead, medical imaging has created a virtual window into the body, fostering a better scientific comprehension of its mysteries, enabling the investigation of underlying causes of medical symptoms through diagnostic processes, and aiding in disease treatment through proper targeting and monitoring.

One key advantage of medical imaging lies in its foundational format. As the body is an incredibly complex system, one of the major challenges for both research and clinical care is the comprehension of its vast quantities of information in such a way that it can be assimilated, interpreted, and utilized. Medical imaging is widely used and highly beneficial in both the laboratory and the clinical settings because of its innate ability to capture and present information as images: an image is one of the most efficient approaches to condense a vast amount of information into a comprehensive format. At the same time, imaging provides a significant depth of quantitative information that can be deciphered through computational analyses. Naturally, research and clinical care have different immediate aims and thus use imaging differently, but both are significantly advantaged by this condensation quality of medical imaging.

CONCEPTS

Historical Foundation of Medical Imaging

To appreciate the role of imaging in modern medicine, it is helpful to consider the historical context and the importance of physics principles. In the 1800s and before, physicians were extremely limited in their ability to obtain information about the illnesses and injuries of patients. They relied essentially on the five senses, and what they could not see, hear, feel, smell, or taste usually went undetected. Even these senses could not be exploited fully because patient modesty and the need to control infectious diseases often prevented full examination of the patient. Frequently, physicians served more to reassure the patient and comfort the family rather than to intercede in the progression of illness or facilitate recovery from injury. More often than not, fate was more instrumental than the physician in determining the course of a disease or injury.

The twentieth century has witnessed remarkable changes in the physician’s ability to intervene actively on behalf of the patient. These changes have dramatically improved the health of humankind around the world. In developed countries, infant mortality has decreased substantially, and the average life span has increased from 40 years at the beginning of the century to beyond 70 years for most people today. Many major diseases, such as smallpox, tuberculosis, poliomyelitis, and pertussis, have been brought under control, and some have been virtually eliminated. Diagnostic medicine has become commonplace, and therapies have evolved for cure or maintenance of persons with a variety of maladies.

How did such progress come about? In this progress of modern medicine, medical imaging has been a significant contributor by offering diagnostic probes to identify and characterize problems in the internal anatomy and physiology of patients. Medical imaging has been instrumental in moving the physician into the role of an active intervener in disease and injury and has a major influence on the prognosis for recovery.

In November 1895, Wilhelm Röntgen, a physicist at the University of Würzburg, was experimenting with cathode rays. These rays were obtained by applying a potential difference across a partially evacuated glass “discharge” tube. Röntgen observed the emission of light from the crystals of barium platinocyanide some distance away and recognized that the fluorescence had to be caused by the radiation produced by his experiments. He called the radiation “X-rays” and quickly discovered that the new radiation could penetrate various materials and could be recorded on photographic plates. Among the more dramatic illustrations of these properties was a radiograph of his wife’s hand that Röntgen included in early presentations of his findings. This radiograph captured the imaginations of both scientists and the public around the world. Within a month of their discovery, X-rays were being explored as medical tools in several countries, including Germany, England, France, and the United State.


Two months after Röntgen’s discovery, Henri Poincaré demonstrated to the French Academy of Sciences that X-rays were released when cathode rays struck the wall of a gas discharge tube. Shortly thereafter, Henri Becquerel discovered that potassium uranyl sulfate spontaneously emitted a type of radiation that he termed Becquerel rays, now popularly known as β particles. Marie Curie explored Becquerel rays for her doctoral thesis and chemically separated a number of elements. She discovered the radioactive properties of naturally occurring thorium, radium, and polonium, all of which emit α particles, a new type of radiation. In 1900, γ-rays were identified by Paul Ulrich Villard as a third form of radiation. In the meantime, J.J. Thomson reported in 1897 that the cathode rays used to produce X-rays were negatively charged particles (i.e. electrons) with about 1/2000 the mass of the hydrogen atom. Within five years of the discovery of X-rays, electrons and natural radioactivity had also been identified, and several sources and properties of the latter had been characterized.

Over the first half of the twentieth century, X-ray imaging advanced with the help of improvements such as intensifying screens, hot-cathode X-ray tubes, rotating anodes, image intensifiers, and contrast agents. These improvements are discussed in subsequent chapters. In addition, X-ray imaging was joined by other techniques that employed radioactive nuclides and ultrasound beams as energy sources for imaging.

Through the 1950s and 1960s, diagnostic imaging progressed as a symbiosis of X-ray imaging with the emerging specialties of nuclear medicine and ultrasonography. This coalescence reflected the intellectual creativity nurtured by the synthesis of basic science, principally physics, with clinical medicine. In a few institutions, the interpretation of clinical images continued to be taught without close attention to its foundation in basic science. In the more progressive teaching departments, however, the dependence of radiology on basic science, especially physics, was never far from the consciousness of teachers and students. The application of physics to medicine in the 1900s established the foundation for modern medical imaging and enabled the progress observed to date. In the current practice of medical imaging, close concordance with radiologic physics is the foundation of precision and innovation of the operation.

MEDICAL IMAGING

Medical imaging is capturing health- and medicine-related information in imagery that is produced through the interrogation of the human body using different sources of energy. Although this definition applies across the broad field of medical imaging, medical imaging comes in different forms, each relying on specific interactions between tissues and incident energy to reveal structural or functional information about the body. It enables image formation for various modalities of medical imaging: X-ray, nuclear imaging, magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), and ultrasonography (US), and many others.

History of Radiologic Technology

The field of radiologic technology began on November 8, 1895, when Wilhelm Röntgen, a German physicist, was working in his laboratory at the University of Wurzburg. Röntgen had been experimenting with cathode rays and was exploring their properties outside glass tubes. He had covered the glass tube to prevent any visible light from escaping. During this work, Röntgen observed that a screen that had been painted with barium platinocyanide was emitting light (fluorescing). This effect had to be caused by invisible rays being emitted from the tube. During the next several weeks, Röntgen investigated these invisible rays. During his investigation, he saw the very first radiographic image—his own skeleton. Röntgen became the first radiographer when he produced a series of photographs of radiographic images, most notably the image of his wife’s hand. He termed these invisible rays x-rays because x is the symbol for an unknown variable.

In 1888, Röntgen began working at the University of Wurzburg in the physics department. During the 1870s and 1880s, many physics departments were experimenting with cathode rays, electrons emanating from the negative (cathode) terminal of a tube. During his discovery, Röntgen worked with a Crookes tube. Sir William Crookes (1832-1919) used a large, partially evacuated glass tube that encompassed a cathode and an anode attached to an electrical supply. His tube was the early version of the modern fluorescent light. Crookes actually produced x-rays during his experimentation in the 1870s but failed to grasp the significance of his finding. He often found that photographic plates stored near his worktable were fogged. He even returned fogged photographic plates to the manufacturer, claiming they were defective. Many physicists created x-rays during the course of their work with cathode rays, but Röntgen was the first to appreciate the significance of the penetrating rays.

The actual day that the significance of Röntgen’s finding became clear to him is the subject of much debate. However, Friday, November 8, 1895, is believed by historians to be the day that Röntgen created the famous image of his wife’s hand. On Saturday, December 28, 1895, Röntgen submitted his first report, titled On a New Kind of Rays, to the Wurzburg Physico-Medical Society. Through his investigative methods, Röntgen identified the properties of x-rays. His methods were so thorough that no significant additions have been made to his work.

For his efforts, Röntgen was honored in 1901 with the first Nobel Prize in physics. He refused to patent any part of his discovery and rejected many commercial company offers. As a result, he saw little financial reward for his work. He died on February 10, 1923, of colon cancer.

Throughout the twentieth century, the use of x-rays advanced significantly to include the imaging of almost all aspects of the human body and the treatment of diseases with radiation therapy. In addition, radioactive substances came into use for both imaging (nuclear medicine) and treatment. By the 1970s, imaging had further advanced to include diagnostic medical sonography, computed tomography (CT), and MRI. Today, through the use of hybrid scanners that combine nuclear medicine imaging with either CT or MRI, both anatomic and physiologic function can be assessed in a single examination.

BRIEF HISTORY OF RADIOLOGY

1895: Wilhelm Conrad Roentgen discovered x-ray (Nov. 8, 1895)

1896: Thomas A. Edison developed fluoroscope using calcium tungstate.

1896: Antoine Henri Becquerel discovered radioactivity with uranium element.

1898: Marie and Pierre Curie discovered radioactive element radium.

1904: Clarence Dally became the first x-ray fatality who died of cancer.

1913: Albert Salomon developed mammography.

1927: Egas Moniz developed cerebral angiography.

1929: Werner Forssman performed the first heart catheterization on himself.

1934: Frederic and Irene Joliot Curie artificially produced radioisotopes.

1940: Andre Cournand and Dickinson Richards introduced the first diagnostic cardiac catheterization.

1940: Dr. Harold Johns developed the Cobalt-60 machine.

1950: Robert Egan introduced modern mammography.

1957: Ian Donald invents fetal ultrasound.

960: Mason Sones introduced the selective coronary angiography.

1963: David Kuhl and Roy Edwards developed the Single Photon Emission Computed Tomography(SPECT)

1964: Charles Dotter introduces image-guided intervention.

1972: Godfrey Hounsfield developed the CT scanner with Allan Cormack as co-developer.

1973: Edward Hoffman, Michael M. Ter-Pogossian and Michael  Phelps invented Positron Emission Tomography(PET).

1977: Raymond D. Damadian invented the first  MR(magnetic resonance) scanning machine or MRI.

1987: Introduction of Computed Radiography by FUJI.

2007: Direct Radiography or Digital Radiography was developed by Eastman Kodak/Carestream.

  

  

Application of Radiation in Medical Diagnosis and Therapy

Radiologic Technology is a  branch of medical science that deals with the utilization of all forms of radiation interaction with human beings(patients) in the diagnosis and treatment of diseases(cancer tumors) operating various medical diagnostic and therapeutic equipment such as x-rays, CT scanners, MRIs, ultrasound machines, Medical Linear Accelerator(Medical Linac), Single Photon Emission Computed Tomographic machines (SPECT), Positron Emission Tomographic machines (PET), Digital Subtraction Angiographic machines(DSA) and 3D/4D medical imaging equipment and among other computer and web-based software programs.

It also involves associated clerical duties, including scheduling and maintaining paperwork for office and clinical settings. Students of radiologic technology are required to attend an on-the-job training (OJT) or hospital training in different tertiary hospitals doing clinical duty. Students are given the opportunity to apply their knowledge and skills in an actual work setting. To become a licensed radiologic technologist, a graduate of BS in Radiologic Technology needs to pass the Radiologic Technology Licensure Examination. The examination is conducted by the Board of Radiologic Technology under the supervision of the Professional Regulations Commission (PRC). Radiologic Technologists perform imaging and therapeutic examinations to patients. They are responsible for positioning patients on the lab equipment to ensure that a quality diagnostic image is produced. They work closely with radiologists in diagnosing these images for any possible disease, injury, and treatment.

CAREER OPPORTUNITIES

Graduates of BS in Radiologic Technology may pursue a career path in different tertiary hospitals with a wide range of opportunities. Here are some of them:

1. X-ray Technologist

2. Ultrasound Technologist

3. CT-Scan Technologist (Computed Tomography)

4. MRI Technologist (Magnetic Resonance Imaging)

5. Mammography Technologist

6. Interventional Radiology Technologist

7. DSA Technologist (Digital Subtraction Angiography)

8. Radiation Therapy Technologist

9. PET Technologist (Positron Emission Tomography)

10.  Nuclear Medicine SPECT Technologist 

11. Industrial x-ray operator  (nuclear power plant, airport x-ray surveillance machine operator)

12. Inspection officer(DOH-FDA-CDRRHR)

13. Medical dosimetrist 

14. Manager

15. Educator


SYNTHESIS

There are many benefits for patients from medical imaging. Images of the human body are created using a variety of means such as ultrasound, magnetic resonance, nuclear medicine and x-rays to allow physicians to see inside the body, to identify and/or rule out medical problems, and to diagnose and treat diseases. Much has recently been written about radiation, so it is important to have some understanding of imaging performed using radiation, especially the benefits to the patient along with the associated risks.

Keep in mind that the radiation doses used in medical radiological imaging examinations like computed tomography (CT) and x-ray scans are much lower than those used in radiation oncology, which uses radiation as a therapy to treat cancer. Radiology (imaging) and radiotherapy (cancer treatment) are quite different.

The modern use of imaging has been one of the great advances made in the practice of medicine, allowing doctors to diagnose and manage their patients’ diseases safely and rapidly.  Many of today’s medical improvements require tests using radiation to confirm diagnoses, plan management, and monitor the response to treatment.

Most people around the world have benefited by imaging and therapy using radiation, whether from a simple chest x-ray for a cough, a bone x-ray for a fracture, or something more complex like a CT scan, MRI, Pet Scan and Medical Linac. This is the main reason why the discovery of x-rays in 1895 by Wilhelm Roentgen led to the first Nobel Prize in Physics, proving that radiology definitely plays an important role in healthcare system.

REFERENCES:

  • Patient Care in Radiography with Introduction to Medical Imaging, R. Ehrlich, 7th Edition, 2016
  • Radiologic Science for Technologists, S. Bushong, 11th Edition, 2017
  • Introduction to Radiologic Technology, L. Gurle, 7th Edition, 2016
  • Introduction to Radiologic Science and Patient Care, A. Adler, 5th Edition, 2017
  • https://smallbusiness.chron.com/organizational-structure-hospitals-3811.html
  • https://comps.canstockphoto.com/entrepreneurship-concept-drawing_csp46435500.jpg 
  • https://i0.wp.com/real-leaders.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/07/leadership.jpg?fit=900%2C600&ssl=1

name: LESSON 4 TOPICS:1. Introduction2. Professional pra...
intro:
LESSON 4 TOPICS:

1. Introduction

2. Professional practice and scope of education qualification

3. History and establishment of Radiologic Technology schools in the Philippines

4. The pioneer Radiologists and Radiologic Technologists

5. Regulations, credentialing  registration, licensing, and certification

TOPIC LEARNING OUTCOMES: 

After the end of the lesson, the student should be able to:

1. Discuss the professional practice and scope of education qualification

2. Outline the historical perspective of Radiology and Radiologic Technology from its first practitioner to the establishment of schools and associations, creation of the board as well as linkages with agencies and parallel groups.

3. Define credentialing, certification, registration, licensure, and regulations.

INTRODUCTION

Radiologic technology as a profession is a four-year tertiary program that requires PRC licensure examination which upon completion requires performing diagnostic imaging procedures, such as x-ray examinations, magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scans, and computed tomography (CT) scans. Some of them specialize in specific techniques such as cardiovascular-interventional radiography, mammography, or ultrasonography.

Radiologic technologists are responsible for accurately positioning patients and ensuring that a quality diagnostic image is produced. They work closely with radiologists, the physicians who interpret medical images to either diagnose or rule out disease or injury. For the images to be interpreted correctly by the radiologist, the imaging examination must be performed properly by a radiologic technologist.

RADIOLOGIC TECHNOLOGY AS A PROFESSION

The Philippine Qualifications Framework

The Philippine Qualifications Framework describes the levels of educational qualifications and sets the standards for qualification outcomes. It is a quality assured national system for the development, recognition, and award of qualifications based on standards of knowledge, skills, and values acquired in different ways and methods by learners and workers of the country. The Philippine Qualifications Framework - It is a collaborative program by the Department of Education (DepEd), Technical Education and Skills Development Authority (TESDA), Commission on Higher Education (CHED) , Professional Regulation Commission (PRC), and Department of Labor and Employment (DOLE). 

The K to 12 Program covers Kindergarten and 12 years of basic education (six years of primary education, four years of Junior High School, and two years of Senior High School [SHS]) to provide sufficient time for mastery of concepts and skills, develop lifelong learners, and prepare graduates for tertiary education, middle-level skills development, employment, and entrepreneurship. Senior High School is two years of specialized upper secondary education; students may choose a specialization based on aptitude, interests, and school capacity. The choice of career track will define the content of the subjects a student will take in Grades 11 and 12. Each student in Senior High School can choose among three tracks: Academic; Technical-Vocational-Livelihood; and Sports and Arts. The Academic track includes three strands: Business, Accountancy, Management (BAM); Humanities, Education, Social Sciences (HESS); and Science, Technology, Engineering, Mathematics (STEM).


  



HISTORY OF RADIOLOGIC TECHNOLOGY IN THE PHILIPPINES

  • FAMILY CLINIC AND HOSPITAL – the first school of Radiologic Technology
  • MARIAN COLLEGE – second school of Radiologic Technology
  • ASSOCIATION OF X-RAY TECHNICIANS IN THE PHILIPPINES was conceived in 1954
  • PD 480 – the creation of Radiation Health Service under the Department of Health on June 6, 1974.
  • R.A. 7431 – An act regulating the practice of Radiologic Technology in the Philippines also known as the “Radiologic Technology Act of 1992” which creates the PRC- Board of radiologic Technology on February 7, 1992.

PAST PRESIDENTS OF PHILIPPINE ASSOCIATION OF RADIOLOGIC TECHNOLOGISTS, INC. (PART)

  • 1954-1957 – GILBERTO V. PALOMIQUE
  • 1958-1963 – Association was inactive and died a natural death
  • 1964-1966 - GILBERTO V. PALOMIQUE
  • 1966-1967 – JOSE QUERIDO
  • 1967-1972 – NORBERTO A. PALOMO
  • 1972-1973 – Emerging of three societies

    1. PHISMERT - NORBERTO A. PALOMO

   2. PSRT - GILBERTO V. PALOMIQUE

   3. PIRT – ALMARIO G. LUTAP

Fusion of the 3 organizations into one society which is now PART, Inc. - GILBERTO V. PALOMIQUE

  • 1974-1975 – JOSE L. CERVANTES
  • 1975-1976 – SANTOS P. RAGASA
  • 1976-1977 – ALFONSO L. ABRIGO
  • 1977-1978 – BENITO RINGOR
  • 1978-1980 – BERNARDO E. RAMOS
  • 1980-1981 – GABRIEL V. MENDOZA
  • 1981-1982 – FELIX P. CASTILLO
  • 1982-1983 – NORBERTO P. DAAN
  • 1983-1985 – JOSE L. CERVANTES
  • 1986-1989 – SANTOS P. RAGASA
  • 1989-2001 – JACINTO C. LAPPAY
  • 2001 – Present – ROLANDO BANARES


REGULATIONS, CREDENTIALING, REGISTRATION, LICENSING, AND CERTIFICATION IN RADIOLOGIC TECHNOLOGY

COMMISSION ON HIGHER EDUCATION (CHED)

         It was created on May 18, 1994 through the passage of Republic Act No. 7722, or the Higher Education Act of 1994, an attached agency to the Office of the President for administrative purposes. It acts as collegial body in formulating plans, policies and strategies relating to higher education. It is in charged with promoting relevant and quality higher education, ensuring access to quality higher education, and guaranteeing and protecting academic freedom for continuing intellectual growth, advancement of learning, research and development.

ACCREDITED INTEGRATED PROFESSIONAL ORGANIZATION/ACCREDITED PROFESSIONAL ORGANIZATION (APO)

         It refers to the single national organization endorsed by the Board(e.g. Board of Radiologic Technology) and approved by the Commission to represent a given profession pursuant to the provision of the respective professional regulatory laws.

CENTER FOR DEVICE REGULATION, RADIATION HEALTH, AND RESEARCH (CDRRHR)

         It is a branch of the Department of Health (DOH)  under the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) which is responsible for the regulation, licensing, registration, manufacture, import, export, distribution, promotion, advertisement, and sale of medical devices, radiation devices, and health-related devices.

PHILIPPINE NUCLEAR RESEARCH INSTITUTE (PNRI)

         It is a government agency under the Department of Science and Technology (DOST) which regulates the safe and peaceful applications of nuclear science and technology in the Philippines. It also undertakes the transfer of research to end-users, including technical extension and training services. It is also responsible for monitoring the radiation measuring and/or detecting devices for radiation workers and facilities in the Phils. 

PHILIPPINE ASSOCIATION OF RADIOLOGIC TECHNOLOGISTS, INC. (PART)

         It is the national professional organization of radiologic technologists accredited by the Professional Regulation Commission. It was conceived in 1954, with primary objectives of uniting radiologic technologists into one umbrella, both from government and private institutions. The objective of the association is to promote the general welfare and upgrade the practice of radiologic technology so as to meet the standard for the protection of life, heath, and property.

PHILIPPINE SOCIETY OF GOVERNMENT RADIOLOGIC TECHNOLOGISTS (PSGRT)

         It is an organization composed of professional radiologic technologists employed in the government sector. It was founded in 1992 to bring together the radiologic technologists to exert their rights in gaining the position title of  Radiologic Technologist.  Its mission is to promote the highest achievable standards of patient care and professional service. 

CONTINUING PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT (CPD)

         It is Republic Act No. 10912, otherwise known as the “Continuing Professional Development  (CPD) Act of 2016”. It is an act that requires CPD  as the mandatory requirement for the renewal of a Professional Identification Card. It is the process of tracking and documenting the skills, knowledge, and experience that you gain both formally and informally as you work, beyond any initial training. It is still a mandatory requirement for the renewal of the PRC ID of all registered and licensed professionals. From 45 units, it’s now down to 15 units every three years.

PROFESSIONAL REGULATION COMMISSION(PRC)

         The Professional Regulation Commission(PRC) was created by the Presidential Decree (PD) No. 223, signed by then President Ferdinand E. Marcos.  Its functions are to conduct and administer licensure examinations to aspiring professionals and to regulate and supervise the practice of the professions exercised in partnership with Professional Regulatory Boards. 

Present members of Professional Regulation Commission:

1. Hon. Charito A. Zamora
   Chairman

2. Hon. Yolanda D. Reyes
   Commissioner, Office of the Commissioner I

3. Hon. Jose Y. Cueto, Jr.
   Commissioner, Office of the Commissioner II

4. Atty. Aristogerson T. Gesmundo
   Assistant Commissioner, Office of the Assistant Commissioner

PRC-BOARD OF RADIOLOGIC TECHNOLOGY(PRC-BORT)

         The Professional Regulation Commission(PRC)-Board of Radiologic Technology was created by the Republic Act(RA) No. 7431 also known as the “Radiologic Technology Act of 1992”, signed by then President Corazon Aquino.  Its main functions are to conduct yearly board examinations to radiologic technology and x-ray technology examinees under the supervision of PRC and to look into the condition affecting the practice of radiologic technology in the Philippines and adopt measures as may deemed necessary for the maintenance of the standards and ethics of the profession.

THE FIRST PRC-BOARD OF RADIOLOGIC TECHNOLOGY:

FORTUNATO C. GABON – Chairman

MEMBERS:

1. DEXTER R. RODELAS – Radiologic Technologist

2. EDITHA C. MORA – Radiologic Technologist

3. JOSE T. GAFFUD – Radiologist

4. EULINIA M. VALDEZCO – Medical Physicist

Present members of PRC-Board of Radiologic Technology:

  • REYNALDO APOLONIO S. TISADO. OIC/Member.
  • ORESTES P. MONZON. Member.
  • BAYANI C. SAN JUAN. Member.
  • MA. JESETTE B. CANALES. Member.
  • Roland Conanan. Member.

SYNTHESIS

The Radiologic Technology profession requires four years in college. After graduation passing the PRC licensure examination is a must to be a registered radiologic technologist. There are many opportunities await for radiologic technologists in the healthcare facility. Aside from diagnostic x-ray, there is various specialization in the field of radiologic technology. Among them are CT-Scan, MRI, SPECT, PET Scan, Radiotherapy, Interventional radiography, and many other emerging specializations. 

It is important to look back and remember the past radiologic schools and institutions and important pioneers in the field of radiology. The future of radiologic technology is full of exciting possibilities with new discoveries and advancements.

REFERENCES:

  • Patient Care in Radiography with Introduction to Medical Imaging, R. Ehrlich, 7th Edition, 2016
  • Radiologic Science for Technologists, S. Bushong, 11th Edition, 2017
  • Introduction to Radiologic Technology, L. Gurle, 7th Edition, 2016
  • Introduction to Radiologic Science and Patient Care, A. Adler, 5th Edition, 2017
  • A Practical Guide to Leadership and Management in Academic Radiology R. Arenson, 2nd Edition, 2016
  • https://pqf.gov.ph/img/pqframework.jpg

name: LESSON 5 TOPICS:1. Introduction2. Radiology as an ...
intro:
LESSON 5 TOPICS:

1. Introduction

2. Radiology as an imaging science

3. The concept of radiation

4. The x-ray machine

5. ImagingaAccessories and protective measures

TOPIC LEARNING OUTCOMES: 

After the end of the lesson, the student should be able to:

1. Outline the basic principles of x-ray imaging, as well as name equipment and accessories employed. 

2. Relate the mechanisms of radiation protection.

3. Discuss the concept of the production of x-ray.

INTRODUCTION

The development of radiology is, in large measure, a story of the development of technical hardware. The work of early scientists and craftsmen made possible the production of x-rays. Evidence of experimentation with the chemical, as well as the physical properties of matter, has been found as early as the first century When the term radiation is used, it generally evokes concern and a sense of danger. This circumstance is unfortunate because radiation not only is helpful but also is essential to life. Radiation is energy that is transmitted by waves through space or through a medium (matter); it has permeated the universe since the beginning of time and is a natural part of all of our lives. For example, the sun radiates light energy, and a stove radiates heat energy. More recently, three specific aspects of physical science helped pave the way for the discovery of x-rays—electricity, vacuums, and image-recording materials.

CONCEPTS

RADIOLOGY AS AN IMAGING  SCIENCE

RADIATION

It is energy emitted and transferred to matter and/or space in the form of waves and/or particles.

X-RAY

It is electromagnetic ionizing radiation with no mass and charge and travels at the speed of light.

c = speed of light = 3 X 10 8  m/s

X-RAY MACHINE

It is an electrical machine that contains an evacuated vacuum glass cylinder called an x-ray tube which produces a high speed of electrons to generate x-ray to provide images of internal structures.

PRINCIPAL PARTS OF X-RAY MACHINE

1. X-ray tube

2. Control (operating) console

3. High voltage section

Main Parts of X-ray tube:

1. Anode – the positive side of the x-ray tube.

2. Cathode – the negative side of the x-ray tube.

CONTROL PANEL

It is the section where you manipulate the x-ray machine to provide technical factors necessary in the production of an x-ray. 

HIGH VOLTAGE SECTION

It is composed of a high voltage transformer that converts 220 volts to thousand volts and electrical circuitry.

 


 


IMAGING DEVICES AND ACCESSORIES

1. X-ray film

2. Film cassette

3. Processing solution(Developer and Fixer)

4. Manual Processing Tanks

5. Automatic Film Processor

6. Safelight

7. Passbox

8. Caliper

 



 




RADIATION PROTECTIVE/SHIELDING DEVICES:

1. Lead rubber apron

2. Gonadal shields

3. Lead gloves

4. Thyroid shield

5. Lead goggles

 

  

Processing/production of x-ray film:

1. Manual processing

2. Automatic processing

3. Printing(laser printing)

4. Digital processing

X-RAY  FILMS

It is a special photographic film consisting of an emulsion-gelatin containing radiation and light-sensitive silver halide crystals and a flexible transparent blue-tinted base.

FILM PROCESSING

The process or technique of producing images on the film by means of x-ray or any other forms of radiation. The chemicals involved in manual, automatic, and daylight processors are basically the same.

FILM CASSETTE

It is a flat, light-tight rectangle or square plastic or metallic container used to hold x-ray film and intensifying screens and backed by lead to eliminate the effects of backscatter radiation.

INTENSIFYING SCREEN

It is part of the radiographic cassette made of phosphor material which converts the energy of the x-ray beam into visible light.

LEAD APRON  

It is a type of protective clothing that acts as a radiation shield against secondary or scatter radiation. 

GONADAL SHIELD

It is a protective shield placed outside of the body to cover the area of the gonads(testicles or ovaries) and other parts of the reproductive system of childbearing years or younger.

THYROID SHIELD

It is a lead collar that wraps around the neck to block radiation during x-ray examination.

LEAD GLOVES AND LEAD GLASSES

These are protective shielding accessories to shield your hands and eyes against radiation during x-ray examination.

X-RAY PRODUCTION

X-rays are produced when high speed of electrons are suddenly stopped or decelerated. When this happens, 99% is converted to heat and only 1% of x-ray is produced.

SYNTHESIS

Radiology as an imaging science is an important aspect of the healthcare system. Determination of diseases and pathologies can be easily identified using modalities that are now readily available. The introduction of the x-ray machines and the evolution of devices and accessories paved the way to radiology as the main assessment tool for the visualization of almost all internal structures of the body. With its beneficial diagnostic provision, harmful effects are the minimal drawback of these machines. Radiation health workers must always balance the benefits and the risks involved in every diagnostic procedure by practicing radiation protection.

REFERENCES:

  • Patient Care in Radiography with Introduction to Medical Imaging, R. Ehrlich, 7th Edition, 2016
  • Radiologic Science for Technologists, S. Bushong, 11th Edition, 2017
  • Introduction to Radiologic Technology, L. Gurle, 7th Edition, 2016
  • Introduction to Radiologic Science and Patient Care, A. Adler, 5th Edition, 2017

name: LESSON 6 TOPICS:1. Introduction2. Other Imaging Mo...
intro:
LESSON 6 TOPICS:

1. Introduction

2. Other Imaging Modalities

TOPIC LEARNING OUTCOMES: 

After the end of the lesson, the student should be able to:

1. Outline the basic principles of other imaging modalities and equipment and accessories.

2. Relate the mechanisms of each imaging modalities

3. Discuss the importance of each machine in imaging diagnosis and therapeutic applications.

INTRODUCTION

Since its discovery in the 19th century, the field of radiology has rapidly grown to enhance diagnosis and treatment for millions of people. New technologies and better practices have made the field safer, less expensive, and more efficient. CT scans, MRI scans, and ultrasound have become clear enough for diagnostics in a much safer and less invasive way. Imaging is even being used to treat cancer through PET scans. The dangers of excessive radiation exposure are well documented. In fact, CT, Fluoroscopy, and PET scans, which amount to only 25% of annual imaging procedures, make up 90% of medically-related radiation exposure. But the medical community has been working hard to reduce radiation dosage through the use of medical equipment and better practices. Practicing the use of lead aprons, certain drugs, improved patient positioning, and stillness can limit the amount of exposure during scanning and reduce the need for repeat scans. In some cases, radiation scanning can be eliminated altogether and substituted for ultrasound or MR scans.



The ISRRT was founded in 1962 as a non-profit organization, and now has over 90 Member Societies representing more than 86 countries, over 500,000 Society members, and in excess of 18,000 Associate Members. ISRRT is officially recognized as an NGO (Non-Government Organization) by the World Health Organization (WHO). The ISRRT is a UK-based registered Charity (Registration number 276218) and a not-for-profit organization. An international organization dedicated to bringing excellence and compassion in the delivery of medical imaging and radiation therapy for patients. It promotes professionalism and integrity among its members. ISRRT is the only organization representing all disciplines of Medical Radiation Technologists internationally. PART, Inc. is an official member of ISRRT.

FLUOROSCOPY

    It is an imaging technique that uses x-rays to obtain real-time moving images of the internal organs of the body. The primary function of the fluoroscope is to aid the radiologist in viewing dynamic studies of the human body. Dynamic studies are examinations that show the motion of circulation or that show the motion of hollow internal structures. It uses contrast media to highlight the anatomy and can be viewed on the TV monitor.

 

ULTRASOUND/ULTRASONOGRAPHY

    It is an imaging technique that uses high-frequency sound waves to delineate areas of different density in the body. The sound waves are bounced off tissues and the echoes are converted into a picture. It can provide 3D and 4D scan images. 3D creates a three-dimensional image, while 4D ultrasounds create a live video effect or real-time imaging.

 

DIGITAL X-RAY IMAGING/DIGITAL RADIOGRAPHY

    It is a form of radiography that uses x-ray sensitive plates to directly capture data during x-ray examination, immediately transferring it to a computer system without the use of film cassette.

 

MAMMOGRAPHY

    It is an imaging technique using x-rays to diagnose and locate tumors of the breasts. It’s a screening tool used to detect and diagnose breast cancer.

 

COMPUTERIZED TOMOGRAPHY SCAN (CT-SCAN)

    It uses a collimated x-ray beam that is directed to the patient and the attenuated remnant radiation is measured by a detector whose response is transmitted to a computer. The computer analyzes the signal from the detector, reconstructs the cross-sectional image, and displays the image on the TV monitor and can be photographed for later evaluation and filing.

 

 

MAGNETIC RESONANCE IMAGING

    It uses a powerful magnetic field, radio waves, and a computer to produce detailed images of the internal organs of the body especially soft tissues. The stronger an MRI machine’s magnetic field is the better the image resolution. Medical MRI machines range from 1.5 to 3.0 Tesla. The latest MRI machine has a power of 7 Tesla.

  


NUCLEAR MEDICINE

    It is a branch of medicine that deals with the use of radioactive substances in diagnosis, treatment and research. It employs a technique called scintigraphy which uses radiopharmaceuticals to produce images of the body’s organs or to visualize certain diseases. SPECT and PET Scans are examples of nuclear medicine.

SINGLE PHOTON EMISSION COMPUTED TOMOGRAPHY (SPECT)

    It is a nuclear medicine imaging technique using a gamma camera with emission of gamma-ray which provides tomographic and 3D images.

  

POSITRON EMISSION TOMOGRAPHY (PET)

    It is an imaging test that uses radioactive tracers that are either swallowed, inhaled, or injected into a vein to be absorbed by organs or tissues. The PET scanner will detect the tracer with a higher chemical activity which is helpful in determining certain diseases. The PET Scan produces tomographic and three-dimensional images that can measure metabolic activity of the body such as blood flow, oxygen use, sugar content, and many more. 

 

BONE DENSITOMETRY

    It is an enhanced form of x-ray technology that is used to measure bone loss. It uses a small dose x-ray to produce images of the body usually the lumbar spine and hips to diagnose osteoporosis, to assess an individual’s risk for developing osteoporotic fractures.

 

INTERVENTIONAL RADIOLOGY(IR)

    It uses a combination of various imaging modalities such as fluoroscopy, MRI, CT-Scan, and ultrasound to guide minimally invasive surgical procedures that diagnose, treat, and cure many kinds of diseases. Examples of IR are CT-guided biopsy, ultrasound-guided biopsy, digital subtraction angiography(DSA)cardiac catheterization, and angioplasty.

  

 

RADIOTHERAPY (RADIATION THERAPY)

    It is a cancer treatment that uses high doses of ionizing radiation to kill cancer cells and shrink tumors. At high doses, radiation therapy kills cancer cells or slows their growth by damaging their DNA. Radiotherapy does not kill cancer cells right away. It takes days or weeks of treatment before DNA is damaged enough for cancer cells to die. 

COBALT-60 THERAPY

    It is the medical use of gamma rays from the radioisotope cobalt-60 to treat cancer. It is an external beam radiotherapy (teletherapy) machine that produced a beam of gamma rays directed into the patient’s body to kill tumor tissue. Cobalt-60 is produced by neutron bombardment of stable cobalt in a nuclear reactor, then it emits gamma rays which is used in bombarding patients with cancer cells. The half-life of cobalt-60 is approximately 5.26 years, therefore, it has to be replaced 5-10 years.  

  

MEDICAL LINEAR ACCELERATOR (MEDICAL LINAC)

    It is an external beam radiation treatment for patients with cancer using x-rays and electrons in megaelectron volt range (MeV). It delivers high-energy x-rays or electrons to the region of the patient’s tumor. It is designed to destroy the cancer cells while sparing the surrounding normal tissue. It is called a linear accelerator because the electrons produced are accelerated in a linear manner or in one direction only.


BRACHYTHERAPY

    It is a procedure that involves placing radioactive material inside your body to treat cancer. It delivers high doses of radiation to specific areas of the body. A tube or a cylinder device containing radioactive material is placed in a body opening, such as a windpipe or vagina to deliver the specific dose of radiation. CT-Scan, ultrasound, or other imaging modalities may be used to guide the devices into place and to ensure they’re positioned in the most-effective locations. After a designated amount of time, the radioactive material is removed from the patient’s body. 


GAMMA-KNIFE RADIOSURGERY

    It is non-invasive stereotactic radiosurgery that treats benign and malignant tumors especially brain tumors and vascular malformations. It is a piece of specialized equipment that focuses about 200 tiny beams of radiation on a tumor or target with submillimeter accuracy. A high dose of radiation is delivered to the place where all the beams meet. It is a one-time therapy completed in a single day. 

  


SYNTHESIS

Diagnostic imaging allows us to more safely place a needle for a biopsy or place a catheter.  Because imaging is integrated into nearly every component of the healthcare system, extensive sub-specialization within diagnostic imaging and therapy is now a realization.

Medical imaging has improved immensely since the first x-rays were taken over 126 years ago. There is much more accuracy in diagnosing a medical problem and because of these advances, there is also much less need to perform exploratory surgery. This hopefully will lead to early diagnosis and better treatment options for many patients.

References:

  • Patient Care in Radiography with Introduction to Medical Imaging, R. Ehrlich, 7th Edition, 2016
  • Radiologic Science for Technologists, S. Bushong, 11th Edition, 2017
  • Introduction to Radiologic Technology, L. Gurle, 7th Edition, 2016
  • Introduction to Radiologic Science and Patient Care, A. Adler, 5th Edition, 2017

LESSON 7 TOPICS:
1. Qualification Standards f...
intro:
LESSON 7 TOPICS:

1. Qualification Standards for Radiologic Technologist

2. Job Description of Imaging Radiologic Technologist

TOPIC LEARNING OUTCOMES: 

After the end of the lesson, the student should be able to:

1. Discuss the qualification standard of Radiologic Technologist in the Philippines as prescribed by the Civil Service Commission(CSC)

2. Enumerate and explain the job description of Radiologic Technologist in diagnostic imaging.

Radiologic Technology Act of 1992 is also known as Republic Act 7431 (RA 7431), which defines important radiologic technology terms, as well as, establishes duties, rights, functions, and responsibilities of the Radiologic Technologists.

X-RAY TECHNOLOGY

It is an auxiliary branch of radiology which deals with the technical application of x-rays as an aid in the diagnosis of diseases and injuries.

RADIOLOGIC TECHNOLOGY

It is an auxiliary branch of radiology which deals with the technical application of radiation, such as x-rays, beta rays, ultrasound, and radiofrequency rays, in the diagnosis and treatment of diseases.

Position                     Salary Grade       Years of Experience

RT I -------------- 11 ------------- none

RT II -------------  15 ------------- 1 year

RT III ------------- 18 ------------- 2 years

RT IV ------------- 20 ------------ 3 years

RT V ------------- 22 ------------ 4years

REPUBLIC ACT No. 1080: An Act Declaring the Bar and Board Examinations as Civil Service Examinations

R.A. 6758 : Compensation and Position Classification Act of 1989

CSC Resolution No. 1701537(MC No. 35, Series 2017): Amended Qualification Standards for Radiologic Technologist I to V Positions, Department of Health(DOH)


Qualification Standards for Radiologic Technologists in the Philippines(Click the hyperlink)

http://www.csc.gov.ph/phocadownload//MC2017/MC%20No%2035,%20s.%202017.pdf

JOB DESCRIPTION OF RADIOLOGIC TECHNOLOGIST      

1. Performs general diagnostic works.

2. Processed the exposed x-ray films.

3. Selects proper technical factors on individual patients to attain quality radiographs.

4. Observe radiation protection in accordance with the radiation safety manual.

5. Select and operate equipment as directed.

6. Provides immobilization devices as required.

7. Assists radiologists, surgeons, physicians in administering contrast media.

8. Assist in the performance of first-aid as deemed necessary.

9. Practice sterile techniques and prevent cross-contamination.

10. Encodes patient’s pertinent data.

11. Filing of x-ray films.

12. Maintains cleanliness and orderliness.

13. Maintains ethical relationships with other hospital personnel.

14. Rotates within the department and/or by shifting as deemed necessary.

15. Participates in paramedical lectures/conferences/seminars/conventions/trainings for staff development.

16. Performs other related duties as required.

References:

  • Patient Care in Radiography with Introduction to Medical Imaging, R. Ehrlich, 7th Edition, 2016
  • Radiologic Science for Technologists, S. Bushong, 11th Edition, 2017
  • Introduction to Radiologic Technology, L. Gurle, 7th Edition, 2016
  • Introduction to Radiologic Science and Patient Care, A. Adler, 5th Edition, 2017
  • http://www.csc.gov.ph/phocadownload//MC2017/MC%20No%2035,%20s.%202017.pdf

name: LESSON 1 TOPICS:1. Introduction2. Atomic...
intro:
LESSON 1 TOPICS:

1. Introduction

2. Atomic structure

3. Concepts of an atom

4. Electron configuration

TOPIC LEARNING OUTCOMES:

After the end of the lesson, the student should be able to:

1. Describe fundamental atomic structure

2. Differentiate the concepts of atom

3. Understand the electron configuration

 INTRODUCTION


Our world is made out of atoms. Your cellphone is made out of atoms. The laptop you are using is made out of atoms. So is the air you're breathing. In fact, you are also made out of atoms. Atoms are too small, very small that can not be seen by the naked eye. Democritus was a Greek philosopher who was the first person to use the term atom (atomos: meaning indivisible)in 400 BC. He thought that if you take a piece of matter and divide it and continue to divide it you will eventually come to a point where you could not divide it anymore. This fundamental or basic unit was what Democritus called an atom. If you could somehow take yourself apart and break your body down to its most basic level, you would find that you're made out of living cells. And those cells are made out of complex molecules. And those molecules contain atoms bonded together. But what is really an atom? What does it look like? The most basic way we imagine atoms is just a series of circles or balls in a clump. But we need to talk about what's inside the circles, what makes them up, to really understand what an atom is.

CONCEPTS

Radiation interaction with matter starts with the smallest particle of an element in our body which is the atom. When radiation strikes our body, the first thing that may cause interaction is at the atomic level. Therefore, it is important to know the basic fundamental of radiation physics.

ATOMIC STRUCTURE

PHYSICS – is a branch of science which deals with the study of matter and energy.
RADIATION – energy emitted and transferred through matter or space in the form of waves and/or particles.

RADIATION PHYSICS – is a science which deals with the study of the interaction of radiation with matter.

ATOM– is the smallest particle of an element. It resembles that of the solar system with the nucleus at the center and the different energy levels surrounding it. 

COMPOSITION OF AN ATOM:
1. NUCLEUS – is the center of an atom. It contains the protons and the neutrons inside. The term “nuclide” is a specie of a nucleus.
2. ELECTRON – negatively charged particle. It has a rest mass of about 9.1 x 10-31 kg..
3. PROTON – positively charged particle. It has a rest mass of 1.673 x 10-27 kg..
4. NEUTRON – carries no charge with a mass of 1.675 x 10-27 kg.
5. ORBITAL SHELL OR ELECTRON SHELL – an imaginary path to which electrons travel.

   

HISTORY OF THE ATOMIC MODELS TIMELINE

 

CONCEPTS OF AN ATOM/ATOMIC MODELS


ATOMIC MODELS:

1. DALTON’S MODEL

· All matter is composed of extremely small particles called atoms.

· Atoms of a given element are identical in size, mass, and other properties. Atoms of different elements differ in size, mass, and other properties.

· Atoms cannot be subdivided, created, or destroyed.

· Atoms of different elements can combine in simple whole number ratios to form chemical compounds.

· In chemical reactions, atoms are combined, separated, or rearranged.

2. J.J. THOMSON’S MODEL (PLUM-PUDDING MODEL)

· The "plum pudding" model of the atom consisted of a uniform sphere of positive charge with negative electrons embedded in the sphere.

· The electrons were embedded in a uniform sphere of positive charge like blueberries stuck into a muffin. The positive matter was thought to be jelly-like or a thick soup.

· The electrons were somewhat mobile. As they got closer to the outer portion of the atom, the positive charge in the region was greater than the neighboring negative charges and the electron would be pulled back more toward the center region of the atom.

· A model gives an idea of what something looks like but is not the real thing.

3. RUTHERFORD’S MODEL (NUCLEAR MODEL)

· Bombardment of gold foil with alpha particles showing deflection of some particles.

· The nuclear model of the atom consists of a small and dense positively charged interior surrounded by a cloud of electrons.

· All of the positive charge and the majority of the mass of the atom are concentrated in a very small space in the atom's interior, which he called the nucleus. The nucleus is the tiny, dense, central core of the atom and is composed of protons and neutrons.

· It did not completely address the nature of the electrons and the way in which they occupied the vast space around the nucleus. 

4. BOHR’S MODEL

· Electrons orbit the nucleus in orbits that have a set size and energy.

· The energy of the orbit is related to its size. The lowest energy is found in the smallest orbit.

· Radiation is absorbed or emitted when an electron moves from one orbit to another.

· It resembles that of the solar system with the nucleus at the center and the different energy levels surrounding it.

5. SCHRODINGER’S MODEL (WAVE-MECHANICAL MODEL)

· It describes the locations of electrons in orbit around the nucleus of an atom.  The number of electrons in each shell of an atom may be described using electron notation.

· It assumes that the electron is a wave and tries to describe the regions in space, or orbitals, where electrons are most likely to be found.

· The electron was a 3-D waveform circling the nucleus in a whole number of wavelengths allowing the waveform to repeat itself as a stable standing wave representing the energy levels of the Bohr model.

                     

ELECTRON CONFIGURATION


A = Atomic mass no.     40

X =  Atom or element       Ca

Z =  Atomic no. (p)         20  

MAXIMUM NO. OF ELECTRONS THAT CAN OCCUPY EACH ELECTRON SHELL

SHELL NO.

SHELL SYMBOL

NO. OF ELECTRONS

1

K

2

2

L

8

3

M

18

4

N

32

5

O

50

6

7

Q

NOTE:

1. Equation for electron configuration: 2n2     where n=shell no.
2. No outer shell can contain more than eight(8) electrons.
3. In a stable atom, the no. of electrons are also equal to the no. of protons. Since, the atomic no. is also the no. of electrons, therefore,
     z=e=p
4. The no. of neutrons in an atom is the difference between the atomic mass no. and the atomic no.
     n=A-z
5. The atomic mass no. is equal to the sum of the no. of protons plus the no. of neutrons in the nucleus of an atom.
     A=p+n

SYNTHESIS

An atom is the smallest fundamental unit of matter or an element. Atoms are the building blocks of matter. Atoms combine to form molecules, which then interact to form solids, gases, or liquids. For example, table salt is composed of sodium and chlorine atoms that have combined to form salt molecules. Many biological processes are devoted to breaking down molecules into their component atoms so they can be reassembled into a more useful molecule.

REFERENCES:

  • https://cdn1.byjus.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Bohrs-Model-Of-An-Atom-1.png
  • https://www.thoughtco.com/thmb/SHu7FW2OY6loTuZtywx9t4iDhi8=/1500x844/smart/filters:no_upscale()/bohr-model-of-the-atom-603815_Final-5f95ec36a8874023b75caef27e337886.PNG
  • https://i.pinimg.com/originals/71/ea/46/71ea469f3dd5b06705afb1c059cde1a3.png
  • https://newsforkids.net/wp-content/uploads/2018/05/768px-atom-diagramsvg-500x500.png
  • Callaway, W.V. & Tolley Gurley L. (2018). Introduction to Radiologic Technology, 8th edition. Singapore. Mosby Elsevier
  • Bushong, S. (2017). Radiologic Science for Technologist, 11th Edition. Mosby Elsevier Inc.

name: LESSON 2 TOPICS:1. Introduction2.&n...
intro:
LESSON 2 TOPICS:

1. Introduction

2. Radioactivity

3. Physical Characteristics of radioactivity

4. Radioactive decay law

TOPIC LEARNING OUTCOMES:

After the end of the lesson, the student should be able to:
