1. Describe radioactivity and radioactive decay in terms of alpha, beta and gamma emission

2. Discuss various half-life in environmental and clinical settings

3. Explain the various radioactive nuclear arrangements

INTRODUCTION

 

Radioactivity is a phenomenon that occurs when an unstable atom has too much energy and it has to be released in the forms of waves or particles or both. It is a naturally occurring substance but it can also be artificially produced. Atoms of the substance spontaneously emit invisible but energetic radiations, which can penetrate materials that are opaque to visible light. The effects of these radiations can be harmful to living cells but, when used in the right way, they have a wide range of beneficial applications, particularly in medicine. Radioactivity has been present in natural materials on the earth since its formation (for example in potassium-40 which forms part of all our bodies). However, because its radiations cannot be detected by any of the body’s five senses, the phenomenon was only discovered 100 years ago when radiation detectors were developed. Nowadays we have also found ways of creating new man-made sources of radioactivity for medical applications, power generation and food sterilization. Radiation emitted through the process of radioactivity can cure and kill lives. It is the responsibility of everyone to properly and effectively utilize it.

HISTORY TIMELINE OF RADIOACTIVITY

  

1895 ---- Wilhelm Konrad Roentgen discovers x‑rays on Nov.8, 1895.

   

1896 ---- Antoine-Henri Becquerel discovers rays produced by uranium, the first observation of natural radioactivity. Concerns first raised about possible injuries from x‑ray exposures. Elihu Thomson conducts experiments on x‑ray burns.

         

 1898 ---- Marie and Pierre Curie discover that thorium gives off "uranium rays," which Marie renames "radioactivity." Marie and Pierre Curie discover polonium and announce the existence of another new radioactive element they name radium.

1899 ---- First malpractice lawsuit is awarded for x‑ray burns. Ernst Rutherford discovers that radioactivity from uranium has at least two different forms, which he calls alpha and beta rays. Fritz Geisel, Antoine-Henri Becquerel, and Marie Curie prove that beta rays consist of high-speed electrons.

1899 ---- Ernst Rutherford discovers that radioactivity from uranium has at least two different forms, which he calls alpha and beta rays.

1900 ---- Rutherford discovers the principle of half-life and sets forth his laws on radioactive decay.

1900 ---- Paul Ulrich Villard is the first to observe that gamma radiation is more penetrating than x‑rays.

1901 ---- Wilhelm Konrad Roentgen wins the Nobel Prize in physics for his discovery of x‑rays. X‑rays are shown to be lethal to mammals through experiments conducted by W.H. Rollins.

1903 ---- Antoine-Henri Becquerel and, Pierre and Marie Curie share the Nobel Prize for physics, Becquerel for his discovery of natural radioactivity, and the Curies for their study of radioactivity. First observation notes that radioactivity can induce tissue and organ damage. George Perthes discovers that x‑rays can inhibit the growth of tumors and proposes the use of x‑rays in the treatment of cancer.

1906 ---- Two French scientists, Bergonie and Tribondeau, theorized and observed that radiosensitivity was a function of the metabolic state of the tissue being irradiated. This has come to be known as the law of Bergonie and Tribondeau.

1911 ---- First reports linking x‑rays to leukemia and cancer in physicians is published. Arthritis patient dies from Radium-226 injections.

1912 ---- Hundreds of young women working in plants in New York and Illinois are accidentally exposed to a luminous paint containing radium while painting dials for watches and clocks.

1913 ---- Hans Geiger unveils his radiation detector.

1915 ---- British Roentgen Society proposes standards for radiation protection of workers.

1920 ---- First x‑ray protection committee is formed by the American Roentgen Ray Society.

1922 ---- Film badges first developed to measure exposures to radiation. Amelia Maggia is first of the "Radium Dial Painters" to die from radiation poisoning.

1924 ---- First radiation tolerance dose proposed by Arthur Mutscheller for use as a guide to limiting exposure of an individual to radiation.

1927 ---- H.J. Muller shows that mutations can be induced in Drosophila melanogaster by low levels of x‑rays.

1930 ---- Charles Lauritsen develops high-voltage x‑ray machine for radiation therapy.

1938 ---- Otto Hahn is the first to split the atom of uranium, opening up the possibility of a chain reaction (nuclear fission).

1941 ---- Glenn Seaborg discovers plutonium.

1942 ---- The Manhattan Project is formed to secretly build the atomic bomb; Los Alamos, New Mexico, is selected as the site

1945 ---- First atomic bomb is exploded in the desert near Alamagordo, New Mexico. Little Boy,” the second atomic bomb, is dropped on Hiroshima. "Fat Man,” the third atomic bomb, is dropped on Nagasaki.

1949 ---- USSR explodes its first atomic bomb.

1951 ---- Experimental Breeder Reactor I starts up in Idaho and produces the world’s first useable electric power from nuclear energy, illuminating four light bulbs.

1952 ---- The first hydrogen bomb is tested by the United States.

1954 ---- The Soviet Union opens the 5 MW Obninsk Nuclear Power Plant, the first nuclear power plant to produce electricity for a power grid.

1956 ---- Calder Hall opens in Sellafield, England. It is the first commercial nuclear power station for civil use.

1956 ---- The United States explodes the first airborne hydrogen bomb over Bikini Atoll in the Pacific.

1963 ---- FDA authorized the first use of irradiation to treat food in the United States. Wheat and wheat flour were irradiated to rid them of insects.

1979 ---- The Three mile island accident is the worst accident in United States commercial reactor history. The accident is caused by a loss of coolant from the reactor core due to a combination of mechanical malfunction and human error. However, no one is injured, and no overexposure to radiation results from the accident.

1986 ---- The Chernobyl disaster occurs after a safety test deliberately turns off safety systems. A large amount of radiation occurs, over fifty firefighter die, and up to 4,000 civilians are estimated to die of early cancer.

2011 ---- A 9.0 magnitude earthquake and tsunami wrecks the Fukushima nuclear plant, triggering nuclear meltdowns that contaminate food and water and force mass evacuations. Nearly 16,000 people are killed in the earthquake and the tsunami and 3,300 remain unaccounted for. However, much of the radiation released of it goes out to sea instead of into populated area. No people are expected to die from radiation dose.

“Atomic power can cure as well as kill. It can fertilize and enrich a region as well as devastate it. It can widen man's horizons as well as force him back into the cave."                                                    Alvin M. Weinberg(1945)

X-ray of the hand of Roentgen's wife, taken on December 22, 1895 and presented to Ludwig Zehnder of the Physik Institut, University of Freiburg, on January 1, 1896. The first photograph of a human body part using x-ray.


A photographic plate made by Henri Becquerel shows the effects of exposure to radioactivity. A metal Maltese cross, placed between the plate and radioactive uranium salt, left a clearly visible shadow on the plate.




From the following list of atoms, pick out those that are isotopes, isobars, isotones and isomers ?

131                130          130            131          132             132         99m           99    
     Xe               I               Ba             I              Ba             Cs             Tc           Tc       
  54              53            56            53            56             55              43           43       

Isotopes:

Isobars:

Isobars:

Isomers:

RADIOACTIVITY/  RADIOACTIVE DECAY/ RADIOACTIVE DISINTEGRATION
It is the spontaneous emission of particles and energy when an unstable nuclide transforms into a stable nuclide.

RADIOACTIVE HALF-LIFE/PHYSICAL HALF-LIFE(T1/2p)
It is the time required for a radioactive substance to reduce 50% of its activity decay. 

BIOLOGIC HALF-LIFE(T1/2b)
It is the time required for the body to eliminate one-half of an administered dosage of any substance by regular process of elimination.

EFFECTIVE HALF-LIFE(T1/2eff)
It is the time required for a radioactive element in a body to be administered 50% as a result of the combined action of radioactive decay and biologic elimination.




RADIOACTIVE DECAY LAW

1. RADIOACTIVE DECAY BY ALPHA(α) EMISSION/ALPHA DECAY

  • it occurs in heavy nuclides
  • it loses 2 units of positive charge(p or z)
  • it loses 4 units of atomic mass no
  • it emits alpha particles (α) and gamma-ray (γ)

Example:

  226               222         4
      Ra           Rn  +   α  +  γ
    88                 86         2

 

2. RADIOACTIVE DECAY BY BETA MINUS (β-) EMISSION/BETA-MINUS DECAY

  • neutron is converted to a proton
  • an increase of atomic no. by 1 unit
  • the atomic mass no. remains the same
  • it emits negatron(β- particles) and gamma-ray(γ)

Example:

   131                 131            0
        I            Xe   +    β +  γ
   53                 54          -1 


3. RADIOACTIVE DECAY BY BETA PLUS (β+) EMISSION/BETA-PLUS DECAY

  • proton is converted to a neutron/neutrino
  • a proton in the parent nucleus decays into a neutron that remains in the daughter nucleus
  • an increase of neutron/neutrino by 1 unit
  • it emits positron(β+particles/positron), neutrino and gamma ray (γ)

Example:

  11                   11            0

   C            C    +      β  +   γ

 6                    5          + 1

 

4. RADIOACTIVE DECAY BY GAMMA RAY(γ) EMISSION/GAMMA DECAY

  • emission of gamma ray(γ) by an unstable nuclide
  • there is no change in the atomic no. and atomic mass no. of an atom
  • it emits pure gamma ray (γ)

Example:

 99m                  99        
       Tc             Tc  +  γ
    43                   43     

 

5. RADIOACTIVE DECAY BY ELECTRON CAPTURE OR K-CAPTURE

  • the nucleus of an atom absorbed one of its orbital electrons
  • an electron is converted into a neutron
  • the nucleus transforms to a daughter of one lower atomic number
  • an orbital electron from the cloud is captured by the nucleus with subsequent emission of gamma ray as the orbital vacancy is filled by an electron from the cloud about the nucleus 

Example:

7                 7    

 Be        Li   +   e-    +   X

4                3 


References:

  • https://science.jburroughs.org/mbahe/BioEthics/ppt_pdf/110RadiationHistoryTimeline.pdf

  • Callaway, W.V. & Tolley Gurley L. (2018). Introduction to Radiologic Technology, 8th edition. Singapore. Mosby Elsevier

  • Bushong, S. (2017). Radiologic Science for Technologist, 11th Edition. Mosby Elsevier Inc.

name: LESSON  3 TOPICS:1. Introduction2.&...
intro:
LESSON  3 TOPICS:

1. Introduction

2. Electricity

3. Magnetism

4. Electromagnetism

TOPIC LEARNING OUTCOMES:

After the end of the lesson, the student should be able to:

1. Understand the difference between particulate and non-particulate radiation

2. Discuss the relationship between electricity and magnetism

3. Identify the properties of electromagnetism and describe the processes of ionization and excitation

INTRODUCTION

The relationship between electricity and magnetism in the past is considered two separate forces. However, with conclusive study developed by various scientists, it is now treated as interrelated forces. Electricity and magnetism are closely related to each other. The electric current flowing through the wire produces a circular magnetic field outside the wire. The direction (clockwise or counter-clock wise) of this magnetic field depends on the direction of the electric current. In a similar way, a changing magnetic field produces an electric current in a wire or conductor. The relationship between electricity and magnetism is called electromagnetism.

Electricity is a form of energy that is transmitted through the wires (especially copper wires) for operating various machines and devices such as lights, fans, refrigerators, computers, television, air conditioner, washing machines, etc. For example, the flow of water in a particular direction is called water current. In a similar way, the flow of electricity or charged particles (especially free electrons) in a particular direction is called current electricity or electric current.

Magnetism is a type of attractive or repulsive force that acts up to a certain distance. The distance up to which this attractive or repulsive force acts is called a magnetic field. Magnetism is caused by the moving electric charges (especially electrons). When two magnetic materials are placed close to each other, they experience an attractive or repulsive force. We know that all the objects in the universe are made of small particles called atoms. The atoms consist of sub atomic particles such as electrons, protons, and neutrons. The strong nuclear force between the protons and neutrons makes them stick together to form nucleus. The electrons present in the atom revolve around the nucleus because of the electrostatic force of attraction between the electrons and nucleus. The electrons revolving around the nucleus also rotates or spins around its own axis. Because of this spinning of electrons, magnetic field is produced. If the majority number of electrons in the atom spins in the same direction, a strong magnetic field is produced. The direction of the electrons spin determines the direction of the magnetic field.

CONCEPTS

Oersted’s Experiment

In 1820, Hans Oersted used a long, straight wire supported near a free-rotating magnetic compass. With no current flowing through the wire, the magnetic compass pointed north. When a current was passed through the wire, the magnetic compass needle swung to pint straight at the wire. This was evidence of a direct link between electric and magnetic phenomena. The electric current evidently produced a magnetic field and cause the magnetic compass to point toward the wire. Therefore, any charge in motion induces a magnetic field.





Faraday’s Experiment

Oersted’s experiment demonstrated that electricity can be used to generate magnetic fields. Is the reverse true? Can magnetic fields somehow be used to generate electricity? It took Michael Faraday, 6 years to find the answer to that question. From a series of experiments, Faraday concluded, that an electric current cannot be induced in a circuit merely by the presence of a magnetic field. He experimented with a coil of wire connected to a current-measuring device called an ammeter. If a bar magnet is set next to the coil, the meter indicates no current in the coil. However, if the magnet is moved, a current flow in the coiled wire. The flow is indicated by the ammeter,. Therefore, to induce a flow of current using a magnetic field, the magnetic field cannot be constant but must be changing. This is what we called “Faraday’s Law” or the first law of electromagnetic induction.


 


ELECTRICITY

It is a form of energy or the flow of electrons. When the balancing force between protons and electrons by an outside force, an atom may gain or lose an electron. When electrons are lost from an atom, the free movement of these electrons constitutes an electric current. Unlike charges attract each other and like charges repel each other.

Electricity is a basic part of nature and it is one of our most widely used forms of energy. We get electricity, which is a secondary energy source, from the conversion of other sources of energy, like coal, natural gas, nuclear power plant, hydrothermal plant, geothermal plant, and other natural resources, which are called primary sources. Electricity is a controllable and convenient form of energy used in the applications of heat, light, and power.

Electricity is generated through an electric generator which is a device for converting mechanical energy into electrical energy. The process is based on the relationship between magnetism and electricity. When a wire or any other electrically conductive material across a magnetic field, an electric current occurs in the wire. This current is what is used for electric power. An electric utility power station uses either a turbine, engine, water wheel, or another similar machine to drive an electric generator. Examples are steam turbines, gas combustion turbines, water turbines, and wind turbines to generate electricity

TYPES  OF ELECTRICITY:

1. ELECTROSTATICS – the study of fixed or stationary electrical charges.

2. ELECTRODYNAMICS – the study of electrostatic charges in motion.

MAGNETISM

It is defined as an attractive and repulsive phenomenon produced by a moving electric charge. The affected region around a moving charge consists of both an electric field and a magnetic field. An example is a bar magnet, which is attracted to a magnetic field and can attract or repel other magnets. The word “magnet” comes from the Greek words magnethis lithos, which means “Magnesian stone” or lodestone.

Magnetism arises from the electromagnetic force of a moving electric charge. A magnet has an invisible magnetic field surrounding it and two ends called poles. The north pole points towards Earth’s north magnetic field. The south pole points toward the Earth’s south magnetic field. The north pole of a magnet is attracted to the south pole of any other magnet and repelled by the north pole of another magnet. Cutting a magnet forms two new magnets, each with north and south poles. Some living organisms detect and use magnetic fields. The ability to sense a magnetic field is called magnetoception. Examples of creatures capable of magnetoception include bacteria, mollusks, arthropods, and birds.

Like magnetic poles, repel each other. Unlike magnetic poles attract each other. The imaginary lines of the magnetic field leave the north pole of a magnet and return to the south pole.

Classification of Magnets:

1.  Naturally occurring magnets

     The best example of a natural magnet is the earth itself. The earth has a magnetic has a magnetic field because it spins on an axis. Lodestone or magnetite in the earth exhibits strong magnetism.

2.  Artificially induced permanent magnets

      They are available in many sizes and shapes but principally as bar or horse-shoe-shaped magnets usually made of iron. A compass is a prime example of an artificial magnet. They are produced by charging them in the field of an electromagnet.  It does not necessarily stay permanent. It can be destroyed by heating or hitting it with a hammer.

3. Electromagnets

     It consist of wire wrapped around an iron core. When an electric current is conducted through the wire, a magnetic field is created. The intensity of the magnetic field is proportional to the electric current.

Classification of matter according to interaction with magnetism:

1. Dimagnetic materials – materials that are unaffected when brought into a magnetic field. Exs. are wood, glass,, and plastic.

2. Ferromagnetic materials – materials that are strongly attracted by a magnet. Exs. are iron, cobalt, and nickel. Rare-earth ceramics are stronger magnets.

3. Paramagnetic materials – materials that are slightly attracted to a magnet  and loosely influenced by an external magnetic field. It lies between ferromagnetic and nonmagnetic. Contrast agents, such as gadolinium used in MRI is an for magnetism example of paramagnetic material.

The SI unit used in magnetism is Tesla(T) or Gauss(G)

1 T = 10,000 G

Scientists involved in the development of elctricity:

Alessandro Volta – an Italian physicist , invented  the battery known as the voltaic pile. He uses two zinc and copper plates which produces a feeble electric current.

Hans Oersted – a Danish physicist , who was the first one to link electricity and magnetism.

Michael Faraday – a self-educated British experimenter, developed the laws of electromagnetic induction also known as the “Faraday's Law”.

Thomas  A. Edison – an American inventor, developed the  direct current for incandescent light bulb.

Nikola Tesla – a Serbian-American inventor, developed the alternating current.

George Westinghouse – an American  inventor who was chiefly responsible for the adoption of alternating current  for electric power transmission.

ELECTROMAGNETISM

It is a branch of physics that involves the study of electromagnetic force(EMF) which occur with electrically charged particle.

TYPES OF RADIATION:

1. PARTICULATE RADIATION

  •  ionizing radiation
  • with mass and/or charge
  • travels at the speed of light in free space
  •  originate in the nucleus of an atom
  • exs. alpha, beta and neutron particles

2. NON-PARTICULATE RADIATION/ELECTROMAGNETIC RADIATION

  • some are ionizing others are non-ionizing radiation 
  • no mass and/or charge
  • radiation in the form of waves but behaves like a photon(particles)
  • travels at the speed of light in free space.

Speed of light in free space = c = 186, 282 miles/second = 300,000 km/sec = 3 X 10 8 m/sec

TYPES OF ELECTROMAGNETIC(EM) RADIATION:

1. IONIZING RADIATION - radiation capable of removing electrons from the
      orbital shell of an atom.

2. NON-IONIZING RADIATION- radiation that are not capable of removing
      electrons from the orbital shell of an atom.

IONIZATION - is the process of removal of electrons from the orbital of an atom.

EXCITATION - is the temporary removal of electrons from the orbital of an atom or vibration of one or more electrons in the orbital shell.


IONIZATION


 EXCITATION

 

TYPES OF IONIZING ELECTROMAGNETIC RADIATION:

1. X-RAY
    - ionizing electromagnetic radiation.
    - no mass or charge.
    - travels at the speed of light in free space.
    - produced outside the nucleus of an atom(electron cloud).

2. GAMMA RAY
    - ionizing electromagnetic radiation.
    - no mass or charge.
    - travels at the speed of light in free space.
    - emitted inside the nucleus of an atom.

NOTE: X-RAYS AND GAMMA RAYS ARE THE SAME IN CHARACTERISTICS EXCEPT THEIR ORIGIN.

TYPES OF EM RADIATION ACCORDING TO ITS WAVELENGTH (from the shortest to the longest wavelength):

1. gamma-ray (shortest)
2. x-ray
3. ultraviolet ray
4. visible light
5. infra-red ray
6. microwave
7. radio waves (longest)

WAVELENGTH - is the distance between two succeeding wave crests or throughs. The shorter the wavelength, the greater the energy or vice versa. It also refers to as the quality of radiation or the penetrating capability of radiation.




ALPHA PARTICLES 

  • positively charged helium nuclei
  • can be deflected by magnetic and electric fields
  • show small penetration 
  • produces great ionization

BETA PARTICLES

  • electrons(β+ and β-)
  • can be deflected by electric and magnetic fields
  • show more penetration than alpha  
  • produces less ionization than alpha 

GAMMA RAYS/X-RAYS 

  • highly penetrating electromagnetic radiation
  • can not be deflected by magnetic and electric fields 
  • produces little ionization
  • no mass and/or charge

NEUTRON PARTICLES 

  • highly penetrating particulate radiation
  • can be deflected by magnetic and electric fields 
  • produces great ionization
  • with mass but no charge


SYNTHESIS

Radiation is the energy emitted and transferred through matter and/or space in the form of waves(photons) or particles. There are two general classification of radiation namely, ionizing and non-ionizing radiation. Ionizing radiation are radiation capable of removing/ejecting electrons from the orbital shell of an atom. While non-ionizing radiation are not capable of removing/ejecting electrons from the orbital shell of an atom. It is a relatively low energy radiation that does not have energy to ionize atoms or molecules. It’s located at the low end of the electromagnetic spectrum. Non-ionizing radiation sources include radio waves, microwaves, visible light, infrared radiation, lasers and power lines.

Ionizing radiation has sufficient energy to produce ions in matter at the molecular level. If that matter is a human significant damage can result including damage to DNA and other molecules or cells. These types of radiation are still use in medical for diagnostic and therapeutic purposes. The beneficial advantage of ionizing radiation always outweighs the harmful effects that may cause clinical human risks.

Although considered less dangerous than ionizing radiation, overexposure to non-ionizing radiation can cause health issues. Different biological effects are observed for different types of non-ionizing radiation. International agencies state that there could be some risk from non-ionizing radiation to humans but it was not consistent with observed incidence. One thing that is definite, prolong and repeated exposure to non-ionizing radiation would definitely yield biological effects to humans. Therefore, strict compliance on how to properly use equipments with emission of non-ionizing radiation must be strictly be followed.

References:

  • Callaway, W.V. & Tolley Gurley L. (2018). Introduction to Radiologic Technology, 8th edition. Singapore. Mosby Elsevier
  • Bushong, S. (2017). Radiologic Science for Technologist, 11th Edition. Mosby Elsevier Inc.
  • http://www.astrosurf.com/luxorion/Radio/spectrum-radiation.png
  • https://encrypted-tbn0.gstatic.com/images
  • https://skullsinthestars.files.wordpress.com/2011/04/oerstedsetup1.jpg?w=58

name: LESSON  4 TOPICS:1. Historical intr...
intro:
LESSON  4 TOPICS:
1. Historical introduction
2. X-ray production
3. Conditions necessary for x-ray production
4. Common Terms related to the x-ray beam


TOPIC LEARNING OUTCOMES: 
After the end of the lesson, the student should be able to:
1. Discuss the historical development of the discovery of x-ray
2. Describe the conditions necessary to produce x-radiation
3. Identify the x-ray beam produced in the x-ray machine
4. Compare the production of bremsstrahlung and characteristic radiation


INTRODUCTION
November 8, 1895 was the date when medicine will never be the same again. A German physicist with the name of Wilhelm Conrad Röntgen accidentally discovered x-ray in his laboratory at Wurzburg, Germany. He was experimenting on the flow of electrons inside the crookes tube. He covered the tube with black paper so that no light would pass through outside, then turn off all the lights in his laboratory and switch on the cathode tube. Accidentally, a barium platinocyanide glass plate was below the tube and he noticed the glow of light coming from it. He called this light “X” light meaning unknown until it became known as x-ray. Through series of experimentation, Roentgen found that the mysterious light would pass through most materials and can see what is inside. He realized then that x-rays would pass through human tissue and can visualize the bones and other organs or tissues through photography. X-rays soon became an important diagnostic tool in medicine, allowing doctors to see inside the human body for the first time without surgery. Scientists were quick to realize the beneficial effects of x-ray but slowly not knowing the harmful biological effects. Before they thought it was harmless until harmful cases such as skin burns, cataract and cancer were reported. In honor of his work, Roentgen received the first Nobel Prize in Physics in 1901. Today, x-ray is widely used in medical diagnosis, cancer treatment, food sterilization and airport surveillance system.   





     





Click the video to watch how x-rays discovered by Wilhelm C. Roentgen






http:// 

CONCEPTS

X-RAY PRODUCTION
X-ray tube is an evacuated glass envelope compose of an anode and cathode where x-rays are produced. The cathode is the negative side where the cloud of electrons are produced. It has a focusing cup so as not to scatter the electrons produced or simply to focus the electrons to a precise hitting area. The anode is the positive side with small area of the target called the focal spot which receives the accelerated electrons from the cathode. Therefore, x-rays are produced when high speed of electrons are suddenly stopped or decelerated. In the diagnostic x-ray tube, 99% heat and only 1% x-ray is produced.
 
Conditions Necessary for X-ray Production:
1. Source of electrons
    The source of electrons in the x-ray tube is the filament which when heated will produce electrons. The number of electrons would depend on the mAs given as a technical factor.
2. Acceleration of electrons
    Electrons can be accelerated by giving the necessary kVp. The higher the kVp the faster will be the acceleration of electrons from the filament to the target material.
3. Focusing the electrons
    Accelerating electrons coming from the cathode to the anode are electrically negative, the electron beam tends to spread out because of electrostatic repulsion.   
A focusing cup is negatively charged so that it condenses the electron beam to a small area of the anode.
4. Deceleration of electrons
    A target metal with high atomic number made of tungsten is required to decelerate or stop the high speed of electrons.
 
TYPES OF RADIATION PRODUCED IN THE X-RAY TUBE:
1. BREMSSTRAHLUNG RADIATION – radiation produced when high speed of electrons are suddenly stopped or decelerated. It comes from German words “bremsen and strahlung” which means “braking radiation” or “deceleration radiation”.
2. CHARACTERISTIC RADIATION – radiation produced when an outer shell electron jumps into inner shell.
3. PRIMARY RADIATION OR USEFUL BEAM – radiation coming out from the x-ray tube before hitting the patient.
4. REMNANT RADIATION – radiation beam exiting  from tissue and hitting the x-ray film.
5. LEAKAGE RADIATION –secondary  radiation emitted through the tube housing.
6. SCATTER RADIATION – radiation that during its passage through an object has been deviated in direction.
7. OFF-FOCUS/EXTRAFOCAL RADIATION -  produced by electrons impacting the anode outside the focal spot. This occurs when electrons striking the focal spot bounce off and are attracted back to the anode outside the focal spot region.


     

SYNTHESIS
The discovery of x-ray by Wilhelm Conrad Roentgen have revolutionized the field of medicine. It was even labeled a medical miracle because of its great significance as diagnostic tool in medicine which allows doctors to see images inside human body without undergoing surgery. Today, x-ray technology is an integral part of any healthcare facility. Its uses range from diagnosis to treatment of cancer.
 
In order to produce x-rays, certain conditions must be met. There must be source, acceleration, focusing and deceleration of electrons. Only 1% x-ray is produced in the x-ray tube and the rest is converted to heat (99%). X-rays are produced when accelerated electrons are suddenly decelerated.
 
There are many forms of radiation beam produced in the x-ray tube. The initial x-ray produced upon deceleration is called bremsstrahlung radiation. When the outer electrons jump into inner shell, another type of radiation is produced in the form of characteristic radiation. All x-rays coming out from the window of tube housing is called useful beam. X-ray beams that may escape in the housing is referred to as leakage radiation. Radiation that strikes the patient and deviated in directions is called scatter radiation and the x-ray beam that exits the patient and penetrate the image receptor is the remnant radiation.


References:

  • https://encrypted-tbn0.gstatic.com/images?q=tbn%3AANd9GcSns95sJXOmsGYmz07me7qd5_18-Kdu7R5T9w&usqp=CAU
  • https://www.slideshare.net/airwave12/the-x-ray-tub  
  • https://radiologykey.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/B9780323069748100050_f05-02-9780323069748.jpg

  • Callaway, W.V. & tolley Gurley L. (2018). Introduction to Radiologic Technology, 8th edition. Singapore. Mosby Elesevier

  • Bushong, S. (2017). Radiologic Science for Technologist, 11th Edition. Mosby Elsevier Inc.

  • https://youtu.be/MtPMIJuWeas

LESSON  5 TOPICS:
1.  Introduction
2.  Quantum nature of electromagnetic wave
3.  Characteristics of electromagnetic radiation

TOPIC LEARNING OUTCOMES:
 
After the end of the lesson, the student should be able to:
1.  Understand the quantum nature of electromagnetic wave
2.  Describe the wavelength and frequency and how they are related to velocity
3.  Explain and calculate using formulas the relationship of energy, wavelength and frequency 


INTRODUCTION

    

The word quantum comes from  the Latin word “quantus”, which means  “how much” or “amount or quantity”.  It means the smallest possible discrete unit of any physical property such as energy or matter. Max Plank, a German theoretical physicist discovered the energy of quanta(plural of quantum). This is now known as the quantum mechanics(Quantum Theory of Mechanics) which is the branch of physics which pertains to anything that is very small. It states that the photon energy is directly proportional to the photon frequency. While the famous  Albert Einstein’s theory of relativity is the scientific explanation of the relationship between space and time in a large scale.  It also states that matter can be transformed into energy or vice versa. There are two theories of relativity, special and general relativity. In special relativity it relates that motion is always relative, meaning the motion of one thing is always relative to the motion of everything else. For example, an apple in outer space, one can not tell if it’s moving or not but if you put another fruit, let’s say watermelon, one could probably see whether it is getting closer or further away from each other.  Then one can conclude that one of the fruits is moving or not. While general relativity says that space-time is like a big trampoline. Imagine taking a big trampoline, and putting a heavy bowling ball on it. The bowling ball would make a dip in the trampoline and make the trampoline bend down.
Planck and Einstein showed that electromagnetic (EM) radiation behaves as if its energy is carried at the nanoscale in small bundles(quanta), or large scale in space of energy with wave/particle dual-like characteristics. The behavior of EM radiation in its interactions with matter is, in fact, where this quantum nature is most clearly revealed.

CONCEPTS

Velocity - is the speed of something in a given direction.

Distance - amount of space between two things, points, lines or the state of being apart in space of one thing from another.
Time - is the ongoing sequence of events taking place in the past, present and future.

V = d/t
where V = velocity
            d = distance
             t = time


CHARACTERISTICS OF ELECTROMAGNETIC RADIATION(WAVE PARAMETERS)
 
1.  WAVELENGTH(λ)   
   It refers  to the distance between two successive wave crests or throughs.
 
         1 Å     = 10 -10 m            Å   = angstrom
         1 nm = 10 -9 m          nm = nanometer
         1 m   = 1,000 mm
         1 m   = 100 cms.

2. FREQUENCY(υ)
    It refers  to the number of waves passing a particular point in a unit of time.

    1 Hz     = 1 cycle/s = 1 1/s              Hz = hertz
    1 kHz   = 1,000 Hz
    1 MHz = 1,000,000 Hz
 
3. VELOCITY(V)
    It refers  to the distance travelled by EM radiation per unit time.

    - speed of EM radiation in a vacuum or   
       free space = 3 x 108 m/s
                            = 3 x 1010 cm/s
                            = 300,000 km/s
                            = 186,000 mi/s

NOTE:
      For all types of electromagnetic radiation, frequency is inversely proportional to wavelength. As the frequency increases, the wavelength decreases.





QUANTUM NATURE OF ELECTROMAGNETIC WAVE

PLANCK’S QUANTUM THEORY (QUANTUM THEORY OF MECHANICS)
It states that the photon energy is directly proportional to the photon frequency.

              E = hυ
where:  E = energy in eV
              h = Planck’s constant
                 = 4.15 X 10-15 eV·s
                 = 4.13 X 10-18 keV·s
                 = 6.62 X 10-34 J·s
              υ = frequency in Hz
              J = joule
              J = 6.24 X 1018 eV
            1 J = 1 kg.m2/s2
 
THEORY OF RELATIVITY
  It states that matter can be transformed into energy or vice versa.

              E = mc2
where:  E = energy in eV
              m = mass of a particle in kg.                
              c = speed of light
                  = 3 x 108 m/s
                  = 3 x 1010 cm/s
                  = 300,000 km/s
                  = 186,000 mi/s

SYNTHESIS
The purpose of science or radiation physics is to understand the world around us as well as the universe. The theory of relativity is an accurate description of nature at the cosmic levels while quantum mechanics is accurate at microscopic or atomic levels. The theory of relativity accounts for gravity, the planetary system, galaxies, expanding and collapsing universe. The quantum mechanics on the other hand, explains the events in sub-atomic particles of nature. These two theories explain the gravitation, electromagnetism, the weak interaction, and the strong interaction which is known as the four fundamental forces of nature.
Common to these two theories is the electromagnetic forces wave parameters that can be represented by precise calculations by means of formula. Electromagnetism and gravity has similar things in terms of velocity, wavelength, frequency, mass and energy. For all types of radiation, frequency is directly proportional to velocity, velocity is also proportional to wavelength while frequency is inversely proportional to wavelength. The small amount of mass of particle can be converted to a great amount of energy. And extremely high energy can be transformed to create sub-atomic particle. This is what the two theories in electromagnetic radiation is all about.

References:
  • Callaway, W.V. & Tolley Gurley L. (2018). Introduction to Radiologic Technology, 8th edition. Singapore. Mosby Elsevier
  • Bushong, S. (2017). Radiologic Science for Technologist, 11th Edition. Mosby Elsevier Inc.
  • https://scx1.b-cdn.net/csz/news/800/2019/bomb.jpg
  • https://scx1.b-cdn.net/csz/news/800/2019/3-quantumphysi.jpg

LESSON  6 TOPICS:

1.  Introduction

2.  Radiation Quantities

3.  Radiation Units

TOPIC LEARNING OUTCOMES: 

After the end of the lesson, the student should be able to: 

1. Define radiation and radioactivity units of measurement

2. Describe the importance of radiation units in detection and measurement of exposure to surrounding areas and body tissues

3. Perform calculations of radiation units from old to international system  (SI)

INTRODUCTION

The five human senses are not capable of detecting radiation, especially harmful ionizing radiation. There are various instruments that are available for detecting and measuring radiation with corresponding units or quantities. Recommendations regarding dosimetric quantities and units in radiation protection dosimetry are set forth by the International Commission on Radiation Units and Measurements (ICRU). The recommendations on the practical application of these quantities in radiation protection are established by the International Commission on Radiological Protection (ICRP). The operational quantities are defined for practical measurements both for area and individual monitoring. In radiation protection radiation should be monitored daily, weekly, monthly and/or annually.

CONCEPTS

RADIATION QUANTITIES AND UNITS:

1. EXPOSURE (X)

  •   It is the charged liberated by ionizing radiation (low-energy photons) per unit mass of air.
  • The old unit for radiation exposure or intensity in air is Roentgen(R).
  • The S.I. (Systeme Internationale) unit is coulomb per kilogram (c/kg)

Note:

Exposure units are an accurate measure only for photon energies between 1 keV and 1,000 keV (1 MeV).
The unit for exposure rate in S.I. unit is coulomb per kilogram.second.
(c/kg.s or c.{kg.s}-1)

 2. ABSORBED DOSE

  • It is the energy deposited by ionizing per unit mass of irradiated material.
  • The old unit for radiation absorbed dose is Rad.
  • The S.I. unit is Gray (Gy).

3.  KERMA ( Kinetic Energy Released per unit Mass)

  • It is the kinetic energy of charged ionizing particles liberated per unit mass of the specified material by uncharged ionizing particles.
  • The common derived unit of kerma is joule per kilogram (J/kg or J.kg -1) with the special name Gray (Gy).
  • The unit of kerma rate is Gray per second (Gy/s or Gy.s-1).
  • Air kerma and tissue kerma differ by less than 10%.

NOTE:
      The difference between absorbed dose and kerma lies in the fact that kerma measures all the energy transferred to charged particles by uncharged particles.

4. DOSE EQUIVALENT

  •   It is used to express the amount of exposures received by a radiation worker.
  • The old unit is REM (roentgen equivalent man).
  • The S.I. unit is Sievert (Sv). 

5.  ACTIVITY (A)

  • It is the disintegration of atoms per unit of time by a radioactive material.
  • The old unit is Curie (Ci).
  • The S.I. unit is Becquerel (Bq)

NOTE:
        In diagnostic radiology wherein x-ray is used, it is considered to assume 1 R = 1 Rad = 1 Rem or 2.58 X 10-4 c/kg = 0.01 Gy = 0.01 Sv. But with other types of radiation this generalization is not true.

RADIATION UNITS:

1. ROENTGEN(R)
    - old unit used of radiation exposure or intensity in       
      air.
    - the S.I. unit is coulomb per kilogram(c/kg)
    - 1 R = 2.58 X 10-4 c/kg
    - 1 c/kg = 3876 R

2. RAD
    - old unit of radiation absorbed dose.
    - the S.I. unit is Gray(Gy)
    - 1 Rad = 100 ergs/gram
    - 1 Rad = 1 X 10-2 Gy = 0.01 Gy
    - 1 Gy = 100 Rad

3. REM
    - roentgen equivalent man
    - the old unit of dose equivalent or occupational
      exposure.
    - the S.I. unit is Sievert(Sv)
    - 1 Rem = 1 x 10-2 Sv = 0.01 Sv
    - 1 Sv = 100 Rem

4. CURIE(Ci)
    - the old unit of the quantity of radioactive material.
    - the S.I. unit is Becquerel(Bq)
    - 1 Ci = 3.7 X 1010 Bq
    - 1 Bq = 1dps
    - 1 Bq = 3.7 X 1010 dps

SYNTHESIS

There are many different quantities and units used to determine the amount or quantity of radiation. The selection of the most appropriate radiation quantities or units depend on the types of radiation and its application. Understanding the various quantities and units is one way of gaining sufficient knowledge of its usage. Old or conventional units in many countries are being replaced with the International System(SI) units. It is for this reason that it is useful reference for the conversion of one system of units to another. It is important to fully understand the radiation quantities and units for determination of radiation present in certain areas and radiation dose delivered to patients or radiation workers.

These are the following conversion units that are commonly used in radiation measuring principles.

1 R = 2.58 X 10-4 c/kg

1 Rad = 0.01 Gy

1 Rem = 0.01 Sv

1 Ci = 3.7 X 1010 Bq

1 Rad = 1,000 mRad

1 Gy = 100 cGy

1 Sv = 1,000,000 μSv = 1 x  10^6 μSv

1 MBq = 1,000,000 Bq = 1 X 10^6 Bq

1 GBq = 1,000,000,000 Bq = 1 X 10^9 Bq

1 Ci = 1,000 mCi

References:

  • Radiologic Science for Technologist, 11th edition, Mosby Elsevier, Inc.
  • Practical Radiation Protection and Applied Radiobiology, S. Dowd, 2nd Edition, 2016

name:
LESSON 7 AND 8 TOPICS:
1. Introduction
2. Ra...
intro:
LESSON 7 AND 8 TOPICS:

1. Introduction

2. Radiation Interaction with Matter

3. Coherent Scattering 

4. Compton Scattering

5. Photoelectric Effect

6. Pair Production

7. Photodisintegration

TOPIC LEARNING OUTCOMES: 

After the end of the lesson, the student should be able to: 

1. Explain the processes of ionization and excitation in relation with x-ray interaction with matter.

2. Discuss the clinical significance of x-ray interactions with matter in diagnostic imaging and therapeutic settings.

INTRODUCTION

The interaction of radiation with matter is more complex because it undergoes five processes. Some of the x-rays will be absorbed, and some scattered and others will be transmitted. An x‐ray beam that passes through a medium is likely to undergo absorption, scatter, or penetration. The first two processes contribute to x‐ray beam attenuation. How much of the beam gets attenuated depends on which interaction process dominates. This in turn depends on the incident photon energy and the atomic composition. 

CONCEPTS

Definition of terms:

IONIZATION - the process of removing of electrons from the orbital of an atom

EXCITATION - the process of temporary removal of electrons from the orbital of an atom or vibration of the electrons of the atom.

SCATTER RADIATION – radiation that during its passage through an object has been deviated in direction.

CHARACTERISTIC RADIATION – radiation produced when an outer shell electron jumps into inner shell.

BREMSSTRAHLUNG RADIATION – radiation produced when high speed of electrons are suddenly stopped or decelerated. 

POSITRON - positively charged electron.

WAVELENGHT - distance between two succeeding wave crests.


RADIATION(X-RAY) INTERACTION WITH MATTER IN ATOMIC LEVEL:

1. Classical or Coherent Scattering

    a. Thompson Scattering

    b. Rayleigh Scattering

2. Compton Effect or Incoherent Scattering

3. Photoelectric Effect

4. Pair Production

5. Photodisintegration

I. CLASSICAL OR COHERENT SCATTERING

  • the incident photon interacts with a target atom, causing it to become excited
  • the incident photon wavelength(λ) equals the excess energy photon wavelength(λ’)
  • undergoes a change in direction without a change in wavelength
  • does not cause ionization, it only cause excitation
  • the target atom releases the excess energy as secondary or scatter radiation
  • it causes film fog
  • it occurs below 10 keV

TYPES OF COHERENT SCATTERING:

1. THOMPSON SCATTERING    

- a single electron is involved in the interaction.

2. RAYLEIGH SCATTERING

- results from a cooperative interaction with all the electrons of an atom.



II. COMPTON EFFECT/INCOHERENT SCATTERING   

  • an interaction of x-ray with outer-shell electron that not only scatters the photon but reduces its energy and ionizes the atom as well
  • produces secondary or scatter radiation
  • causes film fog
  • occurs in moderate energy x-rays




Compton effect yields three products:

        1. an ion pair

        2. a positive atom

        3. a negative electron(recoil electron)

III. PHOTOELECTRIC EFFECT

  • undergo ionizing interaction with inner shell electron of the target atom, so that the photon is not scatter but totally absorbed
  • also called photon-absorption interaction
  • can not occur unless the incident photon has energy equal to or greater than the electron binding energy of the atom

ELECTRON BINDING ENERGY

  • it is the strength of attachment of electron to the nucleus
  • the closer an electron to the nucleus, the more tightly it is bound
  • the greater the total no. of electrons in an atom, the more  tightly each is bound
  • it takes more energy to ionize a large atom than a small atom




Photoelectric effect yields three products:

        1. a characteristic radiation

        2. a negative ion(photoelectron)

        3. a positive ion(an atom deficient of    

            one electron)

IV. PAIR PRODUCTION

  • it occurs if an incident photon has sufficient energy and may escape interaction with the electron cloud and come close enough to the nucleus of the target atom to come under the influence of the nuclear force(electrostatic) field
  • the interaction between the incident photon and the nuclear force field causes the photon to disappear and in its place appear two electrons, one positively charged called positron and one negatively charged(negatron)
  • the incident photon must have an energy of at least 1.02 MeV



V. PHOTODISINTEGRATION

  • it occurs with high-energy photons which escape interaction with electrons(electron cloud) and the nuclear electrostatic field and be absorbed directly by the nucleus
  • the nucleus is raised to an excited state and instantaneously emits a nucleon or other nuclear fragment
  • it occurs with energy above 10 MeV



CLINICAL APPLICATIONS Of X-RAY INTERACTION WITH MATTER IN RADIOLOGY

        INTERACTION                                         APPLICATIONS

1. Coherent Scattering                     No application(low energy)

2. Compton Scattering                    Diagnostic radiology

3. Photoelectric Effect                      Diagnostic radiology

4. Pair Production                             Therapeutic radiology

5. Photodisintegration                     Therapeutic radiology

SYNTHESIS

Interaction of radiation with matter results in the transfer of energy to the patient and surrounding materials, this leads to ionization and excitation. Whether the incident photon has the lowest energy in kilo-electron volts or the highest in terms of mega-electron volt, the interaction will start from the excitation of electrons all the way to the ionization of the particles in the nucleus of an atom. The Compton and Photoelectric effects are two major forms of interaction of radiation with matter which are of imaging importance in radiology. The classical scattering yields no significance because of very low energy. While pair production and photodisintegration are both clinically useful in radiotherapy applications. Pair production is used in positron emission tomography(PET) for nuclear imaging and therapy while photodisintegration because of its extremely high energy is utilize in treating cancer tumors. In diagnostic radiology, the quality of the radiographic image and the radiation dose of the patient will entirely depend upon the Compton and photoelectric effects.

References:

  • Radiologic Science for Technologist, 11th edition, Mosby Elsevier, Inc.
  • Practical Radiation Protection and Applied Radiobiology, S. Dowd, 2nd Edition, 2016

  • https://radiologykey.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/B9780323083225000038_f03-01-9780323083225.jpg

  • https://slideplayer.com/slide/7610527/25/images/15/Classical+%28Coherent%29+Scattering.jpg
  • https://slideplayer.com/slide/7610527/

name: LESSON 1 TOPICS:1. Introduction2. Origin...
intro:
LESSON 1 TOPICS:

1. Introduction

2. Origin and history of medical ethics

3. Nature of ethics

4. Basic group of values

TOPIC LEARNING OUTCOMES:

After the end of the lesson, the student should be able to:

1. Discuss the origins of medical ethics

2. Understand the nature of ethics

3. Describe ethical values related to healthcare

INTRODUCTION


Allied health professionals including radiologic technologists must practice proper decorum both in the workplace and in the community. There are responsibilities to be carried out by healthcare professionals in terms of legal and ethical issues in the daily work routine. Legal and ethical concerns influence the way radiologic technologists perform x-ray procedures, interact with patients and colleagues, and even dress codes. Professional ethics in imaging technology implies a sense of responsibility and accountability. Treating all patients with the utmost respect and maintaining their dignity while still providing specific needs. High-quality medical care should always include patient’s rights to privacy and confidentiality. The key component of successful delivery of medical care is not only the quality of services but the professional conduct imposed by all healthcare personnel. 

CONCEPTS

ORIGIN AND HISTORY OF MEDICAL ETHICS

History of medical ethics, from Hippocrates to the present day

400 BC: HIPPOCRATIC OATH

 Written by Greek physician Hippocrates, the Hippocratic Oath is a code of ethical principles for doctors and their students. The phrase “first, do no harm” is often incorrectly attributed to it. The oath was first used in a medical school graduation ceremony at the University of Whittenberg in 1508, although this practice died out in the early 20th century.

400 AD: FORMULA COMITIS ARCHIATRORUM

The Formula Comitis Archiatrorum is credited to Magnus Aurelius Cassiodorus, and was written during the reign of the Ostrogothic King Theodoric. It laid out a code of conduct for physicians to align their lives and medical practice with.

800 AD: ETHICS OF THE PHYSICIAN

Ethics of the Physician was penned by Ishāq bin Ali al-Rohawi, and is the first medical ethics book in Arab medicine. It contains the first documented description of the peer review process.

1794: THOMAS PERCIVAL

In 1794, Thomas Percival created one of the first modern codes of medical ethics. Percival’s medical ethics largely influenced the American Medical Association code, which was adopted in 1847.

1847: AMERICAN MEDICAL ASSOCIATION

In 1847 the American Medical Association was founded and drafted its first code of medical ethics, largely based on the writings of Thomas Percival.

1865: AN INTRODUCTION TO THE STUDY OF EXPERIMENTAL MEDICINE

An Introduction to the Study of Experimental Medicine was written by French physiologist Claude Bernard. Bernard’s aim in the Introduction was to demonstrate that medicine, in order to progress, must be founded on experimental physiology.

1927: BIOETHICS & FRITZ JHAR

The term "bioethics" was first coined by Fritz Jhar in the scholarly article “Bioethics: A Panorama of the Human Being's Ethical Relations with Animals and Plants” in German journal Kosmos.

1947: THE NUREMBERG CODE

The Nuremberg Code for research on human subjects was formulated and adopted by judges during “The Doctors’ Trial”. Nazi doctors were accused, and found guilty of, shocking crimes against humanity. The first rule of the Nuremberg Code is: “The voluntary consent of the human subject is absolutely essential”.

1951: HENRIETTA LACKS AND HELA CELLS

In 1951, a young black woman named Henrietta Lacks had a piece of her cancerous tumour extracted without her knowledge. The cells from Henrietta’s cervical tumour, known as HeLa cells, were the first human cell line to survive in-vitro and have since been immortalised for testing new medical treatments, most notably the Polio vaccine. However, the case raised serious concerns surrounding the lack of informed consent and taking samples from living patients.

1964: THE HELSINKI DECLARATION

The Helsinki Declaration, a set of ethical principles for research on human subjects, was developed by the World Medical Association in 1964. It has been revised several times since, most recently in 2013.

1967: THE ABORTION ACT

The Abortion Act was passed in the UK after widespread evidence that unsafe illegal abortion can often result in maternal mortality/morbidity. The Act made abortion legal in all of Great Britain (but not Northern Ireland) up until a gestational period of 24 weeks.

1973: ROE VS. WADE

In 1973 the US Supreme Court voted in favour of Jane Roe in the case of Roe vs. Wade. The Court ruled 7-2 that access to safe abortion is a fundamental right. The arguments contained within this court case are still prominent topics of debate to this day.

1978: LOUISE JOY BROWN

Louise Joy Brown was born in Oldham, UK in 1978. She was the first baby to be born as a result of IVF.

1979: THE BELLMONT REPORT

In 1974, American Congress established the National Commission for the Protection of Human Subjects of Biomedical and Behavioural Research. In 1979, this National Commission published the The Belmont Report, which identified three principles essential to the ethical conduct of research with humans: respect for persons, beneficence, and justice.

1984: THE WARNOCK REPORT

The Report of the Committee of Inquiry into Human Fertilisation and Embryology, commonly called The Warnock Report was published as a result of a UK governmental inquiry into the social impacts of infertility treatment and embryological research

1990: TERRI SCHIAVO

In February 1990, Terri Schiavo collapsed at home after suffering a full cardiac arrest. The oxygen supply to her brain was cut off and, as a result, she entered a "persistive vegetative state" from which she would never wake. For the next 10 years, Terri's husband would fight various legal battles against her parents, and eventually the state of Florida, to enable her feeding tube to be removed. The situation sparked an enduring national debate over end-of-life care and the right to die.

2006: THE ASSISTED DYING BILL

The Assisted Dying Bill was blocked by the House of Lords in 2007. The bill would have only allowed those of sound mind and with less than six months to live to seek assisted death.

2008: THE HUMAN FERTILISATION & EMBRYOLOGY ACT

The Human Fertilisation & Embryology Act updated and revised The Human Fertilisation and Embryology Act of 1990 in the UK, and implemented key provisions within IVF and human reproduction. These include the banning of sex selection for non-medical purposes and that all human embryos are subject to regulation.

2008: THE GENETIC INFORMATION NON-DISCRIMINATION ACT

The Genetic Information Non-discrimination Act (GINA) was signed into law by President George W. Bush in April, 2008. It protects Americans from discrimination based on their genetic information, and is supposed to allow individuals to reap the benefits of personalised medicine without  fearing negative consequences.

2016: BIG PHARMA

In 2016 there was widespread outrage in the US as pharmaceutical companies priced their medication at an all-time high. Protestors targeted companies such as Gilead Sciences, which sold its Hepatitis C drug Sovaldi at $1,000-per-pill. It generated many conversations about the morality of viewing healthcare as potentially highly profitable business – to the detriment of the patient.

2017: CHARLIE GARD

Charlie Gard was born in the UK with an exceedingly rare inherited disease - infantile onset encephalomyopathy mitochondrial DNA depletion syndrome (MDDS). The ensuing legal battle between Charlie's parents and his doctors over withdrawing life-support provoked passionate debate, with social media playing a dominant role to facilitate discussions around autonomy, end-of-life care, and parental rights.

Reference: https://blog.oup.com/2017/11/history-of-medical-ethics/

NATURE OF ETHICS

HIPPOCRATIC OATH

I will prescribe regimen for the good of my patients according to my ability and judgement and never do no harm to anyone. 

The Hippocratic Oath begins with the exhortation to “first, do no harm.”

The term ethics is used in three different but related ways, signifying a general pattern or "way of life, a set of rules of conduct or "moral code," and inquiry about ways of life and rules of conduct. In the first sense we speak of Buddhist or Christian ethics; in the second, we speak of professional ethics and of unethical behavior. In the third sense, ethics is a branch of philosophy that is frequently given the special name of metaethics. Philosophy in general, and ethical philosophy in particular, was invented by the Greeks.

Ethics was born of necessity when humans first realized that they required certain behaviors to get along as a group. As time passed, certain individuals were credited with providing bricks in the foundation of ethics. Ethics has continued to evolve with societal changes. This evolutionary process will be evident to the imaging professional as new technology is developed. Each new technology will provide new ethical dilemmas for the patient and the professional.

When did ethics begin and how did it originate? If one has in mind ethics proper—the systematic study of what is morally right and wrong—it is clear that ethics could have come into existence only when human beings started to reflect on the best way to live. This reflective stage emerged long after human societies had developed some kind of morality, usually in the form of customary standards of right and wrong conduct. The process of reflection tended to arise from such customs, even if in the end it may have found them wanting. Accordingly, ethics began with the introduction of the first moral codes.

Virtually every human society has some form of myth to explain the origin of morality. According to this view, ethics is not an independent field of study but rather a branch of theology. Plato considered this impossible and so held that there must be some standards of right or wrong that are independent of the likes and dislikes of the gods. Modern philosophers have generally accepted Plato’s argument because the alternative implies that if, for example, the gods had happened to approve of torturing children and to disapprove of helping one’s neighbors, then the torture would have been good and neighborliness bad. This link between morality and religion has been so firmly forged that it is still sometimes asserted that there can be no morality without religion.


ETHICS

It is defined as the system or code of conduct and morals advocated by a particular individual or group. It is a system of understanding determinations and motivations on individual conceptions of right and wrong. It is not determined by strict rules or rigid guidelines, and although it is relatively stable, it can change overtime.

BIOMEDICAL ETHICS

It is a branch of ethics dealing with dilemmas faced by medical professionals, patients, and their families and friends. It is also described as guidelines for activities and attitudes toward patients and peers. It suggests a standard of conduct that is expected of members of the profession.

VALUES

It is a quality or standard that is desirable or worthy of esteem itself. Values are expressed in behaviors, language, and the standards of conduct a person endorses or tries to maintain. A person’s daily experiences influence and guide the expression of values. Values clarification enables the individual to discover, analyze, and prioritize what he or she has. An individual should make choices only after careful consideration of the alternatives. The person should take pride in these choices and be willing to defend them. 

THREE BASIC GROUP OF VALUES

1. Personal values are the beliefs and attitudes held by individuals that provide a foundation for behavior and the way the individual experiences life. Ex. timeliness and organization. Religious convictions, family, political beliefs, education, life experiences, and culture influence the individual’s personal values.

2. Cultural values are values specific to a people or culture. An example is the cultural value of other country elderly people or the respect by the Arab community to women. 

3. Professional values are the general attributes prized by a professional group. It should be learning through the profession’s values, standards, and motivations by adhering to the code of ethics, formal instructions, and role modeling.

SYNTHESIS

Ethics is the study of acceptable conduct and moral judgment. Biomedical ethics is a branch of ethics that deals with the dilemmas encountered by medical professionals including radiologic technologists, patients, families, and their relatives and friends. High ethical standards must be the foundation of professional practice to ensure the recognition of the imaging technologist as a competent health care professional. Looking back on the historical timeline of biomedical ethics is a realization that there were various problems and dilemmas that were dealt with difficulties. The lesson of the past provides rules, procedures, and codes of ethics to consider the implications of our daily actions in solving ethical dilemmas. Professional and personal morality and responsibility are one of our roles as medical professionals in providing quality health care. 

REFERENCES:

  • https://blog.oup.com/2017/11/history-of-medical-ethics/
  • Ethical and Legal Issues for Imaging Professionals, D. Cook, 2nd Edition, 2017

name: LESSON 2 TOPICS:1. Introduction2.&n...
intro:
LESSON 2 TOPICS:

1. Introduction

2. Ethical School of thoughts

3. Ethical Models

TOPIC LEARNING OUTCOMES:

After the end of the lesson, the student should be able to:

1. Discuss aids to ethical problem solving

2. Understand the ethical school of thoughts

3. Identify the type of ethical model appropriate for specific ethical problem

INTRODUCTION

Ethics aims at the same thing but there are several basic ways to get there. If you prefer, each approach is like using different tools. Using the right tool for the right job makes it easier to do your work and increases the chances that you’ll wind up with a quality product. If you can grasp the basic ideas of each of the different approaches to ethics, you will be in a better position to make a sound ethical decision. Useful way to understand ethics is establishing school of thoughts for theories and models.

The three schools are consequentialism, deontology and virtue ethics. Each approach provides a different way to understand ethics. An analogy to your personal well being is this: What is the best way to achieve a healthy life? One is through good nutrition, another is through exercise, and a third is through a spiritual discipline, and yet another stresses public health measures. Each is vital but inadequate by itself. It is bringing these—and other—approaches together that you can live to the fullest.

Similarly, in ethics, no school answers all the problems raised by social living. In most cases, all three schools need to be considered in order to reach the best ethical decision. Finding ways to successfully deal with ethical conflicts is critical not only to the distressed patient, healthcare worker but also to healthcare facility striving to improve outcomes, since moral distress can adversely affect patient care and is associated with employee burnout and job turnover.  

CONCEPTS

ETHICAL SCHOOL OF THOUGHTS

Consequentialism, deontology and virtue ethics are ways of establishing a value hierarchy in ethical decisions. Each school of thought offers different guidelines for ethical problem solving. No one school is better than the others, imaging professionals must choose the one that best serves individual, professional, and institutional goals.

CONSEQUENTIALISM/TELEOLOGY/UTILITARIANISM

It bases decisions on the consequences or outcomes of a given act. It evaluates the good of an activity by assessing whether immediate harm is balanced with future benefit. For example in  radiotherapy , wherein large dose of radiation is given to the patient which may experience discomfort and side effects now but the the beneficial effect will be palliative cure for cancer. 

DEONTOLOGY

It bases decision making on individual motives and morals rather than consequences. It is therefore the opposite of teleology. It examines the significance of the actions themselves. For example, Jehovah Witness religious group refuse blood transfusions because they believe the act is morally wrong. Although they may be concerned about the consequences of this refusal, they are making the choice based on their religious beliefs regarding blood transfusion. Personal rules of right and wrong derived from individual actions, duties, relationships of all kinds, and society are used for reasoning and problem solving in the deontologic school of thought.

VIRTUE ETHICS

It focuses on the use of practical wisdom and moral character for emotional and intellectual problem solving. It incorporates the elements of teleology and deontology to provide a more holistic approach to solving ethical dilemmas. Careful analysis and consideration of consequences, rules established by society, and short-term effects play an important role in decision making. Virtue ethics lends itself to many situations in which imaging professionals may become involved. 

ETHICAL MODELS

Models for ethical decision making in healthcare broadly describe different types of interactions with patients. They provide frameworks for understanding expectations and responsibilities. Individual health care professionals must choose the model/s they feel are appropriate. Some models may work in certain situations and not in others. Each imaging professional will discover or develop the ethical problem-solving that works best for him or her.

ENGINEERING MODEL

It identifies the healthcare provider as a scientist concerned with facts and defines the patient as a condition or procedure, not a person. It tend to view the patient as a collection of body systems rather than as a whole. Under this model a radiologic technologist considers the patient a gastrointestinal or skull series, not an anxious human patient with emotional and psychological needs.

PATERNAL/PRIESTLY MODEL

The paternal or priestly model casts the caregiver in the omniscient, paternalistic role of making decisions for patients rather than with patients. For example is the imaging professional who dismisses the needs of the patients who want to know more about procedures by telling them not to worry, that everything will be fine. Those who subscribe to the priestly model generally believe they know best and tend to discount the patient’s feelings. 

COLLEGIAL MODEL

It describes a more cooperative method of providing healthcare for the patient. It involves sharing, trust, and the pursuit of common goals. An imaging professional who takes time to get to know the patient and works with the patient to reach a mutual understanding is working with the collegial model. This model may be helpful in addressing patients’ emotional needs and engaging their cooperation. However, it requires that healthcare professional have enough time to spend with the patient.

CONTRACTUAL MODEL 

It defines healthcare as a business relationship between the provider and patient. A contractual agreement serves as the guideline for decision making and provision of services. The patient and provider are seen as parties to a contract in which both side has obligations, right, and responsibilities. This model is exemplified in the informed consent. The imaging professional who explains an invasive procedure like CT-biopsy to a patient is involved in the contractual process.

 COVENANTAL MODEL

This model recognizes that many areas of healthcare are not always covered by a terse, businesslike contract. Instead, care is based in an agreement between the patient and healthcare provider, an agreement often grounded in traditional values and goals. These includes trust in professional’s integrity and confidence that the professional has the patient’s best interest in mind. Many imaging procedures require the patient to trust in the radiographer’s competence and professionalism.  It combines the covenantal and and contractual models to build a business relationship and implement shared goals and values. A person injured in an accident may ask to be taken to a specific hospital because of previous satisfaction with services received in its imaging department.


 

SYNTHESIS

To create a clear and cohesive approach to implementing a solution to an ethical problem, the ethical models are set in a way that it gives the healthcare workers proper decision making. While each situation may call for specific steps to come before others, this is a general process that individuals can use to approach ethical decision-making. Before a model can be utilized, we need to work through a set of steps to be sure what specific model is appropriate for any ethical disputes or problems.  These were the general standards used in creating a decision about how they should be dealt with properly. While this is not a standard model, it does reveal the underlying ideas to formulate principles for ethics through the combination of reasoning and intuition while forming and applying moral principles to an everyday circumstance where a question of ethics could be involved. Ethical models are still using by many healthcare personnel to determine how they deal with ethical issues. Many of these standards can lead to a cohesive ethical decision-making model.  Healthcare leaders have to develop ethical models that employees in their healthcare facility will be required to adhere to. This can help move the conversation toward using a model to decide when someone is in violation of ethic.  Application of any of the ethical model is far more than someone doing the right thing, it is many times tied to legal procedures and policies that if breached can put the healthcare facility in the midst of trouble.

REFERENCES:

  • https://www.elsevier.com/books/ethical-and-legal-issues-for-imaging-professionals/towsley-cook/978-0-323-04599-5

  • Ethical and Legal Issues for Imaging Professionals, D. Cook, 2nd Edition, 2017

name: LESSON 3 TOPICS:1. Introduction2.&n...
intro:
LESSON 3 TOPICS:

1. Introduction

2. Ethical Values

3. Professionalism and Etiquette

4. Medical Professionalism

TOPIC LEARNING OUTCOMES:

After the end of the lesson, the student should be able to:

1. Describe ethical values toward others.

2. Differentiate between professionalism and etiquette.

3. Explain the applications of medical professionalism for the welfare of the patient.

INTRODUCTION

Not all values are ethical values. Some values, such as efficiency, do not have an ethical component. Some ethical values involve qualities of an ethical self (such as honesty and integrity). Others describe positive and ethical behavior toward others, the environment and society. Ethical values by definition are positive and they often require that we stretch outside of our own interests to respect, protect, serve and help others. Our values define who we are and drive the choices we make. Don’t let your daily decisions be made on autopilot. Choose the ethical values that will guide your life and your leadership. ethics in professional practice program to assist in evolving solutions to ethical dilemmas encountered in professional practice.  If you don’t think you need to pay attention to the details when it comes to making your patients happy as well as healthy, think again. If ever there was a time to mind your medical manners, it’s now. 

Patient satisfaction is becoming a key phrase in healthcare. That is not to say that patient outcomes are no longer important. However, it is blatantly obvious that there is a direct correlation between how patients are treated personally and how they are treated clinically. 

Using good manners and following the rules of proper etiquette can make an incredible difference in how physicians and their staff are viewed by their patients. If patients feel valued by their physicians and have positive interactions with the staff, they are most likely to become longtime loyal customers. Yes, patients are customers, too.

CONCEPTS

ETHICAL VALUES

Ethical values can be translated into active language establishing standards or rules describing the kind of behavior an ethical person should and should not engage in. The following list of ethical values incorporate the characteristics and values that most people associate with ethical behavior. 

1. HONESTY. Ethical executives are honest and truthful in all their dealings and they do not deliberately mislead or deceive others by misrepresentations, overstatements, partial truths, selective omissions, or any other means.

2. INTEGRITY. Ethical executives demonstrate personal integrity and the courage of their convictions by doing what they think is right even when there is great pressure to do otherwise; they are principled, honorable and upright; they will fight for their beliefs. They will not sacrifice principle for expediency, be hypocritical, or unscrupulous. 

3. PROMISE-KEEPING & TRUSTWORTHINESS. Ethical executives are worthy of trust. They are candid and forthcoming in supplying relevant information and correcting misapprehensions of fact, and they make every reasonable effort to fulfill the letter and spirit of their promises and commitments. They do not interpret agreements in an unreasonably technical or legalistic manner in order to rationalize non-compliance or create justifications for escaping their commitments. 

4. LOYALTY. Ethical executives are worthy of trust, demonstrate fidelity and loyalty to persons and institutions by friendship in adversity, support and devotion to duty; they do not use or disclose information learned in confidence for personal advantage. They safeguard the ability to make independent professional judgments by scrupulously avoiding undue influences and conflicts of interest. They are loyal to their companies and colleagues and if they decide to accept other employment, they provide reasonable notice, respect the proprietary information of their former employer, and refuse to engage in any activities that take undue advantage of their previous positions. 

5. FAIRNESS. Ethical executives and fair and just in all dealings; they do not exercise power arbitrarily, and do not use overreaching nor indecent means to gain or maintain any advantage nor take undue advantage of another’s mistakes or difficulties. Fair persons manifest a commitment to justice, the equal treatment of individuals, tolerance for and acceptance of diversity, the they are open-minded; they are willing to admit they are wrong and, where appropriate, change their positions and beliefs. 

6. CONCERN FOR OTHERS. Ethical executives are caring, compassionate, benevolent and kind; they like the Golden Rule, help those in need, and seek to accomplish their business objectives in a manner that causes the least harm and the greatest positive good. 

7. RESPECT FOR OTHERS. Ethical executives demonstrate respect for the human dignity, autonomy, privacy, rights, and interests of all those who have a stake in their decisions; they are courteous and treat all people with equal respect and dignity regardless of sex, race or national origin. 

8. LAW ABIDING. Ethical executives abide by laws, rules and regulations relating to their business activities.

9. COMMITMENT TO EXCELLENCE. Ethical executives pursue excellence in performing their duties, are well informed and prepared, and constantly endeavor to increase their proficiency in all areas of responsibility. 

10. LEADERSHIP. Ethical executives are conscious of the responsibilities and opportunities of their position of leadership and seek to be positive ethical role models by their own conduct and by helping to create an environment in which principled reasoning and ethical decision making are highly prized.

11. REPUTATION AND MORALE. Ethical executives seek to protect and build the company’s good reputation and the morale of its employees by engaging in no conduct that might undermine respect and by taking whatever actions are necessary to correct or prevent inappropriate conduct of others.

12. ACCOUNTABILITY. Ethical executives acknowledge and accept personal accountability for the ethical quality of their decisions and omissions to themselves, their colleagues, their companies, and their communities. 

PROFESSIONALISM

Professionalism is the conduct, behavior and attitude of someone in a work or any environment such as healthcare facilities. A person doesn’t have to work in a specific profession to demonstrate the important qualities and characteristics of a professional.  Professionalism leads to workplace success, a strong professional reputation and a high level of work ethic and excellence. It is important to pursue professionalism recognizing that there are rights and responsibilities for healthcare workers who interact with patients on a daily basis.
