9. Adjust the rubber roller on the wash rack if needed.

10. Rinse and flush the tanks and circulation lines with warm water.

11. Refill your chemicals very carefully. Check to make sure that your recirculation pumps are running.

12. Let the processor developer temperature warm up to between 93-95 degrees Fahrenheit.

13. Run test films.

Quality assurance helps to ensure satisfactory performance of the automatic processor equipment for high image quality. The following record keeping is required for equipment quality control: 

1) daily maintenance record

2) weekly maintenance record

3) monthly maintenance record 

4) safety in processing operation

5) management of the automatic processor equipment (operating manual)

6) acquisition and absorption of latest information on the automatic processor equipment system.

These procedures are necessary for efficient processing operations which will give high and uniform image quality.

DAYLIGHT AUTOMATIC FILM PROCESSOR

The daylight system is a method whereby x-ray films can be loaded into a cassette and after being expose, emptied from the cassette into an x-ray film processor in room lighting and without using a darkroom. It is a method of handling and processing x-ray film eliminating the time consuming, labor intensive, darkroom procedures. The development of the roller-type x-ray film processor in the late 1950's was the first step towards this goal. The next major development occurred when Mr. Gunther Schmidt of the Production Company in conjunction with Du Pont, developed a daylight loading processing system for x-ray film in 1969. 






SYNTHESIS

Image-forming x-radiation is that part of the x-ray beam that exits a patient and exposes the IR. The conventional image radiographic IR is a cassette that contains radiographic film sandwiched between two radiographic intensifying screens. Radiographic film is made up of a polyester base that is covered on both sides with a film emulsion. The film emulsion contains light-sensitive silver bromide crystals that are made from the mixture of silver nitrate and potassium bromide. During manufacture, the emulsion is spread onto the base in darkness or under red lights because the AgBr molecule is sensitive to light. The invisible latent image is formed in the film emulsion when light photons interact with the silver halide crystals. Processing of radiographic film converts the latent image to a visible image.

References:

  • Essentials of Radiographic Physics and Imaging, T. Fauber, 3rd Edition, 2020
  • Bushong, S. (2017). Radiologic Science for Technologist, 11th Edition. Mosby Elsevier Inc.
  • https://images.slideplayer.com/18/5674967/slides/slide_3.jpg
  • https://sc01.alicdn.com/kf/HTB1KpjMyYSYBuNjSspfq6AZCpXaT.jpg
  • https://cdn.dotmed.com/images/listingpics/872789.jpg

name:
LESSON 7 TOPICS:
1. Introduction
    ...
intro:
LESSON 7 TOPICS:

1. Introduction

2. Exposure Artifacts

3. Processing Artifacts

3. Handling and Storage Artifacts

TOPIC LEARNING OUTCOMES:

 After the end of the lesson, the student should be able to:

1. Visually identify the screen-film radiographic artifacts.

2. List and discuss the three categories of screen-film artifacts.

3. Explain the causes of exposure artifacts.

4. Describe the types of artifacts caused during film processing.

5. Discuss how improper handling and storage of film can cause artifacts.

INTRODUCTION

Artifacts must be prevented. Identification of the artifact and its cause is critical for screen film radiography quality control (QC). It is important for every radiographer to be alert to artifacts and their origins. The cause of the artifact must be removed to prevent recurrence of the same problem in subsequent radiographs. Finally, records of artifacts must be kept to indicate trends; for example, if sludge artifacts show up more than once before processor cleaning, consider cleaning the processor more frequently. Artifacts are undesirable optical densities or blemishes on a radiograph or any other medical image. An artifact is something in the image that looks like it was created by the object but was in fact created by the process. 

Screen-film radiographic artifacts can interfere with the visualization of anatomical structures and can lead to misdiagnoses. Artifacts can be controlled when their cause is identified.

CONCEPTS

ARTIFACT

It is any irregularity on an image that is not caused by the proper shadowing of tissue.

CLASSIFICATION OF FILM  ARTIFACTS:

1. Exposure Artifacts

2. Processing Artifacts

3. Handling and Storage Artifacts

EXPOSURE ARTIFACTS

Exposure artifacts generally are associated with the manner in which the radiographer conducts the examination. Incorrect screen-film match, poor screen-film contact, warped cassettes, and improper positioning of the grid can lead to such artifacts. Improper patient position, patient motion, double exposure, and incorrect screen-film radiographic technique can result in very poor images that some would call artifacts. Such examples of poor technique have been shown to result in the largest number of repeat examinations. 

Patient preparation is essential for producing artifact free images. Artifacts on or worn by the patient often are concealed by clothing. Among these items are necklaces, pendants, hearing aids, chains, earrings, body and facial piercings, zippers and catches, and a variety of jewelry. Even supposedly “radiolucent”patient change gowns can have radiopaque parts, including traces of staining from contrast media or blood. In cases of trauma, pins, fasteners, dressings, and splints often have to remain in place because their removal could be dangerous to the patient. Internal artifacts from prostheses to dental fillings obviously cannot be removed and, similar to trauma cases, this should be noted on the examination request form.  

A radiograph with motion appears blurred. The patient may have moved or may not have breathed according to the radiographer’s instructions. Clear instructions are required to encourage understanding and cooperation in patients. Double exposures are also avoidable. When radiographers mix up cassettes, double exposures can occur; repeat examination is required. Positioning errors can cause artifacts. If the patient is positioned for examination when the x-ray tube is not centered to the table or Bucky tray, grid cutoff artifacts may occur. 

Artifacts can occur if the wrong film is loaded into a cassette. If high-contrast, single-emulsion mammography film is loaded into a radiographic cassette, an unexpected image results. Cassettes that have not been checked for proper screen-film contact produce smoothness in the area of poor contact that obscures detail and constitutes an artifact. 

Exposure artifacts are usually easy to detect and correct.



 


PROCESSING ARTIFACTS

Any number of screen-film radiographic artifacts can be produced during film processing. Most are pressure type artifacts caused by the transport system of the processor. Pressure-type artifacts usually sensitize the emulsion and appear as higher optical density (OD). Those that scrape or remove emulsion appear as lower OD.

TYPES OF PROCESSING ARTIFACTS:

1. Roller marks

2. Dirty rollers

3. Chemical fog

4. Wet-Pressure Sensitization

Processing artifacts are eliminated with a proper processor QC program and frequent cleaning. 

ROLLER MARKS

Guide shoe marks occur when the guide shoes in the turnaround assembly of the processor are sprung or improperly positioned. If the guide shoe is used before the developer, the ridges in the guide shoes press against the film, sensitize it, and leave a characteristic mark. Guide shoe marks can be found on the leading edge or the trailing edge of the film parallel to the direction of film travel through the processor. 

Pi lines occur at 3.1416-inch (π) intervals because of dirt or a chemical stain on a roller, which sensitizes the emulsion. Because the rollers are 1 inch in diameter, 3.1416 inches represents one revolution of a roller, and the artifact appears perpendicular to the film’s direction of travel through the processor. 

DIRTY ROLLERS

Dirty or warped rollers can cause emulsion pick-off and gelatin buildup, which result in sludge deposits on the film. These artifacts usually appear as sharp areas of increased or reduced OD. Occasionally, particles of sludge are transported through the processor and are actually dried on the film in the dryer.

CHEMICAL FOG

Chemical fog looks like light or radiation fog and is usually a uniform dull gray. Improper or inadequate processing chemistry can result in a special type of chemical fog called a dichroic stain. Dichroic means two colors. The dichroic stain appears as a curtain effect on the radiograph. Dichroic stain is a term that is generally applied to all chemical stains. Chemical stains on a radiograph can appear yellow, green, blue, or purple. In slow processors, the chemistry may not be squeezed properly from the film, and it either runs down the leading edge of the film or runs up the trailing edge. Both events are referred to as a curtain effect. 

WET-PRESSURE SENSITIZATION

Wet-pressure sensitization is a common artifact that is produced in the developer tank. Irregular or dirty rollers cause pressure during development and produce small circular patterns of increased OD. Processing artifacts in digital radiography (DR) are different from those with screen-film because the method of producing the visible image is electronic rather than chemical. Image-processing errors can produce bizarre artifacts in DR. Interference with electronic components involved in processing DR images also occurs.






HANDLING AND STORAGE ARTIFACTS

A number of artifacts are caused by improper film storage conditions. Image fog can result if the temperature or the humidity is too high or if the film bin is not shielded adequately from radiation. Pressure marks can occur if the film is stacked too high.

Causes of handling and storage artifacts:

1. Light or Radiation Fog

2. Pressure or Kink Marks

3. Static

4. Hypo Retention 

Light or Radiation Fog

White-light leaks in the darkroom or within the cassette cause streak-like artifacts of increased OD. If the safelight has an improper filter, the safelight is too bright, or the safelight is too close to the film processing tray, the image may be fogged. Films left in the x-ray examination room during an exposure can become fogged by radiation. Radiation fog and safelight fog look alike. 

Pressure or Kink Marks

Characteristic artifacts can be caused by improper handling or storage either before or after processing. Rough handling before processing can cause scratches and kink marks. Although the kink mark may appear as a fingernail mark, it is not. It is caused by the kinking or abrupt bending of film. Both events usually appear as increased OD. 

Static

Static is probably the most obvious artifact. It is caused by the buildup of electrons in the emulsion and is most noticeable during the winter and during periods of extremely low humidity. Three distinct patterns of static are crown, tree, and smudge.

Hypo Retention

The yellow-brown stain that slowly appears on a radiograph after a long storage time indicates a problem with hypo retention from the fixer. With this event, not all of the residual thiosulfate from fixing was removed during washing, and silver sulfide slowly builds up and appears yellow in the stored radiograph.


 



SYNTHESIS

An artifact is an undesirable OD that appears on the screen-film radiograph. Artifacts occur (1) during the radiographic exposure, (2) during processing of the film, and (3) when the film is being handled and stored before or after processing.  Exposure artifacts are a result of examination technique. These include patient motion, positioning errors, improper grid positioning.

Processing artifacts are most often pressure blemishes on the film emulsion caused by the roller transport system in the processor. They include sludge from dirty rollers, chemical fog, roller marks, and wet-pressure sensitization. The most bothersome handling and storage artifacts are those associated with light or radiation fog, kinkmarks, and static.

References:

  • Essentials of Radiographic Physics and Imaging, T. Fauber, 3rd Edition, 2020
  • Bushong, S. (2017). Radiologic Science for Technologist, 11th Edition. Mosby Elsevier Inc.

name:
LESSON 8 TOPICS:
1. Introduction
2. Sensitom...
intro:
LESSON 8 TOPICS:

1. Introduction

2. Sensitometer

3. Equipment and activities for the production of quality radiographic images

4. Regions of sensitometric curve

TOPIC LEARNING OUTCOMES: 

After the end of the lesson, the student should be able to: 

1. Discuss the three regions of sensitometric curve.

2. Describe the equipments and activities used to monitor the evaluation for radiographic quality images. 

3. Evaluate the relationship between the intensity of radiation exposure and the density produced after processing.

INTRODUCTION

A quality-control program must be implemented and systematically followed to ensure proper processing of radiographic film. A good quality-control program should include steps for monitoring all the equipment and activities required for the production of quality radiographic images.

CONCEPTS

SENSITOMETRY

In film-screen imaging, sensitometry is the study of the relationship between the intensity of radiation exposure to a film and the amount of blackness produced after processing (density). The intensity of radiation exposure is the measure of the quantity of radiation reaching  an area of the film. Sensitometry provides a method for evaluating the characteristics of film and film-screen combinations used in radiography. Radiographic film and intensifying screen manufacturers are capable of designing film and screens to respond differently to a given intensity of radiation exposure. In particular, film and screens designed for radiography of the chest or extremities respond differently to equal amounts of radiation exposure. The radiographer should understand how the selected film and film-screen system will respond to a given intensity of exposure.

Sensitometry is also a method of evaluating the performance of automatic film processors. Because automatic film processors affect a radiograph’s density and contrast, the variability of their performance can be monitored by sensitometric methods.

EQUIPMENT

Several pieces of equipment are needed to evaluate the relationship between the intensity of radiation exposure and the density produced after processing. The radiographic film should be exposed to a range of radiation intensities to evaluate its response to low, middle, and high exposures. This can be accomplished easily by passing radiation through an object that varies in thickness using a radiographic x-ray unit. The resultant effect is an image of varying uniform densities that correspond to specific intensities of radiation exposure.

PENETROMETER

A penetrometer is a device constructed of uniform absorbers of increasing thicknesses, such as aluminum or tissue-equivalent plastic. When radiographed, the penetrometer produces a series of uniform densities that resemble a step wedge. When step-wedge densities are produced with a penetrometer and a radiographic x-ray unit, the variability of the output of the equipment could affect the range of densities produced.



SENSITOMETER

A device known as a sensitometer is designed to produce consistent step-wedge densities by eliminating the variability of the x-ray unit. It uses a controlled light source to expose an optical step-wedge template. The step-wedge template transmits light in varying intensities to expose the radiographic film. After the film has been processed, a density step-wedge image, or sensitometric strip, is produced. Penetrometers and sensitometers are available in 11-, 15-, or 21-step densities.


DENSITOMETER

A densitometer is a device used to numerically determine the amount of blackness on a film after processing (i.e., it measures radiographic density). This device is constructed to emit a constant intensity of light (incident) onto an area of film and then measure the amount of light transmitted through the film. The densitometer determines the amount of light transmitted and calculates a measurement known as optical density (OD).


OPTICAL DENSITY

Optical density is represented as a numerical calculation that compares the amount of light transmitted through an area of radiographic film to the amount of light originally striking (incident on) the film. It shows the mathematical formula used for light transmittance. Because the range of radiographic densities is large, the calculation of radiographic densities is compressed onto a logarithmic scale for easier management.

A film that allows 100% of the original incident light to be transmitted has a logarithmic value of 0. A film that allows only 1% of the original incident light through has a logarithmic value of 2.0. This logarithmic value of light transmittance is termed optical density. The formula used to calculate optical density.

Notice the relationship between light transmittance and optical density. When 100% of the light is transmitted, the optical density equals 0.0. When 50% of the light is transmitted, the optical density is equal to 0.3, and when 25% of the light is transmitted, the optical density equals 0.6. When a logarithmic scale base of 10 is used, every change of 0.3 in optical density corresponds to a change in the percentage of light transmitted by a factor of 2 (log10 of 2 = 0.3).

Optical densities can range from 0.0 to 4.0 OD. Because most radiographic film has a tint added to its base and processing adds a slight amount of fog, the lowest amount of optical density is usually between 0.10 and 0.20 OD. This minimum amount of density on the radiographic film is termed base plus fog (B + F).

DIAGNOSTIC RANGE

The useful range of optical densities is between 0.25 and 2.5 OD. However, the diagnostic range of optical densities for general radiography usually falls between 0.5 and 2.0 OD. This desired range of optical densities is found between the extreme low and high densities produced on the film.

SENSITOMETRIC CURVE

When the optical density measurements from a sensitometric strip are graphed on semilogarithmic paper, the result is a curve characteristic of the radiographic film type.

This sensitometric curve visually demonstrates the relationship between the intensity of radia_x0002_tion exposure (x-axis) and the resultant optical densities (y-axis). The position of the curve on the x-axis and its shape can vary greatly and depends on the type of radiographic film used.



Log of Relative Exposure

When sensitometric methods are used to evaluate the characteristics of radiographic film, it is more useful to measure the intensity of radiation exposure in increments of a constant change, such as doubling or halving. For every doubling or halving change in the percentage of light transmitted, a change of 0.3 occurs in optical density. Along the x-axis, for every change of 0.3 in log relative exposure, the intensity of radiation exposure changes by a factor of 2. 

When it is used as an example, the relative mAs (the product of milliamperage and exposure time) value is 32 for a log of exposure of 1.5, and the relative mAs value is 64 for a log of exposure of 1.8. This relationship can be demonstrated throughout the log relative exposure scale on the sensitometric curve. Two exposures, one double the other, will always be separated by 0.3 on the logarithmic exposure scale.

Regions of sensitometric curve

A sensitometric curve demonstrates three distinct regions. When the characteristics of different types of radiographic film are evaluated, differences will be demonstrated within any of these regions.

Toe Region

The toe region of the sensitometric curve represents the area of low density. The point on the sensitometric curve where a minimum amount of radiation exposure produced a minimum optical density is known as Dmin. Generally, Dmin will be equal to B + F even though they represent two different measurements. Changes in exposure intensity in this region have little effect on the optical density.

Straight-Line Region

At a certain point along the x-axis, changes in exposure begin to have a much greater effect on the optical density. This straight-line region is where the diagnostic or most useful range of densities is produced.

Shoulder Region

There is a point on the sensitometric curve where changes in exposure intensity no longer affect the optical density. In this shoulder region, the point on the curve where maximum density has been produced is known as Dmax. Once the maximum density achievable within the film has been reached (Dmax), continued increases in exposure intensity begin to reverse the optical density. This process is called solarization, and it is used in the design of duplicating film.


SYNTHESIS

Sensitometric monitoring of the film processor for providing valuable information about the daily functioning of the processor. Following the establishment of baseline measurements, daily exposure and processing of a sensitometric strip, measurement of the appropriate optical density points with a densitometer, and plotting them on a control chart with predetermined upper and lower acceptable limits. The graph provides a visual indicator of any acute or evolving processor malfunction.

Typically, a processor control chart should monitor B + F, medium optical density or speed, and upper and lower density differences to evaluate contrast.

Speed and contrast indicators should not have an optical density value that varies more than ±0.15 from baseline measurements.

B + F should not have an optical density value greater than +0.05 from the baseline measurement.

Developer temperature should be measured daily with a digital thermometer and should not vary by more than ±0.5°F (0.3°C).

The darkroom environment should be well ventilated, clean, organized, and safe.

A safelight fog test should be performed semi-annually and result in an optical density of less than +0.05 due to added fog.

Replenishment rates should be checked weekly and fall within ±5% of manufacturer’s specification.

Recommended quarterly quality-control checks include the following:

1.  Developer solution pH should be maintained between 10 and 11.5.

2.  Fixer pH should be maintained between 4 and 4.5.

3.  Developer specific gravity should not vary by more than ±0.004 from the manufacturer’s specifications.

References:

  • Essentials of Radiographic Physics and Imaging, T. Fauber, 3rd Edition, 2020
  • Bushong, S. (2017). Radiologic Science for Technologist, 11th Edition. Mosby Elsevier Inc.
  • Fauber, T., Radiographic Imaging and Exposure, 5th Edition,  Mosby Elsevier Inc.

name: LESSON 1 TOPICS:1. Introduction2. X-ray tube3. Sta...
intro:
LESSON 1 TOPICS:

1. Introduction

2. X-ray tube

3. Stationary and rotating anode x-ray tube

4. Production of x-ray

TOPIC LEARNING OUTCOMES:

After the end of the lesson, the student should be able to:

1. Identify the parts of the x-ray tube.

2. Determine the functions of the x-ray tube.

3. Differentiate between stationary and rotating anode x-ray tubes.

4. Understand the production of x-ray in the x-ray tube.


INTRODUCTION

The X-ray machine is an electrical machine that contains an evacuated vacuum glass cylinder called an x-ray tube which produces a high speed of electrons to generate x-ray. It is composed of a cathode(negative side) and an anode (positive side). X-rays are produced when the high speed of electrons is suddenly stopped or decelerated. Mostly, 99% heat is produced in the x-ray tube and only 1% is x-ray. X-ray machines in the medical field are largely used to diagnose diseases such as broken bones and pathologies of tissues or organs and also for the treatment of cancer tumors. Although there is another application of x-rays in the field of industry, sterilization, power generation, and research, on this topic we will be dealing only with diagnostic x-ray and radiotherapy. 

CONCEPTS

There are three major parts of the x-ray machine-x-ray tube, control panel, and high voltage section. The heart of the x-ray machine is the x-ray tube because this is where the x-rays are produced.  The control panel is the section where you manipulate the x-ray machine to provide technical factors necessary in the production of an x-ray. And the high voltage section is composed of a high voltage transformer for the conversion of  220 voltage to a thousand volts

PARTS OF X-RAY MACHINE:

1. X-RAY TUBE

2. CONTROL PANEL

3. HIGH VOLTAGE SECTION

 

X-RAY TUBE

It is an evacuated glass envelope that produces a high speed of electrons to generate an x-ray. It has a cathode and anode.

     

MAJOR/MAIN PARTS OF X-RAY TUBE:

1. CATHODE – the negative side of the x-ray tube.

2. ANODE – the positive side of the x-ray tube.

PARTS OF THE CATHODE:

1. FILAMENT – is a coil of wire usually thoriated tungsten about 2 mm. in diameter and 1 or 2 cms. in length which is responsible for the production of electrons when heated.

2. FOCUSSING CUP – a metal cup wherein the filament is embedded. It is negatively charged so that it condenses the electron beam to a small area of the anode.

THERMIONIC EMISSION – emission of electrons when the heat is applied.

PARTS OF THE ANODE:

1. TARGET – a tungsten material embedded in copper, rhenium, molybdenum and /or graphite.

2. FOCAL SPOT – is the small area of the target being hit with electrons. It is the actual source of electrons.

 MAIN REASONS WHY TUNGSTEN IS USED AS TARGET MATERIAL:

1. It has a high atomic number (74)

2. It has a high melting point (3,410 degrees centigrade)

3. It has high thermal conductivity. 

TWO TYPES OF ANODE:

1. STATIONARY ANODE

2. ROTATING ANODE

STATIONARY ANODE X-RAY TUBE

   

ROTATING ANODE X-RAY TUBE

   

DUAL FOCUSING CUP (DUAL FILAMENT)

      

OTHER PARTS OF THE X-RAY TUBE:

1. GLASS ENVELOPE – is a vacuum tube or diode made of Pyrex glass to enable it to withstand tremendous heat.

2. INDUCTION MOTOR – an electric motor that works on the principle of electromagnetic induction.

3. STATOR –located outside the glass envelope consisting of a series of electromagnets equally spaced around the neck of the tube.

4. ROTOR – located inside the glass envelope composed of a shaft made of bars of copper and soft iron fabricated into one mass.

STATOR AND ROTOR


PRODUCTION OF X-RAYS

The production of x-ray starts in the cathode side of the x-ray tube where the filament is heated to give off a cloud of electrons. This process of emission of electrons by application of heat is called thermionic emission. These scatter electrons must be aimed directly at the small section of the anode by focusing cup. The electrons are then accelerated and suddenly stopped to strike the small target area in the anode called the l spot. When this happens, 99% is converted to heat and only 1% of x-ray is produced. Therefore, production of x-rays requires a source of electrons, acceleration of electrons, focusing the electrons, and deceleration of electrons.

CONTROL PANEL

   

HIGH VOLTAGE SECTION


SYNTHESIS

The parts of the x-ray machine are the x-ray tube, control console, and high voltage section. All parts have an important role in the production of x-ray. The selection of quantity and quality of x-ray starts in the control panel. The high voltage necessary to create an x-ray will not be possible without the high voltage transformer.  And the x-ray tube is where the electrons impinge on the target surface, more than 99 % of their kinetic energy is changed to heat and only 1% is converted to x-ray. Therefore,  x-rays are electrically produced when clouds of accelerated electrons are decelerated and strike a target.

REFERENCES:

  • https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/proxy/h9.png    

  • https://i.ytimg.com/vi/8XKaEz7cv94/hqdefault.jpg

  • Callaway, W.V. & Tolley Gurley L. (2018). Introduction to Radiologic Technology, 8th edition. Singapore. Mosby Elesevier

  • Bushong, S. (2017). Radiologic Science for Technologist, 11th Edition. Mosby Elsevier Inc.

name: LESSON 4 TOPICS:1. Introduction2. Technique formul...
intro:
LESSON 4 TOPICS:
1. Introduction
2. Technique formula for milliampere-second(mAs) and kilovoltage peak (kVp)
3. Technical factors that affect the quality of the radiographic image


TOPIC LEARNING OUTCOMES: 
After the end of the lesson, the student should be able to: 
1. Explain exposure factor considerations involved in selecting techniques.
2. Discuss how mAs and kVp affect the quality of radiographs. 
3. Describe and calculate the formula for mAs and kVp.


INTRODUCTION
The controlling factor for density and contrast is the mAs and kVp. In order to understand fully its application, simple formulas must be adopted to provide good radiographic quality. These formulas guide radiologic technologists in the systematic way of controlling the technical factors in the control panel. By providing the appropriate kVp and mAs, the film quality is achieved while protecting the patient's health by decreasing its radiation dose. 


CONCEPTS
milliampere-sec(mAs) 
  • primary controls quantity of the x-ray beam
  • directly affects radiographic density
mAs= mA x s
where: 
mAs = milliampere-sec           
mA = milliampere           
s = time in seconds


Problem Solving:
1. What will be the mAs for the technical factors of 200 mA and 0.05 sec.?


2. A chest x-ray examination requires 2 mAs using 100 mA station. What is the requires exposure time?



mA-Time Relationship
  • It states that mA and exposure time are directly proportional.
  • An increase in mA requires a corresponding decrease in exposure time.


Problem Solving: 

1. An abdominal x-ray requires 200 mA and 0.4 sec. The patient is unable to hold his breath which results in blurring of the image. A second exposure is made with an exposure time of 0.1 sec. What is the new mA that is required?



Note:

          If the radiologic technologist wants only to see a slight increase in optical density, then the mAs must be increased by approximately 30%. Less than that will not produce a visible image.

          It is generally accepted that if the optical density on the radiograph is to be increased using kVp, an increase in kVp by 15% would be equivalent to doubling the mAs


kilovoltage-peak(kVp)
  • primary controls the quality of the x-ray beam.
  • directly affects the radiographic contrast.
  • responsible for penetration
  • responsible for secondary or scatter radiation


Problem Solving: 
1. The thickness of the abdomen to be examined is 40 cms.. If the machine's constant is 30, what will be the kVp required for the examination?



15 % kVp RULE
  • It states that a 15% in kVp is equivalent to doubling the mAs or vice versa.
  • It means that increasing the kVp by 15% will reduce the mAs by ½ or vice versa


Problem Solving:

1. A patient’s chest measures 16 cms. and an exposure is made at 72 kVp and 10 mAs. The resulting contrast scale is too short but the density is good. What should the repeat technique be?



References:

  • Callaway, W.V. &Tolley Gurley L. (2018). Introduction to Radiologic Technology, 7th edition. Singapore. Mosby Elsevier
  • Adler, A. & Carlton, R. (2018). Introduction to Radiologic and Imaging Sciences and Patient Care, 6th Edition. St. Louis, Missouri: Elsevier Saunders..
  • Bushong, S. (2017). Radiologic Science for Technologist, 11th Edition. Mosby Elsevier Inc.

name: LESSON 5 TOPICS:1. Introduction2. Line Focus Princ...
intro:
LESSON 5 TOPICS:

1. Introduction

2. Line Focus Principle

3. Anode Heel Effect

4. Air-gap Technique

TOPIC LEARNING OUTCOMES: 

After the end of the lesson, the student should be able to: 

1. Explain the line focus principle

2. Discuss how anode heel effect affects radiographic density.

3. Describe the principle of air-gap technique in reducing scatter radiation.

INTRODUCTION

A large focal spot is useful to protect the tungsten target as it accumulates and dissipates within the area of focal spot. However, a small focal spot is required to achieve a good radiographic image quality. The line focus principle helps resolve this issue by starting that an angulation of the anode surface will result in an apparent decrease in the focal spot size.  The target of an x-ray tube is mounted at very steep angle in the motion of incident electron. Hence, the x-ray will come from a smaller focal area. Whereas the electrons bombard relatively a large focal area. So, suddenly heat is removed or reduced and  sharpness is improved.

CONCEPTS

LINE FOCUS PRINCIPLE

It refers to the fact that the electron stream is focused at a narrow rectangle on the anode target. The smaller the focal spot the sharper the image. Focal spot sizes: 0.6 mm and 1.2 mm. The target face varies with an angle between 6- 20º to the cathode. When the rectangular focal spot is viewed from below in the position of the film it appears more nearly a small square. Thus, the effective area of the focal spot is only a fraction of its actual area and by using x-rays that emerged at this angled, radiographic definition is increased while the heat capacity of the anode is increased.

Effective focal spot -is the area projected onto the patient and film. It is the projection perpendicular to the central ray, which is its apparent area from the position of the film 

Actual focal spot - is the real size of the focal spot.


Line focus principle was incorporated into x- ray targets to allow a larger area for heating while maintaining a small focal spot. The effective focal spot is the area projected onto the patient and film. Focal spot sizes always make reference to the effective focal spot. The lower the target angle, the smaller the effective focal spot size. The advantage of line- focus principle is that it provides the detail of a small focal spot while allowing a large amount of heat dissipation. The unfortunate bi-product of the line-focus principle is the “anode heel effect”

ANODE HEEL EFFECT 

It is the variation of x-ray intensity along the longitudinal axis of the x-ray beam. The x-ray intensity is higher on the cathode side of the x-ray tube. Therefore, the cathode side of the x-ray tube should be positioned on the thicker anatomical part of the body. It is more pronounced when using short SID, large image receptor and small anode angle.




RADIOPAQUE – tissue or material that absorbs x-rays and appears bright on a radiograph.

RADIOLUCENT – tissue or material that transmits x-rays and appears dark on a radiograph.

RADIOLOGIC PATHOLOGY - it is a specialize branch of medical science that involves the study and diagnosis of disease through the use of  radiologic medical imaging.  








CONVERSION TABLE FOR mAs ACCORDING TO AGE

       AGE                        MULTIPLY mAs BY

Birth – 3 months               0.2

4 months – 2 years          0.3

3 years – 5 years              0.4

6 years – 7 years              0.5

8 years – 12 years            0.6

13 years and above     original adult mAs

QUESTION:

The original adult mAs for chest x-ray examination is 10. What is the required mAs for a 4-year old patient ?


CONVERSION FACTORS FOR PATIENTS WITH DRY AND WET CAST:

Patient with dry cast = original kVp + 10

Patient with wet cast = original kVp + 20


Question:

The technical factors for femur without cast are 70 kVp and 20 mAs. What will be the factor if the patient has wet cast ?

AIR-GAP TECHNIQUE 

It is another method of reducing scatter radiation and enhancing image contrast wherein the image receptor is moved 10-15 cms. from the patient. It is equivalent to 8:1 grid. It is also called air-filtration. Increase SID from 180 to 300 cms. will result in little magnification and sharper image but the technique factor must be increased, but the patient dose does not increase.





SYNTHESIS

The relationship of line focus principle and heel effect is in the angulation of the target of the focal spot in the anode side of the x-ray tube. A large focal spot is useful to protect the tungsten target so that it accumulates and dissipates within the area of focal spot. However, a small focal spot is required to achieve a good radiographic image quality. The line focus principle helps resolve this issue by mounting a very steep angle so that the x-ray will come from a smaller area whereas the electrons coming from the filament bombard a large focal area. Therefore, the heat is minimized and sharpness is improved. The disadvantage of line focus principle is that it produces heel effect, meaning the emitted intensity of the x-ray beam emitted is not uniform. The end result is that the field intensity towards the cathode is more than that towards the anode.  

References:

  • Callaway, W.V. &Tolley Gurley L. (2018). Introduction to Radiologic Technology, 7th edition. Singapore. Mosby Elsevier
  • Adler, A. & Carlton, R. (2018). Introduction to Radiologic and Imaging Sciences and Patient Care, 6th Edition. St. Louis, Missouri: Elsevier Saunders..
  • Bushong, S. (2017). Radiologic Science for Technologist, 11th Edition. Mosby Elsevier Inc.
  • https://pbs.twimg.com/media/Dh_ayiaUwAIlzZZ.jpg

LESSON 6 TOPICS:

1.  Introduction

2. X-ray/Radiographic Grid

3.  Types of Grid

4.  Types of Grid Cut-off

TOPIC LEARNING OUTCOMES: 

After the end of the lesson, the student should be able to:

1.  Discuss and compare grid types

2.  Select the most appropriate grid for a given clinical situation.

3.  Describe how grid cut-off can be avoided.

INTRODUCTION

An x-ray grid is the part of an X-ray machine that filters out randomly deflected radiation that can obscure or blur an image produced by the machine. It was invented in 1913. An X-ray grid is a filtering device that ensures the clarity of the image on x-ray film. When an x-ray machine sends radiation through an object, specifically a body, the object absorbs or deflects most of the rays. Only about 1 percent of the x-rays pass through the body on a straight line and burn an image onto the film. The deflected x-rays can hit the film at random angles, obscuring the image. The grid filters out these random X-rays.

CONCEPTS

RADIOGRAPHIC GRID

It is a fabricated series of sections of radiopaque material, which are usually made of lead, alternating with sections of radiolucent material (interspace material), which are usually made of aluminum or plastic. It is designed to transmit only those x-rays whose direction is straight from the source to the image receptor. X-rays that travel obliquely are absorbed in the grid material. It is placed between the patient and the x-ray film to reduce the scattered radiation, thus improving image contrast. It was first demonstrated in 1913 by Gustave Bucky.

General Types of Radiographic Grid:

1. Stationary Grid

2. Moving Grid










TYPES OF GRID:

1.  LINEAR PARALLEL GRID

All lead strips are parallel, easiest to manufacture but clinically undesirable.



2.  CROSSED GRID

It has lead grid strips running parallel to both the long and short axes of the grid. They are usually made  by sandwiching two linear grids together with their grid strips perpendicular to one another.




3.  FOCUSED GRID

It is designed to minimize grid cut-off. The lead strips run along one axis and are tilted so that they lie on imaginary lines of the divergent x-ray beam.





MOVING GRID

It is usually focused grid with a mechanism that is moved at the time of exposure. It is used to removed grid lines. It was developed in 1920 by Hollis E. Potter. Moving grid is also known as Potter-Bucky Diaphragm or Bucky diaphragm.

All stationary grids will give you grid lines on your radiograph. Thinner Pb strips will give you less noticeable lines. However, thinner strips have less Pb content not “cleaning up” as well Grid Lines are made when primary x-rays are absorbed in the grid strips. Motion blurs out lead strip shadows.

TYPES OF MOVING GRID:

1.  SINGLE STROKE GRID

     It causes the grid to move continuously across the film while the exposure is being made.

2.  RECIPROCATING GRID

      It is motor driven, during x-ray exposure it moves back and forth several times.

3.  OSCILLATING GRID

      It has the characteristics of single-stroke and reciprocating grids. It is positioned in a frame with 2 to 3 centimeter tolerance on all sides with spring-like  devices located in the four corners hold the grid. A powerful electromagnetic pulls the grid on one side and releases it at the beginning of the exposure.  The grid oscillates in a circular fashion around the grid frame, coming to rest for 20 to 30 seconds.

GRID CUT-OFF – partial or complete undesirable absorption of primary x-rays by the grid and can result in reduced optical density or total absence of film exposure.

GRID LINES –are the images made when primary x-rays are absorbed in the grid strips.

TYPES OF GRID CUT-OFF:

1. OFF-LEVEL GRID 

     It can be produced by having an improperly positioned radiographic tube and not an improperly positioned grid.



2. OFF-CENTER GRID

     It occurs if the grid is shifted laterally. This error is called lateral decentering.




3. OFF-FOCUS GRID

     It occurs when a focused grid is not used at the proper focal distance.



4. UPSIDE-DOWN GRID

    It shows severe grid cut-off on either side of the central axis. Always look for the tube-side or film-side label to prevent upside-down.


SYNTHESIS

An X-ray grid in its most basic form is a grate with a series of narrow strips of metal that stop x-rays--usually lead, nickel, carbon fiber or aluminum. The grid resembles a set of horizontal window blinds that is partially open. x-rays that create the true image on the film travel in a straight line, so they will pass right through the grid. Deflected x-rays that would add noise to the image hit the grid strips at an angle and will not hit the film. This is the basic principle of radiographic grid. It was later improved by simply moving the grid to even reduced more of the scatter radiation. It is vital in producing radiographic quality especially when performing thick parts of the body with high kVp factoring that yields large amount of secondary radiation that cause film fog. 

References:

  • Callaway, W.V. &Tolley Gurley L. (2018). Introduction to Radiologic Technology, 7th edition. Singapore. Mosby Elsevier
  • Adler, A. & Carlton, R. (2018). Introduction to Radiologic and Imaging Sciences and Patient Care, 6th Edition. St. Louis, Missouri: Elsevier Saunders..
  • Bushong, S. (2017). Radiologic Science for Technologist, 11th Edition. Mosby Elsevier Inc

name:
LESSON 7 TOPICS:
1. Introduction
2. Grid Rat...
intro:
LESSON 7 TOPICS:

1. Introduction

2. Grid Ratio

3. Grid Frequency

4. Grid Conversion Factors

TOPIC LEARNING OUTCOMES: 

After the end of the lesson, the student should be able to: 

1. Interpret grid efficiency in terms of grid ratio and frequency

2. Relate the significance of grid on radiographic contrast 

3. Explain the rationale and provide calculations for using grid

INTRODUCTION

An x-ray grid is the part of an X-ray machine that filters out randomly deflected radiation that can obscure or blur an image produced by the machine. It was invented in 1913. An x-ray grid is a filtering device that ensures the clarity of the image on x-ray film. When an x-ray machine sends radiation through an object, specifically a body, the object absorbs or deflects most of the rays. Only about 1 percent of the x-rays pass through the body on a straight line and burn an image onto the film. The deflected x-rays can hit the film at random angles, obscuring the image. The grid filters out these random x-rays. 

CONCEPTS

GRID RATIO – refers to the height of the lead strips divided by the interspace thickness.

GR = h/D

GR = grid ratio

h = height of the lead strips

D = interspace thickness





GRID FREQUENCY – refers to the number of grid strips or grid lines per inch or per centimeter.

GF = 10,000 µm/cm

         (T + D) µm/line pair

T = lead strip thickness

D = interspace thickness






Advantages of Moving Grids:

1. No grid lines ( motion blurs out lead strip shadows)

2. Reduces secondary or scatter radiation

3. Radiographic contrast is improved

Disadvantages of Grid:

1. Vibration potential cause by moving grid.

2. Limit minimum exposure time

3. Increases patient dose

4. Lateral decentering from motion

5. Up to 20% loss of primary radiation

6. Stationary grid makes interspace gaps darker for same amount of radiation

7. Increased OID, more geometric unsharpness

8. Misalignment of grid and image receptor

9. Can cause underexposure

10. Mechanical problems

11. Expensive

References:

  • Callaway, W.V. &Tolley Gurley L. (2018). Introduction to Radiologic Technology, 7th edition. Singapore. Mosby Elsevier
  • Adler, A. & Carlton, R. (2018). Introduction to Radiologic and Imaging Sciences and Patient Care, 6th Edition. St. Louis, Missouri: Elsevier Saunders..
  • Bushong, S. (2017). Radiologic Science for Technologist, 11th Edition. Mosby Elsevier Inc.

name:
LESSON 7 TOPICS:
1. Introduction
2. Radiogra...
intro:
LESSON 7 TOPICS:

1. Introduction

2. Radiographic Technique Chart

3. Types of Radiographic Technique Chart

TOPIC LEARNING OUTCOMES: 

After the end of the lesson, the student should be able to: 

1. Explain standardization exposure factor considerations involved in selecting techniques.

2. Describe the requirements for radiographic technique chart.

3. Identify and develop the appropriate technique chart for specific radiographic contrast and density.

INTRODUCTION

kVp, mA, time and SID are the principal exposure- technique factors. It is important for the radiographer to know how to manipulate these exposure-technique factors to produce the desired density, contrast, image detail, and lack of distortion on the finished radiograph. These are the factors that imaging technologist should consider and determines the appropriate technique chart and implement to produce radiographic image quality.

CONCEPTS

RADIOGRAPHIC TECHNIQUE CHART

      These are written tables that provide a means of determining the specific technical factors to be used for a given radiographic  examination. For each radiographic unit, a guide or chart should be available that describes standard methods for the radiographer to use to produce high quality  images consistently.    

Requirements for Radiographic Technique Chart:

1. Calibrated x-ray machine

2. Manual or automatic processor must be in good condition

3. Total filtration of 2.5 – 3 mm. Al equivalent is necessary

4. Types of grid

5. Collimator accuracy

TYPES OF RADIOGRAPHIC TECHNIQUE CHARTS:

1. Variable-kVp Technique Chart

2. Fixed-kVp Technique Chart

3. High –kVp Technique Chart

4. Automatic-Exposure Technique Chart

Variable-kVp Technique Chart

It uses a fixed mAs and a kVp that varied according to the thickness of the anatomic part. Kilovoltage varied with the thickness of the anatomic part by 2 kVp per centimeter. 

Beginning kVp = 2 X thickness of anatomy(cm) + 30 (single phase)

Example: Chest PA

kVp = 2 X 20 + 30 = 70

Then, select make test exposures for 9 mAs, 10 mAs & 12 mAs. Select the radiograph that produces the best density and contrast. Minor adjustments and continuing  refinement of each chart must be done.

Fixed-kVp Technique Chart

It is the used most often in radiology department. It was developed by Alfred Fuchs. It is a method for selecting exposures that produce radiographs with a longer scale  of contrast. It produces scales of contrast that are consistent with anatomic regions. The kVp is selected as the optimum  required for penetration of the anatomic  part. Once selected the kVp is fixed at that level for each type of examination and not varied according to different thickness of the anatomic part.  The mAs ,  however is changed according to thickness of the anatomic part to provide the proper density. 

High-kVp Technique Chart

The kVp selected for this chart is greater than 100. This type of exposure technique  could be used for routine chest radiography to provide improved visualization of the various tissue mass densities present in the lung fields and mediastinum.  It produces low contrast or long scale of contrast which is good in chest quality radiograph. It also reduces patient radiation dose.

Automatic-Exposure Technique Chart

It is a computer-assisted automatic-exposure system which uses an electronic exposure timer. The radiation intensity is measured by either a photo cell or an ionization chamber and terminates the exposure when the proper optical density on the image receptor has been reached.  Automatic-control x-ray systems are not completely automatic. Radiographer  must still use a guide for the selection of kVp and optical density setting. Optically density selections are numerically scaled to allow for different thickness of the anatomic part. Patient positioning must be accurate, and positioning must include anatomy to cover the photocell. Excessive scatter radiation will affect the response of the device and reduce image contrast.












References:

  • Callaway, W.V. &Tolley Gurley L. (2018). Introduction to Radiologic Technology, 7th edition. Singapore. Mosby Elsevier
  • Adler, A. & Carlton, R. (2018). Introduction to Radiologic and Imaging Sciences and Patient Care, 6th Edition. St. Louis, Missouri: Elsevier Saunders..
  • Bushong, S. (2017). Radiologic Science for Technologist, 11th Edition. Mosby Elsevier Inc.

name: LESSON 1 TOPICS:1. Introduction2. Sources of human...
intro:
LESSON 1 TOPICS:

1. Introduction

2. Sources of human exposure to radiation

3. Mode of human exposure to radiation

4. Classification of human exposure to radiation

TOPIC LEARNING OUTCOMES: 

After the end of the lesson, the student should be able to:

1. Understand the nature of radiation

2. Distinguish between natural and artificial radiation

3. Differentiate between irradiation and contamination


INTRODUCTION

Radiation is everywhere, it is part of our daily lives. There are good and harmful types of radiation. It can be prevented and limited. Radiation protection is concerned with the protection of individuals, their progeny and mankind as a whole, while still allowing necessary activities from which radiation exposure might result. For human beings, animals and plants, it is impossible not to be exposed to radiation because everywhere there is radiation. We just have to limit our exposure to radiation only to activities that are needed. Diagnostically exposure to radiation is an example of revealing information of certain diseases of the patient. We intend to expose ourselves to radiation simply because the good effects outweigh the harmful effects.

CONCEPTS

RADIOBIOLOGY

It is the study of the action or effects of ionizing radiation on living things. Radiation protection is concerned with the protection of individuals, their progeny, and mankind as a whole, while still allowing necessary activities from which radiation exposure might result.

RADIATION PROTECTION 

It is concerned with the protection of individuals, their progeny, and mankind as a whole, while still allowing necessary activities from which radiation exposure might result.

Sources of Human Exposure to Radiation

1. Natural Environmental Radiation
   Sources:
      A. Cosmic rays

· Radiation coming from outer space

· Aircraft crews and passengers flying at an altitude of 10,000 meters receive an extra dosage(0.03 mSv) of cosmic radiation for every 5,000 km. jet flight every 5,000 km. jet flight.

   B. External Terrestrial radionuclides

· Its sources are principally from radium (226, 228 Ra), radon (220, 222 Rn), and carbon (14C). The largest component of human exposure to radiation is radon.

· The largest component of natural environmental radiation is radon.

· Radon is a radioactive gas produced by the natural decay of uranium, which is present in trace quantities in the earth.

· All earth-based materials such as concrete, bricks and gypsum wallboard (wood) contain radon. It emits alpha particles and contributes dose to the lungs.

    C. Internal radionuclides (40-K)

· Our own body is radioactive, it contains radioactive radium and polonium in our skeleton, radioactive carbon and potassium in our muscles and radioactive noble gases and tritium in our lungs.

2. Man-made Radiation or Artificial radiation
Sources:
A. Medically employed x-rays (or other types of ionizing radiation), both diagnostic, therapeutic and research studies. It is considered to be the largest source of man-made radiation.
B. Radiopharmaceuticals
C. Nuclear weapons testing which caused radioactive fallout.
D. Nuclear power generation
People who work not only in nuclear power plants but also in coal-fired power plants, mines and several sections of metal industry are also exposed to different levels of man-made radiation.
E. Consumer items such as watch dials, exit signs, smoke detectors, television receivers, camping lantern mantles and airport surveillance systems 

Mode of Human Exposure to Radiation:
1. Irradiation-it is used to describe exposure to radiation originating from any source.
Types of Irradiation:
    A. External irradiation - it is the exposure is due to radiation originating from external source.
         Ex. Patient undergoing diagnostic procedure.
   B. Internal irradiation - it is the result of inhalation or ingestion of radioactive materials or direct absorption through the skin.

2. Contamination - it is the undesired presence of radioactive materials on any substance in concentration greater than those which occur naturally so much so as to cause a technical inconvenience or radiation hazard cause by spillage or breakage.
    Sources:
   A. Chemical reactions
   B. Evaporation, aeration or spilling of radioactive liquids.
   C. Mechanical manipulations of radioactive solids (grinding or welding).
   D. Activation of loose dust particles being irradiated or around nuclear reactor.

Classification of Human Exposure to Radiation:
1. Background Radiation Exposure
    Sources:
   A. Cosmic radiation
   B. External terrestrial radiation
   C. Internal radionuclides (radioactive elements in our bodies {40-K}

2. Medical Exposure - it deals with intentional exposure of patients for diagnostic and therapeutic purposes by technically qualified medical and paramedical personnel.
3. Occupational Exposure - it is the exposure obtained by radiation workers as a result of the nature of their work particularly in the radiation area.
4. Exposure of the members of the general public - it is the exposure which might be received by individual members of the population, as a result of their visit to a hospital or walk by a hospital or live or work near one where there is a presence of any radiation sources.


SYNTHESIS

Radiation exposure is part of our routine in this world  - it has existed all along. Naturally occurring radioactive materials are present everywhere, the floors and walls of our homes, schools, or offices and in the food, we eat and drink. There are radioactive gases in the air we breathe. Even our own bodies - muscles, bones, and tissue - contain naturally occurring radioactive elements. Human has always been exposed to natural radiation arising from the earth as well as from outside the earth such as cosmic rays.

We also receive exposure from man-made radiation, such as x-rays and gamma rays, radiation used to diagnose and treat diseases. The fallout from nuclear explosives testing, small quantities of radioactive materials released to the environment from coal and nuclear power plants, and consumer items we used every day are also sources of radiation exposure to man.


References:

  • https://www.nuclear-power.net/nuclear-engineering/radiation-protection/sources-of-radiation/
  • https://sites.google.com/site/radioactivityinbasel/home/sources-of-background-radiation
  • Radiologic Science for Technologist, 11th edition, Mosby Elsevier, Inc.
  • Practical Radiation Protection and Applied Radiobiology, S. Dowd, 2nd Edition, 2016

name: LESSON 2 TOPICS:1. Introduction2.&n...
intro:
LESSON 2 TOPICS:

1. Introduction

2. Justification for radiation protection

3. Somatic and genetic effects

4. Stochastic and non-stochastic effects

TOPIC LEARNING OUTCOMES:

After the end of the lesson, the student should be able to:

1. Justify the need to minimize unnecessary radiation exposure to humans.

2. Distinguish between somatic and genetic radiation effects.

3. Differentiate between the stochastic (probabilistic) and nonstochastic (deterministic) effects of radiation exposure.

INTRODUCTION

It is a fact that radiation can cause harmful effects to biologic tissues. In the field of radiology, we are concern with the health safety of our patients and this includes radiation exposure. Determining the radiation effects will be the key factor to properly address the methods, procedures and equipment necessary to practice radiation protection. Whether the source of radiation is natural or artificial, whether it is a small dose of radiation or a high dose, there will be biological effects to humans. When radiation, especially ionizing radiation strikes our body hitting the atoms, some of its molecules may break apart or become stuck together and may cause abnormal function of the cells. This is the start of long chain of radiation effects that will end in mild or severe consequences. This is the simple reason that radiation protection should be taken seriously.

CONCEPTS

JUSTIFICATION OF RADIATION PROTECTION

There are many different kind of somatic cells in the human body because every cell found inside and on the surface of human body, with the exception of cells that become sperm and egg cells, is a somatic cell. Genetic cells are sperm and egg cells which are an instructional manual of our body. It is a short section of DNA.

Types of radiation effects:

1. Somatic effect – the effects of radiation are manifested in the individual’s own body.

Examples: erythema, cataract, necrosis and desquamation

2. Genetic effect – the effects of radiation are manifested in the descendants or future generation.

Examples: childhood malignancy, congenital malformation and cancer

 Radiation effects in the atomic level:

1. Ionization - the process of removing of electrons from the orbital of an atom.

2. Excitation - the vibration or temporary removal of electrons of an atom.

Radiation effects in the molecular level:

1. Main-chain scission - the breakage of the thread or backbone of the long chain macromolecule.

2. Cross-linking - the side structures behave as though they had a sticky substance at the end, and will attach to a neighboring molecule or to another segment of the same molecule.

3. Point lesions or molecular lesions - formation or production of minute-bit of particles in the irradiated macromolecule.

RADIOLYSIS – irradiation of water molecule and formation of free radicals.

Radiation effects in the cellular level:
1. Cell death
2. Change in the normal function of the cell
3. Mitotic death

Deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) - it serves as the command control for cell to function. It contains all the hereditary information representing a cell or  an individual. It is found in the nucleus of a cell.

Three principal observable effects of irradiated DNA molecule:
1. Cell death
2. Malignant disease
3. Genetic damage

MITOSIS is the most radiosensitive stage of cell cycle.
SYNTHESIS is the most radioresistant stage of cell cycle.
METAPHASE is the most radiosensitive stage of mitosis.

RADIATION EFFECTS IN THE SKIN:
1. ERYTHEMA
2. DESQUAMATION
3. DRYNESS
4. TELANGIECTASIA
5. THICKENING
6. TISSUE NECROSIS
7. RADIATION BURNS
8. RADIATION DERMATITIS

9. SKIN CANCER

RADIATION EFFECTS IN THE MUCOUS MEMBRANES:
1. IRRITATION
2. INFLAMMATION
3. PEELING
4. CHANGE IN TASTE
5. HOARSENESS
6. DYSPHAGIA
7. DIFFICULTY EATING
8. WEIGHT LOSS
9. DECREASE SALIVARY PRODUCTION
10. HEARING LOSS
11. CONJUCTIVITIS
12. DRY EYE SYNDROME
13. CATARACT.

RADIATION EFFECTS IN THE LUNGS:
1. PNEUMONITIS
2. CHRONIC FIBROSIS
3. LUNG CANCER

CARDIAC RADIATION EFFECTS:

1. PERICARDIAL TOXICITY

2. MYOCARDIAL TOXICITY

3. BLOOD VESSELS TOXICITY

RADIATION EFFECTS IN THE GASTROINTESTINAL SYSTEM:
1. ESOPHAGITIS
2. GASTRITIS
3. DYSPHAGIA
4. HEARTBURN
5. ULCERATION
6. ATROPHY
7. FIBROSIS
8. DIARRHEA
9. DIFFICULTY EATING
10. NAUSEA AND VOMITING
11. OBSTRUCTION
12. EDEMA

RADIATION EFFECTS IN THE MUSCULOSKELETAL  SYSTEM:
1. LOSS OF MUSCLE BULK
2. TISSUE THICKENING
3. BONE GROWTH ARREST

RADIATION EFFECTS IN THE HEMATOLOGICAL SYSTEM:
1. DECREASE IN RBC, WBC AND BLOOD PLATELETS

RADIATION EFFECTS IN THE BRAIN:
1. EDEMA
2. NECROSIS 

RADIATION EFFECTS IN THE SPINAL CORD:
1. MYELITIS
2. PARALYSIS

RADIATION EFFECTS IN THE CHROMOSOMES:
1. CHROMOSOME ABERRATION
2. LEUKEMIA (FOR BLOOD FORMING ORGANS)

RADIATION EFFECTS IN THE EYES:
1. CATARACT

RADIATION EFFECTS IN THE OVARIES:
1. ATROPHY
2. DECREASE IN THE NO. OF EGG CELLS (10 Rads/10 cGy)
3. TEMPORARY STERILITY (200 Rads/200 cGy)
4. PERMANENT STERILITY (500 Rads/500 cGy)
5. GENETIC MUTATION IN OFFSPRING

1st Trimester - the most radiosensitive stage of pregnancy.

2nd week of pregnancy -the least radiosensitive

RADIATION EFFECTS IN THE TESTES:
1. ATROPHY
2. DECREASE IN THE NO. OF SPERM CELLS (10 Rads/10 cGy)
3. TEMPORARY STERILITY (200 Rads/200 cGy)
4. PERMANENT STERILITY (500 Rads/500 cGy)
5. GENETIC MUTATION IN OFFSPRING

RADIATION EFFECTS IN THE UTERUS (FERTILITY):
1. PRENATAL DEATH
2. NEONATAL DEATH
3. CONGENITAL ABNORMALITIES/MALFORMATION
4. CHILDHOOD MALIGNANCY
5. GENETIC EFFECTS
6. GENERAL IMPAIRMENT OF GROWTH AND DEVELOPMENT
7. MENTAL RETARDATION

RADIATION-INDUCED MALIGNANCIES:
1. THYROID CANCER
2. BONE CANCER
3. SKIN CANCER
4. BREAST CANCER
5. LUNG CANCER
6. LIVER CANCER
7. LEUKEMIA

LIFE SPAN SHORTENING – accelerated premature aging and death.


                

      

 

GEN. CLASSIFICATION OF RADIATION EFFECTS:

1. STOCHASTIC EFFECTS (PROBABILISTIC)
     These are effects of radiation that occur by chance, and radiation exposure is only one of the agents for which these effects can occur. Any amount of radiation exposure no matter how low it is may possibly cause these effects. An increase in radiation dose will also increase the probability of these effects to occur.
Examples of these effects are cancer, genetic effects and life-span shortening. 

2. NON-STOCHASTIC EFFECTS (DETERMINISTIC)
     These are effects of radiation which occur only after a certain minimum dose (threshold dose) has been exceeded. Once the threshold dose is increased, the effects will become more severe. The primary cause of these effects is the radiation, no other agents can be considered the cause of such occurrence. Examples of these effects are temporary sterility, permanent sterility and radiation burns.

SYNTHESIS

There are various effects of radiation to human body which cause medical implications today and the future to come. There will be biological effects to our body whether the radiation comes from our natural surroundings or man-made. It is how we use and expose ourselves to these types of radiation. It is our obligation as human being to be aware of the radiation effects to seriously take into account the possible ways to reduce or limit our exposure to radiation. Strict implementation of radiation protection is necessary for the success of reducing these diseases directly or indirectly caused by radiation. To be knowledgeable of all the diseases caused by radiation is the first step to determine the proper application of radiation safety procedures.

REFERENCES:

  • https://www.pinterest.nz/malthusta/nagasaki-and-hiroshima-bombing/
  • https://www.bibliotecapleyades.net/ciencia/ciencia_uranium84.htm
  • https://www.agreenroadjournal.com/2014/04/list-of-radiation-induced-diseases.html
  • Radiologic Science for Technologist, 11th edition, Mosby Elsevier, Inc.
  • Practical Radiation Protection and Applied Radiobiology, S. Dowd, 2nd Edition, 2016

name: LESSON 3 TOPICS:1. Introduction2.&n...
intro:
LESSON 3 TOPICS:

1. Introduction

2. Objectives of radiation protection

3. Dose limitation

4. Cardinal principles of radiation protection 

TOPIC LEARNING OUTCOMES:

After the end of the lesson, the student should be able to:

1. Understand the objectives of radiation protection

2. Describe the systems of dose limitation

3. Explain the cardinal principles of radiation protection

INTRODUCTION

Radiation protection is defined as the protection of individuals, their progeny, and mankind as a whole, while still allowing necessary activities from which radiation exposure might result. The main concern is to protect not only the present generation but also the generation to come while doing procedures concerning radiation with prevention and limitations. A high radiation dose, when given to the body, would result in harmful acute radiation effects. In diagnostic radiology, the prevention of providing high radiation doses to patients must be adopted in order not to cause radiation effects. Stochastic effects are effects of radiation that occur by chance, and any amount of radiation no matter how low it is can possibly cause such occurrence. Therefore, prevention of stochastic effects is not possible only a limitation of the radiation exposure can be done. There are many ways, methods, and procedures that can be applied in order to prevent and limit radiation exposure to patients, radiation workers and the general public.

CONCEPTS

The main objectives of radiation protection are the following:

1. To prevent detrimental non-stochastic effects (somatic).
2. To limit the probability of stochastic effects (somatic or genetic).

Systems of Dose Limitation:

1. Principle of Justification

No practice involving radiation shall be adopted unless its introduction produces a positive net benefit.

2. Principle of Optimization or ALARA Principle

All exposures shall be kept as low as reasonably achievable, economic and social factors being taken into account.

3. Principle of Dose Limit

The dose equivalent to an individual shall not exceed the limits recommended by the ICRP.

ALARA VS ALADA

The ALARA(AS LOW AS REASONABLY ACHIEVABLE) was derived from the principle of optimization that requires that all individual exposures should be kept as low as reasonably achievable taking into account the economic and social factors. It is a balance between dose reduction and economic considerations. It is also a restriction on the radiation dose to individuals from a particular source.

 The ALADA(AS LOW AS DIAGNOSTICALLY ACHIEVABLE) principle is a concept wherein an evidence-based assessment of image quality for specific diagnostic tasks with exposure and doses associated with a given level of image quality. It is a design that will reduce the dose to the patient without compromising the diagnostic quality of the images.

It is critical for healthcare providers to weigh the potential benefit of diagnostic information against the expense and risk of the imaging procedure. If you are only after for quality images without considering the radiation dose, we are doing the patient a disservice. All imaging personnel should know the difference in risk between diagnostically acceptable and  quality images. The present technology allows improvements and parameters to obtain a diagnostically acceptable and interpretable quality image. Protocols should be designed that will reduce the dose to the patient without compromising the diagnostic quality of the images. Implementation of the concept of ALARA in general should always be utilized but ALADA principle for more specific dose reduction is necessary.

 


 Dose Limit Recommended by ICRP:

  • Radiation Workers = 20 mSv/yr (2 Rem/yr)
  • General Public        = 1 mSv/yr ( 100 mRem/yr)
  • Effective Dose for Occupational Exposure (ICRP-IAEA -BSS 1996) = 20 mSv in a year averaged over defined periods of 5 years, with no single year exceeding 50 mSv.
  • Dose limit to abdomen of woman of reproductive capacity = 13 mSv in 3 months
  • Dose constraint for fetus during pregnancy                              = 1 mSv

Classification of dose limit for radiation workers:

1. Minimum detection level (MDL) = 0.15 mSv (OSLD)
2. Investigation level (IL)                  = 0.5 mSv/mo. (1.0 mSv/2 mos.)
3. Action level (AL)                            = 1.7 mSv/mo. (3.4 mSv/2 mos.)
4. Derived working limit (DWL)       = 1.7 mSv/mo. (3.4 mSv/2 mos.)


Cardinal Principles of Radiation Protection (TDS):

1. PRINCIPLE OF TIME

Keep the time of exposure to radiation as short as possible (minimize time).

2. PRINCIPLE OF DISTANCE

Maintain a large distance between the radiation source and the exposed person (maximize distance).

3. PRINCIPLE OF SHIELDING

Provide an absorbing material between the radiation source and the exposed person (maximize shielding).






SYNTHESIS

Ionizing radiation has many beneficial applications, including uses in medicine, industry, agriculture, and research. As the use of ionizing radiation increases, so does the potential for health hazards if not properly used or contained especially in the field of medicine. There are many ways to decrease these harmful effects by simply following strict implementation and guidelines. Since we can not prevent exposure to low levels of radiation, the limitation is the only possible way to shield ourselves from the detrimental effects of ionizing radiation. Radiation dose to the patients, radiation workers, and the general public must not exceed the dose recommended by ICRP. The cardinal principles of radiation protection of time, distance, and shielding should always be applied by all radiologic technologists. Exposure time must be minimal because the longer your exposure, the more your body would accumulate radiation dose. Shielding materials made of lead should always be worn to prevent x-ray from entering the vital parts of your body. And lastly, the most practical method of protection against ionizing radiation is distance, simply because as you move further away from the source of radiation, the dose decreases dramatically. It is the responsibility of radiologic technologists to use all these principles to help protect the patients and the public as well.

References:

  • Radiologic Science for Technologist, 11th edition, Mosby Elsevier, Inc.
  • Practical Radiation Protection and Applied Radiobiology, S. Dowd, 2nd Edition, 2016
  • https://www.nrc.gov/images/about-nrc/radiation/time-distance-shielding.gif
  • https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Basic_Physics_of_Digital_Radiography/The_Source 
  • http://www.online-vets.com/exposure_2.html    
  • https://www.sciencenewsforstudents.org     
  • https://www.alamy.com

name: LESSON 4 TOPICS:1. Units, Detection...
intro:
LESSON 4 TOPICS:
1. Units, Detection, and Measurement
2. Radiation Quantities and Units
3. Conversion from old to SI Units
4. Regulatory Agencies


TOPIC LEARNING OUTCOMES:
After the end of the lesson, the student should be able to:
1. Define radiation and radioactivity units of measurement
2. Describe the importance of radiation units in detection and measurement of exposure to surrounding areas and body tissues
3. Perform calculations of radiation units from old to international system  (SI)
4. Identify the various agencies responsible for formulating policies and standards of 
radiation protection


INTRODUCTION

The five human senses are not capable of detecting radiation, especially harmful ionizing radiation. There are various instruments that are available for detecting and measuring radiation with corresponding units or quantities. Recommendations regarding dosimetric quantities and units in radiation protection dosimetry are set forth by the International Commission on Radiation Units and Measurements (ICRU). The recommendations on the practical application of these quantities in radiation protection are established by the International Commission on Radiological Protection (ICRP). The operational quantities are defined for practical measurements both for area and individual monitoring. In radiation protection radiation should be monitored daily, weekly, monthly and/or annually.


                   

RADIATION QUANTITIES AND UNITS:
1. EXPOSURE (X)
  • It is the charged liberated by ionizing radiation (low-energy photons) per unit mass of air.
  • The old unit for radiation exposure or intensity in air is Roentgen(R).
  • The S.I. (Systeme Internationale) unit is coulomb per kilogram (c/kg)
1 R = 2.58 X 10^-4 c/kg
1 c/kg = 3,876 R
1 exposure unit = 1 c/kg
 
Note:
Exposure units are an accurate measure only for photon energies between 1 keV and 1,000 keV (1 MeV).
The unit for exposure rate in S.I. unit is coulomb per kilogram.second.
(c/kg.s or c.{kg.s}^-1)
 
2. ABSORBED DOSE
  • It is the energy deposited by ionizing per unit mass of irradiated material.
  • The old unit for radiation absorbed dose is Rad.
  • The S.I. unit is Gray (Gy).
1 Rad = 100 ergs/gram
1 Rad = 0.01 Gy = 1 X 10^-2
1 Gy = 100 Rad
1 Gy = 1 joule/kg (1 J.kg^-1)
The unit for radiation absorbed dose rate is Gy/s (Gy.s^-1).
 
3. KERMA ( Kinetic Energy Released per unit Mass)
  • It is the kinetic energy of charged ionizing particles liberated per unit mass of the specified material by uncharged ionizing particles.
  • The common derived unit of kerma is joule per kilogram (J/kg or J.kg ^-1) with the special name Gray (Gy).
  • The unit of kerma rate is Gray per second (Gy/s or Gy.s^-1).
  • Air kerma and tissue kerma differ by less than 10%.
NOTE:
      The difference between absorbed dose and kerma lies in the fact that kerma measures all the energy transferred to charged particles by uncharged particles.
 
4. DOSE EQUIVALENT
  • It is used to express the amount of exposures received by a radiation worker.
  • The old unit is REM (roentgen equivalent man).
  • The S.I. unit is Sievert (Sv).
  • The S.I. unit for dose equivalent rate is Sievert per second (Sv/s or Sv.s^-1)
  • Dose equivalent is equal to the absorbed dose multiplied by a quality factor and other modifying factors.
H = D.Q.N
            where :
                       H = dose equivalent
                       D = absorbed dose
                       Q = quality factor
                       N = other modifying factor
1 Rem = 0.01 Sv
1 Sv = 100 Rem


5. ACTIVITY (A)
  • It is the disintegration of atoms per unit of time by a radioactive material.
  • The old unit is Curie (Ci).
  • The S.I. unit is Becquerel (Bq)
1 Ci = 3.7 X 10^10 dps
1 Ci = 3.7 X 10^10 Bq
1 dps = 1 Bq

NOTE:
        In diagnostic radiology wherein x-ray is used, it is considered to assume 1 R = 1 Rad = 1 Rem or 2.58 X 10^-4 c/kg = 0.01 Gy = 0.01 Sv. But with other types of radiation this generalization is not true.

SYNTHESIS

These are the following conversion units that are commonly used in radiation measuring principles.

1 R = 2.58 X 10-4 c/kg
1 Rad = 0.01 Gy
1 Rem = 0.01 Sv
1 Ci = 3.7 X 1010 Bq
1 Rad = 1,000 mRad
1 Gy = 100 cGy
1 Sv = 1,000,000 μSv = 1 x 106 μSv
1 MBq = 1,000,000 Bq = 1 X 106 Bq
1 GBq = 1,000,000,000 Bq = 1 X 109 Bq
1 Ci = 1,000 mCi



INTERNATIONAL REGULATORY AGENCIES:

1. INTERNATIONAL COMMISSION ON RADIOLOGICAL PROTECTION (ICRP)

It is the principal organization that formulates and publishes authoritative recommendations in health physics. It is an independent, international, non-governmental organization, with the mission to provide recommendations and guidance on radiological protection concerning ionizing radiation.

It was founded in 1928 at the second International Congress of Radiology in Stockholm, Sweden and was then called the International X-ray and Radium Protection Committee (IXRPC).[1] In 1950 it was restructured to take account of new uses of radiation outside the medical area, and given its present name.

2. INTERNATIONAL ATOMIC ENERGY AGENCY (IAEA)

A specialized agency of the United Nations organized in 1957 which promotes and works for the safe, secure and peaceful uses of nuclear science and technology, contributing to international peace and security and the United Nations' Sustainable Development Goals. It is an international organization that seeks to promote the peaceful use of nuclear energy, and to inhibit its use for any military purpose, including nuclear weapons. The IAEA was established as an autonomous organization on 29 July 1957. Though established independently of the United Nations through its own international treaty, the IAEA Statute, the IAEA reports to both the United Nations General Assembly and Security Council.

3. INTERNATIONAL COMMISSION ON RADIOLOGICAL UNITS AND MEASUREMENTS (ICRU)

The ICRU (originally known as the International X-Ray Unit Committee and later as the International Committee for Radiological Units) was conceived at the First International Congress of Radiology (ICR) in London in 1925 and officially came in Stockholm in 1928. The primary objective was to propose a unit for measurement of radiation as applied in medicine. To develop and promulgate internationally accepted recommendations on radiation related quantities and units, terminology, measurement procedures, and reference data for the safe and efficient application of ionizing radiation to medical diagnosis and therapy, radiation science and technology, and radiation protection of individuals and populations.

NATIONAL REGULATORY AGENCIES:

1. PHILIPPINE NUCLEAR RESEARCH INSTITUTE (PNRI)

A  It is a government agency under the Department of Science and Technology (DOST) which regulate the safe and peaceful applications of nuclear science and technology in the Philippines. It was founded on June 13, 1958 formerly known as Philippine Atomic Energy Commission(PAEC). It also undertake the transfer of research to end-users, including technical extension and training services. It is also responsible for monitoring the radiation measuring and/or detecting devices for radiation workers and facilities in the Philippines. 

2. CENTER FOR DEVICE REGULATION, RADIATION HEALTH AND RESEARCH (CDRRHR)

It is a branch of  Department of Health (DOH)  under the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) which  is responsible for the regulation, licensing, registration, manufacture, import, export, distribution, promotion, advertisement, and sale of medical devices, radiation devices and health-related devices.

3. PROFESSIONAL REGULATION COMMISSION-BOARD OF RADIOLOGIC TECHNOLOGY (PRC-BORT)

It was created by the Presidential Decree (PD) No. 223, signed by then President Ferdinand E. Marcos.  Its functions are to conduct and administer licensure examination to aspiring professionals and to regulate and supervise the practice of the professions exercised in partnership with Professional Regulatory Boards. 

4. BOARD OF RADIOLOGIC TECHNOLOGY (PRC-BORT)

It was created by the Republic Act(RA) No. 7431 also know as “Radiologic Technology Act of 1992”, signed by then President Corazon Aquino.  Its main functions are to conduct yearly board examination to radiologic technology and x-ray technology examinees under the supervision  of PRC and to look into the condition affecting the  practice of radiologic technology in the Philippines  and adopt measures as may deemed necessary for the maintenance of  the standards and ethics of the profession.

5. CONTINUING PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT (CPD)

It is a Republic Act No. 10912, otherwise known as the “Continuing Professional Development  (CPD) Act of 2016”. It is an act which requires CPD  as the mandatory requirement for the renewal of Professional Identification Card.
