3. Define credentialing, certification, registration, licensure, and regulations.

INTRODUCTION

Radiologic technology as a profession is a four-year tertiary program that requires PRC licensure examination which upon completion requires performing diagnostic imaging procedures, such as x-ray examinations, magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scans, and computed tomography (CT) scans. Some of them specialize in specific techniques such as cardiovascular-interventional radiography, mammography, or ultrasonography.

Radiologic technologists are responsible for accurately positioning patients and ensuring that a quality diagnostic image is produced. They work closely with radiologists, the physicians who interpret medical images to either diagnose or rule out disease or injury. For the images to be interpreted correctly by the radiologist, the imaging examination must be performed properly by a radiologic technologist.

RADIOLOGIC TECHNOLOGY AS A PROFESSION

The Philippine Qualifications Framework

The Philippine Qualifications Framework describes the levels of educational qualifications and sets the standards for qualification outcomes. It is a quality assured national system for the development, recognition, and award of qualifications based on standards of knowledge, skills, and values acquired in different ways and methods by learners and workers of the country. The Philippine Qualifications Framework - It is a collaborative program by the Department of Education (DepEd), Technical Education and Skills Development Authority (TESDA), Commission on Higher Education (CHED) , Professional Regulation Commission (PRC), and Department of Labor and Employment (DOLE). 

The K to 12 Program covers Kindergarten and 12 years of basic education (six years of primary education, four years of Junior High School, and two years of Senior High School [SHS]) to provide sufficient time for mastery of concepts and skills, develop lifelong learners, and prepare graduates for tertiary education, middle-level skills development, employment, and entrepreneurship. Senior High School is two years of specialized upper secondary education; students may choose a specialization based on aptitude, interests, and school capacity. The choice of career track will define the content of the subjects a student will take in Grades 11 and 12. Each student in Senior High School can choose among three tracks: Academic; Technical-Vocational-Livelihood; and Sports and Arts. The Academic track includes three strands: Business, Accountancy, Management (BAM); Humanities, Education, Social Sciences (HESS); and Science, Technology, Engineering, Mathematics (STEM).


HISTORY OF RADIOLOGIC TECHNOLOGY IN THE PHILIPPINES

  • FAMILY CLINIC AND HOSPITAL – the first school of Radiologic Technology
  • MARIAN COLLEGE – second school of Radiologic Technology
  • ASSOCIATION OF X-RAY TECHNICIANS IN THE PHILIPPINES was conceived in 1954
  • PD 480 – the creation of Radiation Health Service under the Department of Health on June 6, 1974.
  • R.A. 7431 – An act regulating the practice of Radiologic Technology in the Philippines also known as the “Radiologic Technology Act of 1992” which creates the PRC- Board of radiologic Technology on February 7, 1992.

REGULATIONS, CREDENTIALING, REGISTRATION, LICENSING, AND CERTIFICATION IN RADIOLOGIC TECHNOLOGY

COMMISSION ON HIGHER EDUCATION (CHED)

         It was created on May 18, 1994 through the passage of Republic Act No. 7722, or the Higher Education Act of 1994, an attached agency to the Office of the President for administrative purposes. It acts as collegial body in formulating plans, policies and strategies relating to higher education. It is in charged with promoting relevant and quality higher education, ensuring access to quality higher education, and guaranteeing and protecting academic freedom for continuing intellectual growth, advancement of learning, research and development.

ACCREDITED INTEGRATED PROFESSIONAL ORGANIZATION/ACCREDITED PROFESSIONAL ORGANIZATION (APO)

         It refers to the single national organization endorsed by the Board(e.g. Board of Radiologic Technology) and approved by the Commission to represent a given profession pursuant to the provision of the respective professional regulatory laws.

CENTER FOR DEVICE REGULATION, RADIATION HEALTH, AND RESEARCH (CDRRHR)

         It is a branch of the Department of Health (DOH)  under the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) which is responsible for the regulation, licensing, registration, manufacture, import, export, distribution, promotion, advertisement, and sale of medical devices, radiation devices, and health-related devices.

PHILIPPINE NUCLEAR RESEARCH INSTITUTE (PNRI)

         It is a government agency under the Department of Science and Technology (DOST) which regulates the safe and peaceful applications of nuclear science and technology in the Philippines. It also undertakes the transfer of research to end-users, including technical extension and training services. It is also responsible for monitoring the radiation measuring and/or detecting devices for radiation workers and facilities in the Phils. 

PHILIPPINE ASSOCIATION OF RADIOLOGIC TECHNOLOGISTS, INC. (PART)

         It is the national professional organization of radiologic technologists accredited by the Professional Regulation Commission. It was conceived in 1954, with primary objectives of uniting radiologic technologists into one umbrella, both from government and private institutions. The objective of the association is to promote the general welfare and upgrade the practice of radiologic technology so as to meet the standard for the protection of life, heath, and property.

PHILIPPINE SOCIETY OF GOVERNMENT RADIOLOGIC TECHNOLOGISTS (PSGRT)

         It is an organization composed of professional radiologic technologists employed in the government sector. It was founded in 1992 to bring together the radiologic technologists to exert their rights in gaining the position title of  Radiologic Technologist.  Its mission is to promote the highest achievable standards of patient care and professional service. 

CONTINUING PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT (CPD)

         It is Republic Act No. 10912, otherwise known as the “Continuing Professional Development  (CPD) Act of 2016”. It is an act that requires CPD  as the mandatory requirement for the renewal of a Professional Identification Card. It is the process of tracking and documenting the skills, knowledge, and experience that you gain both formally and informally as you work, beyond any initial training. It is still a mandatory requirement for the renewal of the PRC ID of all registered and licensed professionals. From 45 units, it’s now down to 15 units every three years.

PROFESSIONAL REGULATION COMMISSION(PRC)

         The Professional Regulation Commission(PRC) was created by the Presidential Decree (PD) No. 223, signed by then President Ferdinand E. Marcos.  Its functions are to conduct and administer licensure examinations to aspiring professionals and to regulate and supervise the practice of the professions exercised in partnership with Professional Regulatory Boards.

PRC-BOARD OF RADIOLOGIC TECHNOLOGY(PRC-BORT)

         The Professional Regulation Commission(PRC)-Board of Radiologic Technology was created by the Republic Act(RA) No. 7431 also known as the “Radiologic Technology Act of 1992”, signed by then President Corazon Aquino.  Its main functions are to conduct yearly board examinations to radiologic technology and x-ray technology examinees under the supervision of PRC and to look into the condition affecting the practice of radiologic technology in the Philippines and adopt measures as may deemed necessary for the maintenance of the standards and ethics of the profession.

SYNTHESIS

The Radiologic Technology profession requires four years in college. After graduation passing the PRC licensure examination is a must to be a registered radiologic technologist. There are many opportunities await for radiologic technologists in the healthcare facility. Aside from diagnostic x-ray, there is various specialization in the field of radiologic technology. Among them are CT-Scan, MRI, SPECT, PET Scan, Radiotherapy, Interventional radiography, and many other emerging specializations. 

It is important to look back and remember the past radiologic schools and institutions and important pioneers in the field of radiology. The future of radiologic technology is full of exciting possibilities with new discoveries and advancements.

name: Welcome to our Mandarin 1 Course!Mandarin 1 is a b...
intro:
Welcome to our Mandarin 1 Course!


Mandarin 1 is a basic Mandarin course for learners with no prior knowledge or very limited knowledge of the Chinese Language. The course aims to help the learners to develop communicative skills in Mandarin. The course will enable them to use basic grammar, sentence patterns, and vocabulary. The class time will be used for lecturing and learner activities including listening, speaking, reading, and writing. Learners are expected to preview each lesson before class and study the covered content after class. At the end of the course, learners are expected to pass HSK level 1 exam. 


Ms. Jen Ray Y. Liang

梁建蕾老师
Mandarin Instructor, LaCHS - CASE

name: GEC_103- Mathematics in the Modern WorldUnits: 3Co...
intro:
GEC_103- Mathematics in the Modern World

Units: 3

Course Description

This course provides a glimpse of the nature of mathematics and appreciation of its practical, intellectual, and aesthetic dimensions, and do some of its applications in our daily life.

It begins with an introduction to the nature of mathematics as an exploration of patterns in nature and the environment.  By exploring these topics, students are encouraged to go beyond the typical understanding of mathematics as merely set of formulas but as a source of aesthetics in patterns of nature. The course then proceeds to survey ways to which mathematics provides tools for understanding and dealing with various aspects of present day living such as making social choices, dividing limited resources fairly, exploring and appreciating geometric designs in arts, understanding codes used in data transmission and security and used graphs to represent routes and networks for optimization.

name: COURSE LEARNING OUTCOMES (CLO)    &...
intro:
COURSE LEARNING OUTCOMES (CLO)                                            :              

At the end of the course and given simulated conditions/situations, the student should be able to:

1.         identify patterns in nature and regularities in the world

2.          express the importance of mathematics in one’s life

3.          debate about the nature of mathematics, what it is, how it is expressed, represented, and used

4.         discuss and explain the nature of mathematics as a useful language

5.         promote the use of logic in solving real life problems

6.         solve problems involving patterns and recreational problems using Polya’s four steps

7.         apply geometric concepts, especially isometries in describing the indigenous arts and creating designs

8.         relate the concepts of cryptography and its applications in data security

9.         apply concepts/procedures in graph theory to real life problems

name: TOPIC OUTLINEWEEKTOPIC LEARNING OUTCOMESCOURSE/TOP...
intro:
TOPIC OUTLINE

WEEK

TOPIC LEARNING OUTCOMES

COURSE/TOPIC

1

At the end of the topic, the learners are expected;

●        To find out guidelines and requirements of the course

●        To relate the dynamics and significance of the course to the learners’ future profession.

●        To discuss among the other students by “getting to know each other well”

●        To watch the Map of Mathematics and identify important tools that were used in the ancient times.

●        Make an essay if “Mathematics is invented or discovered.”

A quick discussion on the course outline as to the ff.

•            Topics and  Course requirements

•            Importance of the course in relation to their field of specialization

•            Grading System

 

2 - 3

●        identify patterns in nature and regularities in the world

●        articulate the importance of mathematics in one’s life

●        argue about the nature of mathematics, what it is, how it is expressed, represented, and used

●        express appreciation for mathematics as a human endeavor

The Nature of Mathematics

●        History of Mathematics

●        Patterns in Nature

●        Fibonacci Sequence and the Golden Ratio

●        Mathematics in our Daily Life

 

4 - 5

●        discuss the language, symbols, and conventions of mathematics

●        explain the nature of mathematics as a language

●        perform operations on mathematical expressions correctly

●        acknowledge  that mathematics is a useful language

Mathematical Language and Symbols

●        The Language of Mathematics

●        Translation from English to Mathematical Statements

●        Structure of Mathematics

⮚      Sets and its operation

⮚      Functions and Relations

6

●        use different types of reasoning to justify statements and arguments made about mathematics and mathematical concepts

●        write clear and logical proofs

●        solve problems involving patterns and recreational problems using Polya’s four steps

●        organize one’s methods and approaches for proving and solving problems (V)

 

 

Problem Solving and Reasoning

●        Inductive and deductive reasoning

●        Intuition, proof, and certainty

●        Polya’s 4-steps in Problem Solving

●        Mathematical problems involving patterns

●        Recreational problems using mathematics

7-8

●        use logic to justify statements and to create proofs

●        advocate the use of logic in solving real life problems

Elementary Logic

●        Proposition

●        Logical Operators

●        Equivalent Statements

Quantifiers

9

MIDTERM EXAM (PROJRCT

 

10-11

●        Understand the concepts of isometry and symmetry

●        Create symmetric patterns

●        Identify the symmetric pattern used in an art.

●        Create wallpaper pattern

●        Identify the wallpaper pattern used in an art.

●        Identify the different tessellations.

●        Create tessellation model.

●        contribute to the enrichment of the Filipino culture and arts using concepts in geometry

Geometric Designs

●      Isometry and Symmetry

●      Types of Isometry

●     · Symmetric Pattern

●      Types of Symmetric Patterns

●      Wallpaper Patterns

●     Tessellations

12-13

●        Understand the concepts of cryptography and its applications

●        Understand how to deploys encryption and decryption techniques to secure data transits

●        Perform modular arithmetic

●        Encrypt and decrypt message

 

Cryptography

●     What is Cryptography?

          Encryption and Decryption

         Ceasar Cipher

●      Modular Arithmetic

●     Addition Cipher

●     Multiplication Cipher

●      Linear Cipher

●     Vigenere Cipher

14-15

 

•  Understand the different voting methods used in election

•  Understand the different methods that can be used to apportion resources/items.

•  Divide resources/items in a fair manner.

 

 

 

 

Apportionment and Voting

•  Voting Theory

    Plurality Method

    Borda Count Method

    Plurality with Elimination

    Pairwise Comparison Method

•  Apportionment and its Basic Elements

    Hamilton Method

    Jefferson Method

•  Fairness in Apportionment

•  Huntington-Hill Apportionment Principle

16-17

●        apply concepts/procedures in graph theory to real life problems

●        advocate the use of graphs in real life situations

Mathematics of Graphs

●        Basic Concepts of Graphs

●        Euler Circuit

●        Hamiltonian Circuit

●        Weighted Graphs

●        Euler’s Formula

●        Graph Coloring

18

FINAL EXAM (PROJECT)

name: COURSE POLICIES:o   Classes will st...
intro:
COURSE POLICIES:

o   Classes will start on time. It is the responsibility of a student to come to class promptly and regularly. 
o   A student should be responsible for any missed lessons, written works, performance tasks, or major exams.
o   Activities should be submitted on or before the deadline. (10% deduction to the score if late for 1 min to less than 3 days, 20% deduction if late for 3 days to 5 days, grade of 0 beyond 5 days)
o   A student who accumulates absences beyond 10.8 hours will automatically receive a grade of 5.00 (See the University Policy on attendance below)
o   Cheating is a major offense. (See Student Handbook )
o   Plagiarism or copying others work is also is a major offense.

name: MIDTERM and FINAL PROJECTSI lieu of Midterm and Fi...
intro:
MIDTERM and FINAL PROJECTS

I lieu of Midterm and Final exams, the students are required to submit a mini documentary about any topic of interest in mathematics. Topics should be on any mathematical subjects not discussed inside the classroom and that will enhance the interest of the students in mathematics. Your teacher will present some topics you may explore or you can propose a topic that must be approved by the teacher.  The documentary must be 5-7 minutes.


See the sample projects below  (copy and paste to your browser).

6.         solve problems involving patterns and recreational problems using Polya’s four steps

7.         apply geometric concepts, especially isometries in describing the indigenous arts and creating designs

8.         relate the concepts of cryptography and its applications in data security

9.         apply concepts/procedures in graph theory to real life problems

name: TOPIC OUTLINEWEEKTOPIC LEARNING OUTCOMESCOURSE/TOP...
intro:
TOPIC OUTLINE

WEEK

TOPIC LEARNING OUTCOMES

COURSE/TOPIC

1

At the end of the topic, the learners are expected;

●        To find out guidelines and requirements of the course

●        To relate the dynamics and significance of the course to the learners’ future profession.

●        To discuss among the other students by “getting to know each other well”

●        To watch the Map of Mathematics and identify important tools that were used in the ancient times.

●        Make an essay if “Mathematics is invented or discovered.”

A quick discussion on the course outline as to the ff.

•            Topics and  Course requirements

•            Importance of the course in relation to their field of specialization

•            Grading System

 

2 - 3

●        identify patterns in nature and regularities in the world

●        articulate the importance of mathematics in one’s life

●        argue about the nature of mathematics, what it is, how it is expressed, represented, and used

●        express appreciation for mathematics as a human endeavor

The Nature of Mathematics

●        History of Mathematics

●        Patterns in Nature

●        Fibonacci Sequence and the Golden Ratio

●        Mathematics in our Daily Life

 

4 - 5

●        discuss the language, symbols, and conventions of mathematics

●        explain the nature of mathematics as a language

●        perform operations on mathematical expressions correctly

●        acknowledge  that mathematics is a useful language

Mathematical Language and Symbols

●        The Language of Mathematics

●        Translation from English to Mathematical Statements

●        Structure of Mathematics

⮚      Sets and its operation

⮚      Functions and Relations

6

●        use different types of reasoning to justify statements and arguments made about mathematics and mathematical concepts

●        write clear and logical proofs

●        solve problems involving patterns and recreational problems using Polya’s four steps

●        organize one’s methods and approaches for proving and solving problems (V)

 

 

Problem Solving and Reasoning

●        Inductive and deductive reasoning

●        Intuition, proof, and certainty

●        Polya’s 4-steps in Problem Solving

●        Mathematical problems involving patterns

●        Recreational problems using mathematics

7-8

●        use logic to justify statements and to create proofs

●        advocate the use of logic in solving real life problems

Elementary Logic

●        Proposition

●        Logical Operators

●        Equivalent Statements

Quantifiers

9

MIDTERM EXAM (PROJRCT

 

10-11

●        Understand the concepts of isometry and symmetry

●        Create symmetric patterns

●        Identify the symmetric pattern used in an art.

●        Create wallpaper pattern

●        Identify the wallpaper pattern used in an art.

●        Identify the different tessellations.

●        Create tessellation model.

●        contribute to the enrichment of the Filipino culture and arts using concepts in geometry

Geometric Designs

●      Isometry and Symmetry

●      Types of Isometry

●     · Symmetric Pattern

●      Types of Symmetric Patterns

●      Wallpaper Patterns

●     Tessellations

12-13

●        Understand the concepts of cryptography and its applications

●        Understand how to deploys encryption and decryption techniques to secure data transits

●        Perform modular arithmetic

●        Encrypt and decrypt message

 

Cryptography

●     What is Cryptography?

          Encryption and Decryption

         Ceasar Cipher

●      Modular Arithmetic

●     Addition Cipher

●     Multiplication Cipher

●      Linear Cipher

●     Vigenere Cipher

14-15

 

•  Understand the different voting methods used in election

•  Understand the different methods that can be used to apportion resources/items.

•  Divide resources/items in a fair manner.

 

 

 

 

Apportionment and Voting

•  Voting Theory

    Plurality Method

    Borda Count Method

    Plurality with Elimination

    Pairwise Comparison Method

•  Apportionment and its Basic Elements

    Hamilton Method

    Jefferson Method

•  Fairness in Apportionment

•  Huntington-Hill Apportionment Principle

16-17

●        apply concepts/procedures in graph theory to real life problems

●        advocate the use of graphs in real life situations

Mathematics of Graphs

●        Basic Concepts of Graphs

●        Euler Circuit

●        Hamiltonian Circuit

●        Weighted Graphs

●        Euler’s Formula

●        Graph Coloring

18

FINAL EXAM (PROJECT)

name: COURSE POLICIES:o   Classes will st...
intro:
COURSE POLICIES:

o   Classes will start on time. It is the responsibility of a student to come to class promptly and regularly. 
o   A student should be responsible for any missed lessons, written works, performance tasks, or major exams.
o   Activities should be submitted on or before the deadline. (10% deduction to the score if late for 1 min to less than 3 days, 20% deduction if late for 3 days to 5 days, grade of 0 beyond 5 days)
o   A student who accumulates absences beyond 10.8 hours will automatically receive a grade of 5.00 (See the University Policy on attendance below)
o   Cheating is a major offense. (See Student Handbook )
o   Plagiarism or copying others work is also is a major offense.

name: MIDTERM and FINAL PROJECTSI lieu of Midterm and Fi...
intro:
MIDTERM and FINAL PROJECTS

I lieu of Midterm and Final exams, the students are required to submit a mini documentary about any topic of interest in mathematics. Topics should be on any mathematical subjects not discussed inside the classroom and that will enhance the interest of the students in mathematics. Your teacher will present some topics you may explore or you can propose a topic that must be approved by the teacher.  The documentary must be 5-7 minutes.


See the sample projects below  (copy and paste to your browser).

Topic Learning Outcomes 

At the end of the topic, the students are expected to;

  • identify patterns in nature and regularities in the world
  • articulate the importance of mathematics in one’s life
  • argue about the nature of mathematics, what it is, how it is expressed, represented, and used;

name: LESSON 1 - PATTERNS IN NATURE (3 hours) LEARN...
intro:
LESSON 1 - PATTERNS IN NATURE (3 hours) 

LEARNING OUTCOMES:

At the end of the lesson, the student should be able to:

  • know the brief history of Mathematics and;
  • identify different patterns in nature

name: LESSON 2 - FIBONACCI AND THE GOLDEN RATIO(3 hours)...
intro:
LESSON 2 - FIBONACCI AND THE GOLDEN RATIO(3 hours)

LEARNING OUTCOMES:

At the end of the lesson, the student should be able to:

  • define and know what is a Fibonacci sequence and the golden ratio;
  • determine the connection of Fibonacci sequence to the golden ratio and;
  • discuss the importance of Mathematics in one's life.

name: INSTRUCTIONSFor your requirement in Family Health ...
intro:
INSTRUCTIONS

For your requirement in Family Health Nursing, you are required to make a Family Genogram spanning 3 generations (including grandparents from both parental sides, all aunts and uncles for both sides, and then only your siblings for your generation). Include all the notable diseases present in all family members included in the genogram.

Submit your work in a PDF format and upload it to the google form provided below on or before September 15, 2022.

Thank you and God bless.

name: Welcome to our Mandarin 1 Course!Mandarin 1 is a b...
intro:
Welcome to our Mandarin 1 Course!


Mandarin 1 is a basic Mandarin course for learners with no prior knowledge or very limited knowledge of the Chinese Language. The course aims to help the learners to develop communicative skills in Mandarin. The course will enable them to use basic grammar, sentence patterns, and vocabulary. The class time will be used for lecturing and learner activities including listening, speaking, reading, and writing. Learners are expected to preview each lesson before class and study the covered content after class. At the end of the course, learners are expected to pass HSK level 1 exam. 


Ms. Jen Ray Y. Liang 梁建蕾老师

Mandarin Instructor, LaCHS - CASE

Master of Arts in Education (TUA, Ongoing)
Teacher Certificate Program (TUA, 2022)
BS Computer Science (CKSC, 2008)

HSK Level 6 & TOCFL Band C

Email Add: jyliang@tua.edu.ph

Problem #2

Is there a significant difference in the Level of Satisfaction of the patients in the different brands of vaccine? Use 1% level of significance.

name: Welcome to Decision- Making Techniques Class!Makin...
intro:
Welcome to Decision- Making Techniques Class!

Making decisions is a part of everyday life. The decisions we make have the potential to affect ourselves and others in the short and long term.

This course will allow you to internalize the process of decision making, while developing an understanding of its application in diverse settings. It will also cover a comprehensive explanation on the process of decision making in Administration. 

I am Dr. Serena Corbeta-Gomez.
Your professor in this course.
You may communicate with me through thru email: scgomez@tua.edu.ph

or for prompt response through Messenger

name: COURSE DESCRIPTIONSCOURSE CODEPA142COURSE TITLEDEC...
intro:
COURSE DESCRIPTIONS

COURSE CODE

PA142

COURSE TITLE

DECISION MAKING TECHNIQUES

COURSE CREDIT

Lecture: 54 hours (3 hours/ week)


COURSE OUTLINE

MODULE #                               TOPIC/S

             1                                        DECISION MAKING – An Introduction

                                                       1.1 Nature and Characteristics of Decision Making

                                                       1.2 Types of Decisions

                                                       1.3 Factors affecting Decision Making

                                                       1.4 Biases in Decision Making

                                                       1.5 Theories of Decision Making


             2                                       STEPS IN DECISION MAKING 

                                                       2.1  Historical Background of Decision Making

                                                                       2.2 Decision Making Styles

                                                       2.3 Steps in Decision Making


             3                                       IMPORTANCE OF MAKING GOOD DECISIONS

                                                       3.1  Understanding Good Decisions

                                                                      3.2 Strategies of Making Good Decisions Making

                                                       3.3 Techniques/Tools used in Good Decision Making

                                                       3.4 Importance of Making Good Decisions


October 17-21                        MIDTERM EXAMINATION WEEK

 

             4                                       PRINCIPLES OF DECISION MAKING 

                                                       4.1  Principles of Decision Making

                                                                      4.2 Quick Decision Making

                                                       4.3 Herbert Simon's Decision Model


             5                                       DECISION MAKING IN RELATION TO PROBLEM SOLVING

                                                       5.1  Problem Solving and Its Types

                                                       5.2  Problem Solving Cycles in Decision Making

                                                       5.3  Unified Model of problem Solving (Gestalt, Goldman, etc.)

                                                                       5.4 Threats in Decision Making

           

             6                                       DECISION MAKING PROCESS

                                                       6.1  Decision Making Process

                                                       6.2  Decision Making in the Workplace

                                                       6.3  Strategies for Dealing Problems in the Workplace

                                                       6.4  Decision making Skills

                                                       6.5  Decision Making Techniques by Paul Newton

December 7 - 10                    FINAL EXAMINATION FOR Graduating Students

COURSE DESCRIPTIONS

COURSE CODE

DEM300/EDD401

COURSE TITLE

DATA ANALYTICS IN EDUCATIONAL MANAGEMENT SYSTEMS

COURSE CREDIT

Lecture: 54 hours (3 hours/ week)


This course will enable the student to examine the role data analytics plays in helping to make better decisions based on data. The student will explore various models that can be utilized to help summarize, visualize, and interpret data in a variety of disciplines.


COURSE OUTLINE

name: GENERAL COURSE REQUIREMENTSClass participation is ...
intro:
GENERAL COURSE REQUIREMENTS

Class participation is both important and required. In cases the students failed to comply with the assigned tasks for the week due to an emergency, they must contact the teacher thru email at scgomez@tua.edu.ph or thru the CHAT spaces group posted above.

It is expected that assignments or tasks will be submitted on time (by Midnight the day they are due). However, it is recognized that students occasionally have serious problems that prevent work completion. If such dilemma arises, students should contact the teacher in a timely fashion.

The completion of all readings of learning materials assigned for the course is assumed. Since the class will be structured around discussion, completion of learning modules and all class assignments/tasks is crucial. 


GRADING SYSTEM

The following provides the criterion for the overall performance in class.

           CLASS STANDING - 60%

             - Case Analyses, Case Presentation, Oral and Written Presentation - 30%

             - Class Participation, interactive discussion/recitation - 10%

             - Group work/Assignment/Research Capsule - 20%

              

             MAJOR EXAM - 40%

              - Midterm and Final Exam

name: THE DIRECTION OF DATA ANALYTICS IN EDUCATIONAL&nbs...
intro:
THE DIRECTION OF DATA ANALYTICS IN EDUCATIONAL

 MANAGEMENT


A wide-range analysis of vast amounts of information, has played a critical role in transforming business practices and industry procedures worldwide, including educational sector.

The potential big data is essentially tied to how teaching practices will develop, so it is vital to understand how that information impacts teaching on a broader scale.

name: In the past, wealth, influence, and progress is de...
intro:
In the past, wealth, influence, and progress is determined by the amount of land, livestock, and workers. Now it is measured by the amount of data and information that a nation or organization controls. 
The advent of the internet and smart devices reshaped the landscape of how society sees itself, how it relates to others, how it learns and relearns, how it improves itself, and, most importantly,  how it governs its citizens. Technology has become ubiquitous in the daily lives of people and has produced a natural byproduct - DATA. 


Data, however, is growing exponentially.  In 2009, 2 zettabytes of global data were generated. This year, experts measured it at 33 zettabytes and predicted to grow to a staggering 175ZB by 2025, a compounded annual growth rate of 61 percent.  


How is data generated?  Data is mostly generated instantaneously. Take for example a mobile app user. Every time that you pause to look at a product, every time you hit that like button, every time that you type in a query....data is generated, stored, and put into some other use. Just like that, the next time you browse your computer, an advertisement pops up. A new video similar to the last one you liked is put in the queue. Your social media friend whose posts you reacted to become more frequent in your feeds. Data that is processed and analyzed becomes information. It further becomes meaningful information if it is used for its intended purpose or why it was collected in the first place. 

In this context, data and information are important resources in any organization. For educational institutions, it may determine school persistence and student retention, for the financial institutions it may spell the difference between a performing and a nonperforming loan.  The COVID 19 pandemic is a glaring example, data, and information on health care capacity, patient behavior, patient characteristics drive policy response and implementation. 

As an introductory course, it will orient you on how data is created, processed and how the organization will work with data and translate it to data driven decision making and action. You will explore the main types of analytics, the basic statistical, and management tools needed in the analytical process. The set of rules or algorithms used for each will be explained by employing illustrative examples. Some discussions would not include the mathematics behind the scenes but will focus on the conceptual and contextual aspects. Learning will be supported by carefully designed laboratory work and exercises and will conclude with a capstone data project. 
The data analytics course endeavors to introduce and prepare students to undertake analysis of data involving multivariate analysis, modelling, data mining, factor analysis, text analysis, and cluster analysis. Students will be exposed to data management of program related information.

name: Why is DATA ANALYTICS important?Data analytics inv...
intro:
Why is DATA ANALYTICS important?

Data analytics involves qualitative and quantitative procedures and methods to increase efficiency and profit. It is a general term that refers to various data analysis techniques.

In Educational management system, there are different components like technology, content, services, e-learner etc.

Data analytics in the educational management system has a potential to discover, analyze and predict meaningful knowledge from vast data which will help in managing system for flexible planning, execution and prediction for future.

name: Label
Welcome to Research and Applied Data Analytics Cla...
intro:
Welcome to Research and Applied Data Analytics Class!

This course will enable you to examine the role of data analytics  research, by helping make better decisions based on data. You  will explore various models that can be utilized to help summarize, visualize, and interpret data in a variety of discipline.



I am Dr. Serena Corbeta-Gomez.
Your professor in this course.
You may communicate with me through our Workspace and thru email: scgomez@tua.edu.ph

name: COURSE DESCRIPTIONSCOURSE CODEMPA/MBA 112COURSE TI...
intro:
COURSE DESCRIPTIONS

COURSE CODE

MPA/MBA 112

COURSE TITLE

RESEARCH AND APPLIED DATA ANAYTICS

COURSE CREDIT

Lecture: 54 hours (3 hours/ week)



The main purpose of the course is to introduce students to quantitative and qualitative methods for conducting meaningful inquiries and research. They will gain an overview of research intent and design, methodology and technique, format and presentation and data management and analysis informed by commonly used statistical methods. 
The course will develop each student's ability to use this knowledge to become more effective in the field of business and public administration.
These tasks include:
1. developing a hypothesis, a research problem and related questions
2. framing the problem with the correct research methodology
3. collecting data that accurately addresses the research problem
4. measuring the effectiveness of a project/program
5. using data to make better decisions
6. evaluating feasibility of research proposals
7. presenting data to support project/programs to decision makers and consumers


This course will provide an overview of the important concepts of research design, data collection, statistical and interpretative analysis and final report presentation. The focus of this course is not on mastery of data analytics but on the ability to use research in business and public administration.

intro:
GENERAL COURSE REQUIREMENTS

Class participation is both important and required. In cases the students failed to comply with the assigned tasks for the week due to an emergency, they must contact the teacher thru email at scgomez@tua.edu.ph or thru the CHAT spaces group posted above.

It is expected that assignments or tasks will be submitted on time (by Midnight the day they are due). However, it is recognized that students occasionally have serious problems that prevent work completion. If such dilemma arises, students should contact the teacher in a timely fashion.

The completion of all readings of learning materials assigned for the course is assumed. Since the class will be structured around discussion, completion of learning modules and all class assignments/tasks is crucial. 


GRADING SYSTEM

The following provides the criterion for the overall performance in class.

           CLASS STANDING - 60%

             - Case Analyses, Case Presentation, Oral and Written Presentation - 30%

             - Class Participation, interactive discussion/recitation - 10%

             - Group work/Assignment/Research Capsule - 20%

              

             MAJOR EXAM - 40%

name: Label
Mga Isyung Moral Tungkol sa Sekswalidad1. Pagtatal...
intro:
Mga Isyung Moral Tungkol sa Sekswalidad


1. Pagtatalik bago ang kasal ( Pre-marital sex)

Ito ay gawaing pagtatalik ng isang babae at lalaki na wala pa sa wastong edad o nasa edad na subalit hindi pa kasal.

May iba’t ibang pananaw na siyang dahilan kung bakit ang isang tao lalo na ang kabataan ay pumapasok sa maagang pakikipagtalik. Ito ay ang sumusunod:

A. Ito raw ay normal at likas na gampanin ng katawan ng tao upang maging malusog Siya at matugunan ang pangangailangan ng katawan. Kapag hindi raw ito isinagawa hindi mararating ng tao ang kaganapan ng kaniyang buhay. 

B. Maraming kabataan ang nag-iisip na maituturing na tama ang pakikipagtalik lal na kapag ang mga gumagawa nito ay may pagsang-ayon. Karapatan ng tao na makipagtalik at malaya silang gawin ito.

C. Naniniwala ang mga gumagawa ng pre-marital sex na may karapatan silang makaranas ng kasiyahan. 

D. Ang pakikipagtalik ay isang ekspresyon o pagpapahayag ng pagmamahal. 

2. Pornograpiya 

Ang pornograpiya ay nanggaling sa dalawang salitang Griyego, "pome," na may kahulugang prostitute o taong nagbebenta ng panandaliang aliw, at "graphos" na nangangahulugang pagsulat o paglalarawan Samakatuwid, ang pornograpiya ay mga mahahalay na paglalarawan (babasahin, larawan, o palabas) na may layuning pukawin ang seksuwal na pagnanasa ng nanonood o nagbabasa. 

Balikan natin ang mga epekto ng pornograpiya sa isang tao. Ito ay ang sumusunod:

1. Ang maagang pagkahumaling sa pornograpiya ay nagkakaroon ng kaugnayan sa pakikibahagi ng tao o paggawa ng mga abnormal na gawaing seksuwal, lalong- lalo na ang panghahalay. 

2. May mga kalalakihan at kababaihan ding dahil sa pagkasugapa sa pornograpiya ay nahihirapang magkaroon ng malusog na pakikipag-ugnayan sa kanilang ay asawa. Nakararanas sila ng seksuwal na kasiyahan sa panonood at pagbabasa ng pornograpiya, at pang-aabuso sa sarili at hindi sa normal na pakikipagtalik. 

3. Ito rin ay ginagamit ng mga pedophiles sa intemet upang makuha ang kanilang mga bibiktimahin. Ang mga mahahalay na eksenang ipinakikita ng pornograpiya ay pumupukaw ng mga damdaming seksuwal ng kabataang wala pang kahandaan para rito. Nagdudulot ito nang labis na pagkalito sa kanilang murang edad.

3. Mga Pang – aabusong Sekswal 

Walang pangkalahatang pagpapakahulugan ang maaaring ibigay sa pang- aabusong seksuwal. Sa gitna ng mga pang-aabusong ito, ang nangingibabaw na posisyon ay ang pang-aabuso ay isinasagawa ng isang nakatatanda na siyang pumupuwersa sa iIsang nakababata upang gawin ang isang gawaing seksuwal. Ang pang-aabusong seksuwal ay maaaring paglalaro sa maseselang bahagi ng sariling katawano katawan ng iba, paggamit ng ibang bahagi ng katawan para sa seksuwal na gawain at sexual harassment. Maaari rin itong hindi pisikal tulad ng paglalantad ng sarili na gumagawa ng sekswal na gawain at pagkakaroon ng kaligayahang sekswal sa pamamagitan ng pagtingin sa mga hubad na katawan, sekswal na pag – aari o kaya’y panonood ng pagtatalik na isinasagawa ng iba.

4. Prostitusyon 

Ang prostitusyon na sinasabing siyang pinakamatandang propesyon o gawain ay ang pagbibigay ng panandaliang – aliw kapalit ng pera. Dito, binabayaran ang pakikipagtalik upang ang taong umupa ay makadama ng kasiyahang sekswal.

intro:
Mini-PETA 4.1: Mga Isyung Moral Tungkol sa Kawalan ng Paggalang sa Katotohanan

Matapos panuorin ang bidyo, gagawa ang mag-aaral ng isang poster na naghihikayat sa mambabasa sa paggalang sa katotohanan. Maaring gumamit ng Canva o ng iba pang editing sites para maging mas maliwanag ang representasyon ng inyong poster. 


Dapat naglalaman ang poster ng sumusunod:

1. Slogan na nagpapahiwatig ng kahalagahan ng paggalang sa katotohanan. 

2. Maliwanag ang mensahe at madaling mauunawaan ng tumitingin. 

3. Rubrics:

a. Creativity: 40%

b. Content: 40%

c. Punctuality: 20%

Total: 100%

4. I-click lamang ang tile ng Mini-PETA upang mapunta sa Gdrive.

name:
Magandang araw! Gusto mo ba na patuloy
na pag-usa...
intro:
Magandang araw! Gusto mo ba na patuloy na pag-usapan ang tungkol sa paggalang ng seksuwalidad? Batid kong alam mo na ang iba’t-ibang isyu tungkol sa kawalan ng paggalang sa seksuwalidad dahil natalakay na natin ito sa ating mga nakaraang aralin. Ngayong araw, kailangan mong makagawa ng malinaw na posisyon sa isang isyu sa kawalan ng paggalang sa seksuwalidad.

Handa ka na ba?


Ngayon, tatalakayin natin ang ilan sa mga pahayag tungkol sa paggalang sa seksuwalidad. Bawat isa sa atin ay hinahamon na buuin at linangin ang seksuwalidad sapagkat ito ang batayan ng pagiging moral. Malaking hamon sa mga guro, lalong-lalo na sa mga magulang ang pag gabay sa mga anak nila dahil sa mga makabagong teknolohiya na nagdudulot ng malaking epekto sa pag-uugali at kilos ng mga kabataan ngayon. Balikan natin ang mga isyung seksuwal na palagi nating naririnig at nababalitaang madalas na kinakasangkutan ng mga kabataan.

__________________________________________________________________________________________________________________

Pag-usapan natin ito isa-sa. 


Una, Pagtatalik bago ang kasal (Pre-marital sex) 

Ang Pagtatalik bago ang kasal o Pre-marital sex ay gawaing pagtatalik ng isang babae at lalaki na wala pa sa wastong edad o nasa edad na subalit hindi pa kasal. Lumilitaw sa isang pag-aaral na dumadami ang mga kabataan na nakikipagtalik sa ka-partner na hindi pa nila asawa. Ayon sa pag-aaral na 2013 Young Adult Fertility and Sexuality Study o YAFS 4 na ginawa ng UP Population Institute at Demographic Research and Development, lumitaw na isa sa bawat tatlong kabataang Pinoy edad 15 hanggang 24 ang sumasabak na sa pre-marital sex. Katumbas umano ito ng 6.2 milyon kabataang Pinoy na kumakatawan sa 32 porsiyento na mas mataas sa naitalang 23.2 porsiyento noong 2012.(1) Marami sa mga kabataang ito ay walang proteksyon na nagdudulot ng maagang pagbubuntis o ‘di kaya’y pagkakaroon ng Sexually Transmitted Disease o STD. May mga kabataang gumagawa rin ng casal sex o pagtatalik ng walang emotional attachment. Pangkasaysayang itunuturing ito na bawal sa maraming mga kultura at itinuturing na isang kasalanan sa maraming mga relihiyon. Hanggang wala siya sa wastong gulang at hindi pa tumatanggap ng sakramento ng kasal, hindi siya kailanman magkakaroon ng karapatang makipagtalik. Mahalaga ang papel ng mga magulang, guro, at maging sa buong komunidad sa pagpapaalala at pagtuturo ng tamang landas sa mga kabataan ngayon. 

Pangalawa, Pornograpiya. 

Ang pornograpiya ay mga malalaswang litrato, panoorin o babasahin. Samakatuwid, ang pornograpiya ay mga mahahalay na paglalarawan na may layuning pukawin ang seksuwal na pagnanasa ng nanonood o nagbabasa. Sa panahon ngayon, hindi lamang ang paninigarilyo, pag-iinom ng alak, at paggamit ng bawal na gamot ang kinahuhumalingan ng mga kabataan kung hindi pati na rin ang panonood ng ipinagbabawal na palabas o porno. Isa sa mga dahilan nito ay ang tinatawag nating “curiosity”. Dahil din sa modernong teknolohiya mas lalong madali na lamang sa mga kabataan ang makakuha o makapanood nito. Ito ang isa sa mga dahilan kung bakit marami ang pumapasok sa pre-marital sex na nagreresulta ng early pregnancy sa mga kababaihan. Sinisira ng pornograpiya ang kakayahan ng isang tao na masiyahan sa normal na paraan o damdaming dulot ng paglalambingan at espiritwal na pakikipag-ugnayan sa katapat na kasarian. Nawawala rin ang kakayahang mag desisyon, nababago maging ang kagandahang-asal at nagiging hindi normal ang kilos at pag-uugali ng tao dahil dito. Kapag ang tao ay nagiging kasangkapan sa seksuwal na pangangailangan at pagkahumaling, lahat ng mabuting layunin sa pakikipagkapuwa ay maaaring hindi na matupad. Gabay ng mga magulang ang kailangan upang ito ay maiwasan. Kailangan din ng tamang pagtuturo at impormasyon tungkol sa masamang epekto nito mula sa mga paaralan at maging sa komunidad.

Pangatlo, Pang-aabusong Seksuwal. 

Ang pang-aabusong seksuwal o kilala rin sa tawag na pangmomolestiya, ay ang pagpilit ng mga hindi kanais-nais na seksuwal na pag-uugali ng isang tao sa iba. Ang pang-aabusong seksuwal ay maaaring paglalaro sa maseselang bahagi ng sariling katawan o katawan ng iba, paggamit ng ibang bahagi ng katawan para sa seksuwal na gawain at panonood ng pagtatalik na isinasagawa ng iba. Ang kadahilanan ng mga taong nagsasagawa ng mga pang-aabusong seksuwal ay taliwas sa tunay na esensya ng seksuwalidad. Palaging tatandaan na ang paggamit ng kasarian ay para lamang sa pagtatalik ng mag-asawa na naglalayong ipadama ang pagmamahal at bukas sa tunguhing magkaroon ng anak upang bumuo ng pamilya. Ito ang esensiya ng seksuwalidad. 

Pang-apat, Prostitusyon. 

Ang prostitusyon ay ang pakikipagtalik na may bayad at layunin na ang taong umupa ay makadama ng kasiyahang seksuwal. Ito ang tinaguriang pinakamatandang propesyon sa buong mundo sapagkat hindi pa lang ipinapanganak ang mga magulang natin, ay marami na ang gumagawa nito. 6 Karamihan sa nasasangkot sa prostitusyon ay ang mga taong madaling makontrol dulot ng kahirapan at kawalan ng kaalaman o muwang. Nawala na ang kanilang paggalang sa sarili at tamang pagkilala kung kaya’t minabuti na nilang ipagpatuloy ang kanilang masamang karanasan. Dahil nasanay na, hindi na nila magawang tumanggi kung kaya’t naging tuloytuloy na ang kanilang pagpagamit sa masamang gawaing ito. Sa prostitusyon, naaabuso ng tao ang kaloob ng Diyos na seksuwalidad. Isa sa mga halaga ng seksuwalidad ay ang pagkakaranas ng kasiyahang seksuwal mula sa pakikipagtalik sa taong pinakasalan. Nakakaranas ng kasiyahan ang taong nasasangkot sa prostitusyon ngunit hindi ito angkop sa tunay na layunin ng pakikipagtalik. Mahalagang maunawaan na ang pakikipagtalik ay hindi lamang para makadama ng kaligayahang sensuwal. Hindi ito isang paraan para makadama ng kaligayan, kundi ito ay isang paraan na naglalayong pagisahin ang isang babae at lalaki sa diwa ng pagmamahal. Ito ay regalo ng Diyos upang magbuklod ang mag-asawa at magpakarami ayon sa kaniyang kagustuhan.

DATA SET FOR DEMONSTRATION OF COMPUTING ONE-WAY ANOVA TEST

Problem #1
Given the data set, is there a significant difference in the IQ Scores of the Mothers based on the three groupings? Use 5% level of significance.


Problem #2

Is there a significant difference in the Level of Satisfaction of the patients in the different brands of vaccine? Use 1% level of significance.

name: HAPP Lecture Module Coverage and List of TopicsMod...
intro:
HAPP Lecture Module Coverage and List of Topics

Module 1: Prelim Period

  1. Chapter 1: The Human Organism
  2. Chapter 2: The Chemical Basis of Life
  3. Chapter 3: The Cell Structures and Their Functions
  4. Chapter 4: The Tissue
Module 2: Midterm Period
  1. Chapter 5: Integumentary System
  2. Chapter 6: Skeletal System
Module 3: Semi-Final Period
  1. Chapter 7: Muscular System
  2. Chapter 8: Nervous System
  3. Chapter 10: Endocrine System
  4. Chapter 11: Blood
  5. Chapter 12: Heart
  6. Chapter 13: Blood Vessels and Circulation

Module 4: Final Period
  1. Chapter 14: Respiratory System
  2. Chapter 15: Digestive System
  3. Chapter 16: Genitourinary System
  4. Chapter 17: Reproductive System

name: OPTIONAL ACTIVITY FOR QUIZ POINTSKindly download t...
intro:
OPTIONAL ACTIVITY FOR QUIZ POINTS
  1. Kindly download the attached file for the format. do not change the formatting. (Times new roman, 12 font, single space)
  2. Answer the question: HOW can you relate the topic “Biochemistry of Transport” in studying the Nursing Program?
  3. This is plus 5 points on you lec and lab quiz depending on your answer.
  4. The ceiling grade for lec is 20 and 10 for lab. Meaning you cannot exceed points beyond those limits.
  5. The deadline is today, October 15, 2021 at 12 noon. no extension. If the submission closed, you can no longer submit. Submit only at the TLC submission tab under this instruction.
  6. The paper must include an introduction, body and conclusion.
  7. Minimum of 1 page and maximum of 2 pages

name: SPECIAL TAKER REMINDERS:Hello FINAL EXAM SPECIAL T...
intro:
SPECIAL TAKER REMINDERS:


Hello FINAL EXAM SPECIAL TAKERS! 

Thank you for your excuse letters... those emails were reviewed accordingly (which I replied as well). Only those students who emailed me last week were allowed to take the special exam today, 10 January 2022 (Monday). Kindly take note of the time.

Again, today is the special exam for both Biochem lecture and laboratory. If you fail to take the exam today, you will risk having an incomplete grade encoded in your LWSIS which will cause problems in your enrollment for the second semester. 

***ALSO, IF YOU FAIL TO JOIN THE GMEET LINK WHILE TAKING THE EXAM, IT WILL BE INVALID.***

Please do not miss this final chance.

Thank you!


Respectfully,

Ms. Pereda

name: September 17, 2022 (Saturday) - AsynchronousGood d...
intro:
September 17, 2022 (Saturday) - Asynchronous

Good day 1NU04,

We will have asynchronous session today due to events you need to attend. 

Kindly accomplish the following in sequence, you wont be able to proceed to the next task if you will fail to follow this steps.

1. Watch the Recorded discussion 1

2. Finish the Activity 1.1 (short write up only)

3. Watch the Rerded discussion 2

name: Label
Welcome to our Mandarin 1 Course!Mandarin 1 is a b...
intro:
Welcome to our Mandarin 1 Course!


Mandarin 1 is a basic Mandarin course for learners with no prior knowledge or very limited knowledge of the Chinese Language. The course aims to help the learners to develop communicative skills in Mandarin. The course will enable them to use basic grammar, sentence patterns, and vocabulary. The class time will be used for lecturing and learner activities including listening, speaking, reading, and writing. Learners are expected to preview each lesson before class and study the covered content after class. At the end of the course, learners are expected to pass HSK level 1 exam. 


Ms. Jen Ray Y. Liang 梁建蕾老师

Mandarin Instructor, LaCHS - CASE

Master of Arts in Education (TUA, Ongoing)
Teacher Certificate Program (TUA, 2022)
BS Computer Science (CKSC, 2008)

HSK Level 6 & TOCFL Band C

Email Add: jyliang@tua.edu.ph

The course aims to help the learners to develop communicative skills in Mandarin. The course will enable them to use basic grammar, sentence patterns, and vocabulary. The class time will be used for lecturing and learner activities including listening, speaking, reading, and writing. Learners are expected to preview each lesson before class and study the covered content after class. At the end of the course, learners are expected to pass HSK level 1 exam. 


Ms. Jen Ray Y. Liang 梁建蕾老师

Mandarin Instructor, LaCHS - CASE

Master of Arts in Education (TUA, Ongoing)
Teacher Certificate Program (TUA, 2022)
BS Computer Science (CKSC, 2008)

HSK Level 6 & TOCFL Band C

Email Add: jyliang@tua.edu.ph

name: Lesson 4: Mathematics in Our Daily LifeLEARNING OU...
intro:
Lesson 4: Mathematics in Our Daily Life

LEARNING OUTCOMES:

At the end of the lesson, the student should be able to:

  • articulate the importance of mathematics in one’s life.
  • argue about the nature of mathematics, what it is, how it is expressed, represented, and uses.
  • express appreciation for mathematics as a human endeavor.

name: At the end of this unit, you should be able to:&nb...
intro:
At the end of this unit, you should be able to: 
  1. Explain the guest cycle; 
  2. Promote Products and Services to Guests; and 
  3. Identify how to handle guest complaints.

name:
Unit 1: Handling Reservation Request

At the e...
intro:
Unit 1: Handling Reservation Request

At the end of this unit, you should: 
  • Identify the different types of reservation, services, forms and modes of payment. 
  • Perform the steps in receiving and processing reservation.
  • Identify how to record details of reservation.
  • Describe the process in updating reservations.
  • Identify the types of reservation system.
  • Identify the types of computer management software. 
  • Perform the method in operating a computerized reservation system.
  • Enumerate the steps in registering the guests.

name: Unit 2: Providing Accommodation, Reception, Club...
intro:
Unit 2: Providing Accommodation, Reception, Club Reception and Concierge Services

At the end of this unit, you should:
  • Identify the steps in preparing a reception area for guest arrival.
  • Perform during stay function.
  • Familiarize with the different front office forms.
  • Identify the steps in providing club reception services.
  • Identify the steps in providing concierge and bell services.

name: Unit 3: Evaluating Front Office Financial Activi...
intro:
Unit 3: Evaluating Front Office Financial Activities

At the end of this unit, you should:
  • Identify the steps in conducting night audit.
  • Enumerate the methods in preparing guest folio.
  • Explain the steps in collecting cash, cash equivalents or non-cash transactions.
  • Describe the appropriate method in processing receipts and payments.
  • Identify the steps in reconciling financial transactions at the end of the shift.

name: Consider the following before taking the examinati...
intro:
Consider the following before taking the examination:

  1. Test your internet connectivity status. Click here to check your connectivity. 
  2. The examination has time limit of 2 hours only. Once you start, time will begin. 
  3. Exercise integrity and honesty in taking the examination. 
  4. If you feel correct answer is not part of the choices, choose the best answer. 
  5. You will know the result after all students took the test.

name: GROUP REPORTING: Search for one person who co...
intro:
GROUP REPORTING: 

  1. Search for one person who contributed to promotion of environmental awareness to the community. Then, list down his/her contributions or works that made a global/national impact. No repetition among groups.

  2. Choose one biome from our discussion and discuss its importance, problems that have been occurring to this environment brought by human activities (cause and effects), and recommend how the government can solve these problems. No repetition among groups.

  3. As a student, list down different ways an individual can do to save the planet Earth from environmental crises such as global warming, pollution, etc.

  4. Lastly, make a self-made quote (no to copy & pasting) at the end of your presentation that promotes environmental awareness.

Topic Learning Outcomes At the end of the top...
intro:
Topic Learning Outcomes 

At the end of the topic, the students are expected to;

  • discuss the language, symbols, and conventions of mathematics
  • explain the nature of mathematics as a language
  • perform operations on sets
  • differentiate a relation from a function
  • acknowledge  that mathematics is a useful language by applying its use to the real-life problem

name: THE LANGUAGE OF MATHEMATICSLEARNING OUTCOMES:At th...
intro:
THE LANGUAGE OF MATHEMATICS

LEARNING OUTCOMES:

At the end of the lesson, the student should be able to:

  • interpret and extract the language, symbols, and conventions of mathematic and;
  • illustrate and explain the nature of mathematics as a languag

name: TRANSLATION FROM ENGLISH TO MATHEMATICAL STA...
intro:
TRANSLATION FROM ENGLISH TO MATHEMATICAL STATEMENTS 

LEARNING OUTCOMES:

At the end of the lesson, the student should be able to:

  • translate English sentence to mathematical sentence;
  • convert mathematical statements to symbols and;
  • determine the solution for mathematical sentences

name: DATA SET FOR DEMONSTRATION OF COMPUTING ONE-WAY AN...
intro:
DATA SET FOR DEMONSTRATION OF COMPUTING ONE-WAY ANOVA TEST

Problem #1
Given the data set, is there a significant difference in the IQ Scores of the Mothers based on the three groupings? Use 5% level of significance.


Problem #2

Is there a significant difference in the Level of Satisfaction of the patients in the different brands of vaccine? Use 1% level of significance.

name: Course Code/Title: TIC114 - Data AnalyticsCourse C...
intro:
Course Code/Title: TIC114 - Data Analytics

Course Credits: 3 units (2 units Lec, 1 unit Lab)

Course Description: 


This course will enable the student to examine the role data analytics plays in helping to make better decisions based on data. The student will explore various models that can be utilized to help summarize, visualize, and interpret data in a variety of disciplines.
 

Topic Outline


Week

Topics

1

Introduction to Data Analytics

-What is Data Analytics

-Data vs Information

-Types of Data Analytics

-Big Data vs Small Data

2

Data Management and Wrangling

-Data Management

-Data Processing Errors

-Data Wrangling

-Examples of Data Wrangling

-Data Wrangling Steps

 

3-4

Descriptive Analytics

-Types of data

-Data Visualization

- Descriptive Univariate Analysis

-Univariate Indicators

-Understanding Data Summary and Trends  Using Box Plot, QQ Plot, and Scatter Plot

5-6

Diagnostic Analytics

-. Bivariate Analysis

- Understanding Data Distribution Using  Histogram, Density Plot, and Correlograms

- Multidimensional Scaling

- Statistical Inference, Estimation & Hypothesis  Testing

-Model Selection and Test of Significance

- Quantitative Attributes and Test of Relationship

- Qualitative Attributes and Test of Association

- Qualitative & Quantitative Attributes and Test of Difference

7-8

Predictive Analytics

-Regression Analysis Model

- Visualization Using Data Pivoting

-Forecasting Model

-Logistic Regression Model

9

MIDTERM EXAMINATION

10-11

Machine Learning

-Cluster Analysis

-Classification

12

Text Analytics

-Understanding Unstructured Data

- Word Frequencies and Word Clouds

- Text Sentiment Analysis

-Thematic Analysis and Pattern Analysis

- Infographics

13

Map Analysis

-Understanding Spatial Data and Patterns

- Heat maps

- Geographic Trends

14

Audio Analysis

-Speech Analytics and Deep Learning

- Audio Data Processing

- Audio Sentiment Analysis

15-17

DATA ANALYTICS PROJECT

18

Final Examination

name:
Unit 1: Handling Reservation Request

At the e...
intro:
Unit 1: Handling Reservation Request

At the end of this unit, you should: 
  • Identify the different types of reservation, services, forms and modes of payment. 
  • Perform the steps in receiving and processing reservation.
  • Identify how to record details of reservation.
  • Describe the process in updating reservations.
  • Identify the types of reservation system.
  • Identify the types of computer management software. 
  • Perform the method in operating a computerized reservation system.
  • Enumerate the steps in registering the guests.

name: Unit 2: Providing Accommodation, Reception, Club...
intro:
Unit 2: Providing Accommodation, Reception, Club Reception and Concierge Services

At the end of this unit, you should:
  • Identify the steps in preparing a reception area for guest arrival.
  • Perform during stay function.
  • Familiarize with the different front office forms.
  • Identify the steps in providing club reception services.
  • Identify the steps in providing concierge and bell services.

name: Unit 3: Evaluating Front Office Financial Activi...
intro:
Unit 3: Evaluating Front Office Financial Activities

At the end of this unit, you should:
  • Identify the steps in conducting night audit.
  • Enumerate the methods in preparing guest folio.
  • Explain the steps in collecting cash, cash equivalents or non-cash transactions.
  • Describe the appropriate method in processing receipts and payments.
  • Identify the steps in reconciling financial transactions at the end of the shift.

name: ASSIGNMENT #2WHAT TO DO???Be able to answer the fo...
intro:
ASSIGNMENT #2

WHAT TO DO???
Be able to answer the following Research Problems

1. Test if there is significant difference in the Numerical Ability test scores in the different Age groups, use 5% level of significance.
2. Test if there is significant difference in the level of adaptability struggle online of the students in the different college they belong to. Use a 5% level of significance.
3. Does the intensity of the effect on overall exhaustion of students with hybrid learning differ significantly by Sections, using the 5% level of significance?

Use the DATA SET-Assignment #2  given below.

SUBMIT ALL ANSWERS THRU my email address: scgomez@tua.edu.ph

name: Our first week will be a self-study sess...
intro:
• Our first week will be a self-study session as we are giving more time to those individuals who are processing their enrollment.
  • Please be advised that the introductory topics will be included in the midterms exam.
  • Schedules for Synchronous classes will be posted here in the announcements.
  • Please be mindful of submission dates, if you have any issues that will hinder you from submitting on time please email me immediately. Deductions will be applied for late submissions as stated in the student handbook.
  • For those who has problems accessing the resources or questions regarding the posted resources, please email me at jbgalvez@tua.edu.ph.

name: As part of your CMBD class, I am posting mock exam...
intro:
As part of your CMBD class, I am posting mock exams that is in line for the Board exams that you will be taking.

  • Topics will be for Molecular Biology and Laboratory Safety.
  • 30 items per set. 30 minutes per set.
  • Exams can be taken until December 10, 2022.
  • There will be several mock exams that will be posted.
  • These mock exams will also be used as questions for your Finals examination.

name: C++ is regarded as a middle-level langua...
intro:
C++ is regarded as a middle-level language, as it comprises a combination of both high-level and low-level language features.

C++ was developed by Bjarne Stroustrup starting in 1979 at Bell Labs in Murray Hill, New Jersey, as an enhancement to the C language and originally named C with Classes but later it was renamed C++ in 1983.

ASSIGNMENT # 2 - due for October 15, 2022


Statement of the Problem
1. Is there a significant difference between the students' satisfaction when the following are taken into consideration?
1.1 Before and After the pandemic
1.2 Traditional and Hyflex mode of delivery


2. Is there a significant difference in the learning of the students, based on the grouping
2.1 Before and after the pandemic
2.2 traditional and Hyflex mode of delivery


You may send the answers thru my email. scgomez@tua.edu.ph

name: INSTRUCTIONSFor today's asynchronous activity, you...
intro:
INSTRUCTIONS

For today's asynchronous activity, you are tasked to view the recorded lecture below for the Cardiovascular System (Heart and Blood Vessels). Afterwards, you are to proceed in viewing the lab guide for the Cardiovascular System which would give you instructions on what to study in your Anatomy and Physiology Revealed.

After doing all of these, kindly proceed to answer the guide questions provided in the google form below, which would serve as your proof of completion of your activities as well as the attendance for this session.

To give ample time for everybody to work on the said activities, the recordings and the form are open ONLY until 11:55pm of October 28, 2022 (Friday) and are expected to be completed by that time.

Because of the extra time given to complete these activities, NO EXTENSIONS will be provided. Please take note.

Your questions for these topics will be entertained during our synchronous session on our next meeting, as well as the respective quizzes for the previous topic.

Thank you and have fun learning!

name: INSTRUCTIONSFor today's asynchronous activity, you...
intro:
INSTRUCTIONS

For today's asynchronous activity, you are tasked to view the recorded lecture below for the Cardiovascular System (Heart and Blood Vessels). Afterwards, you are to proceed in viewing the lab guide for the Cardiovascular System which would give you instructions on what to study in your Anatomy and Physiology Revealed.

After doing all of these, kindly proceed to answer the guide questions provided in the google form below, which would serve as your proof of completion of your activities as well as the attendance for this session.

To give ample time for everybody to work on the said activities, the recordings and the form are open ONLY until 11:55pm of October 28, 2022 (Friday) and are expected to be completed by that time.

Because of the extra time given to complete these activities, NO EXTENSIONS will be provided. Please take note.

Your questions for these topics will be entertained during our synchronous session on our next meeting, as well as the respective quizzes for the previous topic.

Thank you and have fun learning!

name: PART 2 - APPLIED DATA ANALYTICSIn the past, wealth...
intro:
PART 2 - APPLIED DATA ANALYTICS



In the past, wealth, influence, and progress is determined by the amount of land, livestock, and workers. Now it is measured by the amount of data and information that a nation or organization controls. 
The advent of the internet and smart devices reshaped the landscape of how society sees itself, how it relates to others, how it learns and relearns, how it improves itself, and, most importantly,  how it governs its citizens. Technology has become ubiquitous in the daily lives of people and has produced a natural byproduct - DATA. 


Data, however, is growing exponentially.  In 2009, 2 zettabytes of global data were generated. This year, experts measured it at 33 zettabytes and predicted to grow to a staggering 175ZB by 2025, a compounded annual growth rate of 61 percent.  


How is data generated?  Data is mostly generated instantaneously. Take for example a mobile app user. Every time that you pause to look at a product, every time you hit that like button, every time that you type in a query....data is generated, stored, and put into some other use. Just like that, the next time you browse your computer, an advertisement pops up. A new video similar to the last one you liked is put in the queue. Your social media friend whose posts you reacted to become more frequent in your feeds. Data that is processed and analyzed becomes information. It further becomes meaningful information if it is used for its intended purpose or why it was collected in the first place. 

In this context, data and information are important resources in any organization. For educational institutions, it may determine school persistence and student retention, for the financial institutions it may spell the difference between a performing and a nonperforming loan.  The COVID 19 pandemic is a glaring example, data, and information on health care capacity, patient behavior, patient characteristics drive policy response and implementation. 

As an introductory course, it will orient you on how data is created, processed and how the organization will work with data and translate it to data driven decision making and action. You will explore the main types of analytics, the basic statistical, and management tools needed in the analytical process. The set of rules or algorithms used for each will be explained by employing illustrative examples. Some discussions would not include the mathematics behind the scenes but will focus on the conceptual and contextual aspects. Learning will be supported by carefully designed laboratory work and exercises and will conclude with a capstone data project. 

The data analytics course endeavors to introduce and prepare students to undertake analysis of data involving multivariate analysis, modelling, data mining, factor analysis, text analysis, and cluster analysis. Students will be exposed to data management of program related information.

name: Hours Completion: 3 hoursTopic Learning Outcomes&n...
intro:
Hours Completion: 3 hours

Topic Learning Outcomes 

At the end of the topic, the students are expected to;

  • use different types of reasoning to justify statements and arguments made about mathematics and mathematical concepts 
  • write clear and logical proofs 
  • solve problems involving patterns and recreational problems using Polya’s four steps 
  • organize one’s methods and approaches for proving and solving problems

name: Lesson 1: Inductive and Deductive ReasoningLEARNIN...
intro:
Lesson 1: Inductive and Deductive Reasoning

LEARNING OUTCOMES:

At the end of the lesson, the student should be able to:

  • differentiate inductive from deductive argument.
  • identify the type of reasoning used in a given argument.
  • create own mathematical argument.
  • understand mathematical intuition and certainty.

name: Lesson 2: Polya's Problem Solving MethodLEARNING O...
intro:
Lesson 2: Polya's Problem Solving Method

LEARNING OUTCOMES:

At the end of the lesson, the student should be able to:

  • identify the process in Polya's problem solving method.
  • solve a problem using Polya's method

name: GMEET LINK
intro: GMEET LINK

name: Hours Completion: 3 hoursTopic Learning Outcomes&n...
intro:
Hours Completion: 3 hours

Topic Learning Outcomes 

At the end of the topic, the students are expected to;

  • use logic to justify statements and to create proofs
  • advocate the use of logic in solving real-life problems

name: Lesson 1: Introduction to LogicTopic Learning Outc...
intro:
Lesson 1: Introduction to Logic


Topic Learning Outcomes 

At the end of the topic, the students are expected to;
  • determine whether a given statement is a proposition or not. 
  • express a given proposition as an English sentence and vice versa.

name: Topic 2: Logical OperatorsTopic Learning Outcomes&...
intro:
Topic 2: Logical Operators

Topic Learning Outcomes 

At the end of the topic, the students are expected to;
  • determine the negation, conjunction, disjunction and conditional of a given proposition and its corresponding truth value
  • construct a truth table and determine its truth values of a compound statement

name: Lesson 3: Tautology and Logical EquivalenceTopic L...
intro:
Lesson 3: Tautology and Logical Equivalence

Topic Learning Outcomes 

At the end of the topic, the students are expected to;

  • determine whether the given compound proposition is tautology or not.

  • determine if two propositions are logically equivalent or not.

  • give the statement logically equivalent to a given proposition

name: Lesson 4: Rules of InferenceTopic Learning Outcome...
intro:
Lesson 4: Rules of Inference

Topic Learning Outcomes 

At the end of the topic, the students are expected to:

  • determine whether an argument is valid or not

  • determine the different rules of inference.

name: Videos (For Activity)

name: Interpretation:Using Dancey and Reidy (2004), the ...
intro:
Interpretation:

Using Dancey and Reidy (2004), the following relationship exists between the given paired variables.
1. There is very strong positive relationship ( r = 0.89) between idealized influence to inspirational motivation.
2. There is a moderate positive relationship ( r = 0.38) between idealized influence to collegiality 
3. There is a very strong positive relationship (r = 0.79) between inspirational motivation to participative management.
4. There is a very strong positive relationship ( r = 0.80) between intellectual stimulation with academic excellence.
5. There is a strong positive relationship (r = 0.54) between participative management to collegiality.
6. There is a strong negative relationship ( r = - 0.60) between collegiality to academic excellence.

2. There is a moderate positive relationship ( r = 0.38) between idealized influence to collegiality 
3. There is a very strong positive relationship (r = 0.79) between inspirational motivation to participative management.
4. There is a very strong positive relationship ( r = 0.80) between intellectual stimulation with academic excellence.
5. There is a strong positive relationship (r = 0.54) between participative management to collegiality.
6. There is a strong negative relationship ( r = - 0.60) between collegiality to academic excellence.

name: Introduction of Chinese CharactersChinese characte...
intro:
Introduction of Chinese Characters

Chinese characters, also known as Hanzi (漢字) are one of the earliest forms of written language in the world, dating back approximately five thousand years. Nearly one-fourth of the world’s population still uses Chinese characters today. As an art form, Chinese calligraphy remains an integral aspect of Chinese culture.

There are 47,035 Chinese characters in the Kangxi Dictionary (康熙字典), the standard national dictionary developed during the 18th and 19th centuries, but the precise quantity of Chinese characters is a mystery; numerous, rare variants have accumulated throughout history. Studies from China have shown that 90% of Chinese newspapers and magazines tend to use 3,500 basic characters.

name: Evolution of Chinese CharactersChinese characters ...
intro:
Evolution of Chinese Characters

Chinese characters have evolved over several thousands of years to include many different styles or scripts. The main forms are Oracle Bone Inscriptions (Jia Gu Wen 甲骨文), Bronze Inscriptions, (Jin Wen 金文), Small Seal Characters (Xiao Zhuan 小篆), Official Script (Li Shu 隸書), Regular Script (Kai Shu 楷書), Cursive Writing or Grass Stroke Characters (Cao Shu 草書), and Freehand Cursive (Xing Shu 行書).

name: Welcome to our Mandarin 1 Course!Mandarin 1 is a b...
intro:
Welcome to our Mandarin 1 Course!


Mandarin 1 is a basic Mandarin course for learners with no prior knowledge or very limited knowledge of the Chinese Language. The course aims to help the learners to develop communicative skills in Mandarin. The course will enable them to use basic grammar, sentence patterns, and vocabulary. The class time will be used for lecturing and learner activities including listening, speaking, reading, and writing. Learners are expected to preview each lesson before class and study the covered content after class. At the end of the course, learners are expected to pass HSK level 1 exam. 


Ms. Jen Ray Y. Liang 梁建蕾老师

Mandarin Instructor, LaCHS - CASE

Master of Arts in Education (TUA, Ongoing)
Teacher Certificate Program (TUA, 2022)
BS Computer Science (CKSC, 2008)

HSK Level 6 & TOCFL Band C

Email Add: jyliang@tua.edu.ph

2. There is a moderate positive relationship ( r = 0.38) between idealized influence to collegiality 
3. There is a very strong positive relationship (r = 0.79) between inspirational motivation to participative management.
4. There is a very strong positive relationship ( r = 0.80) between intellectual stimulation with academic excellence.
5. There is a strong positive relationship (r = 0.54) between participative management to collegiality.
6. There is a strong negative relationship ( r = - 0.60) between collegiality to academic excellence.

name: INSTRUCTIONSFor today's asynchronous activity, you...
intro:
INSTRUCTIONS

For today's asynchronous activity, you are tasked to view the recorded lecture below for the Cardiovascular System (Heart and Blood Vessels). Afterwards, you are to proceed in viewing the lab guide for the Cardiovascular System which would give you instructions on what to study in your Anatomy and Physiology Revealed.

After doing all of these, kindly proceed to answer the guide questions provided in the google form below, which would serve as your proof of completion of your activities as well as the attendance for this session.

To give ample time for everybody to work on the said activities, the recordings and the form are open ONLY until 11:55pm of November 11, 2022 (Friday) and are expected to be completed by that time.

Because of the extra time given to complete these activities, NO EXTENSIONS will be provided. Please take note.

Your questions for these topics will be entertained during our synchronous session on our last lecture meeting, as well as the respective quizzes for this topic.

Thank you and have fun learning!
