name: SAMPLE SPEECH OF INTRODUCTION     “...
intro:
SAMPLE SPEECH OF INTRODUCTION

     “Good morning ladies and gentlemen. It’s a great pleasure for me to introduce our speaker today, who is going to talk to us about the ten most common personal financial planning mistakes. Our speaker, although having spent almost his entire career advising people on their finances in places like New York, Los Angeles and Toronto, grew up about thirty miles from where we are right now. He is an award-winning professional accountant who has specialized in personal finances and taxation for over twenty years, and has guided the financial affairs of some of this country’s best-known athletes, entertainers, entrepreneurs and executives. This is a subject in which we should all be deeply interested because it’s by avoiding financial mistakes that we can best ensure our financial futures. Ladies and gentlemen, please join me in welcoming home, Steve Robbins!”


ACTIVITY:

  • TUA HS organized a parent seminar.  Your parent/guardian has been invited to be the guest speaker.
  • Introduce your parent/guardian to the attendees of the seminar by giving a correct speech of introduction.

name: SAMPLE SPEECH OF PRESENTATION      ...
intro:
SAMPLE SPEECH OF PRESENTATION

      “Good evening ladies and gentlemen. My name is Wendy Russell and it’s my honour, as Chair of the Selection Committee, to present this year’s Harry Carmichael Memorial Award. The Harry Carmichael Memorial Award was inaugurated in 1985 in memory of the late Harry Carmichael, who was an outstanding athlete and citizen of our city. The recipient of the Harry Carmichael Award must have demonstrated, over a significant period of time, dedication to the promotion of athletics in our city, combined with a strong sense of civic and family duty. It’s been said of this year’s winner that he has for some time, and continues to, put his whole heart and soul into his community, his sports and his family. He’s a past president of the Kiwanis Club. He’s a member of City Council. In his younger days he played baseball and football at the High School, College, and State levels. He’s coached kids’ football and baseball for the past twenty years. He and his wife have raised four outstanding children. Ladies and gentlemen please acknowledge this year’s Harry Carmichael Memorial Award winner…………Mr. Hank Dalton!”


ACTIVITY


  • From the list above, choose any award to give to your classmate.
  • Write a speech of presentation to accompany the award.

name: IntroductionThe social sciences are the fields of ...
intro:
Introduction

The social sciences are the fields of scholarship that study society. "Social science" is commonly used as an umbrella term to refer to a plurality of fields outside of the natural sciences.


Subject Description: 

The course introduces students to basic concepts, subjects, and methods of inquiry in the disciplines that comprise the Social Sciences. It then discusses influential thinkers and ideas in these disciplines, and relates these ideas to the Philippine setting and current global trends.

name: Lesson Outcome:Students will Analyze the basic con...
intro:
Lesson Outcome:

Students will Analyze the basic concepts and principles of the major social science theories:
a. Structural-functionalism 
b. Marxism
c. Symbolic Interactionism

name:
Reflection•Look at the results of your
self-conce...
intro:
Reflection

•Look at the results of your self-concept inventory and answer the following questions. 
 Write your reflection on an A4 bond paper, observe a one inch margin on all sides. It must be hand written.
To be submitted on Nov. 15, 2022.

 1. Are there qualities you consider as your weakness but other people consider as your strength? What are these?

2. How realistic is your self- image?

3. To what extent does it reflect your real self?

4. How do you Feel about the result? Explain.


Rubric: Content (answer to the guide questions)   – 50%

  Readability and Creativity of presentation  - 20 %

  Neatness  - 15 %

  Promptness of submission  - 15%

name: Introduction
intro: Introduction

name:
Politics is the process by which people
decide ho...
intro:
Politics is the process by which people decide how to live together – whether it is a family, a school, or a nation. Government is the system used to make the decisions. There are many different systems of government – ranging from autocracy to democracy. In a democracy everyone has the right to an equal say, and decisions are made through discussion and voting. In school, young people reflect on different systems of government and how decisions are made in their school and society. They learn about the practice of democratic politics through participation in class and student council elections.

reference: https://www.living-democracy.com/key-concepts/government-and-politics/

name: Subject Description: This course introduces t...
intro:
Subject Description: 

This course introduces the students to the basic concepts and vital elements of politics and governance from a historical-institutional perspective. In particular, it attempts to explain how the important features of our country’s political structures/institutions, processes, and relationships developed across time. In the process, the course helps the learners gain a better appreciation of their rights and responsibilities as individuals and as members of the larger sociopolitical community to strengthen their civic competence.

name: INTRODUCTION TO EARTH
intro: INTRODUCTION TO EARTH

name: Our universe is ...
intro:
Our universe is approximately 13.8 billion years old and the expansion still continues. Have you ever thought how big the actual universe? Is there even a word to describe how vast our universe is?

Universe consists everything from space, time, energy and all matter in it. It has billions of galaxies which also consist billions of stars and planets. Like every other galaxies, Milkyway galaxy is just a small part of the universe, it is one of the million galaxies that exists where our solar system is located. 

Excluding Earth, our solar system consists of seven other planets where the sun is in its center. The third planet from the sun is Earth that harbours astronomical amounts of organisms. Why do you think that Earth is the only known habitable planet up to this day? What’s so special about this planet and how did the intricate land, aquatic and marine forms are built in the first place?

In this lesson, we will explore processes in Earth’s nature and dynamism. At the end, you are expected to answer the focus questions: What is the relationship of all the earth’s subsystems? Can one subsystem survive without the other?

name:
Your goal in
this section is to know the differen...
intro:
Your goal in this section is to know the different subsystems of the Earth.

For now, you already have an idea about the appearance of the Earth. From the picture below, what are the most prominent features that can be seen from space?

As seen in the picture, the most prominent feature is the swirling clouds that are suspended above the ocean. It emphasizes the importance of water but it doesn’t mean that the Earth is dominated by water alone. You’d also see land as patches of brown or green. These are all actually parts of the physical environment of the Earth.


Four Subsystems of the Earth

1. Geosphere –largest solid portion of the earth that includes the Earth’s interior, rocks, minerals, landforms and the processes that shape the Earth’s surface.

2. Atmosphere – blanket of the planet.

3. Hydrosphere – the existence of this provided the medium for different life processes to occur.

4. Biosphere – includes all forms of life.


CHARACTERISTICS OF EARTH NECESSARY TO SUPPORT LIFE

Earth has some characteristics that are unique compared to all planets in the solar system, it has water, an atmosphere, and a source of energy that are essential for life.

WATER

Water is one of the most essential ingredients for chemical reactions that is vital among living organisms. Chemical reactions needed for life would not happen if there is no water. It is considered the universal solvent that is capable of dissolving many substances which in turn can be easily absorbed by living organisms.

ATMOSPHERE

Earth’s atmosphere contains oxygen that is coming from photosynthetic organisms like plants and trees. Another is carbon dioxide which helps in regulating the Earth’s temperature. These examples of gas are essential for life to be sustained.

ENERGY SUPPLY

Sun is the main source of Earth’s energy. Its ideal distance from the Sun gives Earth the right amount of heat and light needed to support life. Nutrients produced by plants with the help of sunlight are used as fuel that living things use. There are also different sources of energy like deep water vents which is internal heating of Earth.

name: Introduction and Focus Questions:Swimming is a gre...
intro:
Introduction and Focus Questions:



Swimming is a great recreational activity. Since Philippines is surrounded by water, swimming becomes one of the great hobbies for some Filipinos. Swimming is also good workout for people who want to stay fit. Swimming can be fun and can be take it to a competitive level. The main strokes used in competitive swimming are breaststroke, freestyle, backstroke, and butterfly. The picture on the left is an example of freestyle. In doing freestyle, a swimmer requires a lot of energy because it needs to move against the current. However, for some people who just want to swim for fun, they may do floating like the picture on the right. Floating does not require much energy because it is only moving with the current. Likewise, in transport mechanisms of the cell, active transport requires energy while passive transport does not. Passive transport does not require the cell to expend more metabolic energy. The small molecules just move through the process of diffusion.

            In this module, you will learn the different types of transport mechanisms and differentiate the active transport from passive transport. At the end of the lesson, you will be able to answer the following questions:

1.    What are the different types of transport mechanisms in cells?

2.    How does exocytosis differ from endocytosis?

3.    How can I relate the concepts of transport mechanism to real life applications?

name: Intro and Focus Questions:      &nb...
intro:
Intro and Focus Questions:


                                                                            


Why Do Cells Divide? Cells divide for many reasons. For example, when you skin your knee, cells divide to replace old, dead, or damaged cells. Cells also divide so living things can grow. When organisms grow, it is not because cells are getting larger. Organisms grow because cells are dividing to produce more and more cells. In human bodies, nearly two trillion cells divide every day.

You and I began as a single cell, or what you would call an egg. By the time you are an adult, you will have trillions of cells. That number depends on the size of the person, but biologists put that number around 37 trillion cells.

In cell division, the cell that is dividing is called the "parent" cell. The parent cell divides into two "daughter" cells. The process then repeats in what is called the cell cycle. 

Cells regulate their division by communicating with each other using chemical signals from special proteins called cyclins. These signals act like switches to tell cells when to start dividing and later when to stop dividing. It is important for cells to divide so you can grow and so your cuts heal. It is also important for cells to stop dividing at the right time.  If a cell cannot stop dividing when it is supposed to stop, this can lead to a disease called cancer.  

Some cells, like skin cells, are constantly dividing. We need to continuously make new skin cells to replace the skin cells we lose. Did you know we lose 30,000 to 40,000 dead skin cells every minute? That means we lose around 50 million cells every day.  This is a lot of skin cells to replace, making cell division in skin cells is so important. Other cells, like nerve and brain cells, divide much less often.

Depending on the type of cell, there are two ways cells divide—mitosis and meiosis. Each of these methods of cell division has special characteristics. One of the key differences in mitosis is a single cell divides into two cells that are replicas of each other and have the same number of chromosomes. This type of cell division is good for basic growth, repair, and maintenance. In meiosis a cell divides into four cells that have half the number of chromosomes. Reducing the number of chromosomes by half is important for sexual reproduction and provides for genetic diversity.

SPEECH OF DEDICATION

 

SAMPLE SPEECH

name: Label

Table 2.1 is a typical line listing from
an epide...
intro:
Table 2.1 is a typical line listing from an epidemiologic investigation of an apparent cluster of hepatitis A.

The LINE LISTING is one type of epidemiologic database and is organized like a spreadsheet with rows and columns.
Typically, each row is called a RECORD or OBSERVATION and represents one person or case of disease.

Each column is called a variable and contains information about one characteristic of the individual.

A VARIABLE can be any characteristic that differs from person to person, such as height, sex, status, or physical activity pattern.
The VALUE of a variable is the number or descriptor that applies to a particular person.

name:
TYPES OF DATAA NOMINAL-scale variable is
one whos...
intro:
TYPES OF DATA


A NOMINAL-scale variable is one whose values are categories without any numerical ranking.
An ORDINAL-scale variable has values that can be ranked but are not necessarily evenly spaced, such as stage of cancer (see Table 2.3).
An INTERVAL-scale variable is measured on a scale of equally spaced units, but without a true zero point, such as date of birth.
A RATIO-scale variable is an interval variable with a true zero point, such as height in centimeters or duration of illness.

name: When a database contains only a limited number of ...
intro:
When a database contains only a limited number of records, you can easily pick out the information you need directly from the raw data.
With larger databases, however, picking out the desired information at a glance becomes increasingly difficult.


To facilitate the task, the variables can be summarized into tables called frequency distributions.

A FREQUENCY DISTRIBUTION displays the values a variable can take and the number of persons or records with each value.

It is commonly use if the data type is nominal or ordinal scale.

name:
CONTINUOUS VARIABLES are
often further summarized...
intro:
CONTINUOUS VARIABLES are often further summarized with measures of central location and measures of spread.

> Measures of Central Location (mean, median and mode)
> Measures of Spread (Range, variance and standard deviation)



Source: http://conflict.lshtm.ac.uk/page_125.htm

name:
The third property of a frequency
distribution is...
intro:
The third property of a frequency distribution is its shape.
The graphs of the the theoretical frequency distributions in Figure 2.4 were completely symmetrical.


Frequency distributions of some characteristics of human populations tend to be symmetrical.
On the other hand, the data on parity in Figure 2.5 are asymmetrical or more commonly referred to as skewed.




Figure 2.6, distribution A is skewed to the right.
A distribution that has a central location to the right and a tail to the left is said to be negatively skewed or skewed to the left.
In Figure 2.6, distribution C is skewed to the left.

The LINE LISTING is one type of epidemiologic database and is organized like a spreadsheet with rows and columns.
Typically, each row is called a RECORD or OBSERVATION and represents one person or case of disease.

Each column is called a variable and contains information about one characteristic of the individual.

A VARIABLE can be any characteristic that differs from person to person, such as height, sex, status, or physical activity pattern.
The VALUE of a variable is the number or descriptor that applies to a particular person.

name: Interpretation:Using Dancey and Reidy (2004), the ...
intro:
Interpretation:

Using Dancey and Reidy (2004), the following relationship exists between the given paired variables.
1. There is very strong positive relationship ( r = 0.89) between idealized influence to inspirational motivation.
2. There is a moderate positive relationship ( r = 0.38) between idealized influence to collegiality 
3. There is a very strong positive relationship (r = 0.79) between inspirational motivation to participative management.
4. There is a very strong positive relationship ( r = 0.80) between intellectual stimulation with academic excellence.
5. There is a strong positive relationship (r = 0.54) between participative management to collegiality.
6. There is a strong negative relationship ( r = - 0.60) between collegiality to academic excellence.

Example 1. A study was conducted to find out ...
intro:
Example 1. 

A study was conducted to find out if years of experience predict salary of employees.

We conduct Simple Regression Analysis in JAMOVI.

> First is to satisfy Assumption Checks


(1)DW Statistic = 1.65 (within 1.5<d<2.5) satisfied.

(2)VIF = 1 and T = 1 satisfied.

(3) Normality p value = 0.195 > 5% satisfied.

(4) Graphs and illustrations satisfied.



Linearity satisfied seen in the Q-Q Plot.


Homoscedasticity satisfied.

name: To check if years of experience predicts salary of...
intro:
To check if years of experience predicts salary of employees significantly.

Here is the result of the analysis.


Interpretation:

Based in Table 1, there is a very strong (R = 0.978) strength of prediction seen in the relationship between years of experience and the salary of the employees accounted to 95.7% variation in the salary due to the differences in the years of experiences.

Further, years of experience significantly a very good predictor of salary. (p-value <.001).

Model created:

Y(Salary) = 9450(Years of Experience) + 25792

name: Decision Making and Problem SolvingDecision making...
intro:
Decision Making and Problem Solving

Decision making is a process of identifying and evaluating choices. Numerous decisions is created everyday as a product of problem solving. Problem solving is the application of ideas, skills or factual information to achieve the solution to a problem or to reach a desired outcome.

Problem-solving and decision-making skills are both important because they can help us navigate a variety of situations that might come up at work through the use of analytical and critical thinking.


Just like in decision making, problem solving also follows important steps.
1. Identify the problem
2. Search for alternatives
3. Weigh Alternatives
4. Make a choice
5. Implement the choice
6. Evaluate the results and if necessary, start the process again.

Reference: https://opentextbc.ca/workinginfoodserviceindustry/chapter/effective-problem-solving-and-decision-making/

name: CHALLENGES IN DECISION MAKINGThe decision-making p...
intro:
CHALLENGES IN DECISION MAKING

The decision-making process can pose interesting challenges to leaders. 

1. Bounded Rationality

The notion that challenging complex issues that leaders cannot fully grasp, makes them unable to be rational about the situation, and are, therefore, incapable of understanding an alternative.

“You learn something new every day.” 

With that ideal, no one is ever fully knowledgeable. Therefore, as a leader, it would be best not to work against bounded rationality, but with bounded rationality, understanding its place along continual learning.

2. Escalation of Commitment

This is the idea that leaders and managers remain committed to a poor decision, or find it hard to remove themselves from a poor decision rationally. It is hard, as a leader, to take “being wrong,” but it is a learning process. Mistakes are committed to learn from it and never do the same mistake. It is fine that a poor decision is made, but there are tools in place to help a learner develop new skills to overcome past mistakes, eventually removing the challenge of escalation.

3. Time constraints

When there is little time available to collect information with rationality and make an effective decision, time becomes constraints.

Although some instances are out of leaders’ control, effective planning, forecasting, and time management can be used to alleviate time constraints.

4. Uncertainty

The act of not knowing an outcome until said outcome has transpired and is tied in the belief that an outcome is envisioned, but not seen.  

Leaders can only follow a methodology that works best for the learner to absorb content. A desired outcome can be conceived of, but the uncertainty allows only sight of the outcome after the decision has transpired.

5. Biases

One of the most common errors that leaders and managers make is trusting a poor decision based on preconceived notions. 

Confirmation bias 

The idea that our initial beliefs are given more attention, we pay less attention to beliefs outside of our world view. 

Leader’s own confirmation can have an impact on how they work within organizations, and have an adverse effect on the people who do not follow their precise worldviews. 
One way to avoid bias is to be knowledgeable and empathetic about a contrary idea.  Leaders may make a decision based on personal worldviews, but if they are acknowledging that it is coming from a form of bias, and can work with incorporating contrary views for a more collaborative decision-making process, then such influences can be circumvented.


6. Conflict

Within learning organizations, leaders and managers are constantly faced with barriers in their decision-making from personal indifference or organizational indifference. 

When faced with barriers, the use of expert power can be an effective tool to help avoid barriers.  Being knowledgeable about a variety of situations can be beneficial for members to hear.  

In addition, acknowledging that they are not the beacon of knowledge, and that their decisions may have biases or be uncertain, would lead to a holistic discussion and a collaborative decision, so that everyone is on-board and accountable.

Reference: https://ecampusontario.pressbooks.pub/educationleadershipmanagement/chapter/8-3-challenges-to-effective-decision-making/

name: PROBLEM SOLVING  using SWOT ANALYSISSWOT Anal...
intro:
PROBLEM SOLVING  using SWOT ANALYSIS

SWOT Analysis is a powerful technique for understanding your strengths and weaknesses, and for looking at the opportunities and threats you face.

What makes SWOT particularly powerful is that, with a little thought, it can help you uncover opportunities that you are well placed to take advantage of. It also helps you understand your weaknesses, so you can manage and eliminate threats that would otherwise catch you unawares.

To carry out a SWOT Analysis, write down answers to the following questions:

1. STRENGTHS

Consider this from your own perspective, and from the point of view of the people around you. And don’t be modest; be as objective as you can. If you are having any difficulty with this, try writing down a list of your characteristics. Some of these will hopefully be strengths!

• What advantages (for example, skills, education or connections) do you have that many others don’t have? 

• What do you do better than most anyone else? 

• What personal resources do you have access to? 

• What do other people (and your coach in particular) see as your strengths?


2. WEAKNESSES

Do other people perceive weaknesses that you do not see? Do others consistently out-perform you in key areas? It is best to be realistic now, and face any unpleasant truths as soon as possible.

• What could you improve? 
• What should you avoid? 
• What things are the people around you likely to see as weaknesses?

3. OPPORTUNITIES

• Where are the good opportunities facing you? 
• What are the interesting trends you are aware of? 

Useful opportunities can come from such things as: 
• Changes in technology, markets and your company        on both a broad and narrow scale 

• Changes in government policy related to your field 
• Changes in social patterns, population profiles, lifestyle, etc. 
• Local events 

A useful approach to looking at opportunities is also to look at your strengths and ask yourself whether these open up any opportunities. 

Alternatively, look at your weaknesses and ask yourself whether you could open up opportunities by eliminating them.

4. THREATS

• What obstacles do you face? 
• What are the people around you doing? 

• Is your job (or the demand for the things you do) changing? • Is changing technology threatening your position? 

• Could any of your weaknesses seriously threaten you? 

Carrying out this analysis will often be illuminating - both in terms of pointing out what needs to be done, and in putting problems into perspective.

To check if years of experience predicts salary of employees significantly.

Here is the result of the analysis.


Interpretation:

Based in Table 1, there is a very strong (R = 0.978) strength of prediction seen in the relationship between years of experience and the salary of the employees accounted to 95.7% variation in the salary due to the differences in the years of experiences.

Further, years of experience significantly a very good predictor of salary. (p-value <.001).

Model created:

Y(Salary) = 9450(Years of Experience) + 25792

name: Label
Label
Regression Analysis in Predicting Future ValueMODE...
intro:
Regression Analysis in Predicting Future Value


MODEL in Predicting Salary
SALARY = 9450(Years of Experience) + 25792

Example. What is the salary of Pedro 15 years from now? How about Sharon 10 years from now?

Solution:

SALARY(Pedro) = 9450(15) + 25792 = 167, 542

SALARY(Sharon) = 9450(10) + 25792 = 120,292

EXAMPLE:
intro: EXAMPLE:

name: Label
Example 1. A study was conducted to find out ...
intro:
Example 1. 

A study was conducted to find out if years of experience predict salary of employees.

We conduct Simple Regression Analysis in JAMOVI.

> First is to satisfy Assumption Checks


(1)DW Statistic = 1.65 (within 1.5<d<2.5) satisfied.

(2)VIF = 1 and T = 1 satisfied.

(3) Normality p value = 0.195 > 5% satisfied.

(4) Graphs and illustrations satisfied.



Linearity satisfied seen in the Q-Q Plot.


Homoscedasticity satisfied.

MOTIVATIONAL SPEECH
November 21, 2022 (Monday)
I...
intro:
MOTIVATIONAL SPEECH

November 21, 2022 (Monday)

Instructions:

  1. Create groups of three.
  2. Discuss and agree on the content of your group motivational speech.  There are three types: a) hero b) survivor c) religious
  3.  Write the draft of your group motivational speech on one whole sheet of paper.


Some Tips:

Excellent example of a survivor speech.

 

Suggested parts of your motivational speech:
  1. Get the audience' attention.
  2. Narrate a difficult time in your life briefly.
  3. Present the life lesson (a word or phrase) you want to share.
  4. Explain how how you learned this life lesson and/or how you applied it to your life.
  5. Explain the significance of the life lesson to the audience' lives.
  6. End on a positive note.


November 22, 2022 (Tuesday)

  1. Finalize your group motivational speech.
  2. Rehearse the delivery of your group motivational speech.


November 23, 2022 (Wednesday)

Today, use your phone to take video clips of your group members, to use in your short motivational video.  The content or story of which is the motivational speech that you should have finished by now.

Here's an example:

November 22, 2022 (Tuesday)

November 23, 2022 (Wednesday)

Today, use your phone to take video clips of your group members, to use in your short motivational video.  The content or story of which is the motivational speech that you should have finished by now.

Here's an example:

name: Module 2 described mea...
intro:
Module 2 described measures of central location and spread, which are useful for summarizing continuous variables.
        However, many variables used by field epidemiologists are categorical variables, some of which have only two categories — exposed yes/no, test positive/negative, case/control, and so on.
         These variables have to be summarized with frequency measures such as ratios, proportions, and rates.
         Incidence, prevalence, and mortality rates are three frequency measures that are used to characterize the occurrence of health events in a population.
        Epidemiological information is used to plan and evaluate strategies to prevent illness and as a guide to the management of patients in whom disease has already developed. In epidemiology, risk refers to the likelihood, of an individual in a defined population to develop a disease or other adverse health problem.

name: SYNCHRONOUS SESSION (NOVEMBER 22)
intro: SYNCHRONOUS SESSION (NOVEMBER 22)

name: A measure of central location...
intro:
A measure of central location provides a single value that summarizes an entire distribution of data.
      In contrast, a frequency measure characterizes only part of the distribution.

Frequency measures compare one part of the distribution to another part of the distribution, or to the entire distribution.

Common frequency measures are ratios, proportions, and rates.

name: Label

In epidemiology, ratios are used as both
descript...
intro:
In epidemiology, ratios are used as both descriptive measures and as analytic tools.
As a descriptive measure, ratios can describe the male-to-female ratio of participants in a study, or the ratio of controls to cases (e.g., two controls per case).

name:
Proportions are also used to describe the
amount ...
intro:
Proportions are also used to describe the amount of disease that can be attributed to a particular exposure.

For example, on the basis of studies of smoking and lung cancer, public health officials have estimated that greater than 90% of the lung cancer cases that occur are attributable to cigarette smoking.




As illustrated in Table 3.1, the proportionate mortality for HIV was 0.5% among all age groups, and 5.3% among those aged 25–44 years.
In other words, HIV infection accounted for 0.5% of all deaths, and 5.3% of deaths among 25–44 year old.

name:
In epidemiology, a rate is a measure of
the frequ...
intro:
In epidemiology, a rate is a measure of the frequency with which an event occurs in a defined population over a specified period of time.

Because rates put disease frequency in the perspective of the size of the population, rates are particularly useful for comparing disease frequency in different locations, at different times, or among different groups of persons with potentially different sized populations; that is, a rate is a measure of risk.

To a non-epidemiologist, rate means how fast something is happening or going.
To epidemiologists, a rate describes how quickly disease occurs in a population.


Other types of RATES are the following.


Table 3.2 summarizes some of the common epidemiologic measures as ratios, proportions, or rates

name: MORBIDITY vs. MORTALITYDeath or mortality is class...
intro:
MORBIDITY vs. MORTALITY






Death or mortality is classified as GDR and NDR. GDR represent the death rate including all deaths while NDR represents death rate excluding deaths under 48 hrs. after admission.





The net death rate is different from the gross death rate because it does not include deaths that occurred less than 48 hours after admission to the health care facility. The net death rate is useful because it provides a more realistic account of patient deaths related to patient care provided by a specific health care facility.

name: WHAT TO DO?Be able to make sense with the data giv...
intro:
WHAT TO DO?

Be able to make sense with the data given in CASE Activity #2 by applying different Descriptive measures such as rate, ratio and proportion mentioned in Module 3: Measures of Risk.


Your group is expected to:

1. Create four(4) statements of the problem.
2. Use the data as per the stated problems in number 1.
3. Analyze the data in consonance with the stated problems.
4. Use the appropriate descriptive measures and,
5. Present the output in a creative and artistic way.


Rubrics for the grading


DEADLINE OF SUBMISSION: December 6, 2022

Be able to make sense with the data given in CASE Activity #2 by applying different Descriptive measures such as rate, ratio and proportion mentioned in Module 3: Measures of Risk.


Your group is expected to:

1. Create four(4) statements of the problem.
2. Use the data as per the stated problems in number 1.
3. Analyze the data in consonance with the stated problems.
4. Use the appropriate descriptive measures and,
5. Present the output in a creative and artistic way.


Rubrics for the grading


DEADLINE OF SUBMISSION: December 7, 2022

name: INSTRUCTIONSFor today's asynchronous activity, you...
intro:
INSTRUCTIONS

For today's asynchronous activity, you are tasked to view the recorded lecture below for the Cardiovascular System (Heart and Blood Vessels). Afterwards, you are to proceed in viewing the lab guide for the Cardiovascular System which would give you instructions on what to study in your Anatomy and Physiology Revealed.

After doing all of these, kindly proceed to answer the guide questions provided in the google form below, which would serve as your proof of completion of your activities as well as the attendance for this session.

To give ample time for everybody to work on the said activities, the recordings and the form are open ONLY until 11:55pm (GMT+8 Philippine Standard Time) of November 28, 2022 (Monday) and are expected to be completed by that time.

Because of the extra time given to complete these activities, NO EXTENSIONS will be provided. Please take note.

Your questions for these topics will be entertained during our synchronous session on our last lecture meeting, as well as the respective quizzes for this topic.

Thank you and have fun learning!

name: Label
Hours Completion: 6 hoursTopic Learning Outcomes&n...
intro:
Hours Completion: 6 hours

Topic Learning Outcomes 

At the end of the topic, the students are expected to;

  • Understand the concepts of isometry and symmetry
  • Create symmetric patterns
  • Identify the symmetric pattern used in an art.
  • Create wallpaper pattern
  • Identify the wallpaper pattern used in an art.
  • Identify the different tessellations.
  • Create tessellation model.
  • Contribute to the enrichment of the Filipino culture and arts using concepts in geometry

name: LESSON 1 - Isometry and SymmetryLEARNING OUTCOMES:...
intro:
LESSON 1 - Isometry and Symmetry

LEARNING OUTCOMES:

At the end of the lesson, the student should be able to:

  • perform isometry operations.
  • identify the isometry used in  given symmetric objects.

LEARNING OUTCOMES:

At the end of the lesson, the student should be able to:

name: Label (copy) (copy) (copy)

EXAMPLE:
intro: EXAMPLE:

name: Label
Example 1. A study was conducted to find out ...
intro:
Example 1. 

A study was conducted to find out if years of experience predict salary of employees.

We conduct Simple Regression Analysis in JAMOVI.

> First is to satisfy Assumption Checks


(1)DW Statistic = 1.65 (within 1.5<d<2.5) satisfied.

(2)VIF = 1 and T = 1 satisfied.

(3) Normality p value = 0.195 > 5% satisfied.

(4) Graphs and illustrations satisfied.



Linearity satisfied seen in the Q-Q Plot.


Homoscedasticity satisfied.

name: To check if years of experience predicts salary of...
intro:
To check if years of experience predicts salary of employees significantly.

Here is the result of the analysis.


Interpretation:

Based in Table 1, there is a very strong (R = 0.978) strength of prediction seen in the relationship between years of experience and the salary of the employees accounted to 95.7% variation in the salary due to the differences in the years of experiences.

Further, years of experience significantly a very good predictor of salary. (p-value <.001).

Model created:

Y(Salary) = 9450(Years of Experience) + 25792

name: Regression Analysis in Predicting Future ValueMODE...
intro:
Regression Analysis in Predicting Future Value


MODEL in Predicting Salary
SALARY = 9450(Years of Experience) + 25792

Example. What is the salary of Pedro 15 years from now? How about Sharon 10 years from now?

Solution:

SALARY(Pedro) = 9450(15) + 25792 = 167, 542

SALARY(Sharon) = 9450(10) + 25792 = 120,292

name:
Binary Tree -is a
special type of tree in wh...
intro:
Binary Tree -is a special type of tree in which every node or vertex has either no child node or one child node or two child nodes.

- a data structure in which a record is linked to two successor records, usually referred to as the left branch when greater and the right when less than the previous record.

-is a method of placing and locating files (called records or keys) in a database, especially when all the data is known to be in random access memory (RAM).

-is a method of placing and locating files (called records or keys) in a database, especially when all the data is known to be in random access memory (RAM).

name: To determine if preservation procedures were effec...
intro:
To determine if preservation procedures were effective, food products are tested for sterility or if these are free of pathogens. Sterility testing performed commercially includes the following tests: 
1) thermal resistance test
2) sterility testing e.g. membrane filtration and broth dilution.

The following videos demonstrate these methods. 

A link to the WHO sterility guideline is also provided below for your reference.

name: The key to epidemiologic analysis is comparison.Ca...
intro:
The key to epidemiologic analysis is comparison.
Cases by which comparing the observed group with another group that represents the expected level is considered.

A measure of association quantifies the relationship between exposure and disease among the two groups. 

Exposure is used loosely to mean not only exposure to foods, mosquitoes, a partner with a sexually transmissible disease, or a toxic waste dump, but also inherent characteristics of persons (for example, age, race, sex), biologic characteristics (immune status), acquired characteristics (marital status), activities (occupation, leisure activities), or conditions under which they live (socioeconomic status or access to medical care)

The measures of association that described in the following section compare disease occurrence among one group with disease occurrence in another group. 

Examples of measures of association include risk ratio (relative risk), rate ratio, odds ratio, and proportionate mortality ratio.

name: RISK RATIOA risk ratio (RR), also called relative ...
intro:
RISK RATIO

A risk ratio (RR), also called relative risk, compares the risk of a health event (disease, injury, risk factor, or death) among one group with the risk among another group.

Method for Calculating risk ratio 
 *The formula for risk ratio (RR) is


NOTE:

If R = 1, then it indicates that there is an identical risk among the two groups.
R > 1, indicates an increased risk for the group in the numerator, usually the exposed group.
 R < 1, indicates a decreased risk for the exposed group, that is perhaps exposure actually protects against disease occurrence.

name: EXAMPLE 1In an outbreak of tuberculosis among pris...
intro:
EXAMPLE 1
In an outbreak of tuberculosis among prison inmates in South Carolina in 1999, 28 of 157 inmates residing on the East wing of the dormitory developed tuberculosis, compared with 4 of 137 inmates residing on the West wing.
The data are presented in the table below.


Step 1 - Calculate first the attack rate for each group.


Attack Rate (Risk) for exposed = a/(a+b) 

Attack Rate (Risk) for unexposed = c/(c+ d) 

Therefore,

Risk of tuberculosis in the East Wing = a/(a+b) = 28/(157) 

                                                                                            = 0.178 or 17.8%
Risk of tuberculosis in the West Wing= c/(c+ d) = 4/(137) 

                                                                                            = 0.029 or 2.9%

The Risk Ratio is
a/(a+b) : c/(c+d) = 17.8/2.9 = 6.1

Interpretation:
Therefore, the inmates who resided in the East wing of the dormitory were 6.1 times as likely to develop tuberculosis than those at the West wing.

name: EXAMPLE 2In an outbreak of varicella (chickenpox) ...
intro:
EXAMPLE 2
In an outbreak of varicella (chickenpox) in Oregon in 2002, varicella was diagnosed in 18 of 152 vaccinated children compared with 3 of 7 unvaccinated children. 

Calculate the risk ratio.


Solution:


Risk of chickenpox among vaccinated = 18/152 = 0.118 = 11.8%
Risk of chickenpox among unvaccinated = 3/7 = 0.429 = 42.9%
                       Risk Ratio = 11.8/42.9 = 0.275  


A RR of less than 1, indicates a decreased risk or protective effect for the exposed(vaccinated) children. 

Interpretation:
The Risk Ratio of 0.275 indicates that the vaccinated children were only approximately one-fourth as likely (27.5%, actually) to develop chickenpox as were unvaccinated children.

name: RATE RATIOA rate ratio compares the incidence rate...
intro:
RATE RATIO

A rate ratio compares the incidence rates, person-time rates, or mortality rates of two groups. 

As with the risk ratio, the two groups are typically differentiated by demographic factors or by exposure to a suspected causative agent. 

The rate for the group of primary interest is divided by the rate for the comparison group.


The interpretation of the value of a rate ratio is similar to that of the risk ratio. 

That is, a rate ratio of 1.0 indicates equal rates in the two groups, a rate ratio greater than 1.0 indicates an increased risk for the group in the numerator, and a rate ratio less than 1.0 indicates a decreased risk for the group in the numerator.

name: EXAMPLE 1A study was conducted and found out that ...
intro:
EXAMPLE 1

A study was conducted and found out that there is a perceived increased in Acute respiratory illness recorded in hospital A. In October of 2020, there were 11.6 cases per 1000 patients in hospital A per week and in November of 2020, there were 5.3 cases per 1000 patients. 
Calculate the Rate Ratio.

Rate Ratio = 11.6/5.3 = 2.2

Interpretation:

The findings indicate that there were more than twice as likely of patients in Hospital A during October than that of November per 1000 patients per week.

name: EXAMPLE 2Consider the table below.Compute for the ...
intro:
EXAMPLE 2
Consider the table below.


Compute for the Rate Ratio comparing current smokers 

with Non-smokers.


Solution:
Rate Ratio = 1.3/0.07 = 18.57 = 19

Note that if the rate ratio is greater than 1, means there is likely an increased risk for the smokers to get lung cancer as that of the non-smokers. 
It will be 19 times more likely to happen to smokers compared to non-smokers for every 1000 persons in years.

name: ODDS RATIOAn odds ratio (OR) is another measure of...
intro:
ODDS RATIO

An odds ratio (OR) is another measure of association that quantifies the relationship between an exposure with two categories and health outcome.


The odds ratio is sometimes called the cross-product ratio because the numerator is based on multiplying the value in cell “a” times the value in cell “d,” whereas the denominator is the product of cell “b” and cell “c.” 

A line from cell “a” to cell “d” (for the numerator) and another from cell “b” to cell “c” (for the denominator) creates an x or cross on the two-by-two table.

name: EXAMPLE 1Refer to the given tableCalculate the&nbs...
intro:
EXAMPLE 1

Refer to the given table


Calculate the 
1. Risk Ratio
2. Odds Ratio


Solution:

Risk Ratio = 5.0/1.0 = 5.0

Interpretation:
There is an increased risk or protective effect for the exposed group that is five times more likely to have that disease.


Odds Ratio = (100x 7920)/(1900x80) = 5.2

Notice that the odds ratio of 5.2 is close to the risk ratio of 5.0. 

That is one of the attractive features of the odds ratio — when the health outcome is uncommon, the odds ratio provides a reasonable approximation of the risk ratio. 

Another attractive feature is that the odds ratio can be calculated with data from a case-control study, whereas neither a risk ratio nor a rate ratio can be calculated.

name: The key to epidemiologic analysis is comparison.Ca...
intro:
The key to epidemiologic analysis is comparison.
Cases by which comparing the observed group with another group that represents the expected level is considered.

A measure of association quantifies the relationship between exposure and disease among the two groups. 

Exposure is used loosely to mean not only exposure to foods, mosquitoes, a partner with a sexually transmissible disease, or a toxic waste dump, but also inherent characteristics of persons (for example, age, race, sex), biologic characteristics (immune status), acquired characteristics (marital status), activities (occupation, leisure activities), or conditions under which they live (socioeconomic status or access to medical care)

The measures of association that described in the following section compare disease occurrence among one group with disease occurrence in another group. 

Examples of measures of association include risk ratio (relative risk), rate ratio, odds ratio, and proportionate mortality ratio.

name: RISK RATIOA risk ratio (RR), also called relative ...
intro:
RISK RATIO

A risk ratio (RR), also called relative risk, compares the risk of a health event (disease, injury, risk factor, or death) among one group with the risk among another group.

Method for Calculating risk ratio 
 *The formula for risk ratio (RR) is


NOTE:

If R = 1, then it indicates that there is an identical risk among the two groups.
R > 1, indicates an increased risk for the group in the numerator, usually the exposed group.
 R < 1, indicates a decreased risk for the exposed group, that is perhaps exposure actually protects against disease occurrence.

name: EXAMPLE 1In an outbreak of tuberculosis among pris...
intro:
EXAMPLE 1
In an outbreak of tuberculosis among prison inmates in South Carolina in 1999, 28 of 157 inmates residing on the East wing of the dormitory developed tuberculosis, compared with 4 of 137 inmates residing on the West wing.
The data are presented in the table below.


Step 1 - Calculate first the attack rate for each group.


Attack Rate (Risk) for exposed = a/(a+b) 

Attack Rate (Risk) for unexposed = c/(c+ d) 

Therefore,

Risk of tuberculosis in the East Wing = a/(a+b) = 28/(157) 

                                                                                            = 0.178 or 17.8%
Risk of tuberculosis in the West Wing= c/(c+ d) = 4/(137) 

                                                                                            = 0.029 or 2.9%

The Risk Ratio is
a/(a+b) : c/(c+d) = 17.8/2.9 = 6.1

Interpretation:
Therefore, the inmates who resided in the East wing of the dormitory were 6.1 times as likely to develop tuberculosis than those at the West wing.

name: EXAMPLE 2In an outbreak of varicella (chickenpox) ...
intro:
EXAMPLE 2
In an outbreak of varicella (chickenpox) in Oregon in 2002, varicella was diagnosed in 18 of 152 vaccinated children compared with 3 of 7 unvaccinated children. 

Calculate the risk ratio.


Solution:


Risk of chickenpox among vaccinated = 18/152 = 0.118 = 11.8%
Risk of chickenpox among unvaccinated = 3/7 = 0.429 = 42.9%
                       Risk Ratio = 11.8/42.9 = 0.275  


A RR of less than 1, indicates a decreased risk or protective effect for the exposed(vaccinated) children. 

Interpretation:
The Risk Ratio of 0.275 indicates that the vaccinated children were only approximately one-fourth as likely (27.5%, actually) to develop chickenpox as were unvaccinated children.

name: RATE RATIOA rate ratio compares the incidence rate...
intro:
RATE RATIO

A rate ratio compares the incidence rates, person-time rates, or mortality rates of two groups. 

As with the risk ratio, the two groups are typically differentiated by demographic factors or by exposure to a suspected causative agent. 

The rate for the group of primary interest is divided by the rate for the comparison group.


The interpretation of the value of a rate ratio is similar to that of the risk ratio. 

That is, a rate ratio of 1.0 indicates equal rates in the two groups, a rate ratio greater than 1.0 indicates an increased risk for the group in the numerator, and a rate ratio less than 1.0 indicates a decreased risk for the group in the numerator.

name: EXAMPLE 1A study was conducted and found out that ...
intro:
EXAMPLE 1

A study was conducted and found out that there is a perceived increased in Acute respiratory illness recorded in hospital A. In October of 2020, there were 11.6 cases per 1000 patients in hospital A per week and in November of 2020, there were 5.3 cases per 1000 patients. 
Calculate the Rate Ratio.

Rate Ratio = 11.3/5.3 = 2.2

Interpretation:

The findings indicate that there were more than twice as likely of patients in Hospital A during October than that of November per 1000 patients per week.

name: EXAMPLE 2Consider the table below.Compute for the ...
intro:
EXAMPLE 2
Consider the table below.


Compute for the Ratio comparing current smokers 

with Non-smokers.


Solution:
Rate Ratio = 1.3/0.07 = 18.57 = 19

Note that if the rate ratio is greater than 1, means there is likely an increased risk for the smokers to get lung cancer as that of the non-smokers. 
It will be 19 times more likely to happen to smokers compared to non-smokers for every 1000 persons in years.

name: ODDS RATIOAn odds ratio (OR) is another measure of...
intro:
ODDS RATIO

An odds ratio (OR) is another measure of association that quantifies the relationship between an exposure with two categories and health outcome.


The odds ratio is sometimes called the cross-product ratio because the numerator is based on multiplying the value in cell “a” times the value in cell “d,” whereas the denominator is the product of cell “b” and cell “c.” 

A line from cell “a” to cell “d” (for the numerator) and another from cell “b” to cell “c” (for the denominator) creates an x or cross on the two-by-two table.

name: EXAMPLE 1Refer to the given tableCalculate the&nbs...
intro:
EXAMPLE 1

Refer to the given table


Calculate the 
1. Risk Ratio
2. Odds Ratio


Solution:

Risk Ratio = 5.0/1.0 = 5.0

Interpretation:
There is an increased risk or protective effect for the exposed group that is five times more likely to have that disease.


Odds Ratio = (100x 7920)/(1900x80) = 5.2

Notice that the odds ratio of 5.2 is close to the risk ratio of 5.0. 

That is one of the attractive features of the odds ratio — when the health outcome is uncommon, the odds ratio provides a reasonable approximation of the risk ratio. 

Another attractive feature is that the odds ratio can be calculated with data from a case-control study, whereas neither a risk ratio nor a rate ratio can be calculated.

name: 2022 Published ArticleCitation: CAPUNDAN, Paolo An...
intro:
2022 Published Article

Citation: CAPUNDAN, Paolo Angelo P. et al. “TAKIPSILIM”: A Fantasy-Themed 2D Turn-Based RPG Developed Using Unity Engine. International Journal of Computing Sciences Research, [S.l.], v. 6, oct. 2022. ISSN 2546-115X. Available at: <//stepacademic.net/ijcsr/article/view/343>. Date accessed: 29 nov. 2022.

Link: https://stepacademic.net/ijcsr/article/view/343/154

Title: “TAKIPSILIM”: A Fantasy-Themed 2D Turn-Based RPG Developed Using Unity Engine


  • Paolo Angelo P. Capundan College of Engineering and Information Sciences, Trinity University Asia, Philippines
  • Mark Steven P. Evangelista College of Engineering and Information Sciences, Trinity University Asia, Philippines
  • John Andrei K. LibutanCollege of Engineering and Information Sciences, Trinity University Asia, Philippines
  • Kurtz Warren G. BarisoCollege of Engineering and Information Sciences, Trinity University Asia, Philippines
  • Ferdinand BunagCollege of Engineering and Information Sciences, Trinity University Asia, Philippines

Abstract

Purpose – Role-Playing Games (RPG) are an iconic genre for both tabletop and video game mediums that remains relevant even to this day. With the popularity of video games, it was inevitable that RPGs would also appear in this medium. In this study, the researchers aim to develop a Fantasy-Themed 2D Turn-Based RPG developed using the Unity Engine that will enrich and educate people about Filipino mythological creatures, folklore, cultures, and traditions.

Method - The agile methodology was used in game development, which provided the developer with the ability to deliver faster value, better output quality, and the flexibility to make the necessary game adjustments. The study was broken down into smaller modules and consistent idea collaboration was done together with the stakeholders. The development of TakipSilim was created using the C#-based Unity Engine Language, built on the Unity Engine. The game storyboard was used to familiarize the developers with the game’s story progression and challenges.

Results - For the findings, the system’s evaluation was conducted on twenty (20) gamers in terms of gameplay, efficiency, reliability, usability, compatibility, maintainability, and difficulty and was based on the ISO/IEC 25010:2011 standard. The game was also evaluated by IT experts using different criteria. As a result, a very satisfactory rating of 4.7 was given to readability, ease of program maintenance, low hardware resource consumption, and low complexity. The only Source Code Adaptation received a higher rating of 4.8, which was also very satisfactory.

Conclusion - The study reveals that the game developed was able to provide its users with the gaming experience to promote, enlighten, and educate people about the local culture through folktales, mythological creatures, and superstitions. The game has functions and features that have a unique storyline written by the proponents and proves that there is quite a demand for Filipino-themed games, though niche, in the market today.

Recommendations – The proponents recommend and encourage future researchers to take the initiative to expand the horizons in game development revolving around Filipino culture due to the demand for the game revolving around the mythos. 

Research Implications - The study has shown that the agile software methodology provided the developer with the ability to deliver faster value and better output quality. Also, the system evaluation was implemented based on the basic ISO standards which results in a very satisfactory rate. Lastly, creating RPG games from the ground is very challenging for amateurs, but they it able to grow and hone their skills as researchers and game developers.

name: (1) ANALYSIS OF VARIANCE (ANOVA) - Continuous Data...
intro:
(1) ANALYSIS OF VARIANCE (ANOVA) - Continuous Data



Assumptions for homogeneity(equal variances) has been satisfied (P = 0.876 > 5%) while normality test is not satisfied (P=0.014 < 5%). 

One-way ANOVA (Welch's) is utilized.


Findings suggest that there is no significant difference in the level of stress online as experienced by the different age groups (p = 0.673 > 5%).

name: (2) Chi_Square TestFindings have shown that respon...
intro:
(2) Chi_Square Test


Findings have shown that respondents experienced high to very high level of stress online as cited in the Contingency table across the different age groups.
Hence, the p value = 0.879 suggests that there is no significant difference at 5% level, that age is a factor for the level of stress in online learning.

name: Sample Outcome:

name: Reliability tells you how consistently a meth...
intro:
Reliability tells you how consistently a method measures something. 

When you apply the same method to the same sample under the same conditions, you should get the same results. If not, the method of measurement may be unreliable. 

(Published on August 8, 2019 by Fiona Middleton. Revised on August 19, 2022)


There are four main types of reliability. Each can be estimated by comparing different sets of results produced by the same method.

name: I. Test-retest reliabilityTest-retest reliability ...
intro:
I. Test-retest reliability

Test-retest reliability measures the consistency of results when you repeat the same test on the same sample at a different point in time. You use it when you are measuring something that you expect to stay constant in your sample.

How to measure it

To measure test-retest reliability, you conduct the same test on the same group of people at two different points in time. Then you calculate the correlation between the two sets of results.


EXAMPLE

You devise a questionnaire to measure the IQ of a group of participants (a property that is unlikely to change significantly over time).You administer the test two months apart to the same group of people, but the results are significantly different, so the test-retest reliability of the IQ questionnaire is low.

Improving test-retest reliability

  • When designing tests or questionnaires, try to formulate questions, statements and tasks in a way that won’t be influenced by the mood or concentration of participants.
  • When planning your methods of data collection, try to minimize the influence of external factors, and make sure all samples are tested under the same conditions.
  • Remember that changes can be expected to occur in the participants over time, and take these into account.

name: II. Interrater reliabilityInterrater reliability (...
intro:
II. Interrater reliability

Interrater reliability (also called interobserver reliability) measures the degree of agreement between different people observing or assessing the same thing. You use it when data is collected by researchers assigning ratings, scores or categories to one or more variables.

It’s important to make sure that different people will rate the same variable consistently with minimal bias. This is especially important when there are multiple researchers involved in data collection or analysis.

EXAMPLE
In an observational study where a team of researchers collect data on classroom behavior, interrater reliability is important: all the researchers should agree on how to categorize or rate different types of behavior.


How to measure it

To measure interrater reliability, different researchers conduct the same measurement or observation on the same sample. Then you calculate the correlation between their different sets of results. If there is a strong correlation between all sets of results, the test has high interrater reliability.

Improving interrater reliability

  • Clearly define your variables and the methods that will be used to measure them.
  • Develop detailed, objective criteria for how the variables will be rated, counted or categorized.
  • If multiple researchers are involved, ensure that they all have exactly the same information and training.

name: III. Parallel forms reliabilityParallel forms reli...
intro:
III. Parallel forms reliability

Parallel forms reliability measures the correlation between two equivalent versions of a test. You use it when you have two different assessment tools or sets of questions designed to measure the same thing.


Why it’s important

If you want to use multiple different versions of a test (for example, to avoid respondents repeating the same answers from memory), you first need to make sure that all the sets of questions or measurements give reliable results.


In educational assessment, it is often necessary to create different versions of tests to ensure that students don’t have access to the questions in advance.

Parallel forms reliability means that, if the same students take two different versions of a reading comprehension test, they should get similar results in both tests.

How to measure it

The most common way to measure parallel forms reliability is to produce a large set of questions to evaluate the same thing, then divide these randomly into two question sets.

The same group of respondents answers both sets, and you calculate the correlation between the results. High correlation between the two indicates high parallel forms reliability.

EXAMPLE
The questions are randomly divided into two sets, and the respondents are randomly divided into two groups. Both groups take both tests: group A takes test A first, and group B takes test B first. The results of the two tests are compared, and the results are almost identical, indicating high parallel forms reliability.

Improving parallel forms reliability

  • Ensure that all questions or test items are based on the same theory and formulated to measure the same thing.

name: IV. Internal consistencyInternal consistency asses...
intro:
IV. Internal consistency

Internal consistency assesses the correlation between multiple items in a test that are intended to measure the same construct.

You can calculate internal consistency without repeating the test or involving other researchers, so it’s a good way of assessing reliability when you only have one data set.

Why it’s important

When you devise a set of questions or ratings that will be combined into an overall score, you have to make sure that all of the items really do reflect the same thing. If responses to different items contradict one another, the test might be unreliable.

EXAMPLE
To measure customer satisfaction with an online store, you could create a questionnaire with a set of statements that respondents must agree or disagree with.

Internal consistency tells you whether the statements are all reliable indicators of customer satisfaction.

How to measure it

Two common methods are used to measure internal consistency.

  • Average inter-item correlation: For a set of measures designed to assess the same construct, you calculate the correlation between the results of all possible pairs of items and then calculate the average.
  • Split-half reliability: You randomly split a set of measures into two sets. After testing the entire set on the respondents, you calculate the correlation between the two sets of responses.

Improving internal consistency

  • Take care when devising questions or measures: those intended to reflect the same concept should be based on the same theory and carefully formulated.

name: Reliability tells you how consistently a meth...
intro:
Reliability tells you how consistently a method measures something. 

When you apply the same method to the same sample under the same conditions, you should get the same results. If not, the method of measurement may be unreliable. 

(Published on August 8, 2019 by Fiona Middleton. Revised on August 19, 2022)


There are four main types of reliability. Each can be estimated by comparing different sets of results produced by the same method.

name: I. Test-retest reliabilityTest-retest reliability ...
intro:
I. Test-retest reliability

Test-retest reliability measures the consistency of results when you repeat the same test on the same sample at a different point in time. You use it when you are measuring something that you expect to stay constant in your sample.

How to measure it

To measure test-retest reliability, you conduct the same test on the same group of people at two different points in time. Then you calculate the correlation between the two sets of results.


EXAMPLE

You devise a questionnaire to measure the IQ of a group of participants (a property that is unlikely to change significantly over time).You administer the test two months apart to the same group of people, but the results are significantly different, so the test-retest reliability of the IQ questionnaire is low.

Improving test-retest reliability

  • When designing tests or questionnaires, try to formulate questions, statements and tasks in a way that won’t be influenced by the mood or concentration of participants.
  • When planning your methods of data collection, try to minimize the influence of external factors, and make sure all samples are tested under the same conditions.
  • Remember that changes can be expected to occur in the participants over time, and take these into account.

name: II. Interrater reliabilityInterrater reliability (...
intro:
II. Interrater reliability

Interrater reliability (also called interobserver reliability) measures the degree of agreement between different people observing or assessing the same thing. You use it when data is collected by researchers assigning ratings, scores or categories to one or more variables.

It’s important to make sure that different people will rate the same variable consistently with minimal bias. This is especially important when there are multiple researchers involved in data collection or analysis.

EXAMPLE
In an observational study where a team of researchers collect data on classroom behavior, interrater reliability is important: all the researchers should agree on how to categorize or rate different types of behavior.


How to measure it

To measure interrater reliability, different researchers conduct the same measurement or observation on the same sample. Then you calculate the correlation between their different sets of results. If there is a strong correlation between all sets of results, the test has high interrater reliability.

Improving interrater reliability

  • Clearly define your variables and the methods that will be used to measure them.
  • Develop detailed, objective criteria for how the variables will be rated, counted or categorized.
  • If multiple researchers are involved, ensure that they all have exactly the same information and training.

name: III. Parallel forms reliabilityParallel forms reli...
intro:
III. Parallel forms reliability

Parallel forms reliability measures the correlation between two equivalent versions of a test. You use it when you have two different assessment tools or sets of questions designed to measure the same thing.


Why it’s important

If you want to use multiple different versions of a test (for example, to avoid respondents repeating the same answers from memory), you first need to make sure that all the sets of questions or measurements give reliable results.


In educational assessment, it is often necessary to create different versions of tests to ensure that students don’t have access to the questions in advance.

Parallel forms reliability means that, if the same students take two different versions of a reading comprehension test, they should get similar results in both tests.

How to measure it

The most common way to measure parallel forms reliability is to produce a large set of questions to evaluate the same thing, then divide these randomly into two question sets.

The same group of respondents answers both sets, and you calculate the correlation between the results. High correlation between the two indicates high parallel forms reliability.

EXAMPLE
The questions are randomly divided into two sets, and the respondents are randomly divided into two groups. Both groups take both tests: group A takes test A first, and group B takes test B first. The results of the two tests are compared, and the results are almost identical, indicating high parallel forms reliability.

Improving parallel forms reliability

  • Ensure that all questions or test items are based on the same theory and formulated to measure the same thing.

name: IV. Internal consistencyInternal consistency asses...
intro:
IV. Internal consistency

Internal consistency assesses the correlation between multiple items in a test that are intended to measure the same construct.

You can calculate internal consistency without repeating the test or involving other researchers, so it’s a good way of assessing reliability when you only have one data set.

Why it’s important

When you devise a set of questions or ratings that will be combined into an overall score, you have to make sure that all of the items really do reflect the same thing. If responses to different items contradict one another, the test might be unreliable.

EXAMPLE
To measure customer satisfaction with an online store, you could create a questionnaire with a set of statements that respondents must agree or disagree with.

Internal consistency tells you whether the statements are all reliable indicators of customer satisfaction.

How to measure it

Two common methods are used to measure internal consistency.

  • Average inter-item correlation: For a set of measures designed to assess the same construct, you calculate the correlation between the results of all possible pairs of items and then calculate the average.
  • Split-half reliability: You randomly split a set of measures into two sets. After testing the entire set on the respondents, you calculate the correlation between the two sets of responses.

Taking an Extra Care of your Brain

Every brain changes with age, and mental function changes along with it. Mental decline is common, and it's one of the most feared consequences of aging. But cognitive impairment is not inevitable. Here are some ways you can help maintain brain function.

name: Learning Outcomes:At the end of this module, it is...
intro:

At the end of this module, it is expected that the leaners must be able to:
1) discuss an understanding of teenage relationships, including the acceptable and unacceptable expressions of attractions;


2) express his/her ways of showing attraction, love, and commitment;


3) identify ways to become responsible in a relationship

name: IntroductionRelationship matter. Our daily live re...
intro:
Introduction

Relationship matter. Our daily live revolve around the everyday interaction we have with people we meet, be it  friends, family members, acquaintances or classmates. Building healthy and positive relationships contribute to happiness, success, and satisfaction in different facets of your life.

name: Essential UnderstandingAn adolescent's awareness o...
intro:
Essential Understanding

An adolescent's awareness on what responsible and healthy interpersonal relationships can help them form better relationships in the future and effectively manage their current relationships as well.

name:
Knowing the
self is the most basic of all relatio...
intro:
Knowing the self is the most basic of all relationships that has been created among humans. It is the self the defines who we are and who we are as individuals will determine our relationship to ourselves, and furthermore our relationship to environment.

Thus, the article provides us an understanding that self as we are is the most personal reality, yet never remains personal because this self, after knowing oneself, it will lead us to know other selves.

The basis of our relationship to other selves is defined by how much we know ourselves. As the saying goes, “you cannot give what you do not have”. A good relationship to others is build on a good relationship to oneself.

name: MEET OUR TEAM
intro: MEET OUR TEAM

name:
Message from the DirectorI hope this
message find...
intro:
Message from the Director


I hope this message finds you and your family in good health. Recent developments have been very challenging for our Trinitian community as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic. We are living in a time of unprecedented uncertainty. I just want to say “Thank you” to our students, faculty, and staff for your patience, understanding, and perseverance during their trying times.

 I am sure that most of you had problems with online registration and enrollment. But because you would want to pursue education despite Covid-19, you are here and now to experience learning in the new normal school setting. There is much going on with caring for our families, social distancing, and living very differently than what we were used to.

 Thanks to investments in technology and distance learning, the academic year is resuming with all classes online starting August 24, 2020. The Trinitan journey of discovery and self-improvement that occurs in our classrooms will now continue in distance learning. We will all persevere and our goal is to successfully complete the school year with no student being left behind.

Again, we welcome you, and please continue to be safe and well.


Sincerely,

JEANETTE VICTORIA A. NAVAL, RGC

What are self-affirmations?These are positive phra...
intro:
What are self-affirmations?


These are positive phrases or statements used to challenge negative or unhelpful thoughts (self-affirmation theory, 1988).

You may choose positive affirmations to:
 motivate yourself
 encourage positive changes in your life
 boost your self-esteem

Practice positive affirmations regularly for lasting, long-term changes to the ways that you feel and think.

Source:
Moore, Catherine. (2021, March 16). Positive Daily Affirmations: Is there a Science Behind it? PositivePsychology. https://positivepsychology.com/daily-

name: &nb...
Self-affirmations help you to motivate yourself, e...
intro:
Self-affirmations help you to motivate yourself, encourage positive changes in your life, or boost your self-esteem.

Choose which resonates with you and repeat it to yourself.

name: Here's a powerful positive affirmation for women t...
intro:

Happy National Women's Month, Trinitians!
