name: Career Preparation TipsPlanning your career as ear...
intro:
Career Preparation Tips

Planning your career as early as now will provide you with a roadmap for your future. As a student, there are a number of ways you can do to prepare yourself for your career.

name: A Guide to Identifying your Career Interests ...
intro: A Guide to Identifying your Career Interests

name: 6 Key Traits for Working in a TeamAre you a team p...
intro:
6 Key Traits for Working in a Team

Are you a team player?

Teamwork is important to have a meaningful and lifelong career. You need to work well with others because the diverse skills of teams are needed for reaching success. So, what makes a good team player? Here are some excellent traits to bear in mind whenever you’re working in a team.

name: Character Strengths for SuccessPlanning for your c...
intro:
Character Strengths for Success

Planning for your career? The Guidance Center wants to help with your career success by discussing Character Strengths.

24 Character strengths were introduced by Seligman and Peterson (2004), which contribute to "good life" and well-being. Moreover, there has been an increasing study of Character strength to job satisfaction and career success (Ruch, 2019).

name: Holland's Theory on Career ChoiceAre you having a ...
intro:
Holland's Theory on Career Choice

Are you having a hard time choosing a college course? or are you questioning your career path?

Holland's theory on career choice can help you in your career choice by determining the interaction between your personality and the environment. 

If you want to find out more, you can reach out to your counselors for assistance.

name: Spread love and kindness. Share with all the teach...
intro: Spread love and kindness. Share with all the teachers & school staff you know to remind them that their mental health and well-being are important too.

name: ​What we think in ​our ​minds will eventuall...
intro: ​What we think in ​our ​minds will eventually become what we believe. This is why it is so important that we start saying positive things about ourselves many times each and every day.

name: Relationships are vital to our emotional well-bein...
intro: Relationships are vital to our emotional well-being so take time to nourish your support systems and say hello to your friends.

name: ​What we think in ​our ​minds will eventually beco...
intro: ​What we think in ​our ​minds will eventually become what we believe. This is why it is so important that we start saying positive things about ourselves many times each and every day.

name: Getting enough good-quality sleep keeps your immun...
intro:
Getting enough good-quality sleep keeps your immune system running at its best to fight off infections.

There are parts of the body’s immune response that happen only during sleep.

Scientists know sleep is also one of the top ways we can help keep stress in check, as sleep deprivation can make us more sensitive to the effects of stress, ramping up our reactions (or overreactions).

Finally, the brain needs sleep to function; without it, you'll be less patient and focused, make poor decisions, and be more moody, irritable, and emotional.

Source: everydayhealth.com

name: What kind words can you share with others today?Sm...
intro:
What kind words can you share with others today?

Small acts of kindness can have profound effects on others and on us. Even better, those acts ripple out to the wider community, so in offering them we’re doing more than helping one other person and supporting ourselves. We’re doing something real to build a better world.

name: This weekend, spend some time hanging out with you...
intro:
This weekend, spend some time hanging out with your friends & family.

Research shows that spending time with loved ones is the number one determinant of happiness.

name: Practice deep breathing exercises.Deep breathing i...
intro:
Practice deep breathing exercises.


Deep breathing is one of the best ways to lower stress in the body. This is because when you breathe deeply, it sends a message to your brain to calm down and relax.

name: Listening to your body and reaching for a glass of...
intro: Listening to your body and reaching for a glass of water when you are thirsty can help you feel healthier and more energized. Your best bet is to stave off thirst in the first place by being proactive about drinking water. Make drinking a glass of water a part of your morning routine.

name: Working from home can blur the lines of when the w...
intro:
Working from home can blur the lines of when the workday starts and ends. Determine a schedule that takes into account a start time and an end time, your self-care practices, and breaks.

Realize the importance of setting boundaries for yourself and others.

name: Social media is an invaluable tool for keeping in ...
intro:
Social media is an invaluable tool for keeping in touch with friends, loved ones, and the wider world. But be mindful of how it makes you feel. If spending time on social media exacerbates your stress, anxiety, and uncertainty, take steps to limit your engagement.


Sharing positive things and expressing gratitude will not only uplift your mood but also those who will see your posts. Let's practice and encourage positivity.

name: Rest is essential.You can't pour from an empty cup...
intro:
Rest is essential.

You can't pour from an empty cup. You can't be your best if you're always stressed.

This weekend, find time to calm your mind, rest your body and listen to your soul. These moments of serenity will give you the replenishment and re-energizing you need for better days ahead.

name: As the weekend approaches, make time for yourself ...
intro:
As the weekend approaches, make time for yourself to protect your peace. This means maintaining a healthy environment for growth and also guarding your state of mind. It also means cultivating a safe space internally and externally where you can be productive rather than just doing things just to do them.

Make time for self-care.

name: Self-care is important for everyone. Stay in the p...
intro: Self-care is important for everyone. Stay in the present instead of what may happen in the future.

13Dec22, Tuesday | F2F Final Examination

name: Subject Description: This course focuses on t...
intro:
Subject Description: 

This course focuses on the application of ideas and methods of the social sciences to understand, investigate, and examine challenges of contemporary community life. It focuses on community-action initiatives such as community engagement, solidarity, and citizenship as guided by the core values of human rights, social justice, empowerment and advocacy, gender equality, and participatory development. It aims at enhancing students’ sense of shared identity and willingness to contribute to the pursuit of the common good of the community. It enables students to integrate applied social sciences into community-action initiatives.

name: Definition:Community Engagement is…the process of ...
intro:
Definition:
Community Engagement is…the process of working collaboratively with and through groups of people affiliated by geographic proximity, special interest, or similar situations to address issues affecting the well-being of those people It is a powerful vehicle for bringing about environmental and behavioral changes that will improve the health of the community and its members It often involves partnerships and coalitions that help mobilize resources and influence systems, change relationships among partners, and serve as catalysts for changing policies, programs, and practices (CDC, 1997).
Solidarity: unity or agreement of feeling or action, especially among individuals with a common interest; mutual support within a group.
Citizenship : A legal status and relation between an individual and a state that entails specific legal rights and duties.

name: The Trinitian Community Development Section (TCDS)...
intro:
The Trinitian Community Development Section (TCDS) is the official arm for extension programs and services of Trinity University of Asia, supporting its Vision and Mission to lead its constituents to live a life that is God-centered and service-oriented. 

TCDS primarily ensures that the University Constituency, meaning its students, faculty, staff, and administration, works collaboratively to develop and implement programs and services based on the needs of its partner communities and civil society as a whole, and according to its existing capacities and expertise.

name: LEGAL BASIS AND GENERAL GUIDELINES OF THE TCDSIn C... (copy)
intro:
LEGAL BASIS AND GENERAL GUIDELINES OF THE TCDS


In CHED Memorandum Order NO. 8, s. 2010, Extension refers to the act of communicating and transferring knowledge and technology to specific sectors and target clienteles (as distinguished from those enrolled in formal degree programs and course offerings) to enable them to effectively improve production, community and or institutions, and quality of life, at the same time enhance the academic and research programs of higher education institutions (HEIs).

TCDS adheres to the CHED mandate that the Extension program is integrated and shall include the following components: 

  1. Training programs – non-degree and non-credit course offered by a college or unit; 
  2. Technical assistance and advisory services- to agencies, organization, associations and other groups;
  3. Communication/information services – communication and or dissemination of knowledge and skills in particular client groups through the various means of dissemination such as person-to-person contact, radio, television, newspaper and other printed materials;
  4. Community outreach activities- extension activities conducted increase outside the university /college, e.g. community-based social services, pilot projects, mobile clinic, etc.; and
  5. Technology transfer and utilization – the process of circulating, promoting and marketing research outputs or technologies to potential users

name: TO KNOW MORE ABOUT TCDS' INSTITUTIONALIZATION AND ...
intro: TO KNOW MORE ABOUT TCDS' INSTITUTIONALIZATION AND HISTORY, PLEASE REFER TO THE LINKS BELOW:

name: TRINISYANO- Framework of Community Engagement&nbsp...
intro:
TRINISYANO- Framework of Community Engagement 
(Kristyanong Trinitian sa Paglilingkod- The Trinitian Brand of Service)


The concept of TRINISYANO came from the two words, “Trinitian” and “Christian” or “Kristyano” in Filipino which were combined to represent a brand of service of Trinity University of Asia, thus contributing to its vision, “Premier Christian University in Asia and the Pacific Transforming Learners into Leaders towards a Humane Society."

The “Kristyanong Trinitian sa Paglilingkod” also known as the TRINISYANO exemplifies Christ distinct way of serving and leading people as He build His church through discipleship, developing leaders as servants that will continue and sustain His service to the least - the marginalized sectors (depressed, oppressed, poverty-stricken and struggling) honoring God through the service to our Country – Pro Deo et Patria!

The programs and services of the University to its partner communities and organizations shall be geared towards building the Trinitian brand of service which also adheres to the Anglican Communion’s Five (5) Marks of Mission: 

  1. To proclaim the Good News of the Kingdom 
  2. To teach, baptise and nurture new believers
  3. To respond to human need by loving service
  4. To transform unjust structures of society, to challenge violence of every kind and pursue peace and reconciliation 
  5. To strive to safeguard the integrity of creation, and sustain and renew the life of the earth


“To make the greatest impact on society requires first and foremost a great organization, not just a great program.”- Jim Collins


The Trinitian Community Development Section plays a pivotal role in building and organizing the community using the perspectives of community development as its main practice framework through identifying potential leaders, capacitating them with necessary perspectives and tools of development and to prepare them for community organizing. Thus, transforming their lives in the achievement of holistic development towards building resilient and empowered communities. The following goals shall serve as the University’s commitment and stronghold towards the realization of the Trinitian Brand of Service across all academic and non-academic engagements:

  1. Enhancement of knowledge, skills and attitude of identified leaders in the community to serve as committed agents of change of their community and the society at large 
  2. Facilitate empowerment of communities through discipleship and servant leadership 
  3. Sustainable and holistic programs and services that respond to the needs of the communities 
  4. Engaged administrators, faculty, staff and students in issues of social justice and human rights through education, information and advocacy
  5.  Ensure progressive measures and intervention towards the protection and conservation of environment


The major academic programs such as the National Services Training Program (NSTP), Christian Education and the Service-Learning shall closely coordinate with the Trinitian Community Development Section (TCDS) to ensure that all efforts and initiatives are concerted towards contributing to TRINISYANO- The Trinitian Brand of Service.

name: @@PLUGINFILE@@/TCDS%20VIDEO%20EDITED%20%281%...
intro:
1.      Education and Training – The coverage of this program component are: formal, non-formal and informal training including leadership formation and other capacity-building efforts for community sustainability. The activities and services that are conducted under this program component are as follows:

      • Free Pre-school Education in Barangay Tatalon
      • Mentoring Sessions with Grade School and High School Students on English and Mathematics
      • Computer Literacy Training for Barangay Workers and Officials
      • Computer Literacy Training for Public School Teachers

2.      Alternative Livelihood Opportunities –The community residents are provided technical assistance to develop community enterprises that will be able to augment the income of their family without compromising quality time with their loved ones.  The activities and services that are conducted under this program component are as follows:

      • Food Preservation Training
      • Therapeutic Massage Training
      • Cosmetology Training
      • Dressmaking and Tailoring Training
      • Soap Making
      • Welding Training
      • Barista Training
      • Housekeeping Training

3.      Community Organizing- The center assists in organizing people’s organizations and other sectoral groups as requested and needed.

4.      Advocacy- through the different colleges, we help build mechanisms to address violence in the communities as well as advocating for the rights of women and children.

TCDS ACT Sessions

The Trinitian Community Development Section (TCDS) launched its information and advocacy drive, “Advocate, Conscienticize, and Transform,” or ACT Sessions as a response to one of the Anglican Communion's Five (5) Marks of Mission in "transforming unjust structures of society, challenging violence of every kind, and pursuing peace and reconciliation." Specifically, it aims to provide an avenue for the Trinitian Constituency and its partner communities to enhance their awareness in pressing socio-political and economic issues and challenges that affect different members of the society, especially the marginalized, which eventually aspires them to become advocates or agents of social change and transformation.

5.      Networking –collaboration with other like-minded institutions is a potent force for cost sharing and best practice in community development work. The following organizations and agencies are partners of the University Extension office:

      • Alban Memorial Foundation, Inc. – Scholarship Grant for High School and College level to selected children and youth
      • St. Joseph Foundation for Children and Aging, Inc. – Scholarship Grant for College level to selected children and youth
      • Assisi Development Foundation, Inc.- Scholarship Grant for College level to selected children and youth
      • Philippine Center for Population and Development, Inc.- Funding agency for the advocacy and cause on population, health and environment
      • National Council of Social Development- Network of NGOs working for the welfare and development
      • United Board for Christian Higher Education in Asia (UBCHEA)- Partner of the University in service learning programs and to community service programs focusing on health and environment
      • Tzu Chi Buddhist Foundation- Partner of the University in the advocacy for environment wherein PET bottles are recycled into shirts and blankets

 6.      Health and Wellness– health is an integral part of the development programs of the Center.  This program ensures that our partners are healthy through curative and preventive activities for the total well-being of people. The activities and services that are conducted under this program component are as follows: 

      • Feeding Program with malnourished and undernourished children
      • Health Education sessions with the mothers and elderly
      • Free Laboratory Tests (Glucose Testing, Urinalysis, Fecalysis)
      • Blood Donation
      • Health and Nutrition Session for parents

7.      Ecological – The Center is in the forefront of ensuring that environmental activities are carried out for awareness, protection and conservation of the environment where our beneficiaries live.

name: INTERDISCIPLINARY COMMUNITY EXTENSION PROJECTS&nbs...
intro:
INTERDISCIPLINARY COMMUNITY EXTENSION PROJECTS 


HEALTH AND WELLNESS 


Project CHANGE (St. Luke's College of Nursing)

The Community Health and Nursing GearedTowards Empowerment  (CHANGE)started in 1977, the program provides free diagnosis and consultations, visitations, and taught mothers basic health practices, child care, nutrition, and first aid remedies. CHANGE and HEALS work hand in hand in assisting medical doctor-volunteers during medical mission activities.

 

Project HEALS (College of Medical Technology)

Health Education and Life Services (HEALS) started in 1990. It complements the Nursing community outreach program through blood typing, sputum testing, urine and stool examination, de-worming of children, dialogue on health services and procedures, demonstration on desirable health habits, home visitation, or follow-ups and other allied activities.


Project SNACK (College of Hospitality and Tourism Management)

Supervised Nutrition Advocacy for Community Kids or the SNACK program started in 2007  as one of the health services for the community is focused on nutrition advocacy for the kids. Likewise,  mothers are involved in the program to participate in the preparation of nutritious, low cost, and easy to prepare meals. 

Now, Project SNACK also ventures in conducting learning sessions on local tourism and basic tour-guiding as a livelihood opportunity for the partner communities to consider in the future.

 

EDUCATION AND TRAINING


Project COPE and ASPIRE (College of Arts, Sciences, and Education)

Started in 1982, Community Outreach Pre-School Education (COPE) provides a head start in formal education for children aged 4 to years old; initiates among children and their mothers good health practices; promotes good eating habits and practices through feeding program, which is worked out by the mothers under the supervision and guidance of the volunteer student-teachers. needed in applying for a job. The program started in 1984 to assist out-of-school youths and adults who wish to finish their studies.

On the other hand, the Arts and Sciences Programs for Inspired and Responsive Education (ASPIRE)helps children in the community develop and/or enhance their reading and mathematical skills thus helping them achieve better academic performance. The program started in 1990.

 

Project CODE-IT (College of Engineering and Information Sciences)

 The Community Development and Empowerment Through information technology (CODE-IT) envisions to make information technology accessible to our partner communities through education and training in current information technology (IT) skills practices as well as technical assistance on information technology issues and solutions


Project CAN (Graduate School)

The Graduate School's Change. Achieve. Nurture (CAN) started in 2002,  assists community-based researches mainly to determine the relevance of outreach programs, actual needs of recipients, quantify and quality impact of programs, investigate areas of concern that would contribute to the improvement of the outreach programs.

 


Project DREAM (Basic Education Unit)

The Developing Responsible, Excellent, Action– Driven and Magnimous Youth (DREAM) of the Basic Education provides an avenue for the youth of the University’s partner communities to understand themselves and acquire real-life skills that will foster their growth and development. Their previous program was with the pre-school children but they eventually transcend with the youth, the majority population in the community.



ALTERNATIVE LIVELIHOOD

 

Project BEST (College of Business Management and Accountancy)

The Business Education for Self-Reliance and  Trade (BEST) started in 1987. It trains participants in basic bookkeeping, record keeping and inventory and other financial and management skills necessary in the operation of a small-scale business. It also introduces to participants various means of procuring either for start-up or expansion of small business holding. It likewise gives training on cooperatives for associations in the community that intend to set-up a cooperative. The project BEST is also in-charge with practical skills training that aims to improve the economic and quality of life of people.

name: The extension office consists of ten (10) members,...
intro:
The extension office consists of ten (10) members, administered by the Program In-charge, and assisted by the Community Development Assistant. The remaining eight (8) are selected faculty members from each of the University's academic units that function as the lead Coordinator of their respective community extension projects. Together, they conceptualize and facilitate programs and services using interdisciplinary approaches to benefit the University's constituency and partner communities. 

TCDS is also enjoined by the official student volunteer organization of the University, the Trinitian SHARES (Sustain, Help, Act, Respect, Empower, and Support).  The organization's primary goal is to strengthen volunteerism among Trinitian Students through actively participating in health, education, and livelihood programs and services of the University towards its partner communities.
